I do and don't recommend this game at the same time.

Why don't I recommend it?
1. FSX was released in 2006 which makes a very old game
2. The game is not nowhere near as realistic as for example X-Plane 11 or the new MFS2020
3. Now that MFS2020 has been released I would just go for that since it is so much better
4. Many things in FSX are simplified so everyone can play the game without much practise
5. The game is a buggy mess
6. Flight physics are not the best and do not give you a real feeling of flying
7. Bad stock aircraft selection
8. Way too many DLC's
9. Pretty much all stock aircraft are missing functions that should be there

Why would I recommend it?
1. The game is easy to learn
2. A lot of mods help the game be better
3. For a 2006 game, it still somehow manages to look good even on a low end computer
4. No need for a gaming computer for this game
5. FSX is a decent starter flight sim to learn the basics but I still would go for something more new
6. It's just a lot of fun

Defo; one of my fav sims, its not a game, because there's really nothing to do like a career mode, just odd ball missions. So, I use FSE (Flight Sim Economy) and this gives me the game-play element. Although its all just gone nuts recently in Aug 2020 with the release of the new MS flight sim.

Especially on FSE and other flight sim BB's, people are complaining like mad about useless things that they shouldn't be complaining about, (because they don't really know how to fly or lack the patience to learn correct procedures), 

Re- most of these new flight-simmers (in my opinion), seem to be wannabe YouTuber's, who've just bought the new MS flight sim, and are expecting an arcade style game-play. You cannot just squeeze and go in FSX or the new MS FS.

The beauty is in the simulation, correct procedures and startup routines to start your plane and all that kind of stuff. Add FSE into the mix and you have to really think about where you are going and work out fuel use and costs, weight and journey time. But if you love strategy type sims and games, this will suit you, especially if you also like to fly planes in sims and games.

I reccomend MSFS X as how you can have so much fun playing with friends or without friends. Playing like its a real plane flight or just having fun messing around. There is so much to do like Escorts, Multiplayer challenges -landing ,ect- and much more.

 The basic scenery May not be the best but there are lot of free scenery on websites 
-www.flyawaysimuilation.com- and really boost the gameplay. The base planes have most of the buttons working. The game is AMAZING for its generation and release date -2006-. If you read all of this, Thanks!

Okay. Generally being a game that came out in 2006 it's decent.  But FSX steam version has a terrible support when anything goes wrong.  I started to have problems with Scenery files and FSX just crashes on start.  I tried validating game caches, deleting and reinstalling the game but nothing seems to fix it.   Because this game was abandoned by Microsoft the Dovetail also doesn't care much about supporting this seriously on Steam.  If you get into problems (which I am sure you will, once you start using custom addons for planes and sceneries), you are on your own.   Also even considering this was made by Microsoft, their configurations and game files are scattered everywhere.  If anything minor goes wrong with one of the files, the entire game is fucked.

I have been a Flight Sim user since the release of the very first version all those years ago. FSX Steam is the result of those seemingly endless years of development. Joy, frustration and sometimes heartache have all been a part of my journey with FSX but my enthusiasm for flight simulation always kept me going. In particular the last few years have seen scenery and aircraft development go ahead in leaps and bounds not the least of which by incredibly dedicated freeware developers world wide. Of course payware developers like ORBX and many others have added enormously to the fun. With the release of FS 2020 a new era has begun in flight simulation, however, I for one will not forget where this new generation sim has come from. The years of blood sweat and tears will always be the father of this new child. Just like a much loved vintage car I will park it in my "garage" and bring it out on weekends and keep it polished and never forgotten. Thank you FSX Steam....not gone or forgotten !!

I've played FSX for years, from earlier versions.  Only since I got the steam version have I seen the full potential for multiplayer.  And the addition of a yoke, and the PMDG family of 737s has brought a huge new realism to it all.  Add to that joining VATSIM and having real 2 way ATC - it's amazing.  I'm not going to change to FS2020 for now as this does all I need.  Great job Steam and MS.  5*

EN - TR

EN

-BUGS AND CRASHES  
-- If you thinking buy this game, think one more time. Because FSX still has optimization problem. Think about that, You're playing FSX and you're middle of the flight. OPS! This BS game decided to crashing no reason.
-- Think one more time about shutdown your PC. Beacuse when you're shutdown your PC, you may not find it like you left your FSX.
-- Twice the hours i played the game i spent solving the bugs of the game.

- GAMEPLAY
-- FSX is an old game though still has a impressive GP experience. I'm kidding, if you haven't any PMDG, Aerosoft ect. this game is garbage.  You should add Airplane, Scenery, Texture ect.  
-- Whatever happens this game is father of the FS games. In 2020 i am still playing this game and i enjoy that. 
--Game mechanics is OK. It won't hurt you, but it doesn't make you feel great either.

-CONCLUSION
-- Making the game playable is very expensive. 
-- Get used to getting crash all the time.
-- If you spend money this game becomes a complete masterpiece. (A LOT OF MONEY!)

TR

-HATALAR VE ÇÖKMELER
-- Bu oyunu satın almayı düşünüyorsanız bir kez daha düşünün. Çünkü FSX'in hala optimizasyon sorunları var. Şunu düşünün; FSX oynuyorsunuz ve yaptığınız uçuşun tam ortasındasınız. BAM! Bu saçma oyun hiç bir neden olmadan çökmeye karar veriyor. 
-- Bilgisayarınızı kapatmadan önce bir kez daha düşünün. Çünkü bilgisayarınızı kapattıktan sonra FSX'inizi bıraktığınız gibi bulamayabilirsiniz.
-- Oyunu oynadığımın iki katı kadarı oyunun hatalarını çözmeye harcadım. 

-OYNANIŞ
-- FSX eski bir oyun olmasına rağmen hala iyi bir oynanışa sahip. Şaka yapıyorum, eğer PMDG, Aerosoft vb. sahip değilseniz bu oyun çöp. Uçak, Yeryüzü Dekoru, Doku vb. şeyleri oyuna eklemek zorundasınız. 
-- Ne olursa olsun bu oyun uçuş simülasyonlarının babası. 2020 Yılında bile bu oyunu oynuyorum ve bundan zevk alıyorum. 
-- Oyun mekanikleri fena değil. Sizi üzmez ama sizi harika da hissettirmez.

-SONUÇ
-- Oyunu oynanabilir yapmak çok pahalı.
-- Oyunun sürekli çökmesine alışın.
-- Eğer çok para harcarsanız bu oyun tam bir başyapıt. (ÇOK PARA!)

Late to the party with this review but more than 400 hours in, it's probably fair to say I like the game. I've played most iterations of Flight over the years. The only reason I still have this is the lack of updates (so eagerly waiting to see what happens soon).

I play on a modern laptop, which has adequate performance for most games including this one but I do not use a dedicated gaming machine. With that said, my graphics options are set fairly high with little impact on frame-rate etc.; more tech-minded people with have much more to say about this.

For me, the real enjoyment of MS Flight comes from 'flying' the smaller aircraft at low level taking in the scenery - I love spotting real-world buildings and features in the landscape and taking screen-shots of these. I have upgraded some things with dlc to improve terrain rendering or graphics and added quite a few payware and freeware aircraft (I prefer smaller amphibian aircraft and the more quirky looking real-world machines and not the larger aircraft or modern military aircraft).  I like creating VFR flight plans and 'flying' these using fairly realistic restrictions (e.g. taking in to account range and aircraft performance issues whilst steadfastly ignoring ATC instructions).

I'm not hugely into sims so I probably have little to add about realism. I recognise that some aircraft are harder to fly than others and I set the realism sliders towards the 'realistic' end of the spectrum for all which makes 'flying' a strange mix of relaxation and tension (especially on landing at smaller airfields). I treat MS Flight as the 'real world' version of No Mans Sky which I play to distraction). I also like real-world weather and the challenges that this brings (especially when flying VFR when in reality, you would never take the aircraft up).

I highly recommend this game if you like being a tourist with mild jeopardy(!) but you may want to wait until the new Flight is released (unless this version and DLC is available at a huge discount).

I'm not sure if I will upgrade to the new Flight - I feel that I would like to, but I like the fact that this version works so well on my laptop and would not want my enjoyment to be impacted by poor performance of my hardware.

***UPDATE - FLIGHT SIMULATOR 2020***

So, I bought the MSFS2020 from the MS Store (before they announced it was going to be on Steam).

It looked beautiful but I have read on Steam that it has been a nightmare to install. It is also a nightmare on the MS Store too.

I cannot get it to work and so far have tried installing/uninstalling 4 times! My laptop died and I had to reinstall Windows 10 essentially wiping evrything except my data including my MSF SE with all of the add-ons (and yes I think this was linked to MSFS 2020). I am gutted.

The issue for me seems to be downloading the 90*GB update - I am trying to obtain a refund but becasue the programme takes so long to install, this is unlikely to happen.

I recommend that you do not buy MSFS 2020 until they have fixed the bugs... As of now, I have uninstalled the game and wait in hope - £60 for the basic version is not cheap, and for it not to work for so many people is frankly apalling.

very good

Fortunately, I bought this game on sale. As such, it's a worthy investment for a basic flight simulator.

But, it's now 2020.

The flight model is good. The terrain modeling is horrid, by today's standards. To buy the areas that I would like to fly over, in addition to the US, I would need to spend as much as buying MS Flight Sim 2020.

The aircraft selection isn't bad, but as I've moved on, I prefer simpler aircraft. Buying the additional aircraft for this version is not recommended. Better iterations exist. The base Cessna 172 is well modeled, and is the only aircraft you will need, unless you live outside the US, or want to play the airline game. A simple stick is all you need to play.

Summing up, buy this only at a greatly discounted sale, as a basic flight trainer. It served well for many years, but it's time is over. The add-ons cost too much. As of this writing, the new MSFS 2020 is going through it's teething stages. Wait for it to get straightened out, then buy on sale.

I expected to never play this game after FS2020 released until one fateful August night when my gaming laptop froze and never turned on again. I have been forced to return to my old PC, and wanting to play a flight simulator, I booted up X-Plane 11, and got 2 fps, so I scrapped that idea, and booted up FSX, and I have been truly enjoying playing this game, even if FS2020 is literally photo realistic, this game is still unbelievably fun to play, and runs smoothly on an 11 year old PC. The multiplayer runs smooth, the plane selection is wide, and there are quite a few airline liveries to choose from, compared to just about none in FS2020 (I believe, I've only seen my friends play the game as I can't even download it on this PC). I really REALLY enjoy this game despite its age, and still recommend the game now with FS2020 released! If your computer has the power to run FS2020, then get it. But if you're not sure, this game is still a good alternative, and although the graphics are nowhere near breathtaking or photo realistic, the graphics are upgradeable with the immense selection of freeware scenery (and payware), and you can get just about any plane you imagine with freeware, compared to FS2020 with just about... no freeware. I'm not bashing FS2020, it's an amazing game, but it is not without its flaws, and those flaws are many. This game may seem daunting due to its old age (14 years old!) but it still holds up nicely, and I enjoy playing it to this day.

Until Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 comes out, this is the definitive Microsoft Flight Simulator game. The main thing you need to know if you are getting into this is that it is a simulation game that leans HARD into the Simulation part. What this means is that this game doesn't have any objectives or anything "game-like". It has a few missions, yes, but the real meat and potatoes is getting into a virtual plane, and taking flight, doing what YOU want. Want to fly a 747 from RJBB to KLAX? Can do it. 

It should be noted, however, that this game does have limitations. Without any payware scenery, the game's environments are quite bland. You may get some 3D buildings, but for the most part things are textured onto the terrain. The quality is circa 2006, which is expected considering the game originally came out in that year, but just be warned going in. This isn't a huge deal breaker when you are flying over an ocean, for example, but if you want to fly around your hometown and look for landmarks, you likely won't be able to. 

The other limitation is with the stock and freely available aircraft. While you will likely be able to find the plane you want somewhere, unless you are willing to do research and/or pay, there are going to be cut corners. For example, if you drop the full price for a PMDG 737 (around $75 at time of writing), then you get what is probably as close to accurate a simulation as one can get in this game. But if you find a free version, you will find that some control systems weren't implemented, and the overall flight model may be inaccurate to some comical degrees. 

The last real drawback is that the ATC in the game is...lacking. While IFR flights are very doable (and in fact, VFR is almost a greater challenge with the low visual fidelity), ATC does not always give sensible instructions. I've not had the problem some report of plowing into the side of a mountain, but I have noticed that when taxiing, the ATC can give you...silly directions sometimes. The big example I've seen is routing me through turns that are nigh impossible to pull off in the large airliner I'm piloting. 

But leaving all this aside, consider the following question:

Do you like the idea of trying to be a pilot?

If you answered no, then this is not for you.

If you answered yes, FSX is a great place to try it out. Just be careful, if you end up liking it, you'll fall down the simmer rabbit hole, and find yourself buying all of the kit to create a virtual cockpit. Soon we will find out if MSFS 2020 lives up to the hype, and if that is out of your price range at the moment, this is a decent compromise compared to X-Plane and Prepar3D.

Flying was the first and main reason why I got into computers> My first setup was a Tandy Color computer that I hooked up to my tabletop color television. I eventually moved up to a 286 desktop with a Hercules monochrome monitor (a CRT 'green' screen). From there went to a 386, then a 486 and the first program I loaded onto each of these systems was Flight Simulator. I went from 3.0 to 4.0 to FS 95 and now I have FSX on a Dell Inspirion (Intel Core 15). The computers get better and the simulation gets better and it's always a thrill to climb into the cockpit of a 747 or Airbus, spool the engines up, release the brakes and launch into the air. This program never gets old and it was awesome to actually hear the characters from SNAKES ON A PLANE give credit directly to Microsoft Flight Simulator which helped them land the plane safely! Kudos!!

I'm writing this review, because of some people who said this game sucks, because of the hard controls.
So, this is a plane SIMULATOR! Anyone know what's that? S-I-M-U-L-A-T-O-R! Of course it will be hard to learn. The real pilots spend around 1 year of learning in the simulators, before their first real flight. And yeah, don't worry, this is not a fully real simulator.

Let's talk about Boeing 747-400. It has the most basics controls you need, like flaps and throttle, aircraft lights and anti-ice system and many more. I just want to say it's not that so hard like in a real aircraft, where you need an hour of preparation before flight, don't worry. It takes 10 minutes for me to set everything for takeoff. And if you wonder how many hours it takes for me, before landing in extreme conditions for first time - 24 hours. It's hard, trust me, but not impossible.

Another thing: It's not impossible to play without a joystick. As I said you need time for practise. I play with a keyboard and I have 140 hours, as you can see.

It's not that so hard, you need time! Some people who are buying this game are like: "Oh yeah, I bought a flight simulator. It will be easy to fly."; And then in the game: "OMG, this is so stupid game, I can't even takeoff." Then uninstalls and write a negative review.
I don't know why they are buying a simulator and want things to happen fast and easy. As the beginning of the review - this is a SIMULATOR! There are so many games, where to get flying you need to push only one button, like GTA, you know.

UPDATE 28.09.2015: If DTG won't stop with these DLCs, the game itself will turn into the next DLC Simulator 2015 after the disappointment with TS 2016, but I still recommend it.

As an adult over 65.  I've been playing this game since FS 2004 came out.  In fact, it is the only game I play.  According to Steam, I've played this game more than 13,359 hours.  I would start and international flight from NY with a 747 and time it to get back to the computer, before the plane was close enough to say, Johannesburg, so I could start approach and landing procedures.    
With FSX, I was delighted until they took away the weather support for it.  Also for reasons I didn't understand the performance had deteriorated.  Until I got the Steam version, which worked a lot better achieving frame rates of almost 100 fps, with some of my aircraft.   Like the rest of the world, I'm looking forward to the 2020 version.  But until I find out 'if' it can now support the tons of 3rd party aircraft that I have gotten,  787's, 737-400's, 747 cargo jets, my large group of A380's, A300's, A310's, A340's, 757's and the like.  I wait to purchase FS 2020.  I didn't upgrade my computer to windows 10, specifically because it didn't hand FSX (the boxed versions) well.  But in anticipation of FS 2020.  I've installed an additional hard drive on my existing rig, with Windows 10 on it and nothing else, to eventually load the new FS 2020.  I just switch to that SSD Windows 10 drive in the bios, when I start up my computer.  I'll see how real word folks, enjoy the hotly marketed FS2020, before I leap in.  Keep on flying everyone!

I have enjoyed the FSX flight simulator. It is more a flight simulator than a "game" in the popular sense. if your intent is to "learn" flight skills, FSX is a good starting point. If you are not much interested in flying skills, and want something more "game-like" that allows you to start having fun without having to know what you are doing, I would suggest one of the combat games that has airplanes.  If you are a careful picky purchaser, you may want to sign up in the FlightSim forum and see what FSX users are chatting about. Also, be aware this game is not new or recent and the support is sketchy to non-existent. Thus, you need to be prepared to use it as_is. (Don't expect anybody to fix a bug that you might trip over.) Having said that, there are very helpful people in the FlightSim forum who have seen it all, and very willing to help when you need it. 

Microsoft is threatening to release a new flight simulator any moment now. I tell you that in case you would rather wait for the new one. Personally, IMO, I would not wait for the new one. As with all version 1.0 products, it will be, well, just like a version 1.0 product. FSX works well enough for you to learn on, is easy on your machine (which the new one wont be) and will allow you to get a year or so worth of experience in without performing free QA for Microsoft, and before having to purchase again to move up.

Hi Jim and thank you for giving FSX: Steam Edition a try. 

You will need an Internet connection to download Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition from Steam and install it. Once installed you can then play Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition in offline mode if you wish. For further information on offline mode please visit: 

https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=3160-agcb-2555

Please note that an Internet connection is required for the multiplayer game modes in Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition. 

If you would like some help using the multiplayer features in FSX please check out our Support FAQ where you will find a full guide. You can find the FAQ here:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/discussions/7/530645961936230762/

Just look under the section call "Using Multiplayer"

If you are still experiencing issues you can reach us via our dedicated support website: 

http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/

If you drop us a message a member of our team will get back to you as soon as possible with some advice. 

Thank you for your review, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team

Of all the different types of games I've played (simulators, first and third person shooters, strategy, adventure, puzzles) I played this one the most. It's still the best flight simulator game out there even though the 2020 version will be available soon. The support for the game is mostly gone as Microsoft discontinued support a decade ago, and the multiplayer has quite a few quirks like the "choppy" voice audio, but it is an amazing simulator. 
Flight simulators will never be like the "real thing" but this simulator is incredibly in depth and it has fueled many, including mine, in their endeavors to become pilots or extreme flight enthusiasts.
This game deserves to be running on a gaming computer to realize how realistic the scenery and gameplay is to the real world. Even for being an old game, it still requires demanding requirements, especially the recommended specifications. The last thing you'll need is a lot of free time! As is the case with most simulator games. A great game to have!

I have been a fan of flight sims for a long time and Microsoft Flight Simulator X seems to prove its point! It is focused on letting players play like a real player. However, the multiplayer can be very wonky - no built in voice chat - most often you'll have to join an external discord server for the voice chat.

I think this is one of the most reliable and also realistic flight simulator ever albeit not being graphically impressive.

Controls-wise, I use keyboard and mouse, it took some getting used to because you need to see the keys for throttle. As for airplane steering, I find that using the Mouse Yoke helps! - It is where there is a + cursor on the screen and you position the cursor on the screen to steer the aircraft.

I mean what can I say? I've owned this heap of jank since 2008 and only upgraded to a version that runs well in 2020. It's probably the game I've sunk the most hours into, and (the many) issues aside, I love it. Is it modern or even decent looking graphically? Of course not, it's from 2006. Is it an engaging and fun to fly sim with an utterly insane library of freeware and payware? Absolutely.

The game has issues and I guarantee you you will run into a whole lot of them, and it will need some reading and research to fix, but on a game this old that should be expected really. But if you treat it right when it works it'll usually stay working.

(Protip: the two funnest things you can do with the game are turn off the A321's flight computers and go full fighter jet, and sort the reviews by not recommended and go through laughing at all the people screeching about DLC. It really is surprisingly fun!)

A classic, way better than 98/2000/2004/COF, but it shows it age as well. I remember flying around the world in various aircraft, but now i wouldn't spend much time in it. The graphics by todays standards isn't much to look at, default towns are autogen, which means no satellite maps, and of course no VR support. It did detect my X52 controller though, not bad.

FSX has SOME advantages over simulators like AFS2, it has air traffic, weather and ATC. But so do XPlane 11. Honestly if i didn't have a connection to FSX from earlier, i would have never bought it for sentimental reasons. Having tried it now again like a decade later, it isn't something you want to hang in your christmas tree.

Also some tutorials aren't really that good, and some keybindings does not appear to work, i jumped into the Hornet (which is now included) on a carrier, tried autostart but it didn't even flinch, I tried the manual startup procedure (battery, APU, engines etc) but the engines stalled constantly. And some buttons/knobs are not even clickable. DCS got the hornet startup procedure covered way better. Felt like i was playing an unfinished beta product and i would have been very dissatisfied if i ever had bought the expansion pack back in the day.

The default screen does not use widescreen, everything is in 4:3 resolution. Horrible, and everything is by default zoomed in so you probably have to zoom out before you do anything in FSX. The keybindings are an absolute horrow show in comparison to modern flightsims, you can't search and there is no logical order to how keys are listed, or arranged by relevancy under each plane. At least it defaults to Ultra settings on my games box, but given that it's a 14 year old product it's not surprising and offers little comfort.

If you have an emotional connection to FSX, maybe some expansion packs laying around, you may want to get this. For everyone else, get a modern flightsim (Like AFS2, XPlane11 or MSFS2020 which will be out in a few months). I had fun with this up to around 2009, now it is just a memory that i ruined by replaying it in 2020.
Still after so many years this is one of my favorite games!

This is a high fidelity flight simulator capable of so many countless features. While FSX does require higher-end hardware to run smoothly, it renders a very realistic flight simulation experience. Difficulty settings can define weather it is a game or a simulation, as the realistic settings options requires sound knowledge of real world working aircraft and their systems, as well as very realistic flight dynamics and handling. Even on the easiest difficulty settings however, basic light knowledge is needed to successfully take-off, climb, cruise, descend and land.

The possibilities are nearly endless with add-ons and tweaks. 

10/10.

Hour in Steam edition are insignificant when compared to how many I have in the retail edition. Add that to Fs9 and I have as many hours as an airline pilot lol.

Not much to say really, it holds up well after 14 years. The latest tech is STILL compared to FSX.

There are few differences/improvements in the Steam edition compared to the retail edition, which were added/changed by Dovetail:

Firstly the steam edition is the GOLD Edition Retail equivalent, so it includes the Acceleration Pack, and the SP2 updates, so you get ALL Detailed Cities, and ALL the extra aircraft.
Clouds are better.
Sky colour is more natural.
Directx10 mode offers more performance than before (up to 30%), however has issues of its own these days- flickering runways and taxi markings, easy to fix WITHOUT stevefx.
Multiplayer works a treat and is still very busy, there are also lots fo great discord servers.
SIMCONNECT included now.
UIAutomationCore now included (fixes a few bugs when switching from windowed to full screen etc).
And a few minor tweaks under the hood reducing memory leaks etc, it is STILL 32bit though so if you runs 100s of scenery mods you still may run of memory.

November 2019 update from Microsoft; now features a BETA edition, I personally have had no issues running this, but many have. It includes the return of Real World Weather, a few tweaks to aircraft here and there, and Microsoft use it to collect usage data for the dev team working on Flight Sim 2020 (no personal data is collected, Windows 10 already has that covered lol). Also on my rig I can now run 50-60fps in the BETA edition where as before it was around 45-55... no idea why as there is no mention of performance tweaks.

2006 I would give it 6/10, because very few people could actually run it maxed out, if any.
2014 (steam edition release) I would give it 8.5/10 as finally most people could run it maxed out.
These days I give it 10/10 because it is still massive fun to fly, most desktops will run it maxed out, still looks quite pretty especially if you have some nice HD aircraft and are flying through a storm or some other crazy weather.

I personally fly FSX pretty much default setup these days, I have several different weather packs like Zinertek, AFS Clouds, Zinertek Airports etc and Orbx Ground Textures and so fourth, but honestly after 14 years the default sim has held up so well I dont bother with them anymore, plus I often do fresh installs and try new setups so can not be bothered installing all that again. I do change the Moon though and apply the Widescreen edit to the config, but thats all i do aside adding my own planes.

The MSFS series had been around for decades. This was the final installation in the series before Microsoft Disbanded Angels. In 2020, Microsoft had learned from its mistake in discontinuing MSFS, and is developing a new edition of its series, but for almost 14 years, this was the sole Flight Sim of the series. While Lockheed Martin had taken over the source code, and made it better (and newest editions supporting 64 bit), it does suffer from a high price, and of course, debatable terms of its license (which doesn't seem to be an issue from what I can see.) 

With that said, great classic sim, with pretty much the whole world covered, and plenty of high quality addons.

*Beep beep.* *.....MISSILE ARMED...*OH CRAP! I picked one hell of a day to quit drinking...* Independence Day Russell Case. He won't let ya down !

Graphics are not bad, Settings are best when maxed.(Just nice enough to call google maps) 

AI air traffic control is pretty spot on unless your not familiar with navigating then expect your 24 L landing to turn into a 7L or 8R prompting immediate  seatbelt signs and tray tables in their upright position. *Bring butter for the runway*

Base Game With Payware DLC's 
The game can have many pricey add ons that can actually wear down the experience of the game. Recommended to only buy specific packs. If its onsale then grab it sure. but having every single DLC requires a MASSIVE system or youll be waiting out your loading times like a real pilot at Heathrow. (Busy airport)

Most people will say its better to find the freeware planes or dlcs but its best to always research and ask the community if certain planes are JAH! or Nyeet.

Part of this review i will have a part bias opinion about the multiplayer aspect. If your flying a payware or freeware plane that other players dont have, then most chances you show up to them as a default aircraft in the game. Which makes playing with DLCS on multiplayer less enjoyable. 

This is where you get tempted into buying friends aircraft that wont ever just so they can see you in that aircraft xD (I bought 4 of my friends the C-17A GlobeMaster III) Personally my favorite Payware DLC. 128 Hours and counting (Don't ask me how many times i crashed, so many globies gone) 

the only freeware aircraft i would use is probably something you really really really want to fly. Never download freewares if your gonna never use it again, best to keep to Paywares. :) But i enjoy the AN-225 (Not multiplayer friendly) The only freeware aircraft i use. 

Your now cleared to taxi to runway 25 R via taxiway C,C1 full departure. Have a pleasant flight and look for my Tail number ZH-90 (Zulu Hotel) and come fly with me :D (KLAS Las vegas runway 25 R instructions)
Might be showing its age a little but still really great fun and immersive.

Game is starting to show its age now compared with more recent releases of XPlane and P3Dv4, etc but then, check the Steam summer sale price on FSX-SE compared to the other 2. Not even close! Actually, most other flightsim platforms rarely if ever go on sale. FSX-SE still works well and there is a ton of addon freeware and payware scenery and aircraft upgades available, which is not the case with other platforms. FSX-SE also, still works well on mid-range computer systems whereas XPlane and P3D demand the latest and best hardware you can afford. No doubt that as time marches on, other flightsim platforms will continue to gain more popularity, whereas, FSX-SE is heading in only one direction; down. Several payware developers such as Orbx (scenery) are slowly moving away from FSX and now concentrating on the other two. Good news is that in a few years, FSX-SE will be the way FS2004 (FS9) is presently; payware addons being dirt cheap. Regarding my comments about FSX-SE on mid-range, hardware; FSX-SE still is very 32-bit and very cpu dependent. You can have a $1000.00, cutting-edge video card but FSX won't care. It wants the fastest, clocked CPU you can find and extra cores won't add anything to the game. XPlane and P3D will make better use of your RAM and videocard resourses. The latest version of P3D is now 64-bit based so that is another game changer, although most available addons are still only 32-bit. Like everything else, that will change with time.

Bottom line; if you just want to start flight simming at lowest cost possible, FSX-SE is still valid option but if you have bit extra money to burn and know your hardware can handle it; look elsewhere. In long run, you'll be happier.

This game was IT when it came out, unfortunately, few people had the computer specs to run it maxed out. I must have personally put over a thousand hours on the last copy I had. Now that I have a computer that can run it, I find that the options and "intuitiveness" that we've come to expect in software nowadays, is lacking (complicated keyboard shortcuts, rudimentary/clunky menus/multi-screen capability). After I bought the steam version, I never really put much time in the game and I had to remind myself that it's 14 years old and made to be set up once and left alone for the most part. 
   That aside, this has a staple for practicing basic flight maneuvers and has the ability to simulate traffic or allow multiplayer experiences (good luck finding a serious server, lol) I have always loved the ability to experience real time weather and look forward to the next iteration with voluminous flow capabilities. I wish that the modding community was still alive and as active as it once was, it would be great to fine tune everything just the way you like it. I don't buy the steam add-ons. they are hilariously overpriced.

It's a chill product. Perfect for putting on some music, and challenging yourself to as much or as little as you want. For me, the past week has been trying to take a Cessna 172 Skyhawk from my local airport in upstate NY to an ultimate destination of Cairo, Egypt. The difficulty of a novice taking the "starter" plane on a nearly 7000 journey with 13 fuel stops on the highest realism settings available has not been inconsiderable. My first landing in the pitch blackness of remote northeastern Canada on an unlit gravel landing strip had me holding my breath. Teaching myself VOR flying and ILS approaches while in the air led to some comical moments as I lost my way. Or earlier today, being an hour out from Benina airport, over the Mediterranean, when the low fuel warning lit up, and there were no airports closer than the one I was headed for.

For someone like myself, for whom actual flying lessons are no on the table, but that loves flying this is a great power fantasy. I can't wait until I figure out how to start some of the bigger jets so that I can try them out.

I am just in l o v e with this game. 
I mean I first started playing it when I was 17 and I had such a dream to become a pilot one day so I came across to this game. Back at the time I was a really horrible pilot. I didn't know what's IFR,VFR, autopilot, vectors and everything. 
Now I'm past my 20s and I learned a looot thru this game. I know how to operate CRJ700 and B738 and the smaller planes. Yet I have to learn how to operate Airbus A321 cuz that one's so different from Boeing and Bombardier. 
I've traveled thousands miles thruthough the globe: so many beautiful landscapes, clouds and different weather conditions. All that makes this game never go old and realistic indeed. It has its special way of immersing you into real plane operation and it's fun, it's risky, it's a lot to learn and it's not even just a game, it's like you're doing your job - piloting, flying, making stressful decisions sometimes or just laying back on your seat and watching your plane glide over the clouds. It's more than just a game and that's what I like about the Microsoft Flight Simulator X.

[Edited on 05/06/2020: This is important! Forget about Prepar3d as well, and ignore the couple of times in this review below where I mentioned it. Software behemoth Microsoft is back in the game again, and this time with vengeance. According to them, their new and upcoming Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 is going to be built on latest technology, and graphics, scenery and flight model will be way more superior than anything we have today. Do a search for it on Youtube and check out some of the officially published videos and screenshots. I highly suggest you save your money for now and wait for MSFS 2020's official release instead of spending it on Prepar3d or XP11.]  

TL;DR: Avoid this at all cost. Buy [strike]Prepar3d[/strike] MSFS 2020 when it's released instead. This game has been pretty much abandoned and there's no sign of it getting any further improvements. Most probably the only reason this game still has a decent user-base is because some people who paid a lot of money for add-ons in the past don't want to move on to a better sim because they don't want to pay for a vastly improved and modern flight sim and its add-ons again. 

Long version: I've spent thousands of hours on Microsoft Flight Simulator 2002, 2004 and FSX. FS 2004 actually introduced me to the basic principles of powered flight. When Microsoft and Aces Game Studio were actively supporting it, things were looking great for both add-on developers and consumers. 

Unfortunately, back in 2009, due to some stupid decisions made by the then Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer, ACES Studio was shut down, and around 1500 employees were sacked. (Read more about it [url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/01/23/microsofts-game-studios-take-a-beating-in-layoffs/]here[/url]. Thereafter FSX was totally abandoned until Dovetail Games bought the license from Microsoft and brought it to Steam. 

At that time we hoped that Dovetail would continue to improve the underlying code and bring it up to modern standards (i.e. fix the OOM bug, make it 64 bit, add compatibility for more than 4 gigs of RAM etc) but that never happened. So basically, they abandoned it too. The only reason they are still able to sell and make money out of it is because people who already paid a lot of money for the addons in the past still keep playing and paying, which in turn forces the add-on developers to keep making more broken, low-quality, third-class add-ons for this decade-old, broken, deadbeat platform.

Avoid at all cost. Buy [strike]Prepar3d[/strike] MSFS 2020 when it's released instead.

i like to fly

Microsoft Flight Simulator X (FSX) doesn't have the best graphics. However, the price of this game is very good considering the fact that not everyone has the ability to spend circa $50 on X-Plane 11. There is a fairly wide variety of default aircraft and there are a ton of free options for add-ons which you get less of with X-Plane 11 (although I will say that X-Plane 11 add-ons normally have a better quality). As for DLC, I wouldn't bother, there are better add-ons that you can get for free. I suppose the only DLC I'd really recommend would be the HD graphics DLC for $10-$15 (not sure how much it actually is in the US, here in the UK it's £10). One problem with this flight simulator is that for some people, the game may run at about 30 FPS even on really good PCs due to some older optimisation, you should still be fine as 30 FPS is pretty much all you need to play this game comfortably.

So in summary:

If you want a good flight simulator but are on a budget, this is 100% what I would recommend. Even if you do have the money for X-Plane 11, I would still recommend it aswell as X-Plane 11 because of the HUGE amount of fairly good free add-ons that are available on the internet. I'd give it a solid 7/10, it's amazing for those on a budget.

As an FAA certified pilot, I can assure that this simulator is the go-to for practicing instrument training and procedures, as well as understanding basic flight operations and principles.

As for the simmer who is looking for fun, the Steam multiplayer servers are very outdated (which is to be fixed in the next installation of Flight Simulator), but free mode offers plenty of fun for the simmer who is looking to pass the time. Certain areas have very detailed scenery, while other areas require higher graphics settings (and a more powerful PC) to process auto-generated terrain. The default missions have a clear objective, but there is a lack of interaction between the pilot and the mission guides. However, for the time this sim was released, this sim is a gem. Plus, FSX has perhaps the largest third-party file database, so the expansions one can make to FSX are nearly endless - just steer clear of any of the Steam DLC - you will likely get ripped off.

Until flight sim 2020 comes out, this will have to do, though this version has something that 2020 will not, a massive community of additional airplanes and pilots, you can download concorde, the Spirit of St Louis, Ford Tri-motor, the Spitfire and even aircraft from the pioneer era, the interface is great, the lessons with Rod Machado are great though play a little too fast, if you want to play this game, i'd reccomend hitting up your local thrifts or ebay for a joystick, playing with keyboard is fun but not great, a stick will give you a great sense of control.

That being said, FS2020 is going to be great, wether it has Concorde and other famous planes or not, we do not know, all i know is that FSX will live on, no fancy graphics but the simulation is amazing, the interface (especially the 2D cockpit) is perfect, i've never flown a plane IRL before, but FSX has given me the confidence of at least keeping a craft in the air and maybe even landing it.

I avoided this sim b/c it's so old but after tons of trouble with Oculus Quest + Link in X-Plane 11 and Prepar3d, I finally tried MS-FSX. It's 32 bit and the graphics are unimpressive to say the least, but the VR exprience (with FlyInside-FSX) is very smooth. I'm still getting it dialed in, but even where it is now is livable. Until Oculus gets Link worked out so it can handle large, difficult to compress/decompress frames, this is going to be one of the best options for VR flight sim with the Quest. As a side note, for strictly sail plane VR, Condor 2 is definitely the best.

I am a real world instrument rated pilot and use simulators for instrument practice. I have used all the microsoft versions all the way back to MS2000. I have hundreds if not thousands of hours in these simulators. 
Since FSX came out, I have used both X-Plane 10 and Prepar3d. I currently use P3D. 

I downloaded this because it was $5 and saw that there are improvements. I also sent a gift to a few of my friends. since P3D isn't hobby grade, expensive, and a little bit more difficult to run smoothly. 

After about a half hour in the game I am excited about it. I'll be able to race F-18s against my friends again! I haven't installed any of my add-ons to this, and I probably won't. I am treating this as my "game" sim. 

It runs really smooth compared to what I remember from FSX. I am getting 30+ fps steady on a 4k monitor. 

This is a plug and play flight sim! With a decent joystick and adding trim, flap, and spoiler buttons, it really is something special. 

Dovetail did a great job bringing back this classic and although I will not use it for training purposes (it can) I will be using the multi-player often and think this was well worth the $5

This simulator is certainly a trip down memory lane for me. Before I had FSX:SE or just FSX Gold Edition, I flew on Flight Simulator 2004 which was my first experience being at the controls of a virtual aircraft. Of course, I was only five or six years old and I had absolutely no idea what I was doing, but it really helped ignite my passion for flying. Now, this simulator may be obsolete compared to others like X-Plane 11 and FS 2020 just around the corner, but I'll always come back to this one for old time's sake (and because of the communities on multiplayer).

Now onto the actual review. When first purchasing FSX, it may seem daunting what you need to learn, but there are communities on multiplayer that are willing to teach, flying lessons that can be located in the Learning Center, and of course the basic tutorials that are found under the Missions tab. Once you have a good idea of how to fly, you may realize how old the game is. The default navaids are out of date, airports haven't been updated, and the aircraft that may be considered more advanced (e.g. 737, 747, CRJ, etc.) are drastically simplified compared to the complex and far more realistic components they have in newer simulators. There can be fixes for this, which leads me to one of the more unappealing aspects of FSX. There is third party software, such as PMDG, which sells a close to real life 737, Orbx, which can update the scenery in FSX and improve certain airports, and many more. These can cost more than twice as much money the simulator itself is worth, which means that you could potentially be paying for more than what you could get in one entire simulator, like X-Plane 11, or even FS 2020 that will be coming this year. I myself have never spent extra money on FSX and have strictly used freeware software that are useful for flying purposes. One of them I highly recommend is Littlenavmap, which displays airports, taxiways, procedures, weather (In FSX and real life), can be used for flight planning, and many more! This is the top freeware product I recommend downloading, and that no flight simmer should be left without, unless practicing procedures that make using Littlenavmap cheating.

One last thing, there are many communities on FSX where players can do flights together, and can host events (Depending on the server). This is completely up to the player which community they join, but different servers have different rules and standards, so please keep that in mind while seeing which place you prefer to fly at. Also depending on the community is what type of communication system you use. Because FSX has terrible in-game communication, servers rely on software like Discord or Teamspeak for communication. Servers typically list which one they use in the description when you select a server, so choose wisely!

In short, FSX is great simulator, but it is not perfect. While considering purchasing FSX, keep in mind the graphics aren't up to modern standards, the default planes aren't 100% realistic, ATC communication in single player isn't great, and there are airports that aren't up to date. Despite this, FSX is a great way to get introduced to aviation and know what the basics are. But, this doesn't compare to flying in real life, and if you're interested, find a flying instructor in your area and take an intro flight (At least when the COVID-19 situation is over) to see what the real deal is, and possibly consider flying as a career.

I hope people still see the value of FSX. Happy flying!

Absolute garbage. Already asked for my refund.
EDIT: I decided to give the game a second chance and found out that it is actually a good game.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition.
Or, FSX:SE for short.

A beautiful flight simulator with proper autogen, still played by thousands of aviation enthusiasts and their cheap joysticks and yokes. A massive and mostly kind community, with thousands of free and paid addons, this game has aged akin to fine wine. It gets more and more fun when you get some addons and repaints for your aircraft, and when you join the servers held by multiple people. To be honest, there are only few cons and lots of pros:

Cons:
- Dated graphics coming from 2006.
- Buggy and unstable, even on the highest of computers.
- Some notable terrain mesh and airport bugs.

Pros:
- Beautiful skylines coming from the early 2000s, can be updated.
- Most international and North American airports are detailed and are functional.
- Recent terrain mesh, less bugs than its older counterparts, FS2004.
- Supportive community filled with aviation enthusiasts.
- So many ADDONS, and it doesn't have to be aircraft! It could be ships, cars, and sometimes people and scenery. So much freeware and even more payware.
- Lots of fun missions with small rewards. (Not actual rewards, more like a collection of small pictures and wings)
- Helpful tutorial that eases you into flying straightaway.

In conclusion, I would highly recommend Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition. A beautiful flight simulator that aged like fine wine, as many would state. Still very active, almost 24/7, and with a bright community of both real and trained pilots of all backgrounds. Respectful to all, a beautiful flower of a game.

**So come on down, get in your aircraft, and takeoff to new worlds and cities!**

It's a great game considering it was released in 2006. So don't expect anything major graphics wise. There are a shit ton of mods available for this game but I wouldn't recommend buying through steam because I've heard that some of the mods may not function correctly(and they're expensive af) .Also there are a ton of free mods on the internet so  , yeah. 

[u] Important things to know before buying/playing the game; [/u]

-Even though the game was released in 2006 computers are still struggling to run this game smoothly. Be prepared for that. So unlike other games from that era you CANNOT run FSX on a baby carrot.

-It has multiplayer so you can crash planes with your friends. Noone gives a shit about ATC's in multiplayer so there's no need to learn any callouts or anything. You're free to fuck off from anywhere ,  any time you wish.

-Literally everything you see looks outdated. You'll have to accept that.

-Most of the mods will take up more space than the game itself because deatiled textures and attention to detail in the stock game is non-existent.

-It's a good simulator. But maybe try P3D.

-Who even reads a review about this game? It's FSX, how have you not heard of it?

 You'll see that it's worth the money. Have fun. Thanks for reading.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: gold edition was one of the first games I played at a very early age. Although I wasn't a HUGE enthusiast of the game, I still loved the feeling of flying a plane at age 5. Microsoft Flight Simulator has been around my life in a couple of ways, from having had a few friends that had an entire setup for the game, to going to plane exhibits to see a fully customized plane simulator using this game as the software. I recently decided to learn how to fly because I found my old flight stick in my garage, and I got the steam edition of Microsoft Flight Simulator X. The things I like about this game is that, although the graphics are not too good (the game is from 2006 so this makes perfect sense), I still enjoy the gameplay you get out of it, whether learning the basics of flight in the missions, or playing online with friends. This game gave me a certain nostalgic feel which I haven't felt in a long time. I would recommend getting X-Plane 11 if you are into having every aspect of the game being realistic, but if you just want to learn how to maneuver a plane whilst having realistic feedback from the game, or you want to have a really awesome multiplayer experience, I HIGHLY recommend getting this game.

This is an old game. 
FSX is 32bit program so it uses a maximum of 4gb of RAM. Also FSX was developed during the time when single core CPU's were the go to, so if you check your CPU usage, you'll find that core 0 is at 100% and the other cores would range from 25-60% usage. Furthermore FSX is not GPU optimized, so no matter if you have an RTX 2080ti or intregrated Vega graphics, theres not much difference. Finally FSX is a simulator you have to invest on if you're advanced. Vanilla FSX is boring. If you want FSX to look good you really need to buy Orbx sceneries, PMDG, Aerosoft, Quality Wings aircraft if you want a flawless experience, which at the end costs around $400. But that's up to you. 
If you want a better version of FSX go and buy a license for Lockheed Martin's Prepar3d V4.0-5.0. It's an improved version of FSX with better lighting and PC optimization. But if you're a beginner, ignore all that you read above and buy it. Its a great "starter" simulator.

i paid £4.95 for this in a sale to help pass the time during the Covid crisis lockdown. its been a fantastic purchase. As soon as i could take off and land more or less safely i watched some youtube vids about ils landings, gps and radio navigation then set off on a round the world trip in the Mooney Bravo in real time and real weather. i travel about 700 miles a day.
where ever i stop i read the wiki and try to find out a little about the area's history. then i look around the town on google maps and street view. i check out the bars and hotels to get a flavour of the town ( i try to stop at smaller places) and imagine where i would eat, drink and sleep.

this is so much more than a game i am glad i bought it. without the current crisis i never would have.
reading this back i think i might be going a bit stir crazy!
strange days indeed.

This is an amazing and astonishing simulator. At this moment (2020) it is outdated, but still reliable. I love the selection you get by default with the comprehension of addons. With addons, you can fly your dream aircraft with your dream livery over your desired location. By default, it isn't a good simulator for sightseeing, but can be real eye-candy with the inclusion of various mods. The community for FSX and FSX:SE is amazing because there are constant and plentiful amount of modifications to meet and suit your aviation goals. Whether you want to fly across the pond to Heathrow, or domestically on a short hop, it is fun to simulate a real or fictional route. The missions included are decent and the tutorials available will meet newcomers with surprise and ease. With all of that being said, it is recommended to buy this during a sale (which I have not) and it is very fun to simulate until the next flight simulator you'll own.

Owned the boxed edition back in 2006. Since then, I have been flying various aircraft. Flying freeware for 10 years, joined VATSIM and invested on PMDG aircraft from 2016 onwards. But the boxed edition started to lag out on me (e.g. frame rate drops and etc). Saw that Steam had FSX and bought it without hesitation and it was the best decision made. The FPS in the Steam version was better as compared to the boxed version. I'm also glad that the PMDG aircraft I bought are also compatible with FSX Steam Edition.

If you're still using the boxed editon, try moving to this platform instead.

FSX.

Can you really get much better than this?

I mean, the graphics are not the best. But what about chill, relaxed multiplayer?

Beginner-friendly multiplayer?

Advanced features and a huge variety of mods?

A gigantic part of the flight sim community, even though it is a very old game?

Flight Sim X, you have all of it.

There really is not much to say about the gameplay. Yes, it is a very advanced flight sim, and if you are willing to make the next step big manufacturers like Aerosoft have got you covered with airport and aircraft models.
The graphics? Not great, but with some mods, even free ones, you can step it up real good.
But what I love, is the multiplayer.

You know what? After 1 hour of flight alone, I get awfully bored. I don't have anyone to talk to, and I feel very lonely. 
That's where multiplayer comes in.

There is so many beginner-friendly ATC communities that provide services for free to some other users that want to fly around a bit. My favorite is fsATC, but you can pick your own. It is just so relaxed and so much fun at the same time. I hope they keep it in MSFS2020, because a VATSIM-only future isn't the best outlook for me.

Thank you, Microsoft Flight Simulator X. Thank you so much.

This game is one of the best flight simulators that I have experienced. The fact that the game is able to be formatted for many different computers and consoles is incredible. The graphics that come with the game are decent, but they could use some work. The game physics themselves are great, and I highly recommend this to anyone who is interested in a realistic flight simulator.

Initially the game worked well, however, I purchased the Scottish scenery add-on and had no issues until I flew south from Glasgow to Newcastle. At the transition point between the add-on scenery and the default scenery the application crashes. I removed the application and every thing appeared to be back to normal  except every time  I open the game I get an error message. I open my Steam account and and check verification .... there’s 17 files corrupted and need to be repaired ... that’s every time I open the game.

Unfortunately, by the time these errors cropped up, Ive played too many hours and can’t get a refund. So I’m uninstalling the game, closing my Steam account and going back to the PC version which was more stable.

This is an astonishing game for its time. It has a large variety of aircraft and airports to choose from with the default game, and its players can easily download and add new aircraft to the game. The community of the multiplayer game is amazing and extremely active, even for being such an old game. Also, for those who don't want to fly multiplayer, the extremely accurate simulated ATC brings just as much fun for the single player mode. Lastly, it also has several user options that make the game easily playable for any level of aviationist, from beginners to experts. Overall, I have been very pleased with this game and I would recommend this game to anyone who is even slightly interested in aviation and looking to have a good time while playing it.

Name another game that is more than 10 years old and still has DLC being created for it.  It's a very short list.  The Microsoft Flight Simulator X is still a playable simulator to this day.  That is a major success for its original development team.  The game enabled support for mods before mods was even a thing!  And while it is in fact dated from a system architecture and graphics support perspective, it is STILL a viable and entertaining flight simulator.  The realism in plane and environment was good in the beginning; it's even better with a wealth of add-on options.  I've owned this game for years and even owned previous versions.  Started playing it again in 2019 and can't put it down.  Many add-ons later, the simulation is so engaging and I'm learning what it's like to pilot the large jetliners.  Have an interest in flying?  You can't go wrong.  Sure there are newer attempts at flight simulators.  Some are quite good.  But, if you're looking for a lot of options right out of the gate, FSX is your choice.  Plus, prepare to transition to the next Microsoft Flight Simulator that will put all the others to shame.  Its coming this year!  But don't wait.  Start building your skills today.

This game was possibly one of the bigger inspirations to pursue a career in aviation. Made my training much easier with the various very realistic aircraft, weather and emergency scenario mods (such as alternator failure, CSU leak, detonation etc) which can be found on various websites to download. Although ATC and airports were not life like and had completely different taxi ways and parking bays, the runways and scenery around the airport held up fairly well and I still managed to navigate around the area in VFR conditions without using charts. It is possible to simulate IFR conditions, however it is fairly basic and lacks tools in the base game. The aerodynamics component of the game is fairly mediocre to real life conditions. It does indeed get the basics right, however it falls short for more complex manoeuvres. And again, all these negative points can easily be fixed with the thousands and thousands of mods found online. 

Overall it's a blast of a game and the multiplayer is still holding strong with many active players still playing to this day.

My PC has a Z270-A board, 4.20 GHz Intel 4-core i7-7700K cpu, and 64 GB installed usable memory. The graphics card is an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1070.
I have all the FSX-SE display settings fully maxed out. The frame rate varies between ~35 to 150. So now I have limited it to 50 and that seems fine.
I have had a long and sometimes discouraging experience trying to get FS-SE and the Clouds and Textures DLCs working. After trying for a couple of months, FINALLY, everything seems to be working just beautifully now. It was undoubtedly some stupid mistake on my part. But even now I don't know what was wrong nor how I fixed it.
All I can say as a long time FSX fan, with the add-ons working, the scenery is beautiful. I especially like landing at a big city airport (like KJFK) just after sunset, with some clouds. The city lights together with the golden hued clouds is simply great.
Now, after a long hard battle, I wholeheartedly give FS-SE my highest possible recommendation.

I may not have put too many hours into MFS X, but I do enjoy playing when I have the time. It's great for some(not all) low end computers on low settings and possibly medium settings. The learning curve depending on your controls of choice(flight stick, keyboard, controller, ect) is pretty decent. The DLC together are a bit on the pricey side unless you only want one kidney or one lung. But on the plus side, adding mods sort of adds what some of the DLCs failed to do(kind of like Bethesda and Skyrim). In all honesty, it's a good time passer and will allow you to fly planes that'll take a while of real world training to actually fly. Multiplayer is fine as long as you have good internet and can actually find a room that doesn't always require teamspeak. Some of the graphics could use a little work, like having a co-pilot visible as well as your own body inside as well as outside the cockpit. Would I recommend? Maybe for anyone who wants to try before the new flight sim comes out. As for me, I think I'll stick to this one for now.

The last time I took time to sit down and play a MS FS was back in 1998, and at some point along the years I purchased a PC Phantom Logic 3, model JT250 which back then plugged into a dedicated 'Game Port'. These days I need a 'Game Port' to USB adaptor (which saved a few other controllers from being binned) and everything still works fine.

So, the locations you can fly from and land at are everywhere, and the games graphics have somewhat improved, not I think I'd expected more definition, but coastlines, road ways, and rivers are recognisable, so you can all but fly over where you live which is awesome.
The flight controls, fluidity of the joystick and mouse controls are very precise, and the aircraft dynamics feel how I would expect a aircraft to feel and respond.

I started on 'Beginner' flying the Microlight, then jumped in to a jet fighter, I mean after all, why not eh? Over the span of a few days I found it enjoyable enough that I went on to YT to view videos on how to set up the game up better, adjusting the zoom, seat height, leaning the basic keys and such. It's still not perfect, but it is getting there.

Today I went to 'Realistic' mode, with the jet fighter, I crashed once on take off, something to do with stressing the air-frame, yeah right, whatever happened to battle ready I wonder, lol... Anyway, lesson learnt, second flight was much better, I took off, flew around, saw another airport and landed. Well, that was easy, maybe it was a fluke? So I tried again, and again took off and landed fine.

Lets try a 747-400... Good result, I ain't saying the passengers will ever fly with me again, actually, I think I've put most of the passengers off flying for life, well, less the flying, more the landing, but I promise, we all walked away, some I'm sure were on their hands and knees kissing the tarmac, but meh, I'll take that as a sign that 'Kissing the runway' was something they had on a bucket list and can now cross off, right?.

I've not gone multiplayer or anything that brave yet, and I did awful flying the helicopters, but it's early days, so time will tell...

Is that a Hot Air Balloon going through control while a jet lands at mach 5?

Yes. That statement is a clear example of what you will get in FSX: Steam Edition.

The simulator is graphically lacking in today's age, however being that it was released in 2006 for Steam, I'm satisfied with the community  (there are servers that will enforce proper flight procedure and servers that let you go nuts. Overall, you have complete freedom to roam around.) For a simulator, I have had no problems with the game itself working with my stick and throttle that a few google searches couldn't fix. When entering the game, you go through the lovely experience of programming your flight system for countless hair pulling hours until you get it to work just right. As most simulators, many of the planes and helicopters are locked behind paid downloadable content, some ranging from $10 to $50+. I understand there is a licensing fee, but dear do I wish it was cheaper. You could spend $5,000+ USD on vehicles and updated maps and go crazy, but please save your money and just buy what you will use. Overall, if you enjoy flying, being an ATC, or are a real pilot, go ahead and get this game. For a simulator where you can do anything and not get your license revoked, this is great!

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is one of the best flight simulator games that you can get. With a plethora of aircraft to fly, the entire world to explore, and thousands of airports to land at, there's a lot to experience in Microsoft Flight Simulator X. And although the game is reasonably priced some of the DLC is absurdly expensive. Furthermore, the game suffers from framerate issues and crashes that occur from time to time, but these issues weren't frequent enough to ruin my gameplay experience. But even with those issues, Microsoft Flight Simulator X is still one of the best flight simulators out there and I'd definitely recommend you pick it up.

I honestly cannot recommend FSX as a viable flight simulator any more, as it is simply too old. It was abandoned by Microsoft many years ago, and new developer, Dovetail also appears to have lost interest in it. The on-line live weather and news pages are dead. If it was £2.49 like most other games from 2006, it would be a reasonable option for those with low-spec computers. At £19.99 it's a mickey take. It's just not worth the money.

It is not compatible with Direct X 10, meaning that many features of current graphics cards are not available. It doesn't support multi-core processors properly and can't use more than 4GB of memory, no matter how much you have installed. It will run well enough using its default terrain, scenery and aircraft but it looks dreadful by modern standards. If you install third-party scenery and aircraft, especially ones with detailed virtual cockpits, FSX:SE will crash to desktop without warning, often at the end of a long flight.

If you are serious about flight simulation, you should purchase Prepar3D, which is what FSX became after Lockheed Martin took over the licence. Many of the third-party scenery packs and aircraft designed for FSX:SE are also compatible with P3D. P3D is also fully compatible with modern processors, graphics cards and Windows 10 64bit.

I used FSX:SE for about two months before I got utterly fed up with system crashes, lockups and poor performance. I now use P3D v4.5, which I can confirm is vastly better and completely stable. I have not used FSX:SE since installing P3D, and will probably uninstall it soon. It was a waste of money in my opinion, and if I had known about P3D I would have bought that instead right at the start.

Another popular alternative to P3D is X-Plane. Both are better than FSX:SE, which was great in its day, but should really be a free download now.

As a further point to note, do NOT purchase any of the addon aircraft or terrain through Steam if you ever intend to upgrade to P3D. You will have to buy them again as they are specific to the Steam version and can't be transferred over to P3D. Purchase addons direct from the developer or through a universal seller like Just Flight and you will be able to install the addon in FSX:SE or P3D, or both. I learned this the hard way and it was very expensive. The addons available from outside Steam are generally far better quality anyway.

FSX is the continuation of the excellent line of Microsoft flight simulators.   I like that I can practice ILS approaches, VOR ans GPS navigation.  I like the flight characteristics, and I absolutely love some of the airplanes, including the P-51D.

Another big plus is that I was able to purchase and fly the Diamond DA-20, as this is the aircraft I own in real life. It is incredibly helpful to be able to get some SIM time on "my" airplane when the weather does not allow me to fly the real thing.

The downsides include the buildings and scenery, which is very bad by today's standards.  Flying over Las Vegas, the scenery makes it painfully obvious FSX uses a 1990's rendering engine.

FSX should also offer more airplanes by default.  More airliners, more war planes, more historically significant airplanes, more experimental planes, spy planes, etc.

Ok, so I picked this game up in a sale last year and it ran pretty smooth on my old laptop on max settings and it crashed every 20 mins, and I left a bad review after a couple of hours of trying to fix it. I then contacted Dovetail Support and they said my graphics card wasn't powerful enough. So I took the review down because  I didn't want to impact the game if it was a problem on my side.

A year later, I got my first job and brought a powerful gaming pc (16gb ram, i7-9700f overclocked to 4.7GHz and a 6GB RTX 2060) and I installed FSX on to it... I STILL HAVE THE SAME PROBLEM! Crashes every 20 minutes still, so it's quite obviously due to the game it's self, I have given up on this game and if someone knows how to fix it please tell me... But at the moment I don't recommend this game.

FSX: SE is one of the best simulators out there. It is commonly used for stop motion simulators and is extremely stable even on low end computers. The graphics are excellent, its just that most people that said the graphics are bad didn't realise they can go in settings > custom and adjust graphics to be very awesome. The only major CON is that there is 5K $ of add-ons and DLC. Most good planes are the ones you need to buy for over 20$ but for what the sim is for itself, you should get it.
Compared to X-Plane 11, it is a huge amount more stable. For me, on XP11 (demo), I would need to adjust my settings until everything is a blur and airports would be gone. Even then, key binds are hard to understand. In FSX though, I could adjust my settings as high as I wanted, with getting only medium lag in the biggest airports.
In short: I recommend this simulator for users with laptops or low end computers, as its very stable and reliable.

I've been using Flight Simulator since version 1.0.  I have more than 100,000 flight hours logged.  I am also the CEO of the 2nd oldest virtual airline in the world: Lynx Airways Worldwide.  Lynx Airways Worldwide is the second oldest virtual airline on the WEB opening our hangar doors at John F. Kennedy International on July 1, 1992.  Since then, and as we continue today, we at Lynx Airways provide a unique experience that challenges your imagination.  You can select from our established flight schedules and take scheduled flights around the world.  Or, hop into your favorite aircraft, climb to altitude and just take a left.   Come visit us and take a tour around our WEB site then come into Headquarters located in Terminal #1 at KJFK to read our Pireps and everything else we have to offer.  The Pilots at Lynx Airways Worldwide are quite the story tellers.  It makes sense, as your imagination is where we virtually exist.  www.lynxairways.com

Captain Ginns
CEO
Lynx Airways Worldwide

DO NOW PURCHASE! I REPEAT! DO NOT PURCHASE!
1. The game was already hard enough to set up because you have all of those sh**ty problems like the game dropping to 5fps whenever you have sound on and all of that other crap that I won't even mention here. Also the fact that you gotta spend a fucking week trying to figure out and solve all of this sh**ty problems.
2. I was on a 3 hour flight and everything went smooth. No problems at all. But then... When I come to check the flight plan 10 minuets before landing the damn (not even appropriate for the title game or simulation) thing crashes!
3. INFACT, THE GAME DOES THAT EVERYTIME YOU DO SOMETHING THAT IS MORE INTENSIVE THAN AGAR.IO! For example: I wanted to set up another view mid flight for my 2nd monitor, so I hover my cursor above the "view" catagory at the top, then "outside", AND THAN THE GAME FREEZES, CURSOR TURNS INTO A BLUE CIRCLE LOADING, BOOM! GAME JUST CRASHES! Sorry, not crashes, BUT F***ING DISAPPEARING RIGHT OFF MY GOD DAMN SCREEN WITH NO SIGN THAT IT WAS EVEN ON 3 SECONDS AGO! And why am I mad? Because it happens EVERY F***ING TIME THAT I GO TO THAT SH**TY MENU BAR AT THE LEFT TOP AND TRY TO OPEN/CHANGE/CHECK SOMETHING! It happend to me 7 out of 7 flights that I just sat there like an idiot not knowing this somewhat of an unappropriate called game is wasting my f***ing time for (depending on the flight) 3 to 6 hour a flight!
4. The game crashes when i'm doing other actions too (like it wasn't obvious enough) like I don't know... Maybe STARTING A F***ING FREE FLIGHT!!!
5. This game is incapable, overpriced, and you literally can not play it.
IF YOU ARE LOOKING TO ACTUALLY FLY AN AIRCRAFT OF SOME SORT DO NOT, AND I REPEAT, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.
Only and I mean ONLY buy this game if you want to fly once, and than get a waste of $25 that crashes on you every 5 minuets and makes you angry to the point that not only you can't fly because the game is incapable of actually doing so, but your anger just makes want to punch you monitor!
On that friendly note, I wanted so much to actually play a simulator and be able to fly, but I just wasted my go damn money. Better of with Prepar3d on X-Plane...

EDIT:
Originally I was pretty mad when writing this review but then I realized that its original release date was October 2006 and that it's a miracle that this game even runs on Windows 10 and my PC.
2nd thing is that you also can't expect such a good performance when running a game from 2006. Not to say that it runs smooth and has good performance but it also holds up pretty nicely for a game that's from 2006.
Still not the best thing out there but also not the worst.
EDIT 2:
It has been a while and I finally got everything to work smooth but I would still consider other simulators. If you don't have the budget than this one might be a decent one if you're able to get it to work and function properly!
EDIT 3:
After installing VATSIM (which is a huge part of the game) and not being able to make it work, I uninstalled it but the game crashed every-time I opened a session I reinstalled the game but it still crashes and everytime it crashes around 10 files get deleted and I have to install them again....

I bought this 3 times: On DVD Deluxe Edition, Windows Live Marketplace, and Steam.  I was excited to see it on Steam, because Windows Live Marketplace had shut down.  I can now play it without any DVDs, which is great! I prefer this version over FS2000 and FS2004 which I also own on disk (somewhere in my house).

My hours on the Steam version do not even compare to all the hours I spend since 2006.  This is a great title, and I recommend it to anyone wanting to get into flight sims.  Sure, it has aged, but there is so much content available for this, its hard not to buy again.  If you are new to flying, it even has lessons to teach you, so you are not completely lost.  Give it a go, and you will see hours of fun coming your way.

This game is... ok? There are multiple issues for beginners like me. 
1) There is a crashing problem where the game crashes every 5-10 minutes.
2) The game is already $25 dollary doos. And with a huge amount of DLCs that are pretty pricey too.
3) All the controls are very... Unusual and it's not the same buttons as a lot of games.
4) The game originally seems pretty out of date with pretty low graphic quality.
5) Related to #4, instead of giving better graphics as DLCs, they should actually put in big updates for the game, they could have done that for over 10 years now. (The game came out in 2006)
6) Every thing is pretty complicated.

excellent for navigation  the only weak point is the flight envelope does not include stall and spin training capable aircraft.  MFSX was grown off a program written by Artwick for US Air Force.  This program was a general orientation pilot program for Air Force pilots advance nav and airport work.  The only sim aircraft that has a program stall and recovery analog is the Sopwith Camel in Rise Of Flight. However, MFSX is the Gold Standard in flight sim.  Note to all sim pilots; a real pilot will know how to stall, spin and recover from this dangerous aircraft condition without freezing on the stick and becoming SOS.
