This is a great game and is perfect for anyone who likes planes and would like to see how they work. I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone as it is fun but can also be played seriously if that is what you are into. It doesnt take much to run and overall the scenery could look better but with a few addons that can be changed. If you can pick this game up when it is on sale i would definitely recommend you do so but if not i would wait for it to. There is a few basic aircraft in the game but not many, if you are looking for decent aircraft that operate like real world aircraft you are going to have to pay for them as most mods do not come many working parts. There are also many servers that are free flight so if its not serious simulation you are looking for then get together with some friends or just by yourself and just have some fun. Overall this is a great game and would 10/10 recommend. The game is a decent price but the addons are a little over priced, for every addon you are looking at paying an average of around £13 and there around 240 different addons but some do not work very well. If you were to ever buy addons i would recommend you buy them from other developers from other places other than steam because you will get better quality addons for a better price.

As a retired Air Force Veteran, I enjoy flying many of the aircraft on this edition of Microsoft Flight Simulator X. Cockpit layouts, flight controls, throttle quadrants, gauges and navigational aids are excellently reproduced and function just like instrumentation of actual aircraft.  The number of airports worldwide is virtually endless. I have found airport layouts in the United States, Canada, Great Britain, Germany, Asia, the Pacific Islands and areas around the Mediterranean exceptionally realistic, compared to times when I pulled duty in these countries and geographic areas of the world.  I would recommend this Flight Sim program for anyone from beginner to novice; real flyers or just gamer's.

Ahh, good ol' FSX. This program has been around a while, but it's still a valuable resource for pilots, both virtual and real.

By today's standards FSX has some dated graphics and an outdated flight model, but even those relatively minor attributes can be addressed with the huge assortment of mods available. Everything you could need, from better scenery to an almost unlimited amount of add on aircraft is out there for simming pleasure, and many of it is even free if you go looking for it. Sure, you can see here in the Steam DLC library there are thousands of dollars worth of payware, but honestly you don't need to pay for great add-ons for this application. 

Even without add ons, you get a lot out of the box. Thousands of airports to explore, a large selection of aircraft, ranging from gliders, to helicopters, to jumbo jets are waiting for users to master, and a full world of scenery to fly over and discover all wait those who want to dive into this sim. Granted, that scenery is rather grainy, not true to life and plain in 2019, but the sim tries! Even more than all of that, you get a full index of learning material and missions to get your feet wet. This is a application that can sap endless amounts of hours from your life easily, not that this is a complaint in this case.

The weather simulation is the biggest problem I have come across; it's not very accurate to the real thing and even getting augmenting programs like SkyActive only seem to help a little. It's something I hope the new sim from Microsoft coming out it 2020 rectifies somehow. 

Something users may find with playtime is crashes, sadly. They are common, and the more add ons you have the more likely they seem to occur.  Sometimes they will happen just as you get your aircraft into taxiing, other times at the end of the session you were about to end anyway. There are good days where there are no crashes at all, but one should be weary that crashes do happen. Sometimes.

The controls and customizing is great. I love it. There are a lot of sliders to manipulate and a lot of things to go over, but if you take the time to look at everything and tweak the systems, you can get the sim to do pretty much what you want it to within reason. By today's standards, the game doesn't need a super computer to run well either, and the performance is something you can manage with more in-sim sliders. You can make the sim as sensitive to control inputs as you like too, an important feature for those using joysticks, throttle quadrants, rudder pedals and the like.

Another big issue with the current state of FSX on Steam is the multiplayer. Playing this with other pilots is a great experience, even ones who don't know what they are doing can do some entertaining things that can garner a good laugh or two from those who do. However, in order to take advantage of this feature, you either have to join an existing game, or host one yourself and it's the hosting that makes one jump through some serious hoops to get working. It's rather daunting, especially for someone who isn't into techno babble. Luckily, there are a couple of very helpful tutorials on the subject in the forums.

All in all, I love this program. I've been using it for years and have had it installed in several cases on two different computers, and while it does have some faults, FSX is more of a boon then a letdown for serious simmers. I can whole heartily recommend this to anyone who loves aviation.

Flight Simulator is the best game known to mankind. It has been played throughout history. In ancient days, men looked at the sky and wondered what it would be like to fly like a bird. Fortunately, they had flight simulator to quench their thirst. Legend has it that one reason the Ancient Egyptians were so advanced for their time was that the god Shu gave them the gift of Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to rule the sky forever. One of the main reasons Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill were so strong in World War Two was that they had great skills in planning airstrikes thanks to having countless hours of Flight Simulator under their belts, and they bestowed this knowledge upon the countless bomber and fighter squadrons of the Allied Forces. To this day, Flight Simulator binds the brotherhood of humanity around the world more tightly than the strongest glue ever manufactured. To play this game, if it can even be called one, is to transcend beyond the physical universe and make the transition from a mere mortal man into a living deity, forever to fly.

Well, after a tedious battle against those OOM tragic errors, which I ultimately lost, I decided it was time to switch to some 64 bits version. 
This is sad, I really enjoyed flying FSX and FSX:SE. I thought for a moment that tweaking that HIGHMEMFIX=1 option, a few other settings in fsx.cfg and the Nvidia panel would help but crashes came back as usual, either launching the game or just at random. 

I don't know how you guys did it taming the horse but you certainly deserve respect. 
Not that I have a lot of addons : Orbx global and vectors, my awesome Diamond DA62 + either Rex Sky Force or ASN. All proprerly and carefully configured. 

At least I didn't loose my money on third-party programms and found a solution compatible with what I already have.
Given the difference on my screen now, where I see clouds' shadows, 3D buildings from the distance, and that mist and glare upon sunset, I'm just telling myself that I waited too long to make up my mind.

I've never piloted an actual aircraft , but in my opinion MFSx provides a very convincing and authentic experience of what that must be like. The graphics are extraordinary, making it possible to engage in a fascinating kind of "armchair" tourism (such as flying through the Grand Canyon) that might be  impossible in real life (like flying through the Canyon at night!) The program offers an impressive array of aircraft to fly, including props, jets, gliders, ultralights, and even helicopters (although the dynamics of the latter didn't seem quite as genuine as those of more conventional aircraft). For the relatively modest price of the Steam edition Microsoft's Flight Simulator X is a real bargain.

I am a qualified and highly experienced privater pilot. Microsoft Flight Simulator enables me to practice many aspects of real flying in the comfort of my home, at a cost far below that of the actually flying. MFS is very real and I look forward to the next release in terms of improved reality. I have also over the years mastered the Boeing 737 and 747, the Bombardier Lear Jet,  Airbus and various others. I have often wondered how no trained pilots get to use MFS which I see more as a tool than  a game. Had I not been a pilot, I would never have known where to start.. MFS is real. It is fun. It is challenging and the most important thing is, it keeps my mind on the ball. Although FSX and FSX Steam are dated simulations - they are still amazing! Add third party scenery and aircraft to enhance the base program and enjoy, I like to explore airports and scenery areas that I have not been to and also fly back into areas that I have visited or lived in. I usually open up Google Earth and follow along as I am flying, scouting out the airport and reviewing google pictures that others have posted - it adds richness to learn about the local area I am flying into. You can also copy the Longitude/Latitude coordinates from FSX right into Google Earth Search. Add weather, IFR, avionics and it really does feel realistic. FSX and other flight simulators do take a commitment of time and practice. You need a joystick/throttle at a minimum and a good quality gaming monitor. FSX does allow you to open several windows, so a second monitor is also useful. Those of you who plan on taking flight lessons will benefit from being able to come home and practice what you learned at ground school and in the air.

FSX has a few things going for it for someone new to simming:

 -it is cheap

 -it has some great tutorials/lessons

 -there is an absolute ton of free add-ons available for it

If you already own it, I would take a look at the tutorials and flying lessons from Rod Machado (separate from the missions). These will give you a good basic understanding of how to fly a simple aircraft like the Cessna 172.

What I wouldn't do is spend money on add-ons for FSX. If you decide simming is for you then either look at P3D or Xplane 11.

The simulator is good, although with the upcoming release of Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 I wouldn't recommend buying now. Overall it's good but only if you want to do light simulation, otherwise, you'll have to buy addons to make your game more realisitc. Be aware that some of those addons can go VERY high in price.

I played (for want of a better word) MS Flight Sim 2000 back in the day and was blown away with its attention to detail and graphics for the time. So getting into FSX more than a decade after its release feels quite nostalgic, as it looks about as old as FS 2000 looks in my head. 

On that note, yeah the graphics look aged and there are aspects of the sim that do show its age. But for all that it does still look decent and its still just as complex and involved as ever. There are of course tutorials to help you at least be able to take off and land, along with many missions to complete once you reach some level of competency. Though of course you can pretty much ignore the more advanced stuff and fly around til your hearts content after completing a couple of tutorials. So this sim should keep the more serious flight sim buffs happy, while also not being too overwhelming for casuals to jump in and have a go. 

Like a lot of people 'playing' FSX, I was motivated to get into it after watching Airforceproud95 on YouTube with his antics in the multiplayer part of the sim. You can even take the role of ATC if you wish, or (as most do) you can get up to all sorts of mischief or fly some missions with others that can be as simple or difficult as you want to. I had no trouble finding active hosts for the multiplayer, so there are definitely still people on FSX all these years later. Though some servers are pretty empty in all honesty... 

With all that said, this is still a sim that is over a decade old and there are certain aspects of it where this is very apparent. My PC should have no issues running a sim this old at very high FPS with everything maxed out (3700x with 1080ti, M.2 SSD and 16gb 3600mhz DDR4) but I have to reduce settings otherwise I get frame drops as low as the mid teens here and there even though it doesn't look amazing. When using MSI Afterburner it becomes clear that this sim wasn't designed to make use of multi core CPUs, as one of my CPU cores is at 100% while the other seven are not being used at all by FSX. 

Performance issues with dated graphics aside, there is still a LOT of DLC content as well as a decent selection of aircraft that come standard with FSX. So there is more than enough content to keep any flight sim fan busy and if you bought all the DLC as well, there's enough to leave you bankrupt too!

In summary I would say if you can get this really cheap and you don't care about DLC then it is worth picking up. Otherwise I would hold off as Microsoft will be releasing Flight Sim 2020 next year which is looking like a big leap in visual quality, plus it will no doubt be able to utilise more than one CPU core!

I've been playing MSFS since the 98 version, when i was 7 years old and my grandpa introduced me. 

If you like super-nerdy sims with too much detail for normal people, this is absolutely the game you want. Frankly, if you're looking at it, it's probably a game for you. If this is the first time you've heard of Microsoft Flight Sim, it might not be. Even if this is your first time, though, I do recommend it! It's just a fun, immersive distraction. I recommend having a joystick at the minimum. You can go real deep on equipment and paid DLC, but for the latter, just know there's an enormous community out there of freeware devs who make absolutely fantastic planes!

In short, if you like planes, and want to fly, but don't have tens of thousands of dollars for lessons, this is for you.

Now, even though X-Plane 11 provides better graphics and scenary realism, if you somehow get hold of one of the PMDG series in MFSX I personally prefer the PMDG 737-800NG which is extremly realistic and up to details with the actual plane itself then go for MFSX. MFSX is much more cheaper and has more realism in terms of planes and the modding can be really fun with the large amounts of creators making new Free or Payware aircraft and scenary.

What I like about MFSX 
* It has Multiplayer
* Even has a flight missions that teach you to fly Planes and Helicopters
* The game comes with a variety of planes that start off from Single Engine Props to 2 Jet Engine Airliners
* If you cock up on an approach or you're too fast, you just press Y and you can relocate your aircraft and try again
* The PMDG 737-800NGX helps me with my training 
* You can even get the World Trade Center.


What I don't like about MFSX
* Graphics look like they've been imported from Google Maps Potato.exe (You can mod them)
* Airbus (jk) 
* Camera effects, when you go into a 20-30 degree bank your camera will move off center so it's annoying as fuck.
* Need payware mods to make the game better (Planes, TexturesFixers/Scenary Addons, Camera mods) 
*That's about it............

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Even though the game may have bad graphics, you can get plenty of mods out there cracked or purchased such as the DX10 scenary fixer and addon airports which enhanced the realism of your game. for £6.99 and be able to get free addons (usually not as good as payware), this isn't a bad sim for starters.

I got the original FSX, way before the Steam version, way before anything but the most powerful and expensive computers could run it (mine struggled at the lowest settings). I've spent hundreds on add-ons, spent thousands of hours in-game. To me though, FSX is dead. Killed by X-Plane 11, which is better. Killed by Prepar3d, which is better, Killed by the new Microsoft Flight Simulator (we'll see). Mostly though, it was killed by Dovetail Games which, with it's policies towards 3rd party publishers, effectively ended the life of this game several years before it needed to.

FSX IS still good and I have many fond memories. But if you're looking for a flight sim or are mearley looking at getting the Steam version of FSX, don't. Get one of the games above (or maybe even Aerofly FS2).

FSX released in end of 2006. Steam Edition (FSX-SE) released in 2014.
FSX-SE = Gold Edition + Deluxe Edition + Acceleration expansion pack and both official Service Packs in one + multiplayer support. All in one.

First release in 1982 Microsoft Flight Simulator, so it is 37 years old now in 2019. Falcon series start in 1984, for comparison.

Lockheed Martin hired members of the original ACES Studio team to continue development of the product - Lockheed Martin Prepar3D. Think about it like FSX Engine + patches and DirectX 11. After releasing Version 2 in 2013 and Version 3 in 2015, the team released 64-bit Version 4 in May 2017 ($50).

On the other side we have X-Plane series, available on Steam too.

In this video I have vanilla game, no mods with only two DLC: Skychaser and Albatros D.III
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1263921482
 

I bought it very cheap on Steam, in a double pack, game and Skychaser plane. It was somehow cheaper than a game alone.

TrackIR supported with no need to set it up. Nice thing. My HOTAS works fine too, but it took me a week to set it up in the way I want it. If you going to use some more complex aircraft models, you will probably end up spending more money for a additional soft to get this handle fast - google: FSUIPC4

There are many know bugs, you can find solutions for probably all of them. Here are some I encounter with solutions:

Blinking airfield, that you can see in video, I already fixed:
Free DX10 Shader Fixers V3.2.2 and V3.2.3 if you use ORBX sceneries.

http://www.lockonfiles.com/files/file/2612-fsx-dx10-shader-fixers-v322/
 

https://library.avsim.net/search.php?SearchTerm=DX10+shader&CatID=root

No Rewards fix: To get rewards, you have to create 'Rewards' folder in every DLC folder you own. Example: .../FSX/DLC/379553/Rewards



[b]Learning to fly[/b]
Have a look at Lessons by Rob Machado. Some of those lessons have very anoying buggs but till Instrument Checkride you should do fine. Google single lessons for bugs if you stuck.


[b]Upgrading and buying DLCS?[/b]

Rule no 1 - DO NOT BUY STEAM DLCs.

Save your money for really good things. First buy planes or just one but good. Two the best on a market right now for GA VFR and IFR flights IMO:

1) A2A - Cessna 182 (I recommend 182 over 172, is stronger, more long term usable model, good tourer). Expensive but 45% off from time to time. http://www.a2asimulations.com/
 
One good thing worth of buying for sure is Accu-Feel from A2A. It extend flight experience for all default models. Here is a good video: https://youtu.be/eAkDywoaeRQ
 
2) Flight1 - King Air B200 v2.



[b]Where FSX is strong?[/b]

Lots and lots of freebies:
https://flyawaysimulation.com/ - just put a name of a plane in a search box.

http://www.lockonfiles.com/files/ - best free models selection

Do you like boats and ships? Have a look here: http://deltasimstudio.com/
 


[b]Sceneries[/b]

Don't go crazy, have a look at free sceneries first.

Freeware sceneries library:
http://www.freewarescenery.com/fsx.html
 
FreeMeshX Global 2.0 - 50GB free global mesh
http://ninetwopro.com/freemeshx-2-0-release-announcement/

Free sceneries for USA 1m to pixel with 10m mesh
http://blueskyscenery.com/
 

You should have a look at ORBX products. You can buy just one particularly region, witch are in best accuracy. Discounts from time to time too. Have a look at demos and freebies first: ORBX Tasmania, ORBX Island.
https://orbxdirect.com/
 

Drzewiecki Design airports, cities, etc.
http://www.drzewiecki-design.net/
 

REX textures - Best you can have if you want FTX look photorealistic.
http://www.rexsimulations.com/
 


Good thing is, that ORBX and REX products can be bought ones and use with FSX and Prepar3D in the same time. Someday, when you switch to P3D or start using both sims at once, you have sceneries sorted.

Setup and Tweaks FSX - lots of guides there, check Steam Guides first.

Steam - FSX Guides - look for guide: How to get the Best Experience by [1BDE] L.Thompson

http://www.fstipsandaddons.com/ - FS Tips & Addons
 

http://c-aviation.net/ - good reviews

Add Freeware 3D Lights Tutorial
http://simviation.com/simviation/?ID=69&page=15&mark=7971

If you want more realism and a global flight network simulation experience google for VATSIM.

If you are in to war birds:
Try Carrier landing practice missions and addons. Free carrier and default A/F-18 can give you some serious good basic training before you switch to more advance models or sims.

Many good free models to fly too.

Weapons.
I found a mod Tactical Combat System & Development Kit for FSX/P3D (TacPack) But haven't try yet. Not much about weapon systems in fsx, you can study planes to a detail but weapons are some how ignored.

You can use pedals from your steering wheel as a rudder google for guides.

Conclusion:
+good value for the money
+flight lessons by Rob Machado (in English with audio)
+big community of people in any age
+lot of freebies
+highly modable
+lot of systems to learn and study
+some very masterpiece models, not available in other sims yet

-engine has his limits, if you push to much you get fps drop to 20-30 level or more, no mater how modern and powerful your pc is;
-Some good, old mods not support Win10&FSX-SE or take some work to make them working, so check before you switch to SE;

developer_response:
Hi Minecrafterman6 4and thank you for your review. 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is a re-release Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Gold Edition which in turn was first launched back in 2006. When compared to modern games like GTA V, The Witcher 3, Batman: Arkham Knight and so forth you are correct in your observation that the graphics are starting to show their age. However, there are hundreds of add-ons and freeware scenery packs available which can be used to customise the way FSX: SE looks. In fact, for many FSX players customising and modding their game is a key part of their experience with the sim. 

We highly recommend this video guide by YouTuber Jordan King which will walk you through how to install some of the best free scenery packs. Check it out. 

https://youtu.be/XUDrRR-VW-U

If you would like to find out more about what has been updated in the re-release please see this post in our forum: 

http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/discussions/7/530645961936099124/

We have also updated the game twice since it was first launched on Steam and we are working on a third update which is expected within the next few months. Full details of these updates can be found here in the announcement section of the FSX: SE Steam community Hub:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/announcements

FSX: SE also lets you use a variety of different controls including the classic keyboard and mouse, gamepad and an extensive range of third party controllers. From the settings menu you can further tailor your experience so that the game plays the way you want it to. You might like to explore these options if you are currently find the default control system a little tricky to get to grips with. 

Thank you for giving FSX: SE a try, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

I'm going to be honest here. This simulator is, or at least was supposed to be, the culmination of 10 iterations of Microsoft Flight Simulator. You'd expect nothing but the best for the time...

But unfortunately this software didn't age very well.
It's buggy, horribly optimized, crashes a lot. Flying, for real, is boring and very meticulous, and simmers who fly have a godly amount of patience.

Thus, having Flight Simulator X crash halfway through cruise, or on final, is absolutely nerve wrecking.
No wonder some people still stuck to Microsoft Flight Simulator 2004: A Century of Flight, or took the ticket for X-Plane 11, or even Prepar3D.

When Microsoft (seemingly out of no where!) announced the new Microsoft Flight Simulator for 2020, with game footage at 4K 60FPS and an astounishing level of detail, I just can't recommend anyone to buy or invest more money onto FSX. (For context, the original trailers for FSX were neither 60FPS, and some scenes are even below 30FPS)

It was nice while it lasted, but it's time to bid farewell to this Sim.

I do recommend this game for someone that is just starting flight sim. It was the 1st flight sim game I purchased back when it was available on disc.I logged many hrs. on that game after purchasing it from Steam, a lot of them without yoke & pedals.(in other words, you can get started with just a mouse.) Like any hobby, it can get a bit expensive if you start purchasing DLC, (downloadable content) or yoke & pedals to enhance the experience, but it offers the best variety of aircraft of any flight sim I've seen on Steam. The graphics are a bit basic without DLC enhancement, and of course the detail of the scenery relies on the overall quality of your pc, but as far as simplicity of learning the basics of flight is concerned, it's certainly the way to start. My biggest complaint is no VR availability or I'd still be flying FSX. All I can do is keep hoping they'll upgrade.

TLDR:
Great simulator, better with mods of which there are MANY

I've played this extensively before owning the Steam Edition and FSX is still my go to flight sim after about 13 years

Graphics: Extremely meh but just as easy to make it much better with both freeware and payware mods. 

Physics: Really good but not perfect. Also, can be better with add-ons.

Fun?: If you like planes and want to fly then yes. If not, it's not an arcade game and you'll probably get bored. Missions are moderately entertaining. You can fly to almost any airfield anywhere in the world out of the box and you have an okay selection of aircraft which can be expanded with both freeware and payware downloads. 



I had the Deluxe Edition DVD and Acceleration too and used this simulator extensively for years on previous computers but my DVD-key stopped working so I bought this on sale. Haven't noticed many changes. It's still not a very well optimized game, and Microsoft knew this from the beginning and advertised it as being built for future systems. Well it's over a decade later and it's still lacking in the performance department. For the most part though, this can still be helped by swapping out the cloud textures and making a few other tweaks. Sadly, some of the great tweaks that used to really help performance can't be found anymore (at least I can't) but the community for add-ons has always been hugely extensive. Before you go buying all the DLC here (not that you shouldn't as some of it seems nice if you have the cash), go poking around the internet for freeware because there's a lot of amazing stuff out there including aircraft of extremely great quality and photographic scenery. If you love modern military jets, Dino Cattaneo's blog should be your first stop for a few super detailed planes including F-14 and F-35. Other than that, a quick internet search will bring you huge libraries of planes, sceneries, and mods. All you really need is a basic understanding of file systems and a willingness to learn the one for this game for which most of the sites where you can find downloads will have a tutorial. I'm not sure why Steam/Dovetail didn't put up a Steam Workshop for FSX as it would be good to see some of the old creators bring their stuff here.

Two types of people play Flight Simulator X:

The Tryhards - They take the game very seriously and probably do things like VATSIM or are pilots doing their real life flights in game. They get furious when ATC doesn't know what they are doing, and have about 2,000 hours in game. These players make up 10% of the population.

The Steam Edition Experience - These players are those who slew mode around the globe at 1,000 knots, scream into their mics asking when to land, and calling into ATC that they are about to "September 11". These players make up 90% of the population, and are the kids that get this game on sale to mess around and kamikaze LAX.

I've been into Microsoft Flight Simulator since around the 1980's  and it just keeps getting BETTER and BETTER!!  Started out with Bruce Artwick's (Sub Logic) Flight Simulator, back in the day.   (around the 1980's)

The Steam Edition of this Classic, is simply FANTASTIC, and you can purchase 3rd party add-ons to enhance the basic Microsoft Flight Simulator X.    New and different aircraft (from Carendo,  Just Flight and A2A) for example, and Airport and  Weather enhancements also.  

The NEWEST enhancement I have added is Air Hauler 2.   (AH2) from Just Flight (I think) which you put in the Library TOOLS section of Steam.  You START AH2 from tools, (or the ICON it puts on your desktop... ) 

The manuals of both Flight Simulator X and AH2 are EXTREMELY helpful and user-friendly   

I also ESPECIALLY like the MISSIONS in Flight Simulator X and the Discovery Flight add-ons..  The Discovery add-ons are basically flight plans  (under the .PLN designation)  and are NOT in the Missions section,  you access them from "load flight plan" They CAN be modified and re-edited WITHOUT changing the ORIGINAL plan also, (in case you wish to fly direct GPS or VOR to VOR.  under VFR conditions instead of IFR....   This can make for some VERY interesting flights, by the way.

I have noticed that AH2 has had some bad reviews in the past,  but as for myself, I LOVE all the things you can do in the game. I would venture to say that the "bad reviews" stem from the user NOT knowing how to load and set up the company in AH2

As previously stated, it is found and started in (Library (tools) section on Steam.  Now as for setting up an AH2 company, I did a TUTORIAL on that on YouTube.  (last night in fact)....

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvNBuTnKVU4

Great game and all how ever i will list some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Great for serious role play
- All functions of the planes and ATC are usable meaning you can use the radar and switches and what not
- Public servers have a great community on there team speaks
- Great for real pilots who want to train
- Great graphics for a game developed in 2006
- Great models
- Has an option for mods/addons
- Cities have live cars and 3d models
- Shaders are great
- Has Private servers but you need to host it from your router by port forwarding which all routers cant do and will take time
- Most people are friendly
- Devs are active and are updating the game bi-monthly with new planes 
- Will even work on laptops with 2Gb and intel I2 processors with good frame rate and good graphics

Cons
- Most of the planes you have to purchase
- Voice communication is team speak when team speak is outdated and discord would be better to use
- Public servers are mostly role play and mic required or else its confusing

Old game... but i love it! I do recommend you to play with a joke or a flight stick, if you want to play it with keyboard dont buy it, it is impossible to play with it

Still great, and probably the most robust Sim on the market even today, you can find it on sale regularly but is still worth the base price if you are keen to start flying and I would recommend it over xplane 11 (i'll get to that later)

What I would recommend: NOTE these are all FREE!

DX10 Scenery fixer from Steve, pretty much essential if you want to run it with all settings maxed out because DX10 has obvious graphical glitches without it

HDE Sky Textures
FSX Ground Textures
HD Airport and Jetway Parking
Road V11
Texwater

All of these can be found here: https://flyawaysimulation.com/news/4949/#aitraffic
The DX10 fixer can be found from a simple Google search

the flyawaysimulation site has MANY other FREE additions for FSX that will keep you busy for days if you are into heavily modding your games/sims and your FSX will be all the better for it as it is essentially quite old software.

Now, the reason I recommend this over xplane 11 which I also have is because:

1. xplane scenery autogen is garbage, its terrible. No major city actually looks like it does in real life
2. Missing Airports. I had it on day 1 and ALL Airports in Australia were missing, nothing but runways. There are now many free airports but this is hardly a solution considering you can spend days (and I did) downloading freeware airports to populate the sim and they are not much better if at all better than what you get standard in FSX
3. Its a resource hog. If you don't have a great computer then good luck to you, 16gig of RAM will barely cut it, an i5 will barely cut it and anything under a 4GB graphics card WONT cut it. Xplane 11 is a highly demanding sim and if you cant run a sim smoothly this will greatly diminish you experience with it. I run FSX maxed out without a problem with the above specs
4. Payware. You want anything actually good in terms of addons for xplane 11? be prepared for a serious financial investment. Yes, there is freeware for xplane 11 but most of it aside from some scenery options are garbage and I should know, I scoured the internet for over a week trying to find the very best free everything for it and it was a total waste of time
5. Physics. Every plane no matter what the weight ratio is feels light as a feather and this was still after much configuration with control settings both in and outside of the sim
6. The skybox looks bad, always looks hazy and foggy. Clouds look terrible unless you are using payware to make them better and if you do prepare for a real kick to performance, you make anything look better in xplane 11 it will cost you serious frames to do so
7. Weather change pop in's/outs. Weather can change in an instant in xplane 11 and its very jarring and immersion breaking when it does happen, its an issue that has been with the sim since day 1 and is still present to this day

Sure, xplane 11 can look good if you have the hardware to back it up and night flying can look quite amazing but its hardly a substitute for everything else I have mentioned against it. Its very clear what direction they are taking with it and I'm not going to support a sim that has the business model they do, its an absolute cash-cow of a sim, people thought FSX was bad with the amount of DLC it has but when you put it against xplane 11 you find that its quite reasonable if you even want to spend more money. I don't, I'm a big freeware hunter and the freeware quality in FSX is much better, what you get as standard even without freeware is much better. You actually get the whole world in a box, landmarks, airports and all and larger selection of default aircraft to learn and play with without even having to get more for free, and not even to mention the amazing payware aircraft that are available.

Long live FSX, happy flying.

We live in an age where simulation can and will [i]improve your abilities and proficiency[/i] at work or wherever. [b]THIS[/b] is a great example of it. Flight Simulator X has been used in training future pilots using "[b]study-level aircraft[/b]". Planes such as the [i]PMDG 737, 747 and 777, Aerosoft A320 Family[/i] and even [i]VFR aircraft[/i] are used extensively to test pilots of their abilities to fly, to react, to solve problems and so on. This is what is great about this game, although the product has been discontinued by the developers themselves, the community still stands on and hold the structure of this game together for several years. The scenery, the airports, the random things. With add-ons, this game's once massive [b][i]potential becomes reality![/i][/b]

This game is also very good if you have a tight budget but want to fly, modern flight simulators like [i]P3D[/i] and [i]X-Plane[/i] are more intensive and look more realistic as opposed to this game. But they all work the same, don't they? Sure, the aforementioned games are more detailed than this but [i][b]everyone starts somewhere![/b][/i]

Believe me when I say it, but [i]when you start with this game, the possibilities are endless, and soon enough you will question yourself why you haven't played this game a long time ago[/i]

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] This review doesn't apply to everybody, those interested in aviation and wish to start may relate to what I've said but those who wish to play with the intent to maybe have fun, or try something new, I will not guarantee that this review will be what you actually feel. Also, this game is already great without add-ons, all I'm saying is that with add-ons, you can make your game much, [b]much[/b] better. [i]Read with caution.[/i]

Despite being released in 2006, Microsoft Flight Simulator X is still a good, easy starting point for those who just want to dip their toes into the waters of the simulated aviation world. The base content that the product has with regards to learning how to fly aircraft take the user to a novice level at best - there is an abundance of better, in-depth guides that can be found online, made by the FSX community. The base graphics are good, with manual optimization required by the user to fit best onto the specific system that is being used. The advantage of the game being dated as it is, is that there is plenty of additional content in the form of both freeware and payware that is available. The sim itself isn't too complex to get a hang of, and installation of additional content is a breeze. To make the most of it, one should invest in some graphical packs similar to the likes of OrbX scenery and PMDG aircraft (both of which are payware). The disadvantage of this product is the lack of developer support. Yes, there is DLC available on the store - but a lot of it seems rushed and in poor condition. All in all - I highly recommend this game, at its base level, to anyone who's just getting started in flight simulation. I however would not recommend this to someone who already has Lockheed Martin's Prepar3D or X-Plane 11, both of which I would consider to be a more hardcore experience at their respective base content packages. I would consider FSX to be the casual approach to flight simulation in comparison, but - again- would highly recommend it to the toe-dipper of the flight sim world.

This game is incredible. From a newbie pilot to a seasoned air force veteran, anyone can take to the skies in FSX. There are a few things I deem necessary, however, before you spend $25 on this game.

Necessities:
 - Any Joystick. This could be a simple as an Xbox/Playstation controller that is compatible to PC. Without a Joystick this game is incredibly challenging, but can be overcome with hours of practice.

Recommendations:
 - A real flight stick, throttle, pedals, etc. I recommend Thrustmaster, since each of their products is designed to work independently, without requiring other parts. (If you buy a T16000 stick, it has a throttle slider on it.) Each button on Thrustmaster pieces and two or more separate equipment work together without needing T.A.R.G.E.T. software on FSX.

Final notes:
 - FSX is an incredibly in-depth simulator, with buttons galore and stuff I surely didn't understand. It has taught me many things about aviation.
 - FSX includes plenty of stock aircraft for you to enjoy, and the DLC is completely optional and you can still have fun with the game without purchasing any of these aircraft.

If you are interested in aviation, and have the necessities, the $25 is completely worth it.

This is such an excellent game, 100% my favorite game of all time. I have thousands of hours in this from the original version, the 146 hours listed is just from after I got it on steam. It's kind of badly optimized so even though I have a top-of-the-line computer from 3 years ago it runs at 20-30 FPS at max settings. However, on all low settings it will happily shoot up to 200+ FPS. I currently have an i7-6700 and a GTX 1080. I'm sure I'll conquer the hardware issues eventually, but they are in no way harsh enough to make the game unplayable. While it doesn't scale well at high settings, its a 2006 game so any modern computer will happily run it on low settings. And don't worry about all the DLC on steam: there's a ton of free stuff to download from the internet, just look for sites that mention "FSX Freeware" and you'll be overwhelmed by choice.

As far as simulators go I think this game is THE definitive must-have program, and while the physics aren't 100% spot on it's certainly good enough to teach you all the flying tips anyone could need. Just remember to buy a joystick, the mouse and keyboard controls are unusable. It works with xbox controllers as well, though that won't allow much finesse. 

By the way, does anyone know if this game runs well on threadripper or 9900k? It would be nice to know what CPU is best optimized for it.

Taking a look at flight simulator history i have to say software have come long way going through massive upgrades. This version is basically what was offered back in 2006. It was a nice upgrade from 2004 but take that 13 years later to 2019 and it will feel out of the league compared to what prepar3d and Xplane offer today. However there are two main reasons FSX still proves as a versatile option to simmers. 

1- Performance: Flight simulation is very demanding and if a couple thousand PC is definitely needed for even small setups, with that being said FSX can run better on entry hardware being offered today.
2- Addons : The availability of quality scenery and weather upgrades plus the wide selection of professional aircrafts makes this title super worthy. Overtime it has  accrued the most paid and freeware addons. 

If your PC is not a banger you might wanna give this title a shot after all this is the one that started this genre in the first place. Also check for videos online on realism addons and quality achievements.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X is still one of the best civil flight simulation products available today.  This was originally released in 2006 in DVD format, at a time when the Intel Core 2 processors were just making headlines, and the fastest available graphics were NVidia's GeForce 8 series and ATI's Radeon HD2000 series.  The greatest thing about the Microsoft Flight Simulator series is the ability to extend or enhance them with either freeware or payware aircraft/scenery (these terms are now called "DLC").

What you get in the base installation is a ton of great "default" aircraft, plausible scenery of the entire planet, and a really nice air traffic control system.  For those who say that FSX is a "money making potato," this is nonsense.  For those who say that it offers "no flight training," you will find flight lessons in the "Learning Center" in the main menu.  This has never changed.  

DLC addon products for the Microsoft Flight Simulator series is nothing new, dating back clear to Flight Simulator 6.0 for Windows 95 in 1996.  You can still manually install free DLC (i.e., by dropping aircraft files in to the 'SimObjects\Airplanes' folder, etc.) which you can obtain from several fan-based websites.  As for the paid DLC, the developers (i.e., Carenado, PMDG, FlightOne, Eaglesoft and many others) put a tremendous amount of time and effort into their products in order to create truly authentic aircraft, scenery, etc.  I actually used the FlightOne Cessna 152 to practice flying a real C152, because its simulated handling characteristics were right on the money.

Also, you are not limited to DLC/addons here on Steam.  A simple Google search for "FSX Addons" will reveal hundreds, perhaps thousands of free add-ons and add-on development tools.  The good news is that more and more developers are releasing their addons via Steam to make it a bit easier to install them and re-install them.  Remember that DLC is optional.  Many paid/commercial DLC products are geared towards authenticity.  For example, a company called PMDG offers a Boeing 747 with a fully functional virtual cockpit, complete with a simulated, authentic inertial reference system, flight management computers, control display units (complete with their own software!)  electrical systems, hydraulic systems, etc).  For new virtual pilots, the default aircraft and scenery are still quite good.

Do keep in mind that this product is 13 years old, at the time of this writing.  The civil flight sim world has largely moved to P3D (Prepar3D) and X-Plane.  But there is still a ton of life left in this one, and the fact that it is available on Steam makes it incredibly convenient (instead of installing from discs, activating with Microsoft, etc).  Being able to use external DLC (as we did with the disc-based versions of FSX) is fantastic.

100% recommended.  Especially for the price.

Hi Folks,

I have been playing FSX since it first came out and have never stopped since!!!
 
I love it to bits. Steam edition is not just OK, but getting better all the time. Especially as more and more of our favourite add-ons are appearing at a fast and steady rate as DLCs via the library or are already there. In some cases no work needs to be done, like “FS Passengers”, while it is not in the DLC list yet, it seamlessly works well with FSX SE and there are many other examples of this too. 

As all serious FSX players will know from experience, there are thousands of add-ons for FSX, literally. Name an aircraft or particular airport, and you can find it somewhere on the net, so add-ons or now DLCs are so important for a more realistic FSX experience. 

Every FSX player cries out for a more realistic game, and none of us will be totally satisfied until we ALL have our garages turned into a particular FSX aircraft, with multi-monitors, aircraft seats, real buttons etc. If you don’t believe me go to YouTube, most FSX users take the game (simulator) very seriously and have many hundreds of hours logged even before porting across to Steam! 

Add to this the fact that Dovetail and Steam are clearly not giving up on FSX as Microsoft did, oh so many years ago now and I would happily recommend any FSX user to transfer without worry about the huge collection of add-ons that you have accumulated over the years. In the majority of cases, you can get a Steam edition from the designers to replace your existing one, or find the appropriate DLC from the original designer or Dovetail, or in a lot of cases, it will just seamlessly port over and work!

When I first moved over to FSX SE, I was worried about the lack of DLCs and the fact that our beloved add-ons from MS FSX didn’t work. That position has totally reversed now, and in most cases, you won’t lose out.

In my opinion, even the base FSX SE is far superior to MS FSX without any add-ons or DLCs! That’s a good start without adding anything. Dovetail have taken their time, but for obvious reasons, I am guessing it wasn’t an easy port across to Steam for them, especially since MS had imposed many restrictions on them to start with. But I have nothing but praise for Dovetail and Steam. 
They have done a damn good job.

However, there was another plus to moving over to the Steam Platform that I wasn’t expecting.

Steam is full of all sorts of games, from card games to building your rocket and sending Kerbals into outer space!
So while playing FSX, I just had to try out a few other games. Now I think I own at least 10 games and certainly play at least 4 of them very regularly !!! So just moving over to the Steam Platform has been greatly beneficial to my semi-retirement!   

Anyway, this was supposed to be a review of FSX-SE! Job done I hope. 
Any questions, please don’t hesitate to contact me. 

Good luck to you all, whatever games you like, take care of yourselves and your loved ones.
Best wishes,
Trevor

This game turns 13 this year and is definitely showing its age from a visual standpoint, but as a simulator that can run on almost anything at this point, it's well worth getting. The enormous library of freeware and payware addons for this game that's been built up over 13 years is astounding.

The game also has a very active multiplayer community, which isn't always hyper-serious either.

Plus the in-game tutorials are phenomenal.

In an era where sims like X-Plane 11 and Prepar3d exist, FSX may seem incredibly dated, but I still think it holds up remarkably well, especially if it's your gateway into flight simming.

Some of the reviews for this game are hilarious. You have to bear in mind that this game came out in 2006, at the time of launch this was cutting edge. In terms of vanilla performance, this is more suited towards the casual flyer, as all the default aircraft are simplified enough to make it relaxing to fly.
If you're looking for realism then use X-Plane 11, but for just casual, Sunday flying then FSX is the one you want to choose. The scenery may be awful, (just look on UK2000, they have a lot of older payware that's now free) the default aircraft may be over simplified but for someone whose just coming into the world of sim flying you can't go wrong. Especially considering this game regularly goes on sale for almost 75% off. 
Plus, where else can you go online and find a 747 buzzing the tower at 400 knots with a 13 year old at the controls?

This review is made many, many years after release, so I will clarify a few things: I will be considering the physical features of the base map to be accurate as for the time it was made, and the graphics were very good at the time. Today, both of these claims are false for the most part, though I will say that graphically this simulator is not completely unbearable.

This game has very realistic physics, has accurate crash detection and only small details that should be worked on within the base game. The base game has a decent selection of aircraft with different liveries and more importantly has set up several missions ranging from tutorials to expert-level missions, and the missions often include something special that makes it more entertaining. All of this and more makes this game by 2006 standards one of the best out there.

Modding has only made this game better. While freeware can sometimes includes bugs (they don't get paid so don't expect them to do a bunch of debugging), most paid and indeed some free mods can spice up the simulator experience. Although this is a very old game, the modded flying community has made an insane amount of cool stuff. Not only airplanes, but different types of aircraft, different textures ranging from small airports to entire countries, and different GUI-related mods that can make the simulator's age seem obsolete. Once you are deep into the modding, the base game will seem almost invisible (it's still there, it's just that many mods will override numerous different aspects of the game that you experience.)

Will FSX live forever? X-Plane is not as massive. It only covers a small portion of the world and has limited aircraft although it can also be modded and it is graphically quite nice. I doubt X-Plane will have a large impact on FSX.

P3D is looking like a better replacement. It not only looks much nicer graphically but it is more up to date and has some very nice animations and sounds that are much clearer and simply much more appropriate in the later stages of this decade.

Regardless, I think all FSX Steam pilots can agree that FSX has reigned supreme in flight simulation for many years since its release, an unbelievable accomplishment.

I suggest playing with a joystick, or a yoke system, or with a Xbox controller for easier controlling(Recommend for beginners). But overall this game is amazing, every details is precise. I would recommend buying the HD texture if you have money and good pc.

I originally bought this game after watching the YouTube channel "Airforceproud95" (go check him out, he's pretty funny) having no experience with flight Sims, and thought this game was pretty fun. this game is pretty good if you into flight simulators. it's fairly realistic depending on your experience with flight Sims and has adjustable difficulty depending on the same as well. the controls are pretty fluent if you have a controller and I can only assume they are good if you have a joystick, however, do not use a keyboard with this game, I tried that at first and had zero stable control of the plane, at the end of the day, if you came across this game because of the aforementioned YouTube Channel, and have no experience or general interest in flight Sims, don't bother buying this game.

I picked up FSX when it came out back in 2006 and used it for probably 200-300 hours.  Got the Steam version on sale a few years back and didn't really try it.

Would love to recommend this version but I cannot for a few reasons.   I installed it today, tried it again, and promply uninstalled it.

I recall FSX had a great IFR panel and I wanted to use it to practice instrument procedures.  However it seems that everything you use for IFR is 13 years out of date. 

- the install puts a bunch of really really old MS 2005 runtime executables on my system; uninstalling the game requires going into the settings and hunting down and removing each one of these obsolete packages

- with Win 10 Pro on a fairly new/clean install I had lots of instances where the screen went blank for minutes.  Hitting escape and waiting a bit eventually brought it back in all but the last instance, where I had to go into task manager and kill the game

- perhaps more importantly, the aiport information, navaids, waypoints and anything avionics related has NOT BEEN UPDATED since the game was released in 2006.  If your airport has changed runway headings due to magnetic drift, or if you are looking for current navaids, approaches, departures that are modern and up-to-date, you will be disappointed.

I was interested in Flight Simulator because a friend of mine is a pilot. I wanted a realistic simulation and thought that Microsoft had the talent to provide that. Do NOT buy! This is a very bad simulator. It is almost impossible to control the planes, and the graphics, of course, are very dated. I went through Tutorial 1 and 2, barely surviving #1 after 3 tries. I never made is through #2. Using the keyboard and/or mouse will frustrate anyone. I can't  give an opinion about any special controller experience. If you want a smooth experience, buy the reboot of Descent: Freespace, or Overload. This simulator is horrible and a waste of money and time. I will pursue a refund. Note that I have a high-end Alienware desktop which will handle anything on Steam, so hardware is certainly not the problem.  I have extensive experience in many games, but will try to forget this one as quickly as possible.

Having just passed my first solo flight on FSX, I just wanted to post my early review for all those contemplating purchasing it. I bought this on discount at £8 having a keen interest in all things flight related. I fly models in the real world and so thought being in the cockpit in a virtual world would probably be as close as I get to the real thing! This has been my first experience of a flight sim so cannot compare against anything else. I have a Thrustmaster Hotas X which is £50 worth of hardware that is probably bare minimum for simulation but it works well. I started from scratch with 'Rod' the in game flight instructor who so far has played a great job of being my 'wing man' tutor. I wanted to know everything from the start and the basics, to get full experience. The lessons are simple to understand and explained well. I dont really care for top notch graphics and the framerate isn't too bad to give you that 'flying' feeling as you nose out the cockpit windows. I have a decent gaming pc to keep things rolling ok. I'm more interested in learning the basics of flight, the 'basic six' instruments in the cockpit to allow me to eventually plot a course out into the sunset somewhere. I have passed my first solo (whereby my wife was dabbing the sweat from my forehead as I flew due to the nerves and high level of concentration going on!) If that's not a result of a good simulator I don't know what is. I play War Thunder also and allthough dogfighting is cool in a P51 and simulated flight is good, nothing comes close to the scrutiny of a real (virtual) flight instructor sitting next to you teaching you the real thing!. I'm still a noob on FSX but have made good progress so far and hoping to carry on my flight schooling with it. You can take it as serious as you want to I suppose. It's good for the money (especially at the discounted price)and would recommend it to anyone like myself who has a genuine interest in knowing how to a fly a plane from scratch. It's a thumbs up from me!

An excellent and accessable flight simulator for anyone who wants to fly without having the risks or costs of actually flying. While it is less realistic and has lower graphical quality than newer sims, the amount of third-party support for MSFSX is simply amazing. The multiplayer works quite well and I have few complaints against it. The missions are both compelling and fun, and free-flight offers the freedom to go almost anywhere on earth in almost any plane you want. 

Speaking of planes, there is a fine selection in the base simulator and an unreal amount of third-party add-ons in both Payware and Freeware. If you want to fly something other than the base aircraft, there is no shortage of add-ons waiting to be installed from trikes to the An-225, from the slowest helicoptors to the fastest experimental aircraft. 

For a 12 year old flight simulator, MSFSX does not seem to want to age, and Dovetail releasing it on Steam only made it that much more accessable to the world.
It's a very good simulator for 2006 when it was released. But I wish they could continue to develop it and add Linux compatibility to it.

FSX Is an old flight simulator. As it goes, there are many other options for a simulator. Many people choose XPlane 11. Many choose Prepar3D. But even then, FSX is still a prevailling flight simulator in many areas. FSX is old. For this reason, don't expect the newest models or scenery, but i would say, do expect a fun time. With the addition of a few freeware aircraft and maybe some scenery, you can have a right fun time just flying around. But out of all of these, the crown jewel of FSX is the multiplayer. There's something about the ability to connect to a teamspeak or discord server and screw around with random people(Especially when someone joins the session as "Air Force One"). Even though you might not have the best aircraft or flight dynamics, FSX is still popular because it proves that you don't need to have lots of money or aircraft to play a fun sim.

FSX is the greatest PC game of all time, hands down.  It's kept alive and fresh from the 1000s of addons available, probably the most of any game in history.

Out of ALL of them you only need one, Megascenery Earth.  Any or all...actually I got it all.  Freemesh is second (and free!)

Contrary to misguided belief, FSX  DOES use and benefit from 4 or more cores as long as you apply the affinity mask tweak in the config file (google it).  Running 8 cores or higher is Nivana (for the above addon).  You DON'T need to put all your scenery on a big SSD.  Waste of money!

Here's one more tip: copy the Tail view section from the aircraft.cfg file for the P51 Mustang into any or all of your other aircraft...You'll see what I mean.

Ah yes. The starting place of probably most every person who plays flight sims. FSX: Steam Edition. Let's take it from the top, shall we? 

My first thoughts of FSX were, "Wow, this is great, I finally have a flight sim worth playing." Then I dove head-first into the aircraft. You can pretty well guess what plane I started with. Yes, it's the good old Cessna 172SP Skyhawk. I started learning every nook and cranny of that instrument panel, and with having a good deal of experience with it from X-Plane 10 mobile edition, I already knew of several of the key items such as flaps, magnetos, switches, gauges, and whatnot. 

I then moved on from the Skyhawk onto more advanced aircraft, such as the Baron 58, Mooney Bravo... then moved up to the Bombardier Learjet 45, and from there onto commercial aircraft. Started off with a Boeing 737, but when I sat in the cockpit of an Airbus A321, I fell in love instantly. I instantly knew that I'd be flying this aircraft for a long while. 

Unfortunately, by now I was starting to see that... FSX was missing stuff. The default ATC is...  okay at best. Still haven't gotten around to fixing that. And I saw that the A321 I came to know and love... was missing a lot of stuff. So when I saw the Aerosoft A321, and all of its features... I fell in love again. You bet I snatched that up ASAP. So.. do I recommend FSX? You're damn right I do! 

Though... to be fair.. I recommend X-Plane 11 more. It's more up to date, plus it runs better. You have to keep in mind, FSX was made in 2006. 12 years ago. It's old, and slow. Hell, it's made for 32-BIT SYSTEMS! But.. it's good. You can't deny that.

This game is ridiculously fun. I've sank so many hours into this game simply flying and learning. You gotta remember, these graphics are from over 10 years ago, so for the time this was amazing. If you are a casual flyer and don't care about the specifics of flying or if you are a seasoned pilot, this is your game.

Don't buy DLCs or downloads. You can easily find them on other websites for free.

Realistic and fun too, with Addons like UTX, FTX Global, FTX Trees HD, and especially Accu-Feel, it makes the game more realistic. Its smoother on DX 10 But buggy. Thats what DX 10 Fixer is for. I would buy this game if your interesting in a flying sim, but not for 100% realism without addons. For addons you will spend lots of money to make this realistic. The addons are worth it for realism. This game also has tons of scenery addons for better scenery, but the prices are also high for those too with tons of storage usage. For me i have about 20 GB worth of better scenery content. Check other reviews for scenery addons to see if they are worth it before you cash out.

So if you want this game for just flying, get it on sale. If you want this game for flying and realism, then get your money ready for addons to buy. But for the default version, this game gets a 7/10. If you have a fast PC, get X-Plane 11.

Individual airport models cost most than half the price of the full game.

Some individual planes cost more than the base game itself!

At time of writing, to buy the full experience (base game + all the DLC) it's currently sat at £3,716.15

£3,716.15 !!

I can't give this a thumbs up. 

The sim is solid, don't get me wrong. Sure the graphics aren't the best, looking very dated now. 

There's a good amount in the base game for the money. 

I just can't give this a thumbs up because, who the hell sells a full experience for £3,716.15!

I started my experience with MSFS-2002. I first played it when i was 9. I made fun of myself as i failed even to take off a C170. I was amazed to see my home airport(Chennai Intl', India(VOMM / MAA). Then I got FS2004 as a gift. I was amazed to see 3D clouds and great terrain. After taking a long break from Flight Simulation, I've decided to purchase FSX and play it on my new PC. The first thing I noticed was DX10. While it doesn't change the visuals to an observable extent, the overall smoothness can be observed. Also, DX10 is buggy on some mods, so be careful. The next thing i saw was FPS. It's clear that the game's engine is getting old. Even with an i5-7400+1050Ti+8GB RAM, I need to turn down some settings like Autogen to increase my FPS to a playable rate. It gets even worse in custom airports like the ones I've downloaded from IVAO

FPS ANALYSIS
Setting- Everything maxed except Autogen, which is set on Dense.Everything measured with Aerosoft A320(Indigo VT-IDE), REX4 TD+Soft Clouds, ASN set to Live RW

FPS at VOMM(By IVAO)- 17 at the terminal, 20 while taxiing, 20-22 at the runway(TO) and about 29 while above the city and the airport. But, while coming in for an approach, things get a bit worse like 10, due to loading problems as it is still 32-Bit

FPS above 6000 MSL: 40 to 90. 

FPS when it's overcast plus rain: 14-20 no matter where you are

FPS at a stock airport(VOCI) 30-50 FPS depending on the weather.

While the FPS is quite low for a modern spec PC, the game is smooth. I dont know how or why, but it wouldn't feel like 16 FPS, unless I press Shift+Z.. The game doesnt feel stuttery and jittery and choppy when the FPS is low. I get the same experience everywhere and everytime. I don't how this is possible, but im happy and want it to stay the same way.

The graphics, textures are about normal for a Flight Simulation. I'm saying this for stock, which are basically FS2004 textures with some improvement. There no special touches that make the game look more special, except for airports, cities, etc. The terrain looks a bit OK when viewing from high altitudes. The Real World Weather featured in game doesn't work at all. Even if it does, it is a galaxy away from the latest METAR. The stock airliners(Airliners only, as I flew them and that too, only once for each aircraft) are basic. In-Game ATC supports only VFR and that is a big letdown.

The game gets better with DLCs

For the graphics, I bought REX4 Texture Direct and Soft Clouds. REX does a really great job in improving the overall visual feel greatly. The textures now have a life to them. The colors and contrasts are improved along with lots of sky lighting, ground texture improvements, airport textures,etc. Soft clouds brings the most expected reallistic cloud exprerience, both from the ground and in the sky. I also use the ENB shaders provided by REX themselves. ENB does a great job for overall lighting, but still, the ground shadows are a bit buggy due to DX10. But, does it matter when we are in the air? No. Now, for the weather issues, I started with FSRealWeather. That gave me a beginner experience in real world weather. I bought REX4 TD, REX Soft Clouds and ASN during Summer Sale 2018. While FSRW did a good job in imitating METARs, Active Sky Next gives life to METARs, Now, there are no sudden changes in weather. There is smooth transition between conditions. All these improvements did not reduce even a single frame per second. For the ATC, I purchased PROATC-X(It's not on Steam). It makes ATC reallistic and improves my FSX Xperience

If you want a completely reallistic experience, please be ready to pay more.

For Airlines, you must consider buying DLC aircraft, as the stock ones are basic and would get you bored over time. Pick anything you want during sales. As for me, I've bought the Aerosoft A320 because I like the aircraft and I only do Short-Medium haul flights. But, you can pick anyting you want as per your likes and distances.

PROS:-
 Mostly reallistic experience(With DLCs) 
Great aircraft DLCs
Stock GA aircrafts are great too
Covers the whole world and almost all airports
Multiplayer(I'm still yet to go in)
There's also great free airliners
Good stock airports(Some exceptions in mostly third world countries)
Completely reallistic navigation and procedures, except the VFR only ATC
Free Aircraft (eg: Project Airbus) are also nice
CONS
In Game ATC is VFR only. So, I use PROATC-X
Stock Airliners are pretty basic, so you must consider DLCs
Night flying is ugly if you don't use ORBX or Night Environment X
Lighting issues
32bit and the same old engine
Optimisation issues. Micro Stuttering is still an issue which is a trend from FS2002.
DLCs are a must and they are expensive( They are a NEED and they must be paid above the game cost)
Lots of bugs. Tweaking of FSX.cfg is a must for every FSX player
You need an i7 or i9 to run constant 50 FPS+

Overall, considering that you are ready to buy some DLCs, this game is highly recommended for every flight enthusiast out there. Make sure to also buy a Flightstick or a yoke to further enchance your FSXperience.

Thank you.

Do you want to be a pilot? Most probably you can't afford it (not just in terms of money (for education, instructor and rental fees, etc. just so that you get a license in the USA; more on this here: https://youtu.be/cognzTud3Wg ), but in terms of being denied of a standard 9:00 to 18:00 work schedule and all the social life/family/marriage disturbances that would inevitably follow (the odds of becoming a pilot decrease even more if you're a female). So, don't be upset, get yourself this great piece of software, learn the basic concepts of flying (the tutorials are very helpful, there's also a massive learning center, so prepare for a lot of reading; also, if you have experience in my favourite game "Kerbal Space Program", then you'll find flying a metal box a lot more comprehensible) and enjoy the moment when you're able to take-off, fly, and land manually all by yourself!

Even if you decide to buy all the 263 DLCs (the total cost of which is currently 4699,25€) you'll still be getting the cheaper deal (as opposed to becoming an actual pilot).

If you prefer a simpler flight simulator game, then you might very well enjoy "Simple Planes". I do own it (DRM-free on GOG.com) and I highly recommend it. It comes with the joy of designing your won flyable machine (also, if you don't have the time to do it, there's a lot of community created content — www.simpleplanes.com/Airplanes ).

Note: I haven't tried the competitive simulator "Digital Combat Simulator World" (a.k.a. "DCS World"), because of its enormous system requirements (the MSFSX runs fine on my integrated Intel HD 4000 GPU). I haven't tried (nor do I own) the "X-Plane 10"/"X-Plane 11" either, due to the same reason (I would probably not have problems running XP10). I also haven't tried the professional simulator "Lockheed Martin's Prepar3D", because it costs $200. :)

This classic flight sim can be played both professionally and casually, modded extremely, and enjoyed the heck out of. Learning to fly is very simple, and the game has many tutorials and missions to help you get off the ground in no time. The FPS is not too bad, but its a flight sim, so don't expect 4k 60fps. You can pick from any weather type, any time of day, a multitude of planes, and any airport/airstrip in the world. Also, the world is actual size, so flying even from one US state to another could take a few real life hours. You can explore the skies of the entire world, and it's quite calming when you're flying through the clouds on a rainy day with autopilot on. Not only that, but if you like to play professionally or RP being a real pilot, the game has a multiplayer. There are both casual and serious servers to play on, and you can even play as ATC, directing air traffic from the tower. If you're a fan of simulation, definitely try this out.

I haven't used the multiplayer enough to comment, because I've found single player to be entirely satisfactory to my needs.

Overall, if you're looking for a cheaper flight sim, this is a must-have! And quite simply, the more money you put in, the more you'll get out.

Love multiplayer

Bear in mind this game came out in 2006:

For its time, and even today, these are some of the most realistic graphics you'd expect on any decent flight sim. The physics are on  par with what I'd expect out of a real airplane. The controls are very customizable and response times appropriately differ between each aircraft. Someone coming from a game like GTA V jumping into this would be in for a rude awakening; planes are not that brain-dead easy to fly. But! The learning curve is managable. If I can do it, so can you. A few hours of practice and I've got the hang of a handful of commercial aircraft, my favorite being the Boeing 737 because I like the cockpit layout.

There's a lot of texture upgrades you can install with the Rex4 texture software where you can create your own theme of detailed runway patterns, clouds, water, sky, lighting, etc from both the presets and community creations with click-and-done installation. It's that simple.

Granted, this game is not the most optimized creation; I've an i5-7500 and a GTX 1070 and I've had to tone some settings down to medium to get an interrupted 60 fps frame rate going. I'm guessing the CPU will be the real bottleneck when trying to run this game because as you can imagine, there are a TON of physics calculations being done, especially as you populate the game with more AI aircraft.

All in all, it's wel worth the price, and the DLC offers plenty of gorgeous aircraft packs to choose from. I'm trying to learn the A320/321 series seeing as how many of my international flights seem to favor this jet.

This is a re-edit of my original recommendation, which was not very objective because of technical problems I was experiencing at the time. I let frustration and emotion cloud the reason for this post.
To reiterate the positives, I have enjoyed Microsoft FS since my first copy of FS2004 (A century of flight). Last Christmas I switched to FSX:SE and had no problems until September when only the front splash (title) screen came up and the game did not go beyond that point. This when three days of frustration set in. Eventually FSX user Rogen stepped in with corrective action and the issue was resolved.
As a long time user I love the game and, as Rogen wrote, "Given the sim came out in 2006 there is large wealth of knowledge on the internet, and Steam is just a small part of all that is FSX. That said there are plenty of self help threads in the Steam forums, you just gotta search..." which I didn't make a very good effort of doing.
So, for longevity, user support by users, and, yes, reliability, I objectively recommend FSX

This plays just fine on a Surfce 3!  With graphics bumped up to medium levels, it's surprisingly smooth & playable. I did have some initial troubles launching the game (it didn't see the Steam Client but insisted it had to be running).  Changing FSX.ext to "Compatibilty Mode" fixed it completely.  FSX supports a second monitor using the dock, which is really useful for the  radio nav stack.  The flying lessons are pretty cool.  Having a Joystick and Throttle and rudder pedals really  adds to the realism and  helps A LOT with control, but I wish they made them for people with arthritis.  
  With 3rd party add-ons,  FSX connects to the VATSIM network, whcih is a fully functioning  global virtual airspace, which adds a whole other aspect to the game..  There's people that are Air traffic controllers to virtual flights that mimic real routes.  
  FSX seems to be everytihng from Get-your-feet-wet trainer to Build-a-fully-functioning-Airbus-380-cockpit.   Highly recommended if you have any intrest in flying.

Overall, FSX is a bit of a conundrum. It brings lots of positive features to the table and makes sure that you’ll be able to start becoming a better and more enjoyable pilot. It’s a big improvement over the original edition of the game and makes it much easier to get to grips with, and therefore actually enjoy.

However, does it actually change enough to warrant a full-price purchase if you already own FSX and its assorted mods? This is where perspective needs to come in, and you need to decide whether or not having better performance and online features is worth the cost.

There's something that the 2,000 plus negative reviews don't understand about FSXSE.
It's a simulator, not a game for the most part.

Let me explain this in parts.

I think this program is great. Putting about 140 hours into at the time of this review, I can say that this is definitely worth the $26 bucks.
the reason it's good is:
1. It's a great learning tool
2. It's realistic but customizable.

If you're learning to fly as I am, you will find that this makes a great learning tool to practice meneuvers that your instructor taught you or that you read up on. I've personally found the realism settings to be perfect, because you can choose them to be easy and basic to hell on earth.

That's it. It's a good tool.

But there seems to be other's who have bought this program as a game, find out that it's hard, get confused, give up, then whine on the reviews after under an hour. This isn't all however, as some negative reviewers are veterans to the flight sim community and likely have much more experience than I.

So, TL;DR,
If you're looking for a flying game, look at IL-Sturmovik. This is more like a tool than a game. Yes there's multiplayer, yes people like AirForceProud95 (or daremorsealive79, or fairscrotumguys69, or however you say his name lol) make it look like a simple game, but it's likely you won't find yourself enjoying the game like he does immediately. 
to enjoy a game like this takes time, something most of the negative reviewers I guess didn't have judging by their 0.2-0.6 hour gameplay time.
