Post Scriptum: Joystick is an absolute neccesity in this game.

I thought flying was interesting. Yeah it definitely was until I started playing this game.

Don't get me wrong, this review is wholely subjective and though, there's nothing technically wrong with this game, I personally got some preferences to be met that this game doesn't.

So let's talk about Microsoft's biggest pain in the foot that was a splinter in my eye ever since they released games.

SETTINGS

It's terrible. HORRIBLE. I want to play in Fullscreen but as soon as I do that, my second screen becomes black. I've read you shall play this game in windowed mode which in terms of immersion is something I don't really like at all. You see I wanna be immersed by a game and though, if the game is really good and enjoyable for me playing it in windowed mode is not THAT kind of a big deal but to understand why I dislike this thing you have to know the rest of this review. So hold your buttocks lads, I'm writing a bit more here.

I've been lovehating Simulator games for quite the while now. I love them cos they are fun, I hate them cos they're so blunt. Does this make sense at the first look? Nah. See, I have fun in sometimes doing blunt and simple tasks like driving a truck, flying a plane, making these tasks in a GAME so overcomplicated, that it is almost as in real life. Which is why I really love Sim games in general.

The reason why I hate them so much is that at the time I want some action again, I struggle to stop myself playing these games. But that's a personal issue - as said, this review now should be taken completely relative to me and anyone who feels the same this way. THAT is why I put this in here.

However, MFS:X tries to teach you how to fly but does so SOOOO GOD DAMN COLD. That tutor is treating you like you're the first cavemen that crawled out of the last untouched corner of the earth or a very very very old person that doesn't know how to "keep up with those youngsters o' nowadays!". I do see where this game is directed to but I never had a tutorial that was more boring than this one.

Next up is - when I joined a server for Multiplayer to get some player help me with that, everyone just standed around the ATC pretending they're Airforceproud95 or Kennedy Steve not remotely helping in the slightest. Most of them fly around in this stupid Red Bull plane and there isn't anybody that can explain you how the fuck you bring a Boeing in the air and to the ground safely without crashing into oblivion or hell - get yelled at by the ATC or shot down by a military plane cos you don't comply flight regulations.

I only stopped playing cos I wanted to have my money back. I ain't paying 25 Bucks for this shit, nor 8 bucks after it's reduced. If this shit would be for free I would spend more time on it. MAYBE. IF THERE'S ACTUALLY ANYBODY HELPING.

And yes, I can imagine how many of you MFS fanboys cry "But you sound like you just don't know how to play and that is why you don't enjoy it and" blah blah blah blah blah. Listen bitch, I played all Dark Souls and Demon Souls parts while having all the fun I had on these games. It was really nice. This is about personal preference and I'm speaking for a minor, minor part of the community and that is the part, that thinks alike. This game looks worse than my stickfigure drawings and when it comes down to simulators, I'd rather play Euro Truck Simulator for the fuckkilionth time before I'd touch another fucking Flight Simulator MADE BY MICROSOFT.

Cos yeh, I never really liked their games OR their Simulators.

As a former SR-71 pilot, and a professional keynote speaker, the question I'm most often asked is "How fast would that SR-71 fly?" I can be assured of hearing that question several times at any event I attend. It's an interesting question, given the aircraft's proclivity for speed, but there really isn't one number to give, as the jet would always give you a little more speed if you wanted it to. It was common to see 35 miles a minute. Because we flew a programmed Mach number on most missions, and never wanted to harm the plane in any way, we never let it run out to any limits of temperature or speed. Thus, each SR-71 pilot had his own individual “high” speed that he saw at some point on some mission. I saw mine over Libya when Khadafy fired two missiles my way, and max power was in order. Let’s just say that the plane truly loved speed and effortlessly took us to Mach numbers we hadn’t previously seen. So it was with great surprise, when at the end of one of my presentations, someone asked, “what was the slowest you ever flew the Blackbird?” This was a first. After giving it some thought, I was reminded of a story that I had never shared before, and relayed the following. I was flying the SR-71 out of RAF Mildenhall, England , with my back-seater, Walt Watson; we were returning from a mission over Europe and the Iron Curtain when we received a radio transmission from home base. As we scooted across Denmark in three minutes, we learned that a small RAF base in the English countryside had requested an SR-71 fly-past. The air cadet commander there was a former Blackbird pilot, and thought it would be a motivating moment for the young lads to see the mighty SR-71 perform a low approach. No problem, we were happy to do it. After a quick aerial refueling over the North Sea , we proceeded to find the small airfield. Walter had a myriad of sophisticated navigation equipment in the back seat, and began to vector me toward the field. Descending to subsonic speeds, we found ourselves over a densely wooded area in a slight haze. Like most former WWII British airfields, the one we were looking for had a small tower and little surrounding infrastructure. Walter told me we were close and that I should be able to see the field, but I saw nothing. Nothing but trees as far as I could see in the haze. We got a little lower, and I pulled the throttles back from 325 knots we were at. With the gear up, anything under 275 was just uncomfortable. Walt said we were practically over the field—yet; there was nothing in my windscreen. I banked the jet and started a gentle circling maneuver in hopes of picking up anything that looked like a field. Meanwhile, below, the cadet commander had taken the cadets up on the catwalk of the tower in order to get a prime view of the fly-past. It was a quiet, still day with no wind and partial gray overcast. Walter continued to give me indications that the field should be below us but in the overcast and haze, I couldn't see it.. The longer we continued to peer out the window and circle, the slower we got. With our power back, the awaiting cadets heard nothing. I must have had good instructors in my flying career, as something told me I better cross-check the gauges. As I noticed the airspeed indicator slide below 160 knots, my heart stopped and my adrenalin-filled left hand pushed two throttles full forward. At this point we weren't really flying, but were falling in a slight bank. Just at the moment that both afterburners lit with a thunderous roar of flame (and what a joyous feeling that was) the aircraft fell into full view of the shocked observers on the tower. Shattering the still quiet of that morning, they now had 107 feet of fire-breathing titanium in their face as the plane leveled and accelerated, in full burner, on the tower side of the infield, closer than expected, maintaining what could only be described as some sort of ultimate knife-edge pass. Quickly reaching the field boundary, we proceeded back to Mildenhall without incident. We didn't say a word for those next 14 minutes. After landing, our commander greeted us, and we were both certain he was reaching for our wings. Instead, he heartily shook our hands and said the commander had told him it was the greatest SR-71 fly-past he had ever seen, especially how we had surprised them with such a precise maneuver that could only be described as breathtaking. He said that some of the cadet’s hats were blown off and the sight of the plan form of the plane in full afterburner dropping right in front of them was unbelievable. Walt and I both understood the concept of “breathtaking” very well that morning, and sheepishly replied that they were just excited to see our low approach. As we retired to the equipment room to change from space suits to flight suits, we just sat there-we hadn't spoken a word since “the pass.” Finally, Walter looked at me and said, “One hundred fifty-six knots. What did you see?” Trying to find my voice, I stammered, “One hundred fifty-two.” We sat in silence for a moment. Then Walt said, “Don’t ever do that to me again!” And I never did. A year later, Walter and I were having lunch in the Mildenhall Officer’s club, and overheard an officer talking to some cadets about an SR-71 fly-past that he had seen one day. Of course, by now the story included kids falling off the tower and screaming as the heat of the jet singed their eyebrows. Noticing our HABU patches, as we stood there with lunch trays in our hands, he asked us to verify to the cadets that such a thing had occurred. Walt just shook his head and said, “It was probably just a routine low approach; they're pretty impressive in that plane.” Impressive indeed. Little did I realize after relaying this experience to my audience that day that it would become one of the most popular and most requested stories. It’s ironic that people are interested in how slow the world’s fastest jet can fly. Regardless of your speed, however, it’s always a good idea to keep that cross-check up…and keep your Mach up, too.

There were a lot of things we couldn’t do in an SR-71, but we were the fastest guys on the block and loved reminding our fellow aviators of this fact. People often asked us if, because of this fact, it was fun to fly the jet. Fun would not be the first word I would use to describe flying this plane. Intense, maybe. Even cerebral. But there was one day in our Sled experience when we would have to say that it was pure fun to be the fastest guys out there, at least for a moment. It occurred when Walt and I were flying our final training sortie. We needed 100 hours in the jet to complete our training and attain Mission Ready status. Somewhere over Colorado we had passed the century mark. We had made the turn in Arizona and the jet was performing flawlessly. My gauges were wired in the front seat and we were starting to feel pretty good about ourselves, not only because we would soon be flying real missions but because we had gained a great deal of confidence in the plane in the past ten months. Ripping across the barren deserts 80,000 feet below us, I could already see the coast of California from the Arizona border. I was, finally, after many humbling months of simulators and study, ahead of the jet. I was beginning to feel a bit sorry for Walter in the back seat. There he was, with no really good view of the incredible sights before us, tasked with monitoring four different radios. This was good practice for him for when we began flying real missions, when a priority transmission from headquarters could be vital. It had been difficult, too, for me to relinquish control of the radios, as during my entire flying career I had controlled my own transmissions. But it was part of the division of duties in this plane and I had adjusted to it. I still insisted on talking on the radio while we were on the ground.

Regardless, this game has been very fun to play.

Well, after using lots of simulators, and most of the MS Flight Simulator series (including the original FSX Acceleration) I decided to purchase FSX Steam Edition. The brief review is:
- The Steam Edition has NOTHING different than the original one
- Dovetail even did not fix some glitches and fails (for example, the glitch when adding an Addon Scenery, which is ashaming), nor wrong placed airfields.
- I purchased a DLC airplane (CSA SportCruiser) but after reinstalling FSX the airplane is simply GONE. I have tried to reinstall it for several times with no results. Basically, I've lost my money.

I'm a fan of FSX, but Steam Edition is simply a scam. A trick to sell you sceneries and airplanes through Steam.

Be sensible, do not purchase FSX Steam Edition and enjoy your old (same) FSX.

It's the best flight simulator out there, hands down. The graphics are pretty good, until you start looking at small details. For example, you see houses in flight simulator that aren't there in real life.

   The physics are incredibly accurate, nothing else to say there. Engine spool up time is about right, the stall characteristics are accurate, all that stuff. I am a huge flight geek, and the only reason I got steam in the first place is for FSX (Flight Simulator X). Worth every penny. This requires some kind of interest in aviation, as a normal gamer would become bored of FSX relatively quickly.

   I got this addon that allows me to fly the US Air Force B-1 Bomber, and that was worth it too. There is still a thriving community developing addons for FSX, so the base game is not all that you get. New aircraft about every month or so, and I love anticipating it.

    Overall great for anyone that wants to learn to fly, any real life pilots in free time, or just a flight geek like me. If you buy FSX, PLEASE GET A JOYSTICK. Flight simulators are not enjoyable without a joystick and throttle. I got mine from thrustmaster: http://www.thrustmaster.com/en_US/products/categories/joysticks

    Don't be the 12 year old on multiplayer without a mic or flight stick. :)

I am going through private pilot training and I bought this so i could practice flying, landing the plane. ect. But it didn't take long to find out how far from realistic this game is from real flying. 
1. there is no ground effect in the game, making it usless to practice landing.
2. the stall mechanics in the game are broken. I have no idea what they did wrong but its imposible to recover from a stall in the private pilot standards in the game, i can recover no problem in a real plane by losing 50 -150 ft, in the game i can at best recover within 300 ft.
3. The terrain, roads, buildings, and nearly everything els is not correct. the only thing the game has right is the location/direction of runways, so you can't use the game to practice for a cross country flight.

Over all, if you are a pilot, or becoming a pilot and plan on using the game for practice, I would NOT recomend this, unless you just want to use it to get used to the layout of the cockpit of a plane or to just mess arround.

Don't get me wrong, this is pretty dated - being originally released in 2006, it's 32 bit only and visually, well, looks like something from 2006.  

That being said, Micrisoft Flight Sim is usually cited as one of the best flight simulators on the market and over ten years later this is still true.  The simulation itself is really good and there are tons of addons available online if you want to spice up the experience.

This game has definitely shown its age - it's 32-bit, it runs like shit and even with hundreds or even thousands of dollars of addons (which is pretty much the only reason people stick to this and P3D) it's still inferior to X-Plane 11. 
But this game does hold a special place in my heart - I used to play this religiously back when I was a kid in 2008, with my HDD filled to brim with freeware mods on a laptop that was effectively a potato, back when simtours had a forum with the comment sections of FSX landmark articles getting spammed with ROBLOX ads - it was the game that got me into aviation.
And if this game from 2006 is still good for thousands of people, it should be just good enough for most people, which likely includes you too.

After playing the original disk version years ago, I'm happy to see a version on Steam that has fixed many issues from the original such as the FPS. It still plays like the original and has more planes such as the F-18. Even if you slightly have an interest in aviation, you should check this game.

I've always loved this game it is my childhood memory, I have recently discovered that FSX does not work on my PC anymore why you may ask? well a while ago I installed this mod (nothing special just for experience) called Maldair, you can find it on the website wwwmaldair.com. Wasn't too sure if I should have used it at the first place but I gave it a go anyways. At first it worked perfectly my game experience was good I was confident about who would want to join my multiplayer games as my friend request was pretty much filled with people who wanted to play with me online. Days had passed and I realised something that shocked me, little did I know that this mod was actually slowing down my computers performance dramatically I should have known better to be fully honest but how does this relate to FSX? well it does a lot after I realised that the mod program was using up about a third of my ram performance I immediately shut down everything and began to delete Maldair files. I then hoped that FSX would run a little smoother if not better so I clicked on 'play' as always after this FSX start up showed up so I said to myself great this mod didn't destroy my game experience after all. This is where I was completely wrong to this day I can't play FSX properly little did I know that the Mod actually did more harm than good I absoluely regret every bit of that. FSX was once the pinnacle of flight simulation, but these days, it's getting old, outdated, and there's no reason why you should be investing money in an old simulator. A long time ago, i could reccomend FSX easily, with a wide range of excellent addons, good graphics (at the time) and a good multiplayer. However nowadays this is not the case. The graphics have aged poorly, the game is plauged with bugs, mainly the out of memory crash (this is due to FSX being 32-bit, so it cannot use more than 4GB ram). There are simply far better alternatives, such as XP-11. However, if you'd rather stay in the FSX ecosystem, you should buy Lockheed Martin's Prepar3D. It is somewhat costly at around $60, however it is certainly worth it. It is based off of the FSX engine, so it should feel very similar, however it looks far superior (especially with addons such as TomatoShade, ORBX, and REX texture direct), and performance is far superior, due to it being 64-bit, so no OOM errors. The only reason I have FSX installed is for legacy addons, such as the PMDG MD-11.

It's a different experience that you should try.

This sim seems to take a lot of grief for being so old and unupdated. I bought this game for the soaring sim, I couldn't find many sims that have this nitch feature, and wanted to teach my kids. For that alone, well worth a $7 sale price. Thermals, ridge, and wave soaring all simulated, I'm happy.

However, I've found myself impressed with the riduculous amount of "missions" which are essentially flight training in all kinds of aircraft. Voice overlays on all of them. Then if you dig deeper, there's an entire book of reading material. 

I grew up and taught myself to fly on a very early version of Flight Sim, so maybe there's nostalgia involved, but I think this is a helluva value if you just want to teach yourself how to fly, or even just polish and play with old skills. Flight model doesn't feel bad to me, sure DCS-A10 feels a lot more modern, but flying a bush plane in a remote landing, or ridge soaring, don't think you can get much better than this for the money.

NB. This is a review from a Single Player aspect only

Sadly a negative review here. Yes it is an older game but I had expected a little, or maybe a lot, more from it. I was hoping for something that meant I could fly a classic Cessna or DC3 from airfield to airfield in the NW USA /Canada, or the Caribbean, doing various courier flights and taking in some (basic but quality) scenary, which it essentially does, but not well enough.

So:

I do like the ATC interaction it gave some feeling to the purpose of flying, but there was little else I found satisfying

Generally the frame rate is pretty poor and there was stuttering.

Base grahics are poor, the textures just look so bad when at low altitudes.

Locality maps are far from realistic (try flying along the River Avon at Bristol if you've ever gone along that road in real life, the river bizarely flows up and over and down a hill again?! there's no suspension bridge and it just looks poor)

Some of the interiors (DC3 for example) look terrible

Then, everything, and I mean everything it seems, has to be added, i.e. paid for:

- Aircraft with decent textures and flight/systems models, there's no systems failures modelled by default (as far as I can see)
- Ground textures and locality map improvements
- Realistic weather
- Realistic physics and effects like head wobble, views, wheel bobble on the catseyes/surfaces, damage model (on teh default a message just pops up saying you over stressed?!)

You have to buy them all seperately.

I get that things would need adding, particualrly on the map side, but the physics and weather and damage/systems failure? That is what I was hoping would be in 'a simulator'; giving challenge and a believable environment that meant i could see past dated graphics. but alas no.

I bought one map textures improvement and a physics one* and tried some free map/texture mods. The free ones corrupted my game, the paid for map texture was better but was limited in effect by the general poor performance of this game, the better things start to get the more it all slows down.

Then there is the lack of an in-game 'career', I found an online service that can provide somethin where you earn money and buy/rent aircraft (a free thing!) but sadly I never managed to get into this because of the point about the bought physics mod below.

*So I bought a physics mod from FSPS store ltd, this caused the entire game to take about 20 minutes to load, and when it did, it ran at a handful of frames a second, if that! I reported this and after initial responses it all went quiet, my updates were ignored, so I chased and chased and got a couple of 'looking in to it' replies but now it is 4 months later and it still won't work. Windows apparently detected that the physics programme caused a memory leak.

I've finally lost patience, I can't wait any longer for this paid-for mod to be fixed and maybe provide what I consider the basic physics I would hope for, so this along with the other parts I find lacking, means FSX is being uninstalled.

Overall, you need a number of often expensive add-ons to get anywhere near a complete sim, yet each one runs the risk of reducing the poor fps further, and, you are at risk of corrupting your game files, or buying a broken product.

Very disappointed with the experience.

PROS:
-Many addons from the internet to up your game. Examples include rikoooo.com , flyawaysimulation.com and simviation.com
-Wide array of DLCs for you to buy from steam from sceneries and textures to planes. You can also buy them externally such as PMDG and OrBx products.
CONS:
-Default textures are just too low end and outdated. I reccommend you to go online and find some good textures  
-DLCs. Ah yes, the DLCs. Just waaaaay too expensive to buy all the DLCs. But thats normal because the devs (such as REX, Aerosoft etc.) take a lot of time to develop the DLCs.
CONCLUSION:
Buy this game if you are just starting out in playing a flight sim, don't buy this game if you want are experienced af. Because there are alternatives such as XP11 and P3D.

Of the three major flight simulators around (FSX, X-Plane, Prepar 3D) FSX is the oldest, and cheapest, and has the biggest community. The amount of free mods like aircraft, textures, AI, airports for this game make it endless to play. The modding community is on the daily releasing new content, unlike the other two which can be very hard to find FREE content for.

Sure, graphically this game is not as impressive as the other two. However when you put that aside its really pick which one you want.

[h1][b]CAUTION: Causes problems on 64bit machines.[/b][/h1]

You might think this would run fanstically on a modern machine with 8gb ram and a video card with 1gb ram. But sadly 32bit software is incapable of taking advantage of modern hardware. This simulator will probably run very well at first, however eventually it will cause problems and the headache of getting it to work again is not worth it. Do yourself a favor, get XPlane instead; or if you are into military aviation, I suggest DCS World (the base simulation is free and includes two planes).

Also, while XPlane is a great simulator, even for those who are more serious about aviation, if you are set on MSFS and considering training for your pilot's license, have a look at Prepar3d. It basically is MSFS updated, and maintained by Lockheed Martin, to run on a 64bit system. Prepar3d is not available on Steam, it is not a game.

I am running an AMD 1800X, 32GB RAM, GTX1070 8GB RAM; MSFS runs great, for a while. Then it crashes, and maybe will work intermitently. Then eventually, it doesn't run at all; at which point uninstalling and reinstalling alone does not fix it. You will have to edit the system registry before reinstalling. PITA Pain In The A**

Don't get this unless you plan to run it on a much older system.

As of now, I cannot fully recommend this simulator to everyone (unless on sale). Dovetail refuses to fix bugs that are still present in this version and they refuse to add a workshop or anything except for DLC which combined is over 1k USD.

I am an avid commercial pilot and bought the game so I could fly with other pilots as the original version of this game that I own the multiplayer doesn't work because gamespy no longer exists. Joining in several servers you get a lot of people just flying and doing whatever the heck they want. Nothing is wrong there, but the fact that when you try to be professional and use callouts you get poked fun at and yelled at to shut up cause "its annoying". You also get made fun of for flying small planes. And most of the servers you cannot join unless you fly 737s or 747s. And the fact that I have to turn on "Ignore crashes" is really bothersome because trying to fly professionally and trying to avoid hazardly aircraft all around you and hoping to not get hit by another plane never happens. This game is for non-pilots wanting to have as much fun as they want. And for those that want to be pilots or are already pilots, the only way you'd enjoy this game is if 1. you play singleplayer/free flight or 2. You host your own server.

I would not reccommend the multiplayer to any wannabe/current pilot.

Pros:  

Works with a wide variety of controllers and easily configurable

Excellent Graphics, I enjoy float flying and absolutely love the water dynamics, clouds, and details of cars and trucks on busy highways.  I also use pilotage a lot when flying small aircraft and it's nice to spot powerplants, rivers, etc with ease that match real world flying

Performance is great.  I recommend a good video card, but even more mid-level machines work nicely.

Cons
Controls are very sensitive even with sensitivity all the way down.  Not really a fault of the game, more an issue with the controllers I use which don't make small movements as easy as the real plane.

FSX:SE is a fantastic game and I really enjoy playing it :D The planes (mostly) handle well, scenery is Ok and sound... well I reccomend getting your own addon sound packs, the default ones are not very good. Recently though I have found that sometimes my plane will randomly start losing airspeed and the autopilot will pitch the plane's nose up 30 degrees or more leading to a stall unless the A/P is disengaged and the plane is manually flown which is very annoying especailly on a long flight! I also have GSX as an addon and have again recently found that many of the vehicles will appear hovering 50ft or so above my plane which has never happened before. I reinstalled GSX a few times and updated the addon manager even more times but still no fix :( All these problems have just started happening recently so I am not too sure what is going on. Oh well, I am getting pretty busy with my business anyway so not a lot of time to play it but FSX:SE is still a great game and without the problems I definitely reccomend it!

It pains me to leave a poor review of this game, because ultimately, Microsoft's flight simulator series has been one of the driving forces behind most of my computer purchases and decisions over the years.  I've sunk thousands of hours into 2004, and recently I had to give up on it because it's just become too unstable graphically, and was never designed for 64-bit and multi-cores.  

Well sadly, neither was FSX.  I went from 100fps but frequent graphics crashes in FS2004 to 5-20fps in FSX, and I've struggled to get anything more than that.  Oh sure, at high altitude, I can keep 50fps smoothly.  But approaching any airport with any kind of AI traffic on, and my computer tanks.  I've played with every configuration setting imaginable, experimented for hours on end, and I've concluded that my 2015 computer with a GTX960 doesn't matter to this 2006 era game because FSX wants CPU speed, not GPU.  2.0Ghz is a bit of a lie, unless you want to fly around at low graphics settings by yourself.  In order to use the amazing addons, better aircraft, and to populate your world with real-world AI aircraft, you need an extremely high speed CPU, 4.0Ghz+.  

I'm thoroughly disappointed because now I feel like I've wasted so much time and money on replacing my beloved old 2004 simulator (that wants Windows XP to run stable) with something that wants a NASA supercomputer to run at half the FPS I used to have before.  I know I'm exaggerating a bit, but I'm frustrated.  

Be warned - have a VERY powerful CPU before installing.

[b] Flight simulator X : Steam Edition [/b] is a classic, when it comes to flight simulators. Released in 2006, it's still a good simulator. Especially if you're a beginner and you want to learn the basic's. There is a learning center in-game that can teach you everything you should know. There are also plenty of tutorials (missions) to choose from. I don't own any other simulators, but I think this is the best beginners sim, especially because it's an older game => should run pretty easy. It has it's age, and that shows. Graphics, autogen, aircraft, physics are outdated; but not bad! I have played for many hours (don't be fooled by the number, I have many hours offline) and I can say this: for what you get, it's pretty good! If it's on a sale, give it a chance! Dovetail should lower the price tho, a sim that's a decade old, isn't worth 24,99 euro's.

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Easy to run
- Great to learn the basic's of flight simming
- Great learning center + tutorials in-game
- FSX community is massive
- Steam multiplayer fun

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Old engine, graphics, autogen, aircraft, physics
- Flight model isn't realistic
- Addons are quite expensive (for every sim, addons are expensive)
- Default price is too expensive

I ABSOLUTELY recommend this game! It has good graphics, realistic physics (sometimes), an online mode, and much more!

Pros:
-Realistic physics (most of the time).
-A lot of planes to choose from.
-An online multiplayer mode.
-Working air traffic control.
-Compatible with addons.
(I could go on but I don't have the time).

Cons:
-Very complicated at first.
-The taxi mechanics aren't very good (at least for me).
-In online mode, it's relatively rare to find a large server where people are actually being serious, and not doing stuff like taking off from the taxiways.
-It does cost over $25.

In conclusion, I do recommend this game. However, there are quite a few cons. If you are able to learn how to fly in this game by watching tutorials, you'll eventually get it. If this sounds interesting to you, go ahead and buy it. If you're kind of interested, wait until a sale to get it. If you're expecting a very simplified flight sim, this isn't the game for you.

If you have been a fan of flight simulation for some time, then you’ll no doubt be aware of just how effective the Microsoft Flight Simulator series has been over the years. It’s become the absolute staple of flight simulation quality and realism for many years and is one of the flagship Microsoft gaming products. The most recent release, Flight Simulator X, was hugely received at the time and quickly established itself as the key player within the flight simulation industry. 

If you’ve never played a flight simulator then before then FSX: Steam Edition is just what you are looking for. However, if you’ve previously spent time using these simulators then you’ll be probably wondering just what the reason for buying this again would be. After all, if you’ve been building up a huge collection of add-ons and DLC for the original FSX, do you really need to install the new one?What has changed compared to the old one? Well not much, the changes are minor nor it really have new features but yet it's still one of the best simulators ever made. 
Dovetail done a great job of making it accessible, similar to their own releases in the train simulation department.

Well, there is certainly a lot to say about FSX.

FSX Steam Edition is basically the original FSX released in 2006 but with the expansions included and one or two compatibility fixes with modern OSs. As a result you are buying a 2006 game so expect it to look very much like a game from it's era. However, the thing which has made FSX so enduring is it's 'modability', aka the ability to change almost every aspect of the experience. If you are looking to be a serious flight simmer I would recommend you invest in some decent aircraft beyond the simplified versions offered in this version, then you can look at improving the world aesthetics if it takes your fancy.

ATC is included in the game but it is inaccurate and is mostly based on the US system which differs from how it works for actual commercial operations around the world (Europe is particularly badly done), however it is workable and if you want the extra bit of realism you can connect to a virtual ATC envrionment like Vatsim.

A word of caution however, despite the fixes this game at the foundation is still made in 2006 and you will inevitably run into fixes, in a modern day environment there are now newer platforms such as Prepar3D (The spiritual successor to FSX) and Xplane (which apparently has made huge leaps in realism in recent years. In comparison FSX is clunky, unreliable and reliant on a 32 bit architecture. However if you want a nice cheap flight sim to start off with this is a great way to see what the platforms have to offer.

Pros:
* Highly Moddable
* Probably the biggest available stockpile of Freeware and Payware addons due to it's longevity
* Low Price compared to newer sims

Cons:
* Buggy and prone to reliability issues
* Obsolete compared to newer sims
* Large amount of money required to upgrade game from it's very dated appearance to newer standards.

Overall I reccomend FSX:SE *PROVIDED* you know it's limitations and are willing to deal with them.

[h1]Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition[/h1]
Ah, good old FSX. I spent so many hours on this game, way more than Steam tracked with this Edition. Back in 2006 I bought the original Deluxe Edition, later on the Acceleration expansion pack. Prior to that, I bought FS2004, and even before that, FS2002.

I flew so many hours, experienced so many things with FSX. I'll let you know if this game is good or not - but only at the end, of course! :)


[h1]What it is about[/h1]
Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is about flying. Yes, flying. But that's not it - with add-ons, you can drive cars, boats or walk as a person. Yes, that all is possible with third party addons, that are available en masse on the internet.
Apart from all the DLCs that are available on the Steam Store, there is way more to explore on FlightSim-communities. Not to mention that you do not have to buy any of the DLCs to have fun.

The big point about FSX is its mod-ability (or whatever you spell it). You can modify everything you want - from the sceneries over the aircrafts you are flying to the whole environment.

Yes, it will crash or hang up at times (there is no doubt that this simulator rather should be named "Microsoft Crash Simulator"), but then mostly something is misconfigured in the settings - sceneries overlapping, wrong textures for something or FSX was using too much RAM for everything and said "goodbye".

To put FSX into the genre "Simulation" is a bit far off - it is a game that one can modify to a simulator. But I doubt it will ever feel like a whole simulation - XPlane and Prepar3D are a little more deeper in that niche.

Yet Microsoft Flight Simlator X: Steam Edition is fun, and surely is worth the price for an entry to the flight simulation world - and maybe even for the entry to a real pilots license, if one is getting the hang of flying and bored of FSX!


[h1]In a nutshell[/h1]
Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is for those who wish for an FSX that does not crash as much as the original version off of Steam. Not much has changed, a few files did, which help FSX being a little more stable.
People that want to sniff a little more (virtual) air are welcome to buy this product too - for some it might be addicting when exploring the world of flight simulation, for others it might become boring.

Finally, it depends on you, the reader of this review, to buy this product!

FSX:SE is still a great flight simulator in 2017 even though the sim is not being updated anymore by Microsoft or Dovetail. Some of the default aircraft like the Cessna 172, Baron 58 and Boeing 737 are great planes to start off in but I highly recommend acquiring some add-on planes and scenery like ORBX and PMDG. I will recommend this game for the cheap price tag but would recommend switching to a new simulator like P3D in the coming years, being that this sim is 32-bit which disables FSX from using more than 2 cores of your CPU and 4GB of RAM. Apart from the occasional crashing, which can be avoided by not leaving your VC and changing views, not clicking on too many menus in the sim and saving your flight every 10 minutes or so. I still recommend this 12 year old simulator for first time simmers.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition makes you into the pilot you always wished you could be, bringing out your 7 year old's selfs ambitions of flying, all for a mere £20 and for me it's worth ever penny, leading me to sink 8 hours into it on the first day of geeting it and caused me to pickup a joystick off Amazon later that evening. And that's my issue with it. The cost. £20 for the game, +£40 for a "decent" joystick and throttle, which in my opinion is required for someone who is going to play this seriously, as a mouse and keyboard just don't cut it. Aswell as this, there is £3,379.56 worth of DLC as of 01/03/2018 (dd/mm/yyyy), which makes it feel like a lackluster cash grab, athough a few freeware plane's can easily fix this.   While I wish there was more in the base game and less DLC, its a great simulator or game, ready for casual players aswell as thoes who want some more depth. From, figuring out your first ILS landing, with your freind as Co-Pilot, to attempting to fly a Cessna manually across the Atlantic (don't try this, its not worth it), or flying through Canary Warf inverted, it offers somthing for every player and a steal during a Steam Sale.

I've played FSX for a number of years, and I'm glad someone bought out the game from Microsoft to keep it alive. It runs well, multiplayer is back, and Dovetail regularly updates the content.

A definite buy for the casual and hardcore flight enthusiasts alike.

Wanna become a pilot? 
Start here! 😝

Graphics:
5/10 Obviously isn't high quality like X-Plane, however still good for its time.

Scenery:
6.5/10 Scenery is lacking, even though major landmarks, etc. are present, the terrain is mesh and is low quality.

Variety, quantity and quality craft:
9/10 Pretty large variety of aircraft and liveries, multiple companies, and lots of mods and addons with high quality airplanes. All aircraft have fully animated exteriors, working lights, landing gears, etc.

Community:
8.5/10 Multiplayer servers via Steam are present and sometimes fun to fly in, additionally there are realistic servers such as VATSIM, and friend servers. Also lots of modifications to the game.

Stability:
6/10 Even though game is completely playable on Windows 10, lag does occur and an odd bug where if you open any menu it crashes does furiate me a lot. Though, if you have a decent computer, no major lag should come.

Handling:
6.5/10 Keyboard handling is horrible, don't even try. However, if you have a controller or joystick you can easily handle the aircraft, the airplane does respond to movements and it does feel like you are flying the type of craft at most times.

Realism:
7.5/10 Game is realistic for its time, however, sometimes, eg. at takeoff, you just don't feel like you're in an actual airplane. Also, sounds are lacking and physics is not the best for default and addon aircraft.

Features:
8.5/10 The features on vanilla aircraft, though somewhat lacking on specific elements, are adequate for the price, including working cockpits (even though most buttons on the O/H panel are not functional). Also, addon aircraft can be very indepth and have multiple features.

Map:
9.5/10 Map is massive, you can fly to and from any airport, airports are realistically modelled, even though not the best, the map is great for its time.

Miscellaneous:
8/10 Some other small things like night environment, general feel, and other personal touches are great for its time and for today.

Overall opinion:
Game is very high quality for its price, is incredibly fun and engaging to play, and does simulate realism to the next level. I honestly recommend this game over X-Plane until X-Plane has a lower pricetag.

Overall grade: 76/100 + more for additional features that I missed out (please comment if I did)

Hey, before I get started with the review, I would like to say this is my first ever flight simulator on a PC and I can tell every single one of you, it's still one of the best ones out there. Although this is my ONLY flight simulator I have experienced others at my friend's house and there is no flight sim that gives so much satisfaction as this one. Now with the review:

As a not of a long owner of this game (around 4 months), you can see that I have logged hundreds of hours in the sky using this flight sim. This simulator also comes with in-game audio which I have to say isn't the best but still gives you a better and more realistic experience. Also do not forget that if you there are trollers on this game you can just get a Vatsim account and get vPilot (which you need to know phraseology and how to operate aircraft in it), which will sure to give you a very nice experience.

The DLC's are definitely worth the money according to my friend's and I can back that up as they include things normal or default aircraft wouldn't include. With a wide selection of livery, sound, planes and all other things you can get from the internet, the possibilities are literally endless! You can do so many things it's unreal! Ranging from formation flying, realistic flying, dogfighting (AFP95 reference), and so much more it's just impossible to name them all. One of the perks of buying this game is that it will give you more practice and realism in aviation. Also if you think that you're bad at flying, bad at pretty much everything in aviation (LOL) this game would still fit you!

This game only costs £20 and it still stands strong today. One of my favorite features is to be the Air Traffic Controler which a lot of games don't have. This can make you interact with other players. One of the features I was scared to use was the talk when I got the game. I was so scared to transmit on frequency however, this little press of a button can connect you with an amazing and funny community. It will sure give you many possibilities and drag you deeper into aviation.

Now onto the people that don't like aviation. You may disagree however with this game only costs £20, so give it a try. Come on! I mean it's one of the cheapest fight sim games out there. Not to mention, I only got this game because of a YouTuber. Now, I have had so many experiences. Also, the community can help you out.

To sum this up, FSX:SE is a great game. There is no other thing that is better than this legend game from what? 2006? THIS IS AMAZING. I mean yeah, the graphics might not be that good but seriously, 2006! I have to recommend this to everyone.

Before I end this I would like to say that everyone has different opinions. Personally, I enjoy playing this game and connecting with the community. You might not like to but again, that's your opinion! Even though you might be like: wow nice game. Landing on runways so fun. NOPE! You can land on buildings. I hope this Review helped you change your mind or encouraged you to buy this game and discover the depths of early aviation.

There are also many platforms that can make this experience better. For example discord with frequencies. The server is excellent, perfect and is run by a homeless person named Noah! (Jk Noah is a god! Server link: https://discord.gg/z5dCW34 ) Hope you join us :D!

Thank you for reading this.
-AlphaYankeeRomeo.

Buyer beware!  While FSX SE is fast and great on FPS, getting this version of FSX will create several different issues with the development of your hobby.  As you start to obtain DLCs from Steam for this game you will notice that there are several issues with it.   First of all FSX SE will limit you on the add ons that you get, for example......Aerosoft sells their planes with some add ons like FS2Crew, Steam strips it away on technical grounds...and then sell it to you separately.   Not cool.   Get FSX STEAM and then run for the hills to buy your add ons somewhere else. DO NOT buy DLCs from steam....get them somewhere else and you will save yourself a ton of trouble.

Reminicent.  I've played Flight Sims for quite a while, from Jane's Combat Simulator 1997, to Wing Commander I - IV and all of the WC's in-between, (At one point or another!) to Microsoft Flight Simulator 2002.  Sad.  After a while, I upgraded from my Vintage Windows 95 Desktop, (Not as old as my old Packard-Bell 500 that got passed down to me from my Grandpa, but still a pre-historic beast to most youngsters out there!  Young being Ironic because I turned 20 just before the year 2018, haha!!) and I fell into a hole of First Person Shooters and Role-Playing Games.  

Contrary.  I know what you're thinking, but I say that in the reference that - although I LOVE most of the First Person Shooters and/or Role-Playing games that I have, so do not get me wrong.  Sentimental.  I just, for the longest time, was missing Simulator Games without even knowing it.  Excited.  But THIS, THIS brought me back!!

Controvercial.  I like Combat-Based, "Fight the Bad Guy and Win" games myself - leveling up my character by fighting the Empire, Dragons and other Evil Creatures in the Land of Skyrim, Building Spacecraft and Fighting on-foot in Empyrion, Interstellar Rift, and Space Engineers, and especially Co-op playing with my Friends on Starbound, my Steam Playername, Avatar Pick and where my current style of Speech (One word to describe my feelings before sepaking, which is really useful when you're texting someone and they'll only understand your joke if you say that you're being Sarcastic) on Steam comes from - but to be honest, I think that one of the absolute most challenging games to make is a game that is both absolutely amasing, is a Multiplayer game, and is designed around a theme of NO Violence.

Admirational.  It is so amazing that this game can revolve around subjects like professionalism, seriousness, communication, mathmatics, coordination, teamwork, physics, overall learning, observation, attentiveness, micro-maneuvering, and even (most) Trolling, instead of violence, killing, murder, self-defence, war, famine and death seen in at least some degree in 99% of popular games, yet still be one of the absolute best, most challenging and most rewarding Games ever to be created!!  Disclaimer.  Sure, Modiffications to this game exist and the ability to add these features are possible, not to mention already out there, but for the most part, the people who play this game are dedicated to it's primary objectives and overall appeal.  Motivational.  If there were more games like this out there, then I believe that this would still be a Gem among them.  

Recommending.  If this game isn't either on an installation disc in a box sitting next to your computer or in your Steam Library, then my biggest motivation to you all is to hit that button as fast as you can and add this baby to the cart!!  Motivational.  Even though there are still many people playing this game, there are so many more who I know will enjoy it.  Controvercial.  Granted, it is a much older game compaired to games like X-Plane 11 - which is $59.99 currently - but the truth is that it is remarkably similar, AND it's only $24.99!!  Extatic.  Well, I'll see yah on the Runway, Folks!!!

I have had a lot of enjoyment from this game. In many ways it is more than a game, if you have an interest in flying a plane this is for you. The learning curve is quite steep but very rewarding. I would also point out the steam version is far superior to the original boxed version. Every tweak that actually works has been applied to this version. You can spend many hours on different forums looking for ways to make it run smoother etc but take it from me (I've tried them all) this version is well optimised and the "tweaks" you may read on different forums don't do anything. Finally I would advise buying orbx scenery, its works beautifully with this version and looks fantastic. Start with the global base pack, you'll never go back. Please don't interpret my remarks as warning you off the forums there are many good ideas, flight plans, you name it and the enjoyment of being part of a community just forget the tweaks it's an old game and maybe it will stutter once in a while. People say the odd stutter spoils the immersion, they didn't really think they were flying a plane did they?

The stock planes were awful though, and so folks spent hundreds on proper payware, and everyone had a great time with FSX. That was ever so long ago though, and these days it has aged poorly. Yeah, lockheed updated it with their P3D, but that costs hundreds and isn't worth it in my opinion. You're much better passing this one and going straight for X-Plane 11. That is a sim made for 2018, not 2006.

Oh and I forgot, my playtime on steam doesn't reflect the amount of flying I have actually done, which is ashamedly high at thousands of hours.

Fsx became my main flight simulator. I try to use it like in the real life with all the charts vac, and all procedures that are used in real life as meteorology and so on.

I know there's X-plane and P3D, but the price tend me to by FSX.  I have installed 450Go of satellites maps of Europe, with Rex Clouds and some others stuff. 

As a lot of people, I had a couple of issue with frame rates. I put Steve DX10 Fix who helped me a lot with my very old GTX260M... yes ^^
But with the A2A planes, inside cockpits it was between 10 an 15 frames per second.
Well for simulation it's ok but not so fun.

But yesterday after having changed the relation with the processors core for the 100 times.

Even with a head tracking. 

Since I rediscovered FSX ^^

Microsoft flight simulator x is a very fun game and has ok graphics for being made in 2006. I like that microsft added small airports and airfeilds to the game that only few people know of. Problems i have with the game is in winter weather lakes are not frozen over, and they look the same as the lakes in the summer and they have the same physics. Another issue that i have with the game is that sometimes certain gauges and panels don't load in, i found this out in general aviation planes such as the single engine ones like the mooney bravo or even the large beachcraft. A downside to this game is that in the virtual cockpit in like a 737-800 alot of the switches and buttons don't do anything. Overall, I recomend this game because you get to meet interesting characters, and get to see cool sights, such as the las vegas strip.

FSX, the classic flight simulator. The first BIG flight simulator that really started the FS community. I am still a long time FSX fan, even though there are better sims like P3D and Xplane 11. FSX is still the best flight sim for someone just looking into getting started, someone who does not mind using default airplanes or does not care too much about the most accurate flight model out there. FSX is still an excellent sim for someone looking to get it for like 5 bucks on a steam sale and he/she is just starting to get into flight sim casually, just for the fun of flying. If you are all about realism P3D or Xplane 11 are a lot better sims out of the box and to get FSX to act like P3D and Xplane11 in terms of realism you will need to invest a lot of money into add-ons like I did. Overall, I do recommend FSX and unlike what a lot of people say, I do not believe FSX is anywhere near dying.

This game is actually amazing if you want to get into flight simulators. It's great if you have a low spec PC and multiplayer is really fun (but servers can be slow sometimes). This game is also stating to show it's age, so now I recommend X-Plane 10 or 11, but they require much higher spec PC's... I now have over 410 hours just on this game and it never gets old, especially if you have a flight stick or yoke to go with the game. The modding is also crazy good with many of them all over the web compared to X-Plane's one official website... I think it's a great game to get started on and not have to spend a lot of money on X-Plane or a better PC. (Just as a note, I spent 405 of the 410 flight hours on a 5 year old laptop (with a core i5 and an intel graphics card...), but i'm now playing X-Plane 11 with a much better PC...)

- The airports don't look great compared to other games
- Game can randomly crash, especially on long flights

There are many option in terms of freeware to modify your virtual world but quite a lot addons that are of higher quality require extra speniding. The limit is set at how nice you want your sim to look but you can still have a good time even without spending  any extra money on top of this purchase. Support and certain updates are lacking crippling this simulator from moving forward/ keeping up with the modern times but like mentioned before it's a good relativly cheap (buy during sale) piece of entertainment if you consider buying it.

FSX is a true bang for your buck game.  In my mind, it surpasses all the others just for sheer versitality.  This is a wonderful game, with all encompassing default scenery, that looks decent without a single addon.  (The only place I was able to find with lacking scenery is central Afghanistan, where the desert is highly undetailed and barely rendered).  If you have a high end PC and are looking for an ULTRA type game, pick another game.  But for mid to low grade PCs , this is a perfect, adaptable game.  Thousands of free, high quality mods can be found at simviation.com , (my favorite is the Spartan Executive), and are easy to download.  Hundreds more can be found at various other sites, and the payware offered for this game makes it look simply AMAZING.  The flight systems and physics are very good, while crash physics are bad.  AI ATC adds realism, and you can literally fly anywhere, any time, any weather.  http://www.simtours.net/tours.php  I CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS ENOUGH, IT IS AN AMAZING GAME, WITH DOZENS OF HIGHLY MODELED DEFAULT AIRCRAFT ALONE. Multiplayer is very very fun, but the voice chat is choppy.  Group flights, and cockpit sharing is completely possible, and there are no "maps".  Once again, you can fly anywhere in FSX.  Get this game for an cheap, realistic, all encompassing flight sim.

Flight Simulator X has come a long way since it's humble beginings in 2006. Since then it has seen third party developers create thousands of freeware aircraft, hundreds of payware content, and now a reformat from Dovetail. Comming from someone who has heavily invested my money twards FSX including numerous payware aircraft, and who owned and regularly played the disk version Im happy to recomend that older players of the disk version should think about switching over. Over are the days of FSX.cfg tweeks and low settings to keep the game from crashing. Dovetail have brought this old game back to life! Now it is far from perfect, but FSX never really was perfect to begin with. But now we finally have a stable FSX platform.

As a video game for children or civilians, this game passes. But anyone with professional experience (big jets) should avoid this one, the amount of mistakes/false panel settings/unrealism will just unfuriate a real pilot. Its as if many switches in the cockpit are purposely set wrong so people would not be able to use this as a trainer, for example - the fire switches, yaw dampers, fuel pumps, bleed, window heat, etc. Also the seating position is totally absurd and un-adjustable, making visual approaches impossible for some jets. If you must, buy this game at 80% off and avoid the DLC, they are all overpriced rip-offs.

It's very time consuming however, so it's certainly not a game that you'll play on your laptop during coffee breaks. I just played for 3 hours, and 3 hours ago was when I got the game.

It is somewhat ancient though. There's some incompatibility and quirks with WIndows 10, I have input lag when I try to use my keyboard arrow keys.

I feel that it's well worth even the full price. FSX is a must-get if you're into simulators.

Yes it can work if you don't activate the map, you don't place too many commands at one time and you can live with all the idocyncracies that each addin has (RAAS worked and then errors out, Rex 4 has immense graphic flickering and DC-10 is miscalibrated to the throttle. So all in all, it is time to hang up my FSX's goggles once and for all and move to the newer and shinier X-Plane 11 that is not only supported, but also developed. With all the additional costs of FSX with its addins, X-Plane 11 actually will come in cheaper. Go figure!

Long-time FSX user here and I've made the jump to FSXSE. After playing it for 16 hours some observations, bear in mind everyones PC is different so your findings might well be very different:

(1.) Defenitely much more stable than FSX. Where FSX was CTDing this one doesnt
(2.) More FPS. In some places Im getting 15FPS more than in the identical location in FSX
(3.) Tweaking the fsx.cfg doesnt seem to make the huge difference it did in FSX, however there are still tweaks that help.
(4.) Many of your FSX addons will run on this sim. 
(5.) The age of the engine really shows and if you want it to look good you are going to need a 3rd party global texture because the defaults look horrible. Right out of the box this is where XPlane 11 really shines.
(6.) The LOD circle around the plane is small and blurries are very visible unfortunately. Reducing the visibility helps
(7.) Still the extremely clunky old FSX menus and GUI. Dovetail should have IMO updated these (like what P3D did)
(8.) You are still going to need a 3rd party global mesh if you want more terrain elevation accuracy - theres some nice free and paid ones out there
(9.) No more messing about with Activation codes and such if you have to resinstall
(10.) An internet connection is needed when you start the sim. But once youre up and running you dont need to keep the connection alive.

If you're a long time FSX user and dont fancy switching to XPlane 11, P3D or FSW then I highly recommend this. While its the same old engine under the hood they have made some tweaks here and there that do give some positive gains to the simming experience. 

If you spend some time tweaking the sims fsx.cfg + using 3rd party global textures &mesh + an ENB (or ReShade) you can end up with a very nice looking and stable sim.

One last tip - its best to keep this as the SOLE fsx sim on your system. If after playing aoround with FSXSE youre happy then get rid of the old FSX installation -  unless you have good reason not to (they can exist together no problems)  Remove every last trace of FSX, there are tools on the various simming sites that can help with this. The PMDG site has a good guide. You want every installer to only see FSXSE with no trace of FSX remaining.  My thinking is: why deal with what would be 2 fsx installations? More hassle and confusion.

For beginners like me, I would recommend starting with this sim. It migh be old and getting outdated, but with a few add-ons you can make it look great actually. There are even som free add-ons that can improve the sim. This really got me into the flight sim world!

UPDATE: Finally got it to run, more or less, using these settings [1] No Directx 10 preview [2] No SLI. Also Microsoft dropped support for some graphic compression used by a lot 3rd party developers, some of whom are updating their models. And finally, using GPS navigation on Garmin 1000 goes haywire after a short while, making it useless for cross country navigation.
Another UPDATE: Cross-country navigation Gamin 1000 autopilot problem can be eased but not solved by setting simulate rate to unity during transitions and changing simulation rates while paused.
YET EVEN ANOTHER UPDATE: Late June FSX;SE has taken to hanging during launch, and therefore is unplayable. No help from support. Followed their post on how to deal with the hang but nothing worked,

I've owned MS Flight Simulator '95 as well as MS Flight Simulator 2000. 

It's always been a funny piece of software. Clunky interface, but once you learn it reasonably powerful. I've never really used any other flight simulator... X-Plane looks good, but I'm used to MS FS. It's like an old jumper.

Many reviews mention add-ons. No doubt they would enhance the game in many ways, but I have always just played the vanilla version of the game as I haven't had time to muck around with add-ons. And the vanilla version is fine. 

I love the feeling of freedom in the game. You can fly to any airport anywhere on the globe. You can take in an ultralight trike off from an airport in the Netherlands, fly west over the North Sea to an oil rig, set the weather so there's a realistic breeze to land into, and float the little trike down onto a heli pad on the oil rig.

Or just take off from an island and runway-hop your way around exploring. 

In short, the game has always had a feeling of freedom, adventure, and very scalable levels of challenge.

Oh and I've played through a bunch of the missions in this version and found them quite enjoyable.

Write a review for Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition
Please describe what you liked or disliked about this game and whether you recommend it to others.
Please remember to be polite and follow the Rules and Guidelines.
Outstanding flight sim.  It took a while but I finally finished all the missions.  Would love to have more mission add ons

The basic Steam FS as developed by MS was true to the basic MS utility and concepts; however, as a user I am eager to add supplemental programs that "dovetail" with this FS, but, supplemental software does not "dovetail" very well to the basic FS.

Something as simple as the 3D aircraft lighting add-on  only works at dusk, night and dawn...and the taxi light does not work by iteself...you have to toggle the main landing lights for them to work...so no taxi lights when in taxi mode...unless you taxi with the bright landing lights...and, as I stated does not work in the day time.

Other aircraft add ons are a disappointment as well...had high hopes for the C-7 and DC-10 aircraft simulation but they had some major features missing that rendered them near impossible to fly in the instrument mode.

Also, MS developed the Boeing 777 in its FS...this aircraft should be added to the selection of aircraft available to FS.

The Steam FS could be really outstanding if the Steam folks would develop some working enhancements to the basic FS.

Again, what a pity...because tFS is very good in the basic version of FS...it could be so much better...I am posting with a recommend "Yes" only because of the basic version...for the "dovetail" add-ons I have seen thus far...they need lots of work and they get an unreserved "No".   Don't offer items in the Steam store unless and until they work properly with the basic FS.

I have been using Microsoft Flight Simulator since the inception on the original DOS systems. I think that finally the PC computing power has caught up with the Flight Simulator. Sure it's not perfect, but from my experience so far, it is much better than it was, and still provides a great experience if you want to really simulate real life flying. Well worth the new investment in the STEAM edition because it is up to date and patched centrally, instead of having to tweak and fix the program on your own machine. Much of my old add on content still works too, which is a great big PLUS.

As an aviation fan, I would recommend the simulator IF you are only an amateur and don't take flying seriously.  If you do then I would definitely STRONGLY recommend to get P3D(which I now use). Yet, this simulator is quite realistic, with a wide range of airports to fly to and discover the world with and a good choice of aircrafts to fly with. You also have challenging missions to complete which are quite fun. You can also use a huge amount of addons to make the game more realistic. However, you get a huge amount of lags and bugs constantly which is quite annoying. The default graphics of the simulator with NO addons are mediocre in my opinion. Moreover, some airports look quite similar as well... And the aircraft have mostly working functions but a huge part of them does not work but it is a good value for someone who like aircrafts.

If you’re wondering why there is a review for a game that has been out for almost ten years, it is because there is a new publisher, formed via a partnership between Microsoft and Dovetail Games, the developer of the highly successful Train Simulator series. Dovetail Games have taken over the franchise, made some fixes, and have released the newly titled, Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition onto Steam for the very first time.


FSXSE_review (1)

For the uninitiated, Flight Simulator X was the last game from Microsoft Game Studios to be developed back in 2006. An expansion pack was released in 2007, named Acceleration Expansion Pack. It added new planes, such as the F/A-18 jet fighter and the Red Bull stunt plane alongside new challenges and missions to take part in.

The game does a great job at teaching you how to fly within the game. There are great tutorials that cover different aircraft and different airports. There are also missions to take on, such as Search and Rescue and Red Bull Air Races. These give the game attitude and some neat ways to experiment with different vehicles. But you’ll probably have the most fun creating your own flight paths, weather conditions, time of day, and where to take off and land at. The game is a true sandbox allowing you to be your own pilot on many types of aircraft.

FSXSE_review (6)

At the time of release, Flight Simulator X  required a near supercomputer to run properly. Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is much better than what was released 8 years ago. Dovetail Games has done some great work in getting the game to work on modern systems. As an owner of the original, boxed version, I ran them one after another, and FSX Steam Edition is far superior, allowing it to run at 60fps easily. After maxing the settings, I was getting 120fps without a problem.

The terms of the partnership deal do not allow for any graphical updates. So you should go into this knowing that it isn’t an HD remake, but rather just an update so that modern machines and operating systems can run the game. And with that, using Steamworks, allows for the game’s multiplayer to be updated and enhanced to talk to each other over modern connections. It is still the same great game from 8 years ago. But for anyone who has never played the game before, might be a little disappointed.

FSXSE_review (3)

FSX Steam Edition allows you to play multiplayer not just as a pilot, but on a server with hundreds of players. You can direct traffic in air-traffic controller position, be a pilot, or a co-pilot. There’s a racing mode that utilizes the Acceleration Expansion Pack, that is included here to do Red Bull Air Races with friends, and strangers alike. And the courses themselves have multiple difficulties and varying weather conditions.

There are over 24,000 of the world’s airports to take off and land on. All of it can take place in real-time, or a time of your choosing. Airports look busier, as AI now fills the runways with fuel trucks, baggage carts that make things feel less empty. It’s a small, but meaningful change to the game that makes things seem more lively.

FSXSE_review (4)

If Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition seems too outdated for you, then a new Flight Simulator from Deovetail will probably resemble what you’re looking for, and be worth waiting for. This game is approaching a decade after it’s original release, and the game’s graphical fidelity is not holding up. For everyone else, this is an easy repurchase for an impeccable and realistic tool on learning how to fly with some great gameplay, alongside some challenging fun to be had

While I haven't had a chance to really dive into it fully yet, I can honestly say that this is a golden opportunity to play Flight Simulator X on current hardware. If you've ever been a fan of the Flight Simulator franchise from the recent years (Flight Sim '98, 2000 through 2004), FSX is basically the culmination of some of their best efforts.

Disclaimer: this game probably gives even modern gaming rigs today a run for their money with every single graphic option turned up to maximum. But with modern hardware (and even Surface Pro 3 tablets), those framerate-heavy moments hopefully won't steer you away from the fun to be had.

Of the things I've seen so far:

* Air traffic control is more integrated into the game than in FS2004
* Dynamic scenery by land, air, and sea
* Surprisingly cool special effects
* Really, REALLY good adventure/mission dynamics and experiences

I'll be paying attention to see how well add-ons integrate with this version of FSX. That should take care of some complaints of "my town doesn't look that realistic". (I took a flight over areas where I live and work, and major and regional roads are represented, so you can theoretically fly to a reasonably close proximity of your town.)

Sure, even a game like FSX has its shortcomings, but lack of scenery "authenticity" aside (they did a FANTASTIC job with stock scenery included), this is a world-class conversion and provision of the franchise. Get this game through Steam and let them take care of all the compatibility issues for you!

FSX was a revolutionary simulator when it came out in 2006.  Today in 2017, it still is fun to play but needs a graphical overhaul to make it great especially to keep up with X-plane 11 and other modern games.  With addons whether free or payware, FSX steam edition can be made to look like a whole new flight simulator game.  Of course, it still has setbacks in the realism department and internal coding constraints like being stuck in 32-bit rather than 64-bit architecture remain.   A plus is, it runs on older computers which makes for a great nostalgic return down memory lane or if you're new to flight sims, makes for a great first low cost sim.  Get it on sale and bundled with Rex clouds (or other favorite dlc), and you're off to a pretty good start to flying to your favorite city nearby!

The missions are also a lot of fun too, with Tutorials and challenges. The Multiplayer is awesome (Apart from the microphone support, which isn't too good), you can fly with other players and do so much fun things! I highly recommend this game to any Flight Simulator/Aviation enthusiast, airplanes or helicopters.

[h1]Good, but not as good as competitors[/h1]

[spoiler]]Read at risk of being triggered if you like FSX	[/spoiler]
[b]Since I have to give this a rating, I pick no, but if there was an option where I didn't have to, I wouldn't. Read on to find out why![/b]
There is no denying FSX [i]was[/i] a good flight simulator when it released. It has aged well, with a few exceptions. But as the years go by, FSX isn't what it used to be. The graphics have not aged well, and even with graphical mods, it is lacking compared to competitors such as PREPAR3D and XPlane-10/11. (albeit them being priced more than double FSX's modest $25) However, if you are willing to look past the graphics, and your budget is lower, go for it. Graphics and features do matter in a flight sim, however, so if your budget allows, I would suggest, as I said above, XPlane or another sim. I would give this a so-so rating. Based on your idea of this game, and your budget, you decide.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Mechanics are good and realistic
    [*]Still plays very well after 10 years
[*]Cheaper than competitors
[*]Steam is a nice place to have all your DLC's and addons in one spot
[/list]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Graphics are not good
    [*]32 bit
    [*]Payware is expensive
[/list]

[b]Thank you for reading![/b]
[i]Have any questions?[/i] [b]Add me on Steam![/b]

Pretty good flight sim, I have to say they're generous with the default aircraft because usually these simulators give you less than 10 aircraft. They did a good job with the scenery since I can fly out of any city I have visted and usually I can recognize it. The physics engine is also decent, many times I try to do a long climb in a 747 and usually I stall and have to pull out of it. As far as the graphics go the default ones look like fs2004 but I think that's good because If I take off from a small airport like Portland, Maine the fps is pretty smooth. The game is also cheaper than x-plane 11 and all aircraft have great controllabillity with a mouse.  Also to note is that in free flight you can change the livery of an aircraft by checking the "show all versions" box.

Overall, for my first true flight sim this was pretty good, the only thing I think thats bad about the game is the hordes of dlc that costs more than the base game.

Good flight sim. However the default aircraft are not the best (you can't push every button and cockpit may not look like the real plane PMDG aircraft), just note that you have to pay for a good 747, a better 737-800, a 777, and 757 etc.  (Like PMDG aircraft, quality wings, and captain sim aircraft). PMDG, quality wings, and captain sim aircrafts are the only addons I personally would recommend (and to those who want more and better aircraft). Other addons in the steam store are not the best. Graphics wise, they are not the best but its the simulation of a captains role that counts, however bad graphics can ruin the experience, so if u would want better graphics, the REX 4 Texture Direct addon would be the best for runways, weather, taxiways, etc. Better ground/mesh textures that's FTX global's job. If you want more realistic airports... well those are addons too, such as flytampa addons and FSdream team addons (they're usually worth it) and if you want to take your simulation to the next level with live ATC and where YOU give readbacks and request things from the ATC, get VATSIM. It's free, proffensional, however the rules are very VERY strict. Other than that all the sim needs when you first get it, is better aircraft(s), good texture addon(s), and VATSIM.

EDIT: In July 2017 I switched to XPLANE-11 (I didn't purchase it through steam). I was just tired of constantly having to pay hundreds of dollars for aircraft and for good quality scenery. (Yes I have purchased Prepar3d as well). Xplane-11 has amazing scenery fresh out of the box, and for $60, it's incredible. And most addon scenery and plugins are FREE and of payware quality. Xplane really is an amazing simulator, I really don't understand the hype about P3D v4, Xplane-11 has beat FSX and P3D and many ways EXCEPT for one thing. And that's addon aircraft. Many developers like PMDG, do not make aircrafts like their 747, 777, and 737 series for Xplane. And because of that, people stay with MSFX or P3D. 

But for those of you that are interested in some of the available aircraft for Xplane, here you go:
Flight Factor 767 (Study-level, highly recommend) 
Flight Factor 757 (Study-level, highly recommened)
Jardesign A320 (Don't consider purchasing this)
Jardesign A330 (You can consider purchasing this, but I don't recommend)
JRollon CRJ-200 (Recommend, but default sounds are trash)
Flight Factor A350 (Meh, if you want it, buy it)
Carenado aircraft (Isn't that different from FSX and P3D, even has extra features I think)
Airfoil Labs Cessna 172 (YES)
IXEG 737 Classic series (BEST ADDON, but hella expensive)

Those are just SOME, there are still many freeware aircraft and more GA addon aircraft, FSX and P3D are good if you have money. Average cost of the aircraft listed above is around $60-70. This was not meant to be an XPLANE review but I am just trying to prevent somebody from buying FSX or P3D and hating it.

And notice that I am not comparing the two simulators themselves, (I am only comparing the scenery and addons, NOT THE EXPERIENCE) as XPLANE and FSX based simulators are completely different simulators and unique in their own way.
