Flight Simulator X has been my go to flight sim for quite a while now. From back in 2009 where I had the boxed deluxe edition to now, it has been a great sim. First of all graphics aren't that great without addons, obviously since this game was developed originally back in 2006. However with some graphical mods it looks pretty good, or depending on your system, pretty decent. FSX is also very reliant on the CPU, and not the GPU. That does not make it a bad game though, and if you like to casually fly (nothing too advanced, for example starting an aircraft from cold and dark) then this game is good for you. It can also be advanced, but with payware addons such as PMDG, Level-D, and others alike.

Overall this is a really great game, and can run at decent frame rate on lower end systems.

I cannot recomment the product unless the airport feature is updated and included.

FSX + All DLC = $2,530.63 USD. Did you know the most expansive and beautifully detailed flight simulator is free? It displays actual images of the earth taken within the last few years. Yeah. Google Earth. Didn't know Google Earth had a flight simulator? Just load Google Earth and press Ctrl + Alt + A. It's fun to just fly around with amazing detail. If you are looking for a much immersive experience, sure FSX can help you there just don't expect graphics of a current generation triple A game. Another thing, this isn't a game. This is a simulator. Moving forward.

FSX doesn't sport the glamor that Google Earth can muster, not even close. To be exact in a detailed way, FSX is largely outdated. It makes up for the sounds, details to physics, weather, AI, multiplayer and the single player missions are well rounded, fun and interesting for plenty of hours of fun. But....but I've always just loved flying for the scenery. All of the current 137 DLC items available on Steam equals a total cost of $2,530.63 USD. Majority of items are single aircraft downloads that cost an average of $20 USD while larger city packs or even single planes can cost you over $39 USD.  Is Steam overcharging for all the available DLC? Eh, you decide. I've flown with plenty of people where the hub is a particualr city, which, then we just downloaded a mod that we all had in that particular server but I don't know how things are done this day. Everyone must be paying crazy amounts for just one city. Eh.

Having DLC of one city at the cost of $25 USD is a bit greedy, and besides, the game is about flying and if anyone in charge of the Steam FSX DLC prices has ever flown in a plane, you're not over a city that long. Sure I'd pay for the DLC that make the game look more detailed and photorealistic but FSX is a massive world and as for DLC scenery, it only affects one location (on that massive 1:1 scale world known as Earth) because, well, it's the entire world. And is $25 USD really worth a change in a single tiny location? Why not just download all the DLC for $2,530.63?!? (Please, don't take my money). 

I just can't seem to stomach the price tags of any FSX-SE DLC to be honest, cause even a tree pack is $12 USD. (cough*mods*cough) Maybe it's just the way I fly because I prefer to "hop" my flights VFR from field to field spanning wilderness and mountains, over rivers and canyons Let me continue.... 137 items at $2,530.63. SMH.

Moving on. FSX isn't your average "game" because it is actually a "simulator." Multiplayer? For anyone who has been with FSX since the end of GameSpy we all went to dedicated servers or hosting/connecting. So I'm only sure FSX-SE multiplayer connectivity will be swarms of F-18's flying fast as possible thru any controlled airspace from the grass blades to the heavens edge.  Or the frequencies will be jammed with "maydays" every twenty minutes clogging ATC landing/take-off priorities... I don't miss that, that's right.

FSX was not a "game" to me as I had binders of printed pages all printed off airnav.com or my personal VFR map (http://vfrmap.com/?type=vfrc&lat=40.043&lon=-99.251&zoom=10). That is just the fine-lined version of FSX. Then it get's dirty as you master all the airports you've ever landed at, or thought of landing at, then you want to master more planes... and more and more. Then you study Air Traffic Control like your life depended on it because you don't want to take to long in your next server session when ground control calls "seven lima romeo taxi left bravo right mike right hotel short runway 32 contact departure one two eight decimal two zero." (or something)....

This is a simulator, it is the "steam edition" and this truely is all about "flight." Maybe even some over priced DLC. So yeah. Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition: Over-priced Downloadable Content Option. Enjoy! (cough*mods*cough)

well truth be told out of the box this simulator is just terrible, its bland and doesnt really have anything to offer, the world is empty the textures are terrible, the default content is disappointing it lacks in the immersion which then forces you to get addons, graphic wise it runs on DX9 and you can run it on DX10 but a lot of the addons you have or might get most likely will not like it, and you will end up having to buy another add on just so you can use DX10 for that extra bling with your scenery. Simulators are cash cows when it comes to add ons, if you want a beautiful world to fly in youll have to put another 150-200 bucks into it to fly proper planes and have proper airports and world scenery, being a flight simmer is not cheap... after over 1200 hours on FSX i actually moved over to Prepared 3D, for that extra bit of performance that FSX:SE (already a slightly beefier version of FSX) cant offer, after spending another 2000+ hours on P3D i am now moving over to X-Plane, because it is the future of 64bit sims (P3D and FSX are both 32bit so you are very limited, especially when it comes to memory issue and memory leaks) 

X-plane is a little low on content right now, but for the last year they have been getting a lot of work done and there are more and more content coming in and with the release of X-Plane 11 at the end of this year, you are probably better off waiting for a bit and getting X-Plane as a simulator, and if you are already an owner of FSX and/or P3D you are able to bring over all your Sceneries to X-Plane, although there is no compatibility at the moment to do so for your aircraft... No matter what an FSX or P3D simmer tells you, X-Plane is the sim you need, and if you dont agree with me now you will be after spending a couple thousand hours on both sims.

Note to new buyers and first timers... 

before you buy this and expect to have an awesome experience like you see on youtube videos and such please know that to have the same result you will have to spend a lot more than the initial 24 bucks price tag (24 swiss francs in my case)

Aircraft 
Weather
Airport
Scenery

all come at a price and any of these can cost you anywhere from 15 - 100 bucks more per addon depending on developer and quality (the good planes for example can go anywhere from 30 to 100 bucks, but they do tend to come as a package, 2 models for the price of one and such). I for example have over 1000 bucks invested on my sim and thats just on addons not including hardware such as joysticks and pedals etc...

Flight Simulator X was the game does a great job at teaching you how to fly within the game. There are great tutorials that cover different aircraft and different airports. There are also missions to take on, such as Search and Rescue and Red Bull Air Races. These give the game attitude and some neat ways to experiment with different vehicles. But you’ll probably have the most fun creating your own flight paths, weather conditions, time of day, and where to take off and land at. The game is a true sandbox allowing you to be your own pilot on many types of aircraft.
The terms of the partnership deal do not allow for any graphical updates. So you should go into this knowing that it isn’t an HD remake, but rather just an update so that modern machines and operating systems can run the game. And with that, using Steamworks, allows for the game’s multiplayer to be updated and enhanced to talk to each other over modern connections. It is still the same great game from 8 years ago. But for anyone who has never played the game before, might be a little disappointed.
There are over 24,000 of the world’s airports to take off and land on. All of it can take place in real-time, or a time of your choosing. Airports look busier, as AI now fills the runways with fuel trucks, baggage carts that make things feel less empty. It’s a small, but meaningful change to the game that makes things seem more lively.
If Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition seems too outdated for you, then a new Flight Simulator from Deovetail will probably resemble what you’re looking for, and be worth waiting for. This game is approaching a decade after it’s original release, and the game’s graphical fidelity is not holding up. For everyone else, this is an easy repurchase for an impeccable and realistic tool on learning how to fly with some great gameplay, alongside some challenging fun to be had with the missions.

It's a good simulator, a tad dated but there is essentially infinite content to create a better world. Default is fun, interesting, and you can see parts of the world - however it's not entirely realistic. Some of the larger cities have more details but if you make a lot of road trips or spend out time in the country you'll quickly realize that there's not a lot of realism near ground level. I prefer to fly low following roads, rivers, streams, canyons and it always amazes me when I see a house in the middle of an interstate or houses lining runways at smaller airports next to terminal buildings and hangars. I'm not complaining too much because the game is dated but the fact that it's still in use by so many and new content is always appearing shows that there is a lot of love for this sim. You will probably spend days or weeks searching through free content and you could easily spend hundreds or thousands of dollars for paid content. Personally, I don't want to spend too much to make it better I would rather wait for a newer sim with better/modern coding and better graphics out-of-the-box. I think Dovetail is going to be delivering something soon or perhaps I would look into P3D or X-plane. 

This is still a great sim though and is usually on sale throughout the year for a low price. If you fly high or do standard traffic routes you may not care about the up-close ground level details, but if you prefer to fly under 500ft you're going to notice a lot of goofs and glitches with the world. There are mods and DLC packs that can correct and modernize and make things more realistic, but again it's going to take or money or both and the game is around ten years old or so. 

I love the amount of content though, sadly a lot of the freeware aircraft out there are still optimized only for DX9 and I don't like having to turn my graphics down to enjoy games or simulators so I've wasted many hours, probably days or maybe even a week or two downloading and trying to use aircraft only to delete them after being forced to cut my graphics and performance backwards. I recommend it, it's great for beginners or advanced flight sim fans but just like any other simulator or hobby it can become quite pricey depending on what you want to fly, where you want to go, what you want to see, and how much detail and realism you want to experience. There are plenty of stores that offer content and they have plenty of sales throughout the year as well. Be warned though, more realism you want the more you will spend - but even going baseline or buying one of the packages on a Steam sale you'll get plenty hours of this. After-all there have been sim pilots flying this for over ten years...

Even taking the age into account I would give it 7 or 8 out of ten, fly high and it looks good enough, fly low and you'll need to make it look better. I'm not talking about 4k textures or over-detailed roads or anything but I tried following a couple familiar interstates and highways and found very little realism - even some smaller cities and towns the layout just appears completely randomized. I found a spot on I10 where the interstate twisted around a random house - I've seen HP cars sitting in the medians before but never houses. So take that how you will, good simulator, good out of the box, great with pricey add-ons like ORBX. 

*You can get a lot of free trial-ware add-ons for scenery but most of the trial aircraft are so limited it's not worth it. Yay I can throttle up and throttle down and look at it in chase plane but can't lift off or turn! If you go with add-ons I would suggest flying a specific path in stock version, load the add-on - I love the Pacific Northwest trial from ORBX - fly the exact same path to see the new level of detail. Stock version you may see power line towers, with a good add-on package you can actually follow the power lines visually, or follow actual roads. 

I have not tried any of the "Photo-real" packages though but I'm tempted - however P3D and X-plane are also trying to tempt me these days. 64bit optimized versus adding onto 32bit...

FSX is good though, just make sure you have plenty of hard drive space and some extra spending money to make it better for you.

AMD FX 8350, Asus Sabertooth v.1 mobo 8 Gb memmory,  Sandisk SSD extreme pro 490 GB drive.  So I built the machine above with an Asus AMD R 390 4 GB, with a big A$$ radiator. It ran FSX ok without OOM's but the VAS came close to bringing the whole works down.
I then discovered Steam and began to read about the good results being rialized. I installed it. Coexisted with Boxed FSX. Again it was ok, I saw some improvement, it was still worth a try. Was running Win 7 pro, MS was a pain regarding updates and wanted to install 10, I refused a dozen times. Finaly one day I booted up into9 Windows 10, ???- how the heck did that happen?  I gave in!
I download the windows 10 ISO and burned it to an executable. I was a bit surprised at how well it went,  and found some newer drivers all by its'self.in.  Win 10 with the aniversity update and Steam FSX is a whole new ball game. It's perfect in every way.  Do Win 10, fresh Steam FSX install by itsself and see a BIG improvement. Getting 30 FPS at KJFK and 55-60 flying outside. Everone say's dovetail cannot change the core, etc, etc. They didn't need to I guess, but they sure as heck seemed to plug some memmory holes and manage memmory much better than MS did. Unseen graphic memmory seems to get released when not needed.  This seteup Fly's the PMDG 777 as smooth as silk with ASN and soft clouds. Sim Brief with Navigraph is also excellent!
Valve did a great jobe here!

Microsoft Flight Simulator X was abandoned by Microsoft about 9 years ago. Dovetail Games was given the license to redistribute it, though. This means FSX is a ten year old game that hasn't been updated in almost a decade. It still manages to stay alive by people who just want to mess around. Compared to todays technology, this is a bad simulator. The physics are rubbish, the planes are unrealistic, and the scenery is awful. The thing that keeps it alive is the 3rd party support. There are SO many addons to this game. I have played this game for 200+ hours (including offline time), and I know in order to make this game good, you have to spend hundreds of dollars on addons and equipment. For example, t isn't really worth it to spend $90 on good physics and wind patterns, when they are already in X-Plane or P3D. P3D should actually replace this, for it copied FSX, since Microsoft abandoned it, and started making new updates with DX11 support! Dovetail is just trying to trick people into buying a game not updated in 10 years, to make a bunch of money. Overall, the community is great, and you can make this better than X-Plane if you spend a bunch of money like I did, but for the base game, I cannot recomment this. Get X-Plane or P3D. 3/10

Hi, I'm a huge fan of flight sims, but this was not what I expected out of a very well respected flight simulator. I have been flying on Flight Gear, an open source flight simulator that is totally free, and I decided to upgrade to a sim with a more reliable game engine and better graphics. I did some research and found that FSX: Steam edition is almost the same as the $100 version. So, after buying and downloading FSX:SE I booted up the game and saw a terrible thing... the plane was already running. I then closed the simulation and looked through the settings to find a "Start aircraft cold" setting. After looking through the menus and multiple online forums I found that I could only "Cold Start" an aircraft by turning off the aircraft and saving it in that state. So, I booted up FSX:SE in a 747 and I look up to the overhead panel to turn off the aircraft and hit the battery switch. And then again. And again. But the battery switch will not turn off. I try to hit other buttons on the overhead pannel, and then discover, to my dismay, that I can only turn on the external lights. I go through the rest of the plane and discover that I can only hit a scarce amount of buttons and switches on the aircraft. I then go throught multiple aircraft and discover how little buttons I can hit. Very dissapointed in this simulator, cough (just a game) cough, I refunded my money. Don't buy this simulator (I'm sorry game) if you like going through full aircraft checklists.

I have been a Microsoft Flight Simulator enthusiast since inception, and my enjoyment for Flight Simulator has continued to grow as each release corrects bugs, makes improvemetns and provides opportunities for 3rd party support for add-ons.  The Steam Version has made several improvements while keeping the basic FSX concept intact but ignored the one factor that all users face and hate about the FSX franchise - the Out of Memory Error.

2016 brings very powerful CPUs and GPUs to our disposal, and while my PC is at the top Tier in performance, Flight Simulator Steam Edition does not fully take advantage of this power due to FSX 32bit program structure.

Many vendor's add-ons such as ORBX, Aereosoft, and even Steam DLC for Flight Simulator place greater demands on the finite 4GB Memory limits of Flight Simulator.  Thus when using the products with a fully capable aircraft cockpint simulator you will face the Out of Memory (OOM) issue at some point.  It could be 10 minutes into your flight, but more often than not it happens just as you approach that "mega" airport you paid $50.00 for  - resulting in a fatal error,  and the need to restart the program to begin again.

The 4GB memory limit is the one thing that needs to be addressed more so than anything.  Otherwise it is pointless to buy highly detailed aircraft, scenery and airports then dial everything down to bare minimums to avoid running beyond the 4GB barrier causing a simulator crash.

I use a tool called ProcessExplorer to monitor my memory usage during flights, and when the memory usage creeps up to 3.7gb I immediately save the flight because I know what is coming next - this is ridiculous. For everyones edification - Out Of Memory is not a "physical" memory limit but the restrictions of 32bit limits of the program itself, Memory caps out at 4gb regarless of how much physical memory you have installed. 

For consideration: Starting up the SIM at a detailed airport with an iFLY 747 you just used about 3.2 gb or Vmemory and as you fly, use the panel cockpit instruments and enjoy the views, the remaining memory will slowly be depleted until your sim crashes - OOM.

Even if developers of this Steam Flight Simulator version produced a tool that automates saving the flight when memory is near the crash limits at least that would be a step in the right direction, but no tool is offered. I guess creating one would be admiting the problem exist and wise folks would avoid the 32bit  franchise all together.  

The other issue with this version as in previous ones is Flight Simulator does not properly flush memory between flights, and with each session, the more you fly it too will deplete the 4gb limit eventually,  unless of course you restart the program and waits the 3 minutes for a re-load.
Once again no in game "memory flush" feature for a long known issue.

The one major limiting factor that needed to be fixed went answered: and companies are more than happy to sell you add-ons knowing their add-on products place added demands on the limited memory space of this 32bit program. 

Back when Aces was doing the development they would make a statement following each release, "they intentionally build the simulator for the next generation of the PC", WELL here we are, and my system can throw this around at 40+ fps BUT crashes because no one has taken time to address the 32bit limit.  the issue rapidly begain to manifeste  itselft once end users moved up to more powerful systems, and content creators offered "better" higher detailed planes, airports, and scenery.

Moving forward: I would think offering a 64bit release would destroy compatibilty for all those add-ons, and this is the underlying reason the program remains 32bit, to keep the 3rd party suppliers happy more than the end user. 

My prediction is this simulator will simply be 32bit forever, and a NEW Flight Simulator will be offered, sold and we enthusist will venture out and buy it, and cough up money for basically the same add-ons to get us to this point in time to facilite the true enjoyment of flight simulation without the OOM crashes. as they say in contracting - you dont make money fixing it, sell them something new.

So how do you avoid all this OOM stuff:  Stick to the basic Flight Simulator and Aircrafts, forgo any add-ons, or at least keep them to the bare minimum. Make your choice- Do you want to look at pretty scenery or have a simulator cockpit experience - with the limits of 32bit program it is difficult to have both.

IMHO it would be best to stick with the basic FSX steam version with limited add-on purchases, and hope the next FXY version will be 64bit.

So how do I like the Flight Simulator Steam Edition - I love it, due to the vast content one has access to, the realiasm, and landclass graphic details frim orbx that can be achieved using new improved land classes, and add-0n airports. but as stated, fatal program crashes will occur depending on your combonation of aircract, area, and detail level settings. 

With all the above being said.  Flight Simulator Steam Edition has plenty to offer with many hours of enjoyable game play for all flight simulator enthusiast. 
- buyer be Advised of the 232bit limits.

In case you're not very familiar with FSX as a flight sim, the general consensus of it's rather small userbase is that it provides a decent platform for civil flight simulation.

Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is an updated, not remastered, version of Flight Simulator X, and it's expansion, Acceleration, released back in 2006 and 2007, respectively. A bunch of bugfixes were applied by Dovetail, the developer, as well as some optimization which previously required the user editing configuration files, and the game had it's multiplayer component integrated with steamworks, replacing the now dead Gamespy client.

FSX on it's own, provides a very average simulation experience for today's standards: Scenery might not be that great or detailed, aircraft systems aren't simulated with much depth, visuals aren't really breathtaking. However, as written above, it's a rather solid platform for addons.

And this is where FSX starts to shine. The addons available for this, in particular aircraft made by companies like PMDG, Flight Sim Labs, Real Air and Majestic, are really quite something. Incredible systems depth, broadly documented in countless available manuals, mixed in with scenery developed by companies like ORBX and others pump new life into this ageing sim, providing with a flight simulation experience which is extremely hard to compare with.

Summing up, if you do fancy flight sims, in particular of the civil kind, and intend to spend money not only on this product, but on other products which would fit into it, I'd say you're in for a pleasant and enjoyable ride.

If you do intend to acquire this on it's own just to have an introduction to flight simming, keep in mind that FSX: Steam Edition alone might not offer much in simulation depth and visuals department.

I'm a very avid flight simmer, having simmed for more than 7 years, I would know a good sim from a bad sim. FSX (the original) wasn't the best, but it was alright. FSX:SE is almost the same, but with improvements and optimization for slightly more modern computers. Now with FSX:SE, you get a few more stock missions, planes, and much better frame rate than the original. However, FSX still has a few butgs and glitches here and there. But if you're more than a noobie, but less than an expert simmer, I recommend FSX:SE. Because with a strong enough computer, and the right mods, you can turn FSX into something ultra-realistic, or into a game.

Overall, I reccommend it for those with decent computer, and graphics card. And enough money for a few payware aircraft. With just that, you'll have a pretty nice looking sim. But you don't have to get payware aircraft, if that's not the type of flying you plan on doing (Payware, like PMDG,=realistic flying and routes, stock=treating FSX like a real game, like running into other planes, things like that for fun.).

I moved from FSX (Boxed) to P3D and now to FSX:SE. In my opinion this is the best of all three, and I am very happy with the speed and ease of install, including the fact that I can add it to as many computers as I want too. It is smooth with improved graphics over the older FSX, and so far all my addons, which I used on FSX and had problems with on P3D all worked perfectly.

I recommend when you install this FSX, that you make it a clean install making sure that you removed all the left-overs or remnants of the (Boxed) FSX, if you had one; this includes cleaning up the Registry. Not doing so could run you into working problems with some of your (Boxed) FSX addons. This happens because FSX:SE was re-designed to work in dual with the older (Boxed) version if chosen to, and this causes the install program to name the FSX:SE folders to FSX:SE rather than FSX, and this is where problems can occur.

Go for it and get this newer version, I think you will be satisfied as I am. Since I moved over their have been two updates; which happens automatically when you boot-up your computer.

I have simmed with FSX boxed for a long time now, and I just recently made the switch to SE, and I must say, I really enjoy having multiplayer back without worrying about LAN servers. SE allows you to hop into a lobby of your choice, or even create your own session for simming with friends. 
Likes: 
MASSIVE MOD COMMUNITY! YOU WILL LOVE FINDING NEW AIRCRAFT TO DOWNLOAD AND FLY! 
1000s of FREE AIRCRAFT AVAILABLE!
Slightly optimized for new gen PCs & hardware
Great multiplayer aspect revived via steam servers (versus obsolete Gamespy)
Works with a ton of my joysticks, yokes, and even custom mapped switch panels
Fun with friends: FSX is great alone, but if your looking into SE, you probably want to fly with other pilots around the world! This is the main reason I picked up SE and I am very happy.
Cons:
Some public servers are pretty chaotic & uncontrolled. If you want a true flight experience, you must VATSIM or host your own server and invite your friends. The public servers are still fun!
OVERALL:
If you are reading this, and you enjoy aviation, avionics, ATC, airports, or if you want to be a pilot some day, this is a MUST HAVE! FSX is to pilot enthusiasts as Nascar is to racing fans! :) 

TIP: DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE!! FSX GOES ON SALE PRETTY OFTEN; SCOOP IT DURING A SALE FOR >$10!!!

A re-release of the dated, but loveable classic, FSX-SE will once again enchant newcomers to the genre, but may disappoint existing fans.

Do not expect shiny visuals, a modern game engine, bug-free play or anything new: this is a repackaged Flight Simulator X, sold on Steam. The one exception to that is a re-kajiggered Multiplayer system, bringing it up to the standards of convenience that the original probably should've released with. As such, [b]it is well worth your while looking up the multitudes of FSX original reviews[/b], given that it is, again, a classic game with many devotees and much attention paid to it over the years. Also because of this legacy, there are thousands of free add-ons online that can still work with this edition, in place of the scant collection of money-grabbing DLC that presently reside in the store. This game being opened up to the Steam Workshop platform would be a suitable godsend, and will likely come as soon as the DLC-money-well runs dry.

The game's price is rather interesting given that this really, really is a re-release, and it wouldn't be hard to find FSX Gold Edition sitting in the back row of a store's PC DVDROM collection for less than $10. Still, the price is not so high as to be unfair.

If you already own FSX, consider carefully whether you want this. Perhaps your flight-sim community is mainly on an FSX-SE server now - although that is unlikely, as the native multiplayer servers are not presently cross-platform with Prepar3D and X-Plane. Perhaps like me you'd rather the convenience of an automatically-repairable installation tied to an account, not a disc. I do not recommend concurrent installations of both - despite using mostly different directories, some registry entries are shared, and many add-ons are not programmed to recognise each separate installation.

If you do not own FSX, ultimately I would have to recommend the game as an educational and, if you're geeky enough, fun experience. Proceed at your own risk, as further involvement may involve countless hours of installing better or more hardcore aircraft, becoming fluent in air traffic control-ese, and looking up real-world charts with which to fly.

If you nurse a secret ambition to be a pilot, this is a great game.  Very realistic, and there's loads of add-ons and hardware out on the market you can purchase to make it even more so.

There's a serious bug in it, however, that ruins the whole thing, and there's enough people complaining online that I know it's a very common problem.  What's more, considering the number of years the franchise has been around and constantly upgraded, it's reallly inexcusable.  

The game crashes, regularly.  When I first bought this game and installed it on my previous PC, it worked well enough at first, but then started to stop working after a period of time.  The more I played it, the more quickly it stopped working.  Finally, it would stop working within a few minutes of starting, and I'd be lucky even to get the airplane off the ground.

I tried reinstalling it.  It made no difference.  

So I quit playing it for a while.  After I'd bought a new PC, I installed the game again.  Again, for the first little while, it worked just fine.  Then the software started crashing.  And then the longer I played, the quicker it would stop working.  Rght now, the game will work for about 30 minutes, which is barely enough to take off, turn around and land again.

I've hunted online for explanations and solutions.  Microsoft seem to have none.  Various forums contain posts saying, "You need to install this link."  Of course, you have no idea what you're downloading, or whether it contains a dozen virusses, and the reactions of other people on those forums don't suggest any of those links really make a difference.

Given the years this franchise has been available, Microsoft really should be aware of this problem and ought to have solved it by now.  But while it's a great game, and lots of fun, I cannot recommend that people spend quite a lot of money for software that crashes inexplicably and without fail.

*Recommended*

With this game on a big sale right now, there are certain to be people on the fence about buying this game.  I thought it is time for me to write a review on this game.

Over the past year, I have tried all of the current "big three" sims: FSX (got it 75% off), X-Plane 10, and Prepar3D v3.  I also have Dovetail Flight School and even FlightGear.  Out of all five, FSX:SE is by far my favorite.

Yes its technology (32 bits and unfinished DirectX 10) is aged by today's standards.  However, I myself am a diehard retro gamer and I am able to overlook its age to make the most of a sim that is still relevant in today's market.

Its greatest strengths are:

-Diversity in gameplay.  You can take lessons and try to pass checkrides, fly in a variety of missions, or go on a solo or multiplayer free flights.  The game has GA aircrafts, airliners, a helicopter, a glider, and a few other aircraft types right out of the box.  Even if you don't feel like flying, you can read its vast in-game library to learn about the game and the planes' different features and how they are used in real life.

-Expandability.  The default terrain is a a bit bare (but still waaay better than FlightGear).  There is a good number of add-ons available through Steam, and around 75% of the add-ons designed for boxed FSX still work for FSX:SE with no or only a little tweaking.  The default game will keep you busy for many months and the add-ons will keep you busy for YEARS.

-User friendliness.  Almost everything works right out of the box.  Yes there are a couple of bugs that DTG unfortunately cannot fix due to its distribution agreement with Microsoft, but some of them can be fixed by the players with the right amount of research (and back up all originals!).  The in-game options, AI planes, ATC, dials and gauges, four seasons landscape, real-time weather, map, flight planner, rewards, and frame rate all work.  You can start on the runway or at any of the parking or gate area in the game's 20,000 airports.  You aren't given a million options to choose from just so you can set the game the way you like it and take to the skies.

People very new to flight simmings or to aviation in general will not have their hands held - they will still need to take the lessons, read the library, do additional research online, and invest in at least a cheap joystick to make the most of their experience.  That is where many would-be simmers give up.  If you want to fly as soon and as easily as possible, this sim is not for you.  If you want to learn how to fly and enjoy the rewards out of doing so, this sim is for you.

Will FSX:SE be our go-to flight sim forever?  Maybe not forever, but for at least for the rest of this year, yes.  Prepar3D (based on FSX) is still boring and built on old technology despite its price tag.  X-Plane 10 baits and switches for sales and still can't offer detailed airports, good ATC, and the four seasons right out of the box.  Dovetail Flight School is missing too many features for serious simming, but the upcoming Dovetail Flight Simulator may be FSX:SE's rightful replacement.  FlightGear is admirable, but it is freeware for a reason.

So in short, if you are interested in aviation and you are willing to learn, then take advantage of this sale.  FSX:SE, sale or not, is an affordable and accessible entry point to the wonderful hobby of flight simulation.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X is a great game to go to if you have a passion for aviation. Although FSX might not be the most realistic flight simulator, this is a great game to start.

If you want to get that "flight sim experience", but you don't want X-Plane's extreme graphics and realism/difficulty, then FSX is for you.

Pros:
- Cockpits are very detailed.
- Airports are very detailed
- SO many airports to choose from
- The multiplayer is excellent
- Lots of helpful tutorials and challenging missions to choose from
- There's a "Learning center" where you can view guides and such
- Wide variety of aircraft to choose from
- Ground is very detailed, from elephants to cruise ships to buses
- Runs nicely at high settings even on low-end CPU's

Cons:
- Keyboard controls are horrendous

10/10 would fly again
I heard good things about this game but I’m disappointed that I can’t play it because it stay's "Steam must be running to play this game (Steam initialisation failed)"

-bought game for 75% , $25, I don't think I would have spent $99  upfront but probably overtime.
-it's my new pilotwings
- I like the 360 controller cockpit view.
-having the 360 Controller on the table, it's easier to manipulate and keep thumbsticks in place.
-x52 Saitek flight stick is great 
- Some of the mission packs are not working (could be my own ignorance.). I'll review them when I finish them or if I can't finish them because I can't get them to work I'll review that I can't get them to work.

  I wish I could or I wish I knew how to use two 360 controllers. I'd like cockpitview mapped to a second controller right thumbstick and throttle on the first controller right stick. I would like to do that without a 3rd party gamepad mapping software. 

  I've googled (not deeply), but it's generally a load of people saying "Omg, you can't use a 360 controller". A 360 Controller works reasonably well and the people asking are not asking about 'what they should be using' but 'what they are using'. Reddit had a post and the replies nice enough, but they didn't really suggest any information other than "Yeah, 360 controller works". What I am using is a 360 controller, and I'd like to use 360 controllers (2+).

With that idea seemingly dead, I went shopping online for flight gear. Looking at flight sticks and yokes... okay, I want that yoke with the quandrant, instrument panel, box with the flippy switches and the box with the knobs, captains shirt and tie, .. okay just the yoke and quandrant because this is going to be expensive. 


22 hours into this game and 
I can confidently fly a cesna (I don't ATC though :\). I've finished most of the tutorials a few missions, Soaring had me confused for a bit, I almost have a feel for helicopters, and jets are quite difficult.

31 hours. Flight stick arrived, Saitek x52 for half the original price. This makes the game at least 2x easier than the 360 controller. I am still using the 360 controller, but it has moved to my lap and is for cockpit view and a few switches (like landing gear). I just had the most beautiful landing of my desktop piloting experience. Only issue I've had with the flight stick was that the rotation x and y (throttle joystick) didn't work very well for panning :( made the view shaky (and I calibrated). Anyway, I was able to Transistion to Jets Tutorial 8 without much problem. Helicopter Manuevers are seemingly harder now, which was unexpected... but an hour later and I was getting the hang of helicopters,

I bought this game on sale, thought why not, I generally like simulator-type games. Unfortunately I don't own a working controller/pad at the moment, and this proved to be a game ruiner. This game really doesn't seem to work well with a keyboard, and the control bindings and the settings weren't exactly user friendly if you don't know plane jargon. I spent an hour fiddling around with various settings and still couldn't get a setup that allowed me to control the basic plane properly and so I gave up and got a refund before I spent so much time playing around with the settings that I didn't qualify for one anymore. I'm sure this game is great once you actually get to play it, but unfortunately I can't give a thumbs up because I never actually got to play it and I don't have several hours to spend tweaking settings to get the sensitivity just right so that it's playable.

A quick Google search told me I wasn't the only one to have this problem, there were whole forum threads stretching back years talking about this issue. It's annoying that there's nothing telling you before you buy this game that it requires a controller to be fully enjoyed or indeed be playable.

Oh, and the graphics do look like they're from 2006, which is of course when the game was first released, but I'd have expected at least some minor improvements since then. Apparently not.

The classic is reborn with some new content, plus revived and revamped multi-player!

This is the quintessential flight simulator!  It is the most accurate, in-depth, and authentic flight simulator available.  So realist, I have seen this software used in flight sims in museums!  Whether you are looking to pilot a hand-glider, a helicopter,  a prop plane like Cessna, or a jet airliner like a Boeing 747, it is here; and true to life.  From the control panel layouts and aircraft operation, to Air Traffic Control and flight planning.  If you are looking for a non-military flight simulator, you can not go wrong with Flight Simulator X:Steam Edition.

The Steam Edition adds the ability to play in multi-player environments; where you can play as a pilot or co-pilot to an air traffic controller.  There are also different races like Red Bull Air Race and Reno National courses, and even more!  There are also the original missions from the game plus many more, providing 50+ hours worth of single-player missions; or just pick an airport, pick a plane, and take off!  You will be playing this game for years.
In addition, if you really become addicted to this game, there is a plethora of accessories that you can get.  You could literally have professional grade flight simulator with life-like throttle levers, panels, headsets, and more.

PROS:
I could say everything but...
Added multi-player and single-player content, stunning visuals, realist (or not so much, if you prefer) flight conditions and aircraft controls, ridiculous re-play value

NEUTRALS:
Aircraft selection-While there is a variety in the types of aircraft you can pilot, it still feels like one or two aircraft were selected from each category of aircraft and that's what you get.  Some may have some color options, but for the most part, if you want to fly a prop plane you have these 2 or 3, if you want fly a jet plane you have these 2 or 3, and so on.

CONS:
I don't have any cons for this game, what there are cons for is from Steam.  This is not a con in the non-Steam version of this flight simulator, since it can be resolved.  Sorry guys; love ya but this is on you...
Add-on Content.  If you own the original Microsoft FSX game, there is FREE add-on content; literally by the hundreds of thousands.  From texture and airport upgrades, to improved visuals on landmarks, and I couldn't even begin to list all the options.  But NOT with Steam Edition.  The game description blames it on compatibility, which I concede may have a level of truth to it.  However, to charge over $1500 for DLC is truly...rediculous...outlandish...unbelievable...I think those are even understatements.  I don't understand this pricing on any level, period.

Overall
If you are looking for a flight simulator, you need not look further.  This is the pinnacle of consumer-level flight simulator.  In regards to the DLC pricing issue, my recommendation would be this.  Buy the Steam Edition, for two reasons. First is the online multi-player content, this is not available on the original game.  (*There is a multi-player option on the original game.  However, it is LAN multi-player meaning you don't play online, and I don't have any experience with it.)  Second, if you really like the game and find that you want to improve the experience, buying a copy of the original game isn't too expensive and then you can download all the free add-on content until you heart's desire.  I stress this because if you want to put some time into it, there are a countless number of beautiful fly-bys you can do in this simulator; and in fairly realist graphics with add-ons and high settings.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
NOT WORTH YOUR MONEY.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
If you're looking at this game because you played FSX and are getting nostalgia for it again, you'll find everything is exactly how it was on the original CD release. All the control mappings and defaults are the same. Flight controls are the same. Missions are the same. It's the same simulator that Microsoft released a full 10 years ago. The scenery is that outdated look and the engine still has the same fun problems (except for some compatibility issues, see "Steam Edition"). The plus side is the base package can be run on max settings from even mid-range laptops with integrated graphics.

[h1]Steam Edition[/h1]
Let me explain just why this game is now available on Steam. Dovetail Games (a pretty bad developer who sees itself as the god of sim-games) bought the rights to distribute FSX 2 years ago so they could make their own flight simulator. What they did for FSX was quickly patch some issues with compatibility for Windows 8/8.1 devices (and probably W10 too), so that it could run on Steam users' current PCs. Then they released it into the wild to earn cash to fund their development project for a new flight sim. I don't think they've touched it since.
[i][u][b]Warning![/b][/u][/i]
Lots of add-ons for MFSX will not work with the SE version for a number of reasons. The most basic is that an add-on refernces the standard installation directory, which is not where the SE version is installed. There are other reasons, but I can't really explain them.

[h1]Persistent Issues[/h1]
While Dovetail [i]supposedly[/i] fixed some compatibility issues with newer operating systems, they certainly didn't fix all of them. In addtion, there are some things they should have fixed before re-releasing this on Steam. For example, the mission compass is still really stretched out on a monitor that isn't at a 4x3 aspect ratio. If you use DX10 rendering (better performance), you will never be able to go near an airport because of the horrid texture clipping that occurs. Every line and every asphalt surface that overlap encounter the WORST texture clipping with the DX10 engine. And if you go back to the default renderer, DX9, it then becomes impossible to see some pause menus (for example, rebinding keys mid-flight). Instead all you see is a black screen where you know there should be a menu. At that point, the only thing you can do is close the program externally. So you're basically forced to have massive texture clipping.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
While I miss the days of FSX when it was new, I definitely am not reliving those now. The software has so many issues relating to newer operating systems that it makes the game unplayable on any modern platform (especially on the Windows 10 that Microsoft has been shoving down our throats). If I had a computer running Vista or XP (both no longer supported by Microsoft, fyi), this would be a worthwhile buy. However, to get this playable on a modern system requires you to dig around the web for solutions that involve manual edits to the game's source code/installation files. It's just not worth it.

[h1]Footnote to Dovetail Games[/h1]
Dear Dovetail: how is it when you're given only a handful of things to do that you still manage to fall short? Even a cash grab should be well patched to work on a modern system. And you saw that your new flight sim/school was targeted at the wrong audience (I mean, what did you expect? The last good flight sim at its release was THIS, in 2006, or XPlane, which is quite a bit more complicated to use. Of course we're first in line for a new flight sim). And can we talk about how all of your other sims seem to tank in the reviews as well? You're not [i]acclaimed[/i] for anything, and the only thing you're [i]renowned[/i] for is pissing people off with shitty simulators. I.E. your train simulator should still be in the oven for optimization fixes. Your new flight school still has a lot of artifacts from the FSX engine like details popping into view and it's only got 2 planes. From all I've seen, you're one of the worst developers I know of. I WANT to enjoy a new flight simulator. Don't push out a release too early when you build the full thing. GET IT RIGHT. It's so frustrating when a developer is desperate for cash so they push a game out before it's ready. Then it never gets fixed and everyone hates it. Thing is, this is what it feels like you, Dovetail, are doing with EVERY SINGLE THING YOU MAKE.

The best 'game' I've ever played. 

Even though it originally came out in 2006, Flight Simulation X still holds up as a truly amazing simulator.   The Steam Edition has made improvements to the performance.

The base simulator covers the entire globe, has flying lessons built in and also many missions to complete. 

A word of warning though, if you end up getting into flight simulation, it may end up costing you a lot more as there are some amazing addons to pick up. 

I'm a photoscenery fan, as I like to know that what I'm flying over is an exact replica of what I would see if I was really flying.  Plus it can be used to navigate accurately.

If you're new to flight simulation, here are my recommendations, bearing in mind I'm a GA flyer: 

Firstly, buy the book FSX for Pilots- Real World Training.  It is the perfect way to learn how to fly using the simulator. 

Essential Addons:

General:
REX
FS Global (preferably ultimate editions)
Natural Tree Environment X - not essential but I like it.
Accu-Feel - Makes the default planes feel more realistic.

If you're not into photoscenery:
FTX Global
FTX Vector

If you prefer photoscenery, then it might not be worth getting the two FTX products, as your photo scenery will overwrite them

UK Photoscenery: 
VFR Generation X v3
Revolution X ( a criticism levelled at photoscenery, is that they can appear flat, however this adds loads of autogen andis fantastic).
UK2000 UK airports

These titles are amazing.  So realistic.

USA Photoscenery
Megascenery Earth
TreeLines (like Revolution X, but only includes trees.  Works well though)
Night Environment for each state where available.

Airplanes:
The default ones are ok, but there are better ones out there.  For GA flying I love the A2A Piper. 

Traffic:  
Ultimate Traffic 2 is a good one.  Makes things a lot more interesting with other planes flying around.

Finally, I recommend a decent PC to run it on, and a decent yoke and rudder pedals.  I use the Saitek products. 

You might want to try a few tweaks too.  I recommend Frooglesims youtube video called 'VLOG: How to get better FSX performance' and the tweaks referenced in the Megascenery manual.  Matt Smith is also a good user to watch youtube videos on.

As I said, beware, because if you do get hooked, you may end up spending a lot (of time and money) on the hobby. Time and money very well spent though.

So, being a newbie to Steam, I purchased this title for my library.  Little did I know, this is not a VR game!  It's apparently a "steam enabled" game.  The title says "steam edition", so I naively purchased it thinking I could play it with my Vive headset.  WRONG.  When I access the title in my library, it says "Play in Theater".  Why would I want to play it in theater?  I want to play it in VR.  Oh well, so I try to play it in theater mode.  It says "Connecting to Game"... then, [crickets chirping], nothing happens.  

Frustrated, I walk away from my computer, and come back sometime later.  It still says "Connecting to Game...".  I close everything out and request a refund through Steam.  Of course, they coldly deny my refund because the game time has 20hrs on it.  Of course, I didn't play the game for 20hrs, I played it for 0.00 hours.  But, the Steam folks don't care.  No refund.  No sympathetic ear fo a newbie.

Do yourself a favor and don't buy this 90's rehash.  Wait for a real VR flight sim title to come out from a real VR developer.

And, be very skeptical of any game in the Steam Store, because once your purchase it, if it doesn't work, or is absolute crap, your money is gone!

Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition offers players a connected world where they can choose who they want to be, from air-traffic controller to pilot or co-pilot. Racing mode allows you to compete against friends with four types of racing, including Red Bull Air Race courses, the unlimited Reno National Championship course, as well as cross country, competition sailplane courses, and fictional courses like the Hoop and Jet Canyon. Test your skills with three different levels of difficulty, from simple pylon racing to racing highly challenging courses in a variety of weather conditions.

With over 80 missions, test your prowess to earn rewards. Try your hand at Search and Rescue, Test Pilot, Carrier Operations, and more. Keep track of how you have done on each mission and improve your skill levels until you're ready for the next challenge.

Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition enables pilots to fly the aircraft of their dreams, from the De Havilland DHC-2 Beaver floatplane and Grumman G-21A Goose to the AirCreation 582SL Ultralight and Maule M7 Orion with wheels and skis. Add to your collection of aircraft and improve the fidelity of your world with FSX Add-ons.

The inclusion of AI-controlled jetways, fuel trucks and moving baggage carts, adds extra realism to the experience of flying at busy airports.

First of all, my thanks to DTG for bringing some life back to this dying "Dinasaur" of Flight Simulation!!! If you are new to flight simulation you'll be relieved to know that this program works right off the box unlike Boxed FSX that needed hours of tweaking of the .CFG file and also knowledge of .xml. It has simple aircraft models that will be enough for you to get a feeling what is like to be up there. 

If you are a current user of FSX this release only adds some more stability to the Simulator and the .cfg is already tweaked to run nice and smooth. Then again as you start to add the mountain of addons gathered through the years, then your millage will vary and you could potencially bring this version of FSX also to its knees. And I know there is some of you out there that just enjoy spending days on end tweaking FSX to squeeze one more FPS (Frame Per Second), for those of you fear not for FSX-SE will allow you to tweak its .CFG to your heart's content. Over all fell that it runs better that Boxed FSX without any Tweaking to it.

There is only one reason that would make me go back to Boxed FSX and that is to fly the F-18 by VRS. I say that because the Boxed FSX version of that addon will not work on FSX-SE unless you also purchase the TACPACK.

Final thoughts on FSX-SE, I own it!! I like it!! And I have already retired my Boxed FSX for good!!!

This is a must-have for anyone looking for a flight sim.
FSX is a very old simulator though (I myself have used this for the best part of 10 years), and its age is now showing. 
I will warn anybody looking to buy this that you are probably going to have spend a hell of a lot of money if you want to make it look and feel realistic. The simulator was developed in 2005/2006 and now requires DOZENS of add-ons to bring it up to todays standards.
Be warned, You will require a high-end PC to run it on high settings. And will spend countless hours tweaking your settings and config files to get those all important frame rates to a reasonable level.
Personally I think FSX days are numbered.
It is time a simulator was developed with the same user-friendly interface (sorry, x-plane just does not cut it...) but optimised and developed to today's standards.
Until then, FSX (+addons) will have to do.

I have probably logged a thousand hours on the original FSX....What this game could have been had the development team not been forced to shut down. In it's day, with support, it promised to be the most realistic flight simulator software avalible to the general public. Then support ended. Yet, that did not stop us die hard enthusiasts from creating libraries of add ons, modifications to dated/ glitched script and other improvements that kept the simulator relevent. 

Enter Steam. They bring the game back! Hooray! But no, not hooray for anyone but Steam. All of the simple fixes to make the game more enjoyable or even playable (logbook.bin, anyone?) did not even get touched. Missions still glitched to hell and back. Some airports still unplayable. Logbook issues, keybinding issues. I could go on but you get the drift here.

This is a money grab by steam. Although it is cheaper than the boxed version, the developers spent minimal time fixing any of the bugs that made the boxed set so damn frustrating. Although it still works, if you are going to slap you name over a product like it is something new and improved, then improve it. Don't rely on us enthusiasts to improve the game for you. That is all.....

I have been playing this game since 2008 and just last year I bought the steam edition of the game. One of the few games that never really got old for me. One of the best simulators of the 21st century. I am so glad I grew up playing this. 10/10.

Still the better civil aviation simulator due to its extensive support with a vast selection of 3rd party addons. This means that although the base package is very dated, it can be easily improved with better scenery and aircraft for a more up-to-date and fun flying experience.

[h1]Performance and Playability[/h1]
The base game works fine out of the box with Windows 10 and because it’s from 2006 it should run on the average computer without difficulty. However I found DX10 to be mostly broken on various graphics cards, its hit or miss whether it will work for you – if it doesn’t, DX9 mode will play fine. This is simply because the DX10 that came with the game was only a preview build rather than a full DX10 support.

Another thing to note is that when you start installing lots of addons, the game does suffer from performance issues relating to the fact it’s a 32-bit. While there are no-shortage of community config file edit suggestions, the only thing that will really help is a really high end computer here (notably cpu etc.). To avoid issues, simply be wary about what you install as some scenery addons can be terribly un-optimized.

[i]NOTE: This Steam Edition is essentially the 'Gold Edition' of the game, which contains the base FSX and the Acceleration Add-on in one install. It also uses Steam multiplayer instead of Game-spy. I have however found this version does not contain all the SDK files which were found in the Deluxe edition of the game, but most of this can sourced with a few google searches. None of this really matters unless you are going to be developing content for the game or trying to install a really outdated add-on that doesn't work around the newer service packs.[/i]

[h1]Aircraft[/h1]
The game comes with more than a dozen aircraft, ranging from airliners like the [b]Boeing 737[/b], bush planes like the [b]Piper J-3 Cub[/b], General aviation planes like the [b]Cessna 172 Skyhawk[/b], classic warbirds like the [b]P-51D Mustang[/b], and even some helicopters thrown in the mix such as the [b]Robinson R-22 Beta II[/b]. All these come with detailed cockpits and various paint scheme options.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=679814115
While this is indeed a reasonable selection of planes included for new pilots to the game, it has to be said that experience does improve considerably when getting 3rd party aircraft as these are not only better looking, but can feature more accurate flight models.

[h1]Multiplayer[/h1]
Multiplayer works out of the box via Steam, is pretty easy to join and works well. However the game does not come with a dedicated server, but there are 3rd party hosting applications (Such as [url=http://www.chocolatesoftware.com/fshost/]FSHost[/url]) that will fill this gap.

Exploring during a group flight with friends is something I really enjoy, and one of the things that keeps me playing FSX. 

[h1]Free Flight[/h1]
In Free Flight you can choose to spawn at nearly any airport in the world with the aircraft, time, and weather conditions of your choice. From here you can file a flight-plan or just fly wherever you want. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=679813932
While the scenery included by default is global, it is strongly recommended you do replace it with either payware such as [url=https://www.fullterrain.com/]Orbx FTX[/url] or freeware such as [url=http://ninetwopro.com]FreeMeshX[/url] as it is very lacking and not very accurate by default. With modifications it can become really nice to look at and will improve your enjoyment of the game.

[h1]Missions[/h1]
There are dozens of included missions with the game, ranging from tutorials, to racing, to landing on an aircraft carrier! There is quite a varied selection here, with skill levels ranging from beginner to expert, and mission lengths of around 15 minutes, up to a few hours. 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=679813639
No career mode is included, just individual missions, but plenty to keep you busy here.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
So if interested in civil aviation or aviation in general then FSX is well worth the purchase, but do so under the knowledge that your experience will improve considerably when done so with 3rd party addons, even if freeware.

[b]Good[/b]
Varied selection of included aircraft (good, however not as good as payware)
Steam multiplayer
Vast selection of payware and freeware mods
Global Scenery
Lots of available missions

[b]Not so good[/b]
Included aircraft flight models lacking (can buy payware aircraft that fly more realistic)
Default scenery outdated (can be improved with freeware and payware)
No included dedicated server
Possible performance issues due to 32-Bit

So I'm an avid FSX user since its launch in 2006. I've clocked over 1000 hours in the game, half on Vatsim/Multiplayer, other half offline. The game was tremendously helpful in my pursuit of my private pilot's license. I've been wanting a modernized flight simulator that runs on a modern OS since Windows 8 came out. I've heard of Prepar3d but I do not like its EULA policy even though I'm an undergraduate student and I'm qualified for its academic license. The interface and software for Lockheed's variant is tailored for flight training institutions and for professional environments and it's not very user friendly for the home user. I thought about converting to X-Plane but couldn't commit because I already have so many add-ons for FSX. Fast forward to 2014 and Windows 10, FSX was released on Steam (which by the way I couldn't believe, but very happy) from Dovetail and after downloading and installing the game, it was compatible 100% with Windows 10, no tweaking needed. Not only that but Dovetail made several improvements to the game even after Microsoft released Service Pack 2/Acceleration for FSX in 2007, a big one being adding their own multiplayer since GameSpy servers were shut down, major optimization for framerate issues and so on. PMDG and 90% of my addons work well with the Steam Edition and the other 10% have updates that make it compatible as well. Overall it’s a good competition to other Flight Simulators already out there and I can’t wait until Dovetail announces their new plans for 2016.

Stop producing DLC's and polish your main product ffs.

If I had to think of a single purchase in my life that returned the greatest value for the smallest initial investment (5 dollars on a Steam sale), this game would have to come near the top of that list. I've never flown an actual plane and don't know if I ever will, but I certainly feel like I could now, and I owe that all to this game. 

Of course, flying a real plane and flying in a simulator are never going to be identical given the level of potentially life-threatening danger involved with a real plane, but at the same time, this is software that instrument-rated pilots use to keep their skills sharp, so it's probably the closest you'd get without buying a multi-million dollar simulator. At the very least, you will learn the fundamentals of flight.

I never purchased any DLC because I didn't really see the point, as there was already a good collection of default planes (and excellent freeware depending on where you look). On top of that, there are around 24,000 airports covering basically every country on Earth.

There are quite a few missions and they're structured more or less like tutorials, teaching you everything from the ground up and ranging to emergency situations/expert level missions. 

There's even a mission where you are a stunt/trick pilot who has to land on top of a schoolbus driving down the runway at 50 mph. Flying Hannibal's route through the Alps into Italy, or landing at Lukla at the base camp for Mt. Everest are some of my favorite highlights too.

The rush you get during the last two minutes of every landing is one of the best feelings I've ever experienced, so I can only imagine what it must be like for an actual pilot. Landing a fighter jet on a carrier in high-wind or taking off after barreling down the slope of Mt. Fuji in an Orion on Skis, how could you possibly go wrong there? Buy this, you won't regret it.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X (Steam Edition and all that bull...) is a great flight simulator, and a game.

I used to play this game from the boxed edition (Golden Edition), and I had a blast of a time, sitting for hours on end trying to figure out how to automatically land an Airbus A321, or just sitting for hours on end just flying, admiring the scenery (which to modern day standards, isn't the best, but hey, it's an oldie).

But now with Dovetail's 'new' game, it's given this old gem a new platform, more players and all from the comfort of using Steam as a multiplayer platform. Multiplayer still has it's downsides (compared to the previous Gamespy thing FSX had). Voice chat still sounds like everyone's face-fucking a blender to no avail. Planes jitter if you try to fly in formation with friends over the internet. All of these issues were common with Gamespy, so no change there.

Knowing Dovetail's track record with Train Simulator 2016, FSX(SE) has more DLC than a pimples on a prepubescent teenager's face, and that's saying something. Although this isn't much of a bad thing, it allows everyone to buy payware aircraft from one centralised platform. If anything, this pleasures Lord Gaben's cock even more when those sales hit.

It's about time I gave my opinion on FSX:SE.

I never owned the boxed edition of FSX, however, I had a friend of mine who did, and he reccomended that I get FSX. I got it about a year ago when it was on sale for $5.00. When my friend found out, he was as excited as I was.

Simply put, it was the best $5 I ever spent. I love FSX:SE. As this was my first full fledge flight simulator, I didn't need all the bells and whistles of newer flight sims such as X-Plane. I just enjoyed flying planes. I really learned a lot playing this game, as it taught me the basics of aircraft flight. I started off on small Cessnas and Pipers but gradually worked my way up to larger Boeings. The default aircraft are good but not perfect. If you are just beginning, you won't be able to tell the difference, but if you are an experienced flight simmer/actual pilot, you will see some things missing. However, if you get bored with the default aircraft, you can always download more planes for free at simviation.com.

The multiplayer is very fun. The Steam multiplayer works well and I enjoy flying formations and airline hops with other players online. As a member of the FSX Competition Center, I can participate in landing competitions online. However, I do have a few complaints about multiplayer. The first is that the microphone communication is TERRIBLE - it's almost impossible to make out anything anyone says. It is for this reason that most servers use TeamSpeak to communicate. I personally prefer using the chat box. My other issue is that you can't use the direct connect feature - which prevents FSX:SE from playing online multiplayer with FSX Boxed. This was something dissapointing I found out when I tried playing with my friend - luckily, he recently purchased FSX:SE himself, so now we can do multiplayer! My last problem isn't with the multiplayer itself, but with the people. Many people on the SE multiplayer are less experienced than people who played the boxed edition. So if you want the most realistic ATC multiplayer possible, you may want to get VATSIM (which works great with FSX:SE BTW).

The graphics are nothing special, considering this game is over 10 years old. But I can ignore poor graphics if the gameplay is good, which the gameplay in FSX is OUTSTANDINGLY FUN!!! However, if you want improved graphics, they have addons for that.

The most notable thing about FSX:SE is how WELL it runs on my PC. My laptop is far from a gaming powerhouse, and it even struggles to run some of the most basic games at times. However, at times, I am getting maximum framerates on FSX:SE at high settings! FSX:SE is the most playable game on my PC by far, so if your PC is weak, don't worry, it will likely handle FSX:SE fine. Also, I'm running Windows 7.

In the end, FSX:SE is a great flight simulator. It has excited me for hours and taught me a lot about aviation in the process. It may have even inspired me to eventually get a real pilot's liscence! If you are a beginner or expert in flight simming, and you want an excellent flight simulator that will grow with you, then FSX:SE is the game for you. I give it a 9.5/10.

Tip: Be sure to pick up the game when it is on sale, as the price sometimes drops as low as $5.00!

There should be a somewhat recommend option, because that's how I'd sum the game up. It could be the best flight simulator out there, but it isn't and I'll get into the why it's good, and why it's bad with 4 points:

1st point: It's highly convenient. Microsoft set it up with simplicity in mind, it works well with both old and new joysticks, aircraft are set up to fly as soon as the game has loaded without any random surprises & it's highly modifiable with semi-competent knowhow required. If you're after complexity to rival the real world you can set that up too.

2nd point: The whole world is in the simulator, and is practically complete. Fly from seattle to Sydney with a stop off in Honolulu & you can see iconic buildings, entire downtown districts surrounded by their suburbs and dynamic weather if chosen to give you a near perfect realistic experience. The detail the microsoft team put in with the default game is unrivalled.

3rd point: The support online is huge. Add mods to update the games graphics to todays next-gen standards, or add to your library of flyable aircraft with hundreds, if not thousands of additional aircraft.

4th point: The age of the game is getting up there. Released in 2006, the last support for the game was in around 2007-08 before microsoft discontinued the series after disbanding the dev team. Dovetail games, the new publishers have been denied access by microsoft to modernise the internal code to utulise todays hardware. What this means for you is if your pc is newer than 2009, regardless of your pc's graphics power you will have performance issues. Stuttering, low framerate will be a plague unless you can tweak your system and the game's external code to fix performance, and these tweaks are different for each computer, requiring a high level of competency in knowing what you're doig. This is the biggest letdown & you can blame microsoft for that.

The other option is X plane 10, but that's not perfect either unfortunately. Watch that space though, the game developers are still highly active...

I already love this game. When I first bought FSX, I thought the technology of the plane would be too complicated for me, and that I wouldn't be able to enjoy the game due to me not having the throttle. I was wrong. While you do have lots of tech at your disposal (Especially in larger planes like the 747), most of the tech is optional. After watching a quick Youtube tutorial, I was already a pro! On my first take off(In Moscow), I crashed several times (but I had fun). Then I tried doing an actual flight, from Montreal (YUL), to Ottawa on a smaller plane (I tried with a 737, I failed), I enjoyed the beautiful and realistic views during the flight, I failed the landing. To this day, I still fail at landing. I remember doing a longer flight, going from Shanghai (Pudong) to the Japanese coast in a fighter jet, that is the farthest flight I have ever done. I love the game, I enjoy doing flights, seeing the beautiful and realistic views. This game is perfect for people that love exploring the world, the game is also good for people that like simulation games and people interested in aviation. I would recommend this game to any patient gamer. I give Microsoft Flight Simulator X an 8/10 realistic and very fun

Great game, graphics are amazing. I love the realism and compatibility with joysticks/controllers. I also like that there are over 24,000 destinations and that there are many different kinds of aircraft!

Unfortunately Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition requires you to run the program as administrator to function.  There are several kludges listed in the forums from "start Steam as Administrator" then "start fsx.exe as administrator" but who wants to have to do that each time and in this age of malware it isn't wise to do so.  I actually even get it to run using that method.  I actually had to change my account to admin privileges before I could get past the "Steam must be running", obviously not wise to do on a regular basis.  There are fixes listed in the forums for editing the manifest with visual studio, and forcing it to run as invoker: <requestedExecutionLevel level="asInvoker" uiAccess="false">,   However, I don't have visual studio on my home personal PC and don't want to go through that much trouble just to get a game started.  From a coding standpoint it sounds like the fix was rather simple - if VS was installed would take maybe 10 minutes. A slightly re-vamped version of the 2006 classic.  Dovetail Games have agreed distribution rights with Microsoft for this flight-sim and released it on Steam late 2014.  Along with the distribution rights they have been permitted sufficient access to the code to allow them to adjust and optimise the sim to better suit todays PC.  That having been said, this is [strike]still a single threaded[/strike] [i]a poorly optimised[/i] 32-bit application and even the most powerful of todays PC's struggle to attain "high" frame rates, especially when you start to include a few add-ons.

That brings me nicely on to the add-ons.  Due to the program being around since 2006 there is an unbelievable amount of DLC available for this sim, before you reach for your credit card though, make sure that the supplier specifies that it is compatible with FSX Steam Edition or the add-on is listed in the known compatible add-ons on the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/discussions/2/620703493312371968/]community page.[/url]

There are some very good add-ons that are free, there are some exceptional add-ons that cost quite a bit of money (A2A Simulations, PMDG) and there are add-ons that are free for limited functionality or can cost for full functionality (FSUIPC). The key is research, have a look at [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XUDrRR-VW-U]Jordan Kings Freeware Video[/url] to get an idea of what is possible for nothing more than bandwidth. Alternatively you can very quickly rack up a £100 or more spend and still think there is room for improvement (REX, Orbx).

A final word about add-ons. FSX requires you to generally get your hands dirty when adding features, if you don’t know your “%appdata%” from “My Documents” make sure you have fully researched the product you intend to buy and ensure you are comfortable with the installation procedure before you cough up the dough for it. This isn’t the case for the DLC that can be purchased from Steam, though I have to admit, most of the Steam DLC doesn’t appeal (see edit at the bottom).

Regardless of whether you stay with the stock program or buy enhancements, the core sim can give hours of enjoyment if you have an interest in aviation. Users range from the complete novice that has only sat in row 14F of an A320 (me), to fully licensed pilots (so it must be OK).

Although not a requirement, a joystick is recommended as well as a bit of patience and a lot of reading. You can jump into a Cessna 172 and lark about, or you can plan a flight for the same plane and follow, as close as can be reasonably expected in a 2006 sim, required procedures and protocols.  If, for example, you buy a PMDG add-on you have to calculate the fuel for the plane based on the number of passengers and their luggage, then you have to program the flight management computer and select your route, waypoints, approach etc. It must take 20 minutes or more to get to a point where you can actually start the engines! Alternatively you can just jump into a micro-light and be flying over Friday Harbor in a trice, the choice is yours.

Edit 18/12/15: DTG are introducing a number of add-ons that don't deserve my original comment. Examples are FTX Trees HD, REX Texture Direct 4, RAAS Pro, Accu-Feel and a couple of the aircraft.
