Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition (FSX:SE or simply FSX is commonly abbreviated by players) is a simple multiplayer or singleplayer game which falls into the genre of Simulation games, specifically Flight Simulation (if it isn't obvious already). In this game, you fly a plane in real-world terrain and airport layouts with real-time simulation.

Pros:
-Almost never crashes (on my system, anyways. See my system specifications listed below.)
-Real-world terrain, making you feel like you're a pilot.
-(Mostly) functional cockpit, which allows you to turn off engines, taxi lights, etc. There is also autopilot (both IFR and VFR).
-In-flight radio communications with audio in singleplayer. You can contact air traffic control towers and includes human speech (not ugly robotic sounds).
-Multiplayer support. Allows you to interact with other FSX players and plan group flights (commonly called 'hops') between  airports.
-Affordable for low-end machines (though I wouldn't recommend it much). You can still play it on lower-end machines and laptops if you can handle lower quality.
-Crashed only on one instance (for me, at least). It's when I open a new window when FSX is simulating a flight. I solved this issue by going into windowed mode (Alt+Enter).
-Missions. To challenge yourself.
-Public and Private Multiplayer. There are public servers, which are listed in the multiplayer window. Some are public but require passwords. There are also private servers, which can be accessed by entering one's IP address so you can play with your friends and without strangers.

Cons:
-LOTS of keyboard shortcuts. You're gonna have to get used to them.
-Can be hard to fly on your first days of flight. In my first days, I forced the turning too much and ended up crashing a lot of times. However, with some patience, you can easily fly a plane.
-Low quality terrain (though solvable with paid DLC). The terrain and airport's terrain are quite poor in quality. Though there are DLCs to solve this, they require money.

My opinions: If my playtime hasn't predicted what I'm about to say, then... here are my opinions.
It's the perfect non-combat full flight simulator and certainly the best one. I love the customizability (if not just a biiit pricey) but either way it's pretty realistic (though I've never been a pilot, so take that with a grain of salt). Multiplayer is smooth and the missions are really well coded and the voice acting is amazing! FSX probably has the best community, both on Steam and on its multiplayer.
I also like how it has Steam's direct messaging service built into it. I don't have to get out of the client to answer messages! Awesome!

RAM: 8GB Corsair Vengeance LP DDR3 RAM
HDD: Seagate 2TB HDD
GPU: ASUS GTX 660 Ti
Motherboard: MSI Z97S SLI Krait Edition

Coming from the boxed edition of FSX to FSX:SE I notice/experience very few improvement to the sim mostly on how CTD (crash to desktop) occurs, before I could hardly finish a long flight, now mostly I could. Still there are errors that occurs that results to CTD but not as often as before, but occurs rather randomly in different phase of the flight.

One very noticeable improvement is to the Piper J-3 Cub default aircraft, before you could hardly land it without ground looping even when there is no wind. 

As a bonus if you have invested on some add-ons the odds are you could still "add-it" without a problem or at least with minimal fuss, but of course not all of your add-ons will work.

Would not recommed to a casual user (non-techy), but I could still recommend this game to people who would not mind not having a constant update and who could in one way or the other resolve their own issues or thru other users.


P.S. Still hoping that DTG will continue to improve/update or to the very least maintain compatibility to newer OSes and modern hardwares.

Way back when, I used to play Microsoft Flight Simulator 2000 with actual CDs. A lot has changed since then. I’ve passed quite a few grades in school, I have a much more powerful system to play games on (I mean schoolwork… yes), and Steam is an integral part of my day to day activities.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623900512
What hasn’t really changed is Microsoft Flight Simulator. A lot of the elements, such as being a reasonably build product, hasn’t changed. MS Flight Simulator X is probably one of the last in a long line of flight simulators.

Being on Sale for 75% off I thought I might as well pay for the Premium version, it was less than if I was to just pay for the base game without any discount. Some of the DLC content is really just gimmicks, such as Rex Texture 4, which just changes runway textures at a cost of $27.99.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623827082
Going back to having a powerful system, I thought that a GTX 980Ti would be more than capable of maxing out settings while still providing a very high frame rate. I was kind of wrong in that department, as the game still uses the old DirectX 9. MS Flight Simulator X still has a lot of shaders and what not in DirectX 9, and even states “2.0 Ghz or higher (single core)” as a minimum requirement. Performance isn’t as great as I had hoped. Sure there is a DirectX 10 “preview” option (whatever that means) in the graphics settings, but that doesn’t really help out. A lot of DirectX 10 cards were in customer’s PCs before MS Flight Simulator X was put on the market, it’s just a shame that we will never see an update to address this.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623765534
Besides performance, graphics, and overpriced DLC, the core mechanics are great. I was surprised how easy the game was to play with just a keyboard and mouse – I did find myself using the keyboard instead of the mouse most of the time to fly however. It has certainly been a while since I’ve played a proper flight simulator, but I was piloting jet aircraft in a short period of time. If you were to actually play the game seriously, I would recommend buying a joystick at some point.

Microsoft Flight Simulator has been and still remains the gold standard of flight simulation. This version has, remarkably, been around since 2006, but has worn amazingly well. While it gets stiff competition nowadays from Prepar3D and X-Plane in particular, it can still more than hold its own.

For the purposes of this review, I am only going to concentrate on the default, "out-of-the-box" scenery and aircraft - in other words, what you first get when you buy this game. As is the case with P3D and X-Plane, there are numerous add-ons that can enhance the game enormously, but I think the fairest way to review a game like this is focus on what it comes with initially.

One thing I really love about Microsoft Flight Simulator X (hereinafter: FSX) is the extent to which it teaches you about the basics of flying. Quite aside from tutorial missions, there is a section called the "Learning Center" which has an incredible wealth of information. There are detailed instructions about how to fly each of the default aircraft, for instance. Then too there is a tab in the "Learning Center" called "Lessons". This will give you highly detailed "ground school" articles by professional flight instructor Rod Machado, along with practical lessons guided by Rod. You will learn the fundamentals of taking off, landing, turning, stalls, VOR/DME/ADF navigation, ILS landings and so much more besides. You can also do checkrides and, if you pass them, get a certificate that will go into your "Pilot Rewards" (an unnecessary but fun component of FSX).

"Boring," you may say. "I want to fly, not study!" Well, there's nothing stopping you from flying straight away if you want. (Indeed, I did.) But take it from me, repeatedly crashing because you have no clue about how to land a plane, or much of a clue about any aspect of flying, is not a lot of fun. Yes, it may take a bit of time to go through Rod Machado's lessons and study some of the other articles in the Learning Center, but it will enhance your experience of the sim enormously in the long run. And it is immensely satisfying when you apply what you have learned and begin to master new skills. FSX can, if you are willing to make the effort, train you in a way that its rival X-Plane will not. (I don't know about Prepar3D, so can't comment on how helpful or otherwise it is to flying and flight simming novices.)

There are two main ways you can play FSX. The first is "Free Flight". With this mode, you can select an airport and simply take off from it to go wherever. Or you can file a proper flight plan and fly from one airport to the next. If you change your mind mid-flight, just open up the appropriate menu and file another flight plan. You get pretty much the whole world - including Antarctica - to fly in. You also get plenty of noteworthy landmarks to see.

The other main playing mode is Missions. There is a great variety of different missions you can do, with difficulty levels ranging from "Beginner" to "Expert". Some of the missions seem a bit mis-classified though. Several of the "Beginner" lessons require some pretty advanced piloting skills, although you don't have to know about navigation or ATC interaction to fly them. In that sense, they are "Beginner" difficulty, but they're otherwise really hard. Other missions are more straightforward though. The missions are a good way to get acquainted with the different kinds of aircraft that FSX has to offer and see what types you like best (I discovered for instance that I really enjoy GA planes and airliners, but can take or leave helicopters and gliders aren't my scene at all). They are also a good way to challenge yourself in a variety of interesting situations. And if the default missions aren't to your liking or just aren't enough for you, there is no shortage of mission packs on offer (such as "Cargo Crew", "Arctic Rescue" and "Dangerous Approaches" available here on Steam). You get rewards for passing missions (nothing that special, just a "sticker" in your Pilot Records, but still, quite good fun).

Actually, there is also a third mode: Multiplayer. However, I have never used that, so can't comment on how good or otherwise it is. All I will say is that it doubtless adds another dimension if you want to use it.

Planning a flight couldn't get much easier in FSX. This process is very intuitive and easy to learn. I especially love the Navigation Log that is generated, and which you can refer to on your "Kneeboard" (press Shift + F10 for that) during a flight. Interacting with ATC is also very straightforward. The ATC window can be used to auto-tune your "comms" radio, although you can also quite easily tune radios manually if you want to do things more like a real pilot. Aircraft come with both 3D virtual cockpits and 2D panels. When you're in 2D mode, you can make mini-panels pop up (press Shift + 1, 2, 3 etc.) that give you access to things like the radio stack, throttle quadrant and overhead panel. Very handy, and saves a lot of fumbling around trying to find where things are.

As seriously awesome as this game is however, it is not without its faults. The "out-of-the-box" scenery of instance is pretty blah. Cities - especially less well-known ones - are not very accurately rendered, and the textures are decidedly average. Topography is one area where X-Plane 10 beats FSX hands-down. However, there are plenty of add-ons to improve the scenery (I especially recommend Orbx's FTX products), and at least FSX gives you buildings at airports, which certainly can't be said for X-Plane in a lot of cases! In flight dynamics too, FSX can be a bit ho-hum, especially when it comes to helicopters. Taxiing can also be rather fiddly. The "Pilot Records" section is a bit of a mess. It would be nice if some real airlines were represented rather than just generic ones (although it's quite easy to add new liveries). And because FSX is so old, it is only capable of running in 32-bit mode, which means that it tends to struggle with more sophisticated add-ons. 

That said, there is a vast amount of add-ons out there, and you can do a tremendous amount to FSX without breaking it. But the more advanced computers become and the more sophisticated add-ons get, the more FSX will struggle in the future. For now though, it still works very well and there are so many great ways to enhance it. Steam alone offers a lot of great add-ons, but there are more to discover at places like The FlightSim Store or Just Flight. No shortage of freeware to be found either (check the AVSIM Library for instance).

Another thing I sometimes struggle with is visibility. However, a neat trick I have discovered is to open a "mini-window" while in 2D panel mode and set this "mini-window" to Outside Spot view. This way, I can keep an eye on my instruments while being able to see easily to taxi or land. Best of both worlds!

All in all, I recommend Microsoft Flight Simulator X very highly indeed. If you are new to flight simming and flying generally, as I was when I bought this game a little over a year ago, this game, with its Learning Center, will teach you a tremendous amount. It gives you a far better grounding in the basics of flying than X-Plane, which is really designed for people who already have a reasonable amount of experience. (Again, I don't know how novice-friendly or otherwise Prepar3D is.) And once you have grasped the fundamentals of flying, there is no end of fun to be had and discoveries to make. Be warned though that it is quite addictive once you master it (also the case with real flying, so I've heard), and while the basic game is very cheap (certainly a better deal initially than X-Plane or Prepar3D), your wallet can still suffer as you chase after add-ons to further fuel your virtual flying addiction. You may or may not be in love with flying (virtually or otherwise) now, but once you have played FSX, you will be!

Really like this game, I discovered it through the boxed edition a while back, then switched to FSX-SE a few months ago on my new rig. No problem so far, integration into the Steam platform and community around is really great. I use external addons (like ORBX suite, REX4) and DLC addons, both work well. Eventually, having the game and its extensions in a cloud storage is a great advantage, and easier to use for the end user.  

Concerning FSX, the fact that a 10 years old game remains on the spot and still creates so much interest is enough to say. The real strength pertains to its open platform. I am not even an enthusiast, I'm just a guy who likes planes. I like flying in them, I like watching them, I like the experience. So a flight sim let's me fly around and explore my city. I can hop from airport to airport. It's almost a sandbox exploration game to that effect.

The roads, rivers, and lakes are done in surprisingly well detail. The buildings, not so much. Don't expect too much there.

I'm sure this doesn't quite compare to better sims out there, but to someone who just likes to fly around and explore, it's really fun. You don't even really have to know too much about flying a plane either, if you stick to something simple like a cessna or ultralight. Once you start getting into the bigger planes, then you need to know how to do flaps and gear and trim and stuff like that. Meh, I prefer a more "arcade" setting.

So if you're interested in what I'm interested in, you'll probably like this game and it's not very expensive for what you get.

Bringing the FSX world to Steam, making the game playable for Windows 10 made it so I could finally upgrade from Windows 7. It has kept the same level of realism and compatibility with most after market add ons. I have not had any problems adding Blue Sky Scenery with helps the ground realism (in select areas) greatly, while also adding many vintage warbirds for truly exciting flying.
The added attraction of the multiplayer capability makes an interesting new dimension to flight, where you have to avoid other fliers that may maneuver irregularly. The only drawback to the multiplayer realm is that you get an interpreted display of other's aircraft unless you have the exact same plane installed, with precisely the same name on your system. With there being literally tens of thousands of add-on aircraft and helicopters out there it makes it a guarantee that many, perhaps MOST, will be flying something entirely other than what you see. If there was some way to have the game transmit the appearance of the plane you are flying so others see you as you are, this would add a level of realism that would have me in multiplayer every time I fly.
I truly enjoy the level of realism FSX has over older versions of Flight Simulator. I've been flying various versions for 27 years and having it available in Windows 10 means that I will still have many more years to enjoy this simulation.
I've been using it for many years, but it's one of those games that needs addons for an experience.

In real life, I'm a beginner pilot. To begin with, this game feels more like a "adjust your seat and field of view" simulator, than an actual flight simulator. I can't even comment on the simulation much, as I've only just got the game set up properly, although it seems very good from the 50+ hours I put up with the default view and flew around in the non steam version of this game.

When you first start the game, your field of view will be so far zoomed in you'll feel like a blinkered horse with its face smeared against the inside of the cockpit windscreen. If you want to look at your instruments (airspeed, altimeter, DI etc), you have to take your eyes completely off the horizon. VFR flight from the default view is damn near impossible.

To fix this, go to the game's settings, and note the key bindings for moving your eyepoint backwards (by default: Ctrl + Enter) and downwards (by default: SHIFT + Backspace). In your config files (Appdata\Roaming\Microsoft\FSX), open fsx.cfg in Notepad and set WideViewAspect to True (erase "False" and type "True". In the Cameras.cfg, under camera002, set InitialZoom to 0.3, so you have a bearable field of view (you can do this in-flight by holding the spacebar and scrolling the mouse wheel back).
Once you get in-flight, use the aforementioned eyepoint key bindings to move your view as you would like it, and if you hold the spacebar, you can use the mouse to move your view. When you let go of the spacebar, your view is locked there. Very handy IMO.

If you're hardcore and want all the options in-flight, an Xbox 360 controller doesn't really have enough buttons. You'll have enough bindings for your throttle, control surfaces, and I even set pitch and rudder trim, but if you want to mess with landing lights, carb heat, fuel mixtures, individual engine throttles etc, you'll need to mess with the keyboard bindings or invest in a proper flight joystick.
Sadly the game counts the keyboard's num pad buttons and the home, end, page up, page down, and arrow keys as the same thing, so you lose some key bindings there.

However once you've set everything up, this game is fantastic.
Good for people who want to be a pilot.

developer_response:
If you are having problems running Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition on your PC KingNyan please try the following steps:

[b]Verifying your game files on Steam[/b]
This causes Steam to compare all the Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition files installed on your computer against the ones it believes you should have. If any are missing Steam will update and download them. In order to complete this procedure you will need to be connected to the Internet. 

To verify you game files please do the following:

1.	Load the Steam platform and log into your account
2.	Click the Library tab in the menu at the top of the screen
3.	Click the List View from the view options on the top right of the screen
4.	Right click on Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to bring up a popup menu
5.	Click on Properties from the popup menu to bring up another popup box
6.	Click on Local files from the popup box menu
7.	Click on Verify integrity of game cache from the Local file options
8.	Wait for the progress bar to finish verifying your files. Additional files may download
9.	Restart Steam
10.	Restart Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition 

[b]Free up your computer’s memory[/b]
Running lots of different programs in Windows at the same time may mean that Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition does not have enough memory available to run correctly. Your computer might be displaying an Out of memory error as a result. 

Please try the following steps:

1.	Check that your PC meets the minimum memory requirements to run Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition. The game requires 2 GB RAM to run. If you have less than the require 2 GB RAM then you will be unable to run the game. 
2.	Press Ctrl+Alt+Delete on your keyboard and select Task manager from the list options. Click on the Applications tab in the task manager to see all of the programs currently running in Windows. Shut down any additional programs you have running. Even if you have not started any programs running Widows may launch certain ones upon start up. Please refer to the Windows help files for more information about enabling and disabling programs when Windows starts. The less programs you have running the more memory will be available for Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to use. 

[b]Reinstall Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition[/b] 
Steam provides the ability to reinstall the game to the default system. To perform this reinstallation, you should perform the following steps:

1.	Sign out off Steam
2.	Backup the disk containing your FSX installation
3.	Delete the contents of "<drive:>\Program files (x86)\ Steam\SteamApps\Common\FSX\" and all subdirectories
4.	Log on to Steam
5.	Select "View Games Library" from the "Games" menu
6.	Right-click the Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition icon and select "Properties"
7.	Select the "Local Files" tab and click on "Verify Integrity of Games Cache"

If you are still experiencing issues you can reach us via our dedicated support website: 

http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/

If you drop us a message a member of our team will get back to you as soon as possible with some advice. 

Thank you for your review and we are sorry for any inconvenience these unexpected issues may of caused you.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

TL;DR: It's basically the same simulator that Microsoft published in October 2006. See the chapter about differences if you're not new to FSX.

[h1]Long version:[/h1]

Those who don't know the series, should know that Flight simulator X is called FSX by short. 

I've been using flight sim software for a long time now, and actually got the FSX: Gold edition for free from Microsoft in 2006, so i have spent some hours (about 1500-2000) in this before it was released on steam. 

In this review i will focus on FSX: Steam edition as a game presented for new users, and then point out the differences between the Steam edition and the regular one that was published in 2006. 

[h1]Flight Simulator for new users:[/h1]

To be fair, if you only want to play FSX for casual arcadeish gameplay, crashing planes and so on [b]DON'T BUY THIS[/b].
If you have checked out FSX on youtube and found HD videos of big living Airports, shiny ultra realistic planes, and other things that look very realistic, and think that this is what the "game" is, then [b]DON'T BUY THIS[/b]. These videos is a result of many add-ons, a beast of a machine, several short clips, and a lot of editing. They look incredible, but doesn't represent FSX for what it is. 

But if you are new to flight simulators and want to learn the basics of flying, and/or want to learn how to fly by instrument rules, or knows how to fly and want to fly from/to locations you know, you should buy this!

[b]A short list of what this simulator has to offer from stock:[/b]

Pros:
- It includes the whole world, with almost every airport (some big cities, but mostly blocky buildings at airpots).
- Decent flight model (How the airplane reacts to the world)
- Extreme rate of customization (see add-on chapter below)
- Many settings that allow anything from basic to advanced flights
- Decent amount of stock airplanes.

Cons:
- 32-bit architecture/VAS (See Add-on chapter)
- Poor performance (Very CPU demanding, and not forgiving for AMD users)
- Stock planes (very basic and does not represent the real aircraft very good)
- Add-ons (see chapter below)

[h1] Add-ons [/h1]

Flight simulator must be the sim with the most add-ons in the world. It's amazing how many developers that make things for FSX. Without the add-ons i would NOT recommend this simulator. An example of what add-ons you can buy/get is:

- [b]Airplanes:[/b] Anything from basic free planes, to really advanced and realistic airplanes like the Majestic Dash-8 Q400 or PMDG 737 NGX. 
- [b]Scenery (Landscape/Cities/Airports):[/b] Anything from free fan-made stuff, to professionally made add-ons from companies like Orbx FTX, Aerosoft, Flight1, and so on. 
- [b]Weather/Textures:[/b] Like with Airplanes and Scenery you can get a lot of other software to boost the quality of the weather system (new textures and possibilities to get the real world weather), ground and water textures. 
- [b]Tools/Mission packs:[/b] You can also get a lot of mission-packs, and other tools. Both freeware and payware. 


[b]Add-on cons:[/b]

Even tho FSX is nothing without it's add-ons, it's still many problems with them. Often to get what you really want, you need to pay a lot of money to buy all the good add-ons. And there is also the fact that the more add-ons you add to FSX the slower it loads. Some add-ons also cause problems with other add-ons installed (from minor bugs to FSX not starting at all). This happens more often with freeware add-ons than payware add-ons. 

Also because of the poor performance in FSX, and the fact that it's heavy CPU demanding (I got an 4Ghz AMD 8-core processor) you might not get to a playable framerate if you have combine a detailed airport with for example the PMDG 737 NGX (6-10 FPS). If you run Intel you will get a much better performance because of the logical cores in the intel processor.  

Also; Remember that this version of FSX is called FSX: Steam edition. Even though every add-on for FSX should work on FSX:SE, some might have problems if not optimized for FSX:SE

[b] 32-bit architecture / VAS [/b] 

[i]Disclaimer: Im no expert on how the architecture of software works, nor how VAS is built. The following are own experiences and forum research to find a solution to this problem.[/i]

The biggest achilles heel that haunt allmost every FSX user is VAS (Virtual Access Space). Im not going to go in detail on what it is and how it works, but i will tell you the basics, and it's limitations.

VAS is basically virtual memory (Note: this does not equal RAM, nor harddrive space). Each program you run gets it's own chunk of VAS that it can fill up. If the VAS limit is exceeded the program will STOP WORKING with the well known "Out of Memory" (OOM) error. 

FSX is built on the old 32-bit architecture. This limits the programs VAS to about 4GB. This becomes a major problem when you start putting add-ons in FSX. Too many add-ons, or add-ons that is poorly optimized will push the VAS limit and cause an OOM. 

The VAS will fill up over time. An example: FSX base game will take about 1,2 GB. When loaded into the world you will be at aprox 2 GB VAS. You then have a fancy add-on airport that takes about 300MB, and an add-on airplane that takes about 350MB. You then start flying with a VAS at 2,6GB. No problem you think? You take off and fly towards the destination, that is on the other side of the country. On your way you fly over 4-5 other add-on airports, and your VAS is suddenly 3,7GB. Then you reach your destination, and on final, about to land you hear a "DING", with a message telling you "Out of memory", and FSX quit. 

Another problem with the VAS is that it doesn't clear it's memory when you don't need it anymore. So if you fly a short trip from airport A to airport B where you reach 3,2GB VAS usage, and then start another flight from airport C, your VAS will still be 3,2GB. 

FSX Users have several solutions to avoid this error, like for exampel using a program to monitor their VAS so they can save the flight and restart FSX. Another solution is to deactivate all the scenery you don't need for the flight. Also, the AI traffic fills up the VAS, so be sure to have this set to 0%. Some developers also run the core of their add-on in windows and not FSX to save VAS usage. 

Other than that, it is NOT possible to fix this issue, other than developing a new simulator that uses a 64-bit architecture and allow higher VAS usage. 

[h1]Difference between FSX and FSX:SE[/h1]

If you are a long-time user of FSX and wonder if you should buy the steam edition, the answer is maybe. 

I will list the main differences i've found between FSX and FSX: Steam edition:

- FSX:SE is a re-released FSX: Gold edition, so all servicepacks are included
- FSX:SE uses Steamworx for multiplayer. FSX used gamespy (no longer supported after february 2013)
- FSX:SE can be installed on every computer you own using steam, and no CD-key required. Every FSX disc have a maximum installation limit of 5 before the disc is useless, and you had to save the CD-key.
- FSX:SE is still supported and receives updates. Microsoft doesn't support FSX anymore.
- Some bugs from FSX is fixed, and FSX:SE is tweaked to run better on modern computers.
- FSX:SE does however NOT include the SDK that's included in FSX.

There might be even more differences that i haven't noticed/forgot about when i wrote this.

Overall it runs slightly better than FSX, and when i finally had to reinstall FSX i landed on using the steam edition. 

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

I recommend FSX:SE because of all the add-ons from FSX, and that there are few other decent options out there. You should also check out x-plane 10 and P3D (Lockheed-martins version of FSX).

I have been a simmer for twenty years. the issues with FS9 and FSX are simple.  Microsoft stopped further development of the base platforms, which failed to keep up  with the progress of the computers on which they run. The most recent problem for me has been compatability issues around windows 10. I have re installed a clean windows seven and started again. I have downloaded FSX Steam and bought the FSX Steam CD's ( I have always preferred to keep the disks, there's something comforting about not having to rely on the  downloads).  I am writing simply to say that Dovetail / Steam has done a terrific job with the Flight Sim base programme which gives me better frame rates and an ability to re - install all that I have wanted to from my extensive library of add ons. I have learned that it can be a real challenge with some of the installs and finding your way into the FSX files has been a bit clumsy (so that I can install directly into the file instead of trying to run an install, which older add -ons can't navigate). I will try and get some images out there for any other Brize geeks. Happy Simming Rob C.

Intel core i5-5200U
8gb ram

Windows 10
Intel HD 5500 Integrated graphics - yes, thats right, INTEGRATED GRAPHICS!!! not some fancy expensive graphics card.

I originally wrote a long-winded review on this title, with the developer actually replying in an obviously scripted manor.  Needless to say, in the months since nothing has changed.  Starting out with the game, don’t let the title fool you because this new "edition" is the same Flight Simulator X that’s been around for over 10 years.  There is nothing additional added.  There are no additional default aircraft, the scenery isn't better, it' only some minor workarounds that have been done.  Let me explain that further…

While Microsoft is still the developer of FSX, Dovetail Games has taken over as a “publisher” for this title.  Now, it might sound a little unclear but here’s the facts surrounding Dovetail’s involvement.  They’ve done some work on the multiplayer aspects of the game, making it once again “functional”.  Not that you couldn’t play multiplayer before Dovetail got involved.  You just needed a 3rd party program and a little instruction from a Google search to get connected with your friends.  Now, due to Dovetail's involvement, that method of multiplayer has been blocked so they can provide a centeral hub for all games.  They also made the game “Steam Compatible”, which is another way of saying they modified the game so DLC could be directly installed by Steam.  That said…

When you discuss the core of the game, nothing has changed.  The scenery is still the same.  The default aircrafts are still the same.  The interface is still the same.  It’s all the same as it was 10 years ago.  Nothing has changed or been added to this new "edition".  There have been no noticeable improvements, quite the contrary.  New bugs have crept up that cause the game to occasionally crash.  This coming from someone who has had the original FSX since it originally launched.  So why would Dovetail resurrect a game that is 10 years old when Microsoft itself doesn’t see fit to keep on the store shelves?

To answer that question you only have to browse other simulation titles by Dovetail.  The company is the kings of DLC content.  Look at their Train Simulator 2016 game.  There is very little content included with the actual game yet the cost of all the DLC for it, 232 items, comes in at close to 3 THOUSAND DOLLARS!  The DLC for Flight Simulator X is a little more tame, only around $650 for all of it, but that's still fairly ridiculous considering nothing has been added to the new "edition".  THIS is the main focus of Dovetail bringing FSX to Steam.  It’s not to make improvements to the game.  It’s not to fix the glaring bugs they've added and fix the outdated graphics.  It’s to sell DLC so they can make a quick buck off an old (and relatively dead) title.

If you already own Flight Simulator X… DO NOT BUY!
If you’re on the fence… DO NOT BUY!
If you expect new scenery… DO NOT BUY!
if you expect more aircraft… DO NOT BUY!

There is ONLY ONE reason you should ever consider buying this Steam version.  It’s the same reason I bought it.  Because I already have a large library of free FSX content that I’ve gathered over the past years, my DVD’s were damaged somehow, and this is the only way I can now reinstall FSX.  Don’t let my play-time fool you.  If I could have avoided buying this buggy Steam version and stuck with my original FSX, I would have.

Update: the game now works perfect, after 11 months being uninstalled they seemed to have fixed the old issues. i can now recommend this game.

A good game, featuring a wide selection of quality aircraft for free, a world-wide map of considerable accuracy and infinite modabiliy. However, it is not very friendly to non-yoke/joystick owners. It's strongly recommended that players of this game consider purchasing a flight simulator yoke or joystick; though i personally prefer the CH Controls Yoke.

I also feel it is worth mentioning that my weak laptop runs the game perfectly, even with the PMDG 737-800. Many, I note our daunted by the apparent dramatic system requirements of simulators- yet it is worth mentioning that this game easily maintains strong preformance even on my pathetic laptop- wether it be minimum or maximum settings. 

An unfortunate downside of the game is that modding it can be difficult, and for those seeking to get a much more advanced/shiny preformance on their computers, you may have to devote serious time and effort to getting the pretty landscape or shiny aircraft you want. Though the PMDG products simply used an installer, few mods have this liberty.

Overall, especially when on sale (like now, 12/23/15) for four dollars, it is most certainly well worth the purchase.

I am a pilot and a retired flight test engineer for a major Flight Training company that also builds "real" flight simulators.   I've owned all the versions of Microsoft Flight Simulator over the years and was very disappointed when Microsoft abandoned the Flight Simulation world back in 2008 or so.  When I recently bought a new Laptop and also upgraded my Desktop to Windows 10, I discovered that I couldn't get my MS Flight Simulator X DVS's to load on either computer.  I also discovered that it was impossible to find new MSFSX new anywhere, in stores or on line.  I hadn't even heard of STEAM but my 14 year old grandson did, so we went there and I decided to get the Steam Version.  Well, what a disappointment.  Not so much with the software, which so far seems to mostly work on the laptop but more with the horrible interface that is STEAM.  I'm not exactly what STEAM is other than a venue to distribute aging software titles, while offering little or absolutely no support along the way.  I guess when you're a kid, you have no choice in the matter and you really don't know what decent customer service is, or should be.   

I have a IPhone and an iPAD and, although I'm not much of an Apple fan (I prefer the open architecture of the PC platform over the Apple), I am very impressed with the APP STORE.  But, trust me. STEAM is no APP STORE.

The Flight Simulator X program is at least as good as it always was (originally).  Having to log in the Steam to use it, really sucks.

I highly recommend this to anyone who llikes flying planes and helicopters.

I wonder if this game is only a loader for components and libraries for which you have to pay for+sceneries. I moved from old MSFS versions(early 90s, more realistic systems) to X-Plane and i'd like to try FSX because it was for few bucks.

Realism of sceneries is quite a good for flightsim and i definitely like it, but realism of controls/systems in default models (even cessna) is far from realistic. I cannot setup circuit breakers, disable alt and or bat power, omg even fuel valve, open the door etc. Some of those procedures are in basic checklists! And it is damn simple cessna skyhawk!. Even open source simulator alternatives are more precise. How can you motivate young pilots with this junk?

When i crash, i simply crash and nothing is torn apart. No damage seen. But this is what i've expected from FSX. Its 20 years old concept.

Default aeroplanes like boeing or airbus are crappy. For example in airbus if i disable engines, the power from batteries are not depleting, many essential switches like electrical system are not active or they are not working at all. I know this is free variant included so i am not expecting FMC or pressurization system controls. But with basic model you have to be able perform basic checklists to motivate you for buying more sophisticated models. I am not expecting every system controllable on default model, but basic checklist components even on small aeroplanes are not working. 

Game acts to me as simulator framework with sceneries and a few hello world examples (default models). It is worth of 5 in discount but definitely not 25. If you want to start seriously, then i suggest to buy even older version of X-Plane for similar price or spend money(it hurts i know, but pilot training cost much more then X-Plane+HW:) to new version X-Plane. 

BTW: I remember funny situation when i tried to push fire extinguisher to on of my engines and they are able to start again:)))

developer_response:
Hi NinjaBeest, thanks for writing us a review. 

As you correctly point out Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is a highly detailed and realistic simulator. It is not something you can just pick up and master in a few hours. There is certainly a lot to learn. 

If you are interested in developing your pilot skills you can simulate flight lessons with professional flight instructor Rod Machado. To access them click:

1. On the Main menu, click Learning Centre.
2. Click the Lessons tab.

That all said, we understand that simulation is not for everyone and that some players may prefer a more arcade type of experience. In which case we agree with you, this is probably not the game you are looking for. 

Thanks again for taking the time to write us a review. 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team 
Dovetail Games

review:
I will split this into a quick Good points Bad points and Neutral points, with a final conclusion at the end!

Good:

Highly Realistic simulation of aircraft
Great Price on offer
Active Multiplayer community
Lots of easy to follow lessons and missions
Free flight mode allowing you to plan and carry out your own flights.
Millions of addons available on the web (I do not recommend any of the DLC aircraft listed on steam personally)

Bad:

To get realistic planes you are looking at around $30 to get the Airbus or $70 for the pmdg, the default ones simply aren't that great.

Outdated graphics don't look that great.

Extremely unoptimized, people with GTX titans can sometimes get 15 fps from a 10 year old game.

CPU hog

Multiplayer is quite unrealiable



Overall

Microsoft Flight Simulator is still the leading product of Aviation simulation to this date, it is quite frankly amazing, but the fact that the market for a game like this is so small means that we will have to cope with the older engines as this is it as far as the FS series goes, however you cannot blame the devs for work done 10 years ago when this would of truly been a even more amazing example of simulation technology

9/10

Planes are nice and easy to control even though I use a cruddy 3d extrme pro joystick. The game is a tad dated, but still does what it was made for: Being a damn good accurate/reliable flying simulator.

The geography is a little bland, but from what I've seen on youtube, you can change this incredibly, thanks to fsx's scenery management options.

You get a very fair amount of planes to choose from, not like other crappy flying sims that give you 2 planes to choose from and charge 10 dollar per plane.  You get around 20-30 planes, varying from holiday trikes to fighter jets. The virtual cockpits are also unique to each plane.

The atc system, wheather, flight plan system/design, tutorials, information etc... Are pretty polished. If the new tutorials didn't explain enough for you, they've got another section of tutorials from the older msfs games, which is PLENTY to wet your whistle.

10/10.

I don't even know where to start. The game itself isn't bad; I've had the disc version for years and I loved it. One lost install key and a hard drive crash later, though, and I was stuck with this.
Here's the SHORT list of everything wrong with this game:
-Dovetail gave it their signature laundry list of overpriced DLC. On games like TrainSim, you at least know you're paying for good stuff, but on this, it seems DT is just adding in a bunch of low-quality payware and even former-freeware addons at a ludicrous markup.
-To ensure their profits keep coming in, DT ensured that there would be enough tweaks to the game's code so that it rendered most third-party addons incompatible. (chief among which being VRS' TacPack)
-The multiplayer community is a shadow of its former self. While this isn't Dovetail's fault, they could certainly do a lot more to promote the multiplayer experience. There seem to be a lot of military groups; why not add an AWACS to their mile-long list of DLC?

To sum it up, I'd say that if you're already familiar with this game, go ahead and buy this. But if you're a first-timer, don't waste your money. Get something else, like X-Plane or even Prepar3D if you can spare the extra cash.

Even though released in 2006 and thus a bit dated, FSX is still one of the 3 most played flight simulators.

Flight Simulator X offers different grades of realism for differend kinds of players, newcomers and professionals alike. Luckily, the Steam Edition also includes the "Acceleration" Add-On, which added a bunch of content.

FSX is great to boot up and take a short flight or spend several hours with, although the default aircraft aren't as detailed, there is tons of Add-On content out there, both free and payware. With it's plug and play system for new content, FSX made it incredibly easy to develop more, and most importantly, realistic content for. From aircraft that couldn't get closer to reality, with detailed cockpits and every switch working as it does in real life, to amazingly detailed scenery and sounds. Latter is often found in payware content, though.

There is also a multiplayer mode, so you can fly with your friends or strangers and even have real people in charge of ATC. If you want it even more realistic, you can join VATSIM, a network dedicated to giving you the most realistic flight experience right at home.

[h1]However, FSX is still the most accessible flight simulator out there, and even though it has aged a little, it's still a lot of fun to play no matter if you're an airplane enthusiast, or just want to fly planes. [/h1]

For People who plan on using their sims for serious matters:

Why I do NOT recommend it:
If you are one who wants to make their simming experience as realistic as possible, I would NOT recommend this "game". At least when it comes to the feel of it The reason for quoting it as a "game" is because people who are serious about flying, don't want a game, they want a Simulator. FSX (SE) has been long debated wether it is a true Simulator or just a game. Of course there are always people who want to defend what they are used to and so you'll have mixed reviews. Truly, the flight controls, no matter how much you tweak this game or purchase more add-ons, will always be less realistic. This game doesn't feel like flying a real plane. It's close, but not quite there. Also, the standalone aircraft are absolutely obsolete. there is no way of learning much about an aircrafts systems when flying these planes. If having the feel of flying and being more into a planes systems without purchasing 3rd party Add-Ons is important to you, I'd reccommend X-Plane 10. The wise choice is to not go for this game when taking things more suriously but I also do. 

Why I recommend it: 
FSX, because it is so old, has made a lot of progress. The game itself is already a fun experience but when truly taking things suriously, one can just purchase 3rd Party Add-ons. I will be honest, if one plans on purchasing them, this game is a must for you. There are highly realistic replicas to real aircaft to buy that are absolutely a great experience. Such as the famous PMDG developers or A2A, RealAir. Then others such as ASN, REX and FSUIPC. If you have this kind of money, this game is perfect for you because such complex simulations do exist, but for a price. 

Summary:

Reasons not to buy:
- When wanting to get to know how flying a plane feels like
- When not wanting to spend more money to learn about an aircraft's system

Reasons why to buy:
- If you have the money, the best 3rd Part Add-ons exist and are great for learning a planes systems
such as: PMDG, A2A, RealAir

All factors can be important but overall, for what I look for in a sim, I'd recommend FSX (SE) more. The reason is because I find learning the systems before flying is more important. I do have the money to purchase 3rd Part add-ons and do. I own many nice Aircraft which have tought me great things. I also own X-Plane 10 and use it if wanting to practice Hands-on flying. Of course I also own 3rd Party add-ons for X-Plane. With about 6-7 years of simming in my life and 4800 hours of flying experience, I am happy to share my thoughts about this game.

Review/How I made the game a good experince
Flight Simulator X, for the price is a truly amazing simulator. When you account for its true age (10/2006) it makes it even more astonishing. While only being on steam for a short while most of the modding community have embraced it although I will go into detail with this later.

The unmodified experience is great, until you start getting into it more. For my first 100-120 hours I was playing with just the base game planes and free online mods and it was plenty of fun. But once you decide to really get into it, say hello to montly subscriptions, goodbye to $500+ in addons and much more!
Here is my summary though.

Air Traffic Control:
The Air Traffic Control in hine sight is terrible but I never knew at the time not with only being new to the community, now I am a member of Vatsim and a paying customer of PilotEdge to get online ATC which greatly improves your experience.

Planes:
After that is sorted you get into the issue of planes. If you are happy with the stock planes, I urge you to continue using them because once you decide to expand on your library and get premium planes you struggle to go back to the limited ones. When purchasing planes also dont go crazy on your first purchase, and buy adverage planes. My first payware plane was the Just Flight Boeing 737-200Adv. and it is alright but as I continued to advance I discovered the wonderful world of PMDG. They are from my understanding the best addon company for planes on the market. I started off with their flagship, the 777-200LR/F package, a truly fantastic plane and then advanced to purchase the BAe 41 Jetstream which is where I run into my first truly major con of Steam Edtion. I learnt the hard way that not every mod is compatable with Steam Edition, and I can not urge you enough to ensure that any mod you purchase clearly states that it is supported because spending $50 on a unsupported mod does not make you happy (There are work arounds but it is not perfect). I am now wanting to add few more planes to my fleet then will be happy with that department.

Scenary:
I am yet to purchase scenary mods because I personally like to fly all over the world so purchasing scenary is just not going to work for me yet. But the option is there and the built in stuff is terrible but changing it costs a lot. If you fly in one area and VFR a lot then I couldnt recommend anything better.

Gameplay Mods:
The final polish in my opinion is mods like GSX (Ground Services), FS2Crew (Co-Pilot/Voice control), FSIPanel (Training) and many others that just add so much to the overall experince. GSX was the first thing I added to my collection because it makes all the time you spend on the ground a little bit more fun and the I got FS2Crew with my 777 which makes the games fantastic. FSIPanel is new to my collection and I am still to really play around with it but it will help make me a much better pilot. I also have mods like FSPassengers which add a goal to the game, to run an airline but that didn't appeal to me much. It will make some people enjoy it a lot more though. These either mean a lot to you or just about nothing, but to me these are probably the most important.

Conclusion:
I get asked a lot how do you have so many hours in that game. I reply I dont know :P At first look it looks boring but once you really get into it and put the time into planning out what you are going to do, roleplay and do it it is really damn fun. It has cost me a lot to get it to where i have it and it was not easy, trail and error like anything I guess.
This game is not for everyone but I can not suggest it more to anyone that is really into planes.
I really like the game, but i dont like that you cant add 3rd party games to it. LIke flight simulator FS passengers, or I can even fly with a virtual airline. I hope this gets fixed fast.

I've had this program for a couple of months now, and I'd highly recommend the steam version of FSX. They've done an excellent job of updating and integrating a very old flight simulator. I've bought quite a few add-ons for the program, and I haven't had any significant issues getting them to work, even when installing them to another drive and pointing back to the Steam FSX folder. So far I've installed Orbx FTX Global Base, Vector Global, PNW and NCA and Australia scenery upgrades, several of the Orbx airports; PFE ATC program, MyTraffic 6 (a little bit of an odd install, but it works well), REX Cloud textures (though the full REX weather engine didn't seem to like FSX:SE very well), an unregistered version of FSUIPC, and finally, and my favorite by far, A2A's Cessna 172 Trainer. It's amazing and has worked nearly flawlessly with FSX: SE.

I tried X-Plane 10 (and reviewed it separately), but even with it being a much newer simulator, and over twice the cost on Steam, FSX to me does a much better job of conveying the realities of flying, at least as much as a simulator can. The A2A Cessna helps a lot with that as well. I'm currently about a third of the way on a virtual flight around the world in the 172, and loving nearly every minute of it (though an 8 hour flight over Siberia between runways was tedious at best).

I haven't run into any showstoppers so far, fingers crossed, and enjoying FSX:SE very much.

I used (and still have) the boxed FSX. I was disappointed to discover that the boxed version was very glitchy and buggy on Windows 8 and 8.1. Then I saw this on sale - £2.89!

This works MUCH better than the boxed version. Now time for the pros and cons:

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
• Less glitchy on newer systems
• Fixed major bugs and applied common fixes (e.g. HIGHMEMFIX)
• Ongoing support from DTG (Dovetail Games)
• Steam forums
• Add-ons available fom Steam
• Most freeware and payware works
• [u][b]SALES!!! [/b] [/u]
• Steam Multiplayer*

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
• Some 3rd party add-ons don't work
• Might crash on older systems (e.g. Windows Vista, Windows XP, etc.)
• [u][b]ALWAYS[/b][/u] requires an active internet connection to start the game. (DTG are going to make a workaround for this... hopefully sometime soon!)
• [b][u]NOT[/u][/b] backwards compatible with FSX Boxed multiplayer sessions.

All in all, this version of FSX is great for new systems and new hardware, but, if you don't mind the bugs, and all your friends have FSX boxed, you might want to get that and this so that you can play with them as well.

*Not backwards compatible with FSX Boxed multiplayer sessions.

developer_response:
Hello TheNavigator25, thank you for the Steam review. 

FSX: SE is indeed compatible with Windows 10. 

Windows 10 is a brand new operating system, and like all new OS, a few problems are likely to pop up. Likewise, many graphic and sound card makers are yet to release driver updates which are compatible with Windows 10. Things will get better, however it will take a little time. We understand that this doesn’t stop the situation being any less frustrating when you are experiencing unexpected problems.

We have compiled a list of possible fixes if  you are having issues running FSX: Steam Edition on Windows 10. While these fixes may solve the majority of problems, we cannot guarantee they will work for everyone. 

Please see either [url=https://fsxinsider.com/windows-10-fsx-steam-edition]FSXinsider[/url] or our [url=http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/Knowledgebase/Article/View/160/14/windows-10---fsx-se-advice]support website[/url] for the list of recommended fixes. 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team 
Dovetail Games

The eyeview point advances and recedes when advancing or retarding the throttle. The Caravan model is distorted to the point where it is imossible to see the wing or struts when the view is panned, the top frame of the door appearing at chest level. The view menu no longer includes magnifaction. The initial setup is finnicky and certain settings are lost when the program is closed.
 Compared with 2004 which ran perfectly satisfactorily on the present setup; this installation is, in gardener's terms, a pot of  crock; which incidently, we get for free at the local garden centre. Never been bitten by a 20 pound note before. Mus'n't grumble though. Will attempt  redemption of the program: failing which, it will be return to '2004' and eradicate the nescessary inconvenience of 'Steam'. PROS:

- Accurate Flight model
- Active Modding Community
- Active Multiplayer Community
- Active Sim Support despite over 10 years of development
- Exellent selection of aircraft to pilot
 
This is by far one of my favorite simulators of all time.  I remember playing this years ago with my buddy who got this to replace his 'Janes' simulator.  I can't talk well enough about this sim, it literally has everything, the whole planet, amazing aircraft, fantastic flight mechanics (STILL), an outstanding modding community ...

CONS:

- Dated Graphics
- Dated Current/Weather Models
- Empty World
- Airports!!!!
- Expensive Modding Community

As with any game more than 10 years old, things will start to look a little dated.  Some of the textures really need a reolution touch-up being they were made for old tube-style 240p televisions but hey - that's progress!  The airports are abysmal seriously, Dev's wanted to keep things light-weight rendering the whole world and all but still, abysmal.  The world while absolutely gorgeous feels somewhat empty even when you are online with DTG's FANTASTIC multiplayer addon.

I saved this part for last as in my opinion it is the most important and potentially the most controversial:  FSX:SE DOES still have a hyper-active modding community, but they don't come cheap.  There are a lot of free addons but for the most part, the supported and most widely used addons will cost TONS of money.  A single airport mod can run almost $40 or more and just ONE aircraft *addon* can run nearly the same figure (or upwards of $100).  For those of you on a fixed income like most of the world at present - You really need to pick and choose.

CONCLUSION:

For the newly initiated in the flight-sim community, FSX:SE is still one of the best sims in town despite the grey hair and crow's feet.  If you do just a little research, you can gussy this girl up to be the GPU/CPU Killer she was always meant to be (seriously be careful) and fly some of the best aircraft available today.  

A special thank you to DTG for showing the love to the flight-sim community and bringing us back from the shadows and into the ... well .... streetlights at least.  Great Job I look forward to Microsoft Flight.  PLEASE!!!!!  If you are absolutely looking for the best flight-sims - stay tuned for my upcoming review on X-Plane 10!

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition:

Coming from the regular boxed edition of FSX the switch to Steam Editon was a little bumpy at first with some of my favourite addons such as PMDG, Ultimate Traffic 2 and many more not working out of the box. Over time DLC developers updated their software to work with the new steam edition. So anyone planning to purchase FSX:SE now I'd say go right ahead.

For me I feel like the only really noticable improvement is with the content management now that DLC can be bought through steam. As for actual in-game performance I haven't noticed much/ if any improvement at all. If you play Flight Simulators often then the chances are you've built a pretty good PC to run the simulator well and so an improvement of 4 or 5 frames per second on top of your usual 30 isn't an awful deal.

Saying that I do appreciate how the multiplayer servers are back online and thus allow virtual pilots to fly together, this was a really nice editon to the updated game. 

All in all FSX is really a must buy for any flight or aviation enthusiast with thousands of DLC aircraft, scenery and scenarios to purchase from the steam store and online FSX is probably the most supported flight sim available.

9/10

There's been a lot of debate on which flight sim is the best, and it generally comes down to two sims FSX and X plane. I have played both, a lot more hours than shown here.  It has to be said that I am no expert pilot, but I have been gaming for well over 30 years, and in my humble opinion, I would say FSX wins hands down on the overall gaming experience. Ok the basic game you download doesn't look fantastic (although pretty good for a 32bit system), and you may feel that it's lacking in something. But with little or no money you can get it looking and playing fantastic. I myself have "GSX" ground operations program, Traffic 360 ( both paid for, and well worth it in my opinion ), and a large amount of free stuff too, aircraft, scenery, and tweaks. That's just it with FSX there some fantastic FREE stuff out there you really can't lose. You can get FSX looking fantastic for free.

Flight Simulator 10 is an odd duck of a game to be sure. I feel some days it is not as much a game but an operating system. The potential is one of the allures to the game, some days it feels like it is as close as you can get to real world flying and have fun doing it. I own X plane 7 and 9 do not want to argue about realism.  X plane is the cheapest wind tunnel you can buy it can simulate planes that do not exist yet and can do things by the numbers, It is technically better a better simulator, so why not just fly X plane?  I have never been able to completely switch over because Flight Simulator feels more fun. 

X Plane uses a Blade element theory to figure out flight.  Lift is simulated by flowing virtual air over an approximation of a virtual wing. This is very good, the feeling of lift and interaction of lift and balance of a plane is well represented. If you design a new plane and want to sort of know if it works you can. It falls short where there are odd drag or flow interactions on a plane that make the perfect math model not match the real world. 

Flight Simulator 10 uses Table lookup so the planes are more of a grab bag. They only can simulate the Data and are only as good as the Data in the table. Some mod planes all feel the same because they don't have the flight model they deserve. It is cheaper to calculate the plane this way computer wise.  It has fun multiplayer and with a good plane it is wonderful. If I were to start today I would buy FSX 10 and the A2A piper cub http://store.steampowered.com/app/360080/ and a Joystick, and have fun.

Flight Simulator is not a trouble free game; it is much better as the steam edition then the boxed version of the past. All problems are solvable with some reading, and people are usually nice and knowledgeable. I needed to install the Orbx Felts field and had an error of missing building tops  I needed to write into a forum to get an answer, and it has been patched, but sometimes things don’t always work as you would expect them. I have had good luck with windows 10 no real errors or crashes when flying. I found if when I am choosing a flight and click out of the game window and start looking stuff up on line or starting other programs it will get mad at me and crash. It is a far cry from the boxed edition when I would save on a schedule so I didn’t have to start the flight over from the beginning and crash at the same spot. As long as the crashes are just in the menu and only because I am trying to multitask I can live with that. I also hope with continued development we will see 64-bit version in the future.

If you want to shoot down stuff, have latest technology or have a very short attention span then this game is not for you. If you love learning new things, detail, tinkering, flying, messing with how computers and graphics work, moding, or honing a skill this could be the game for you.

Microsoft Flight Simulator X, now owned by Dovetail games have re-released the game onto the steam platform. There may be no actual new gameplay features, but a endless list of bug fixes to help support this classic, yet fantastic game onto newer computers makes the experience much better.

Back in the days before 2010 I would play the boxed editon, I would encounter endless crashes mid-flight for no apparent reason. I would be cruising at 35000ft directing to my next waypoint and all of a sudden, "Microsoft Flight Simulator X has stopped working." Then boom. Flight over. This use to drive me nuts. Thanks to Dovetail Games re-releasing the product to make it extremely stable with new computers, I can fly now without the stress and worry that the simulator would stop working.

If you have the boxed edition, getting the steam re-release is an absolute must.

If you don't have it, then I will still say the exact same thing, I have spent so many hours on this extremely versitile simulator. Whether I go for an IFR flight with a virtual airline whilst connecting to an online network with thousands of pilots and controllers or whether I go for VFR flight, I still get the same satisifaction.

Admittely though, if you are like me and wanting to take your simulation experience to the next level, you are going to have to purchase addons, to make especially IFR flights in commercial planes more realistic. As much as the default 737 -800 and A321 are ok to start off with, you become hungry to endevour in the replica aircraft, like the PMDG Boeing fleet that costs up to £40 or the Aerosoft fleet that usually is about £30. Then you want your home airports to look like the real thing and so on. You become to demand more.

This is game fantastic, But in my opinion, it is a very much a base package for what is an ever growing flight simulation world.

I still though totally recommend this. It could be your purchase of the year.
Worth it.

Hello everybody, I have to say that I was very impressed with everything I've seen with FSX so far, I've flown a Cessna out of Groton-New London Airport in Connecticut while taking flight lessons so naturally this was the first airport I had to check out. And I was really surprised to see it was basically the same right down to the office building I use to do my PTI in front of before going up. The physics of the aircraft felt and behaved the same as if I was flying the real deal, Oh sure, a few of the switches and knobs were there for looks but I was really impressed with the number of switches that did work and even though a lot of the terrain is only 2 dimensional like what you find on Google earth, I was really pleased to see how much of the buildings and such was actually in 3D. I took a flight in a DC3 over the mountains in Alaska and from 9000 feet they were realistic enough that I was glad I was flying in good weather. The only real issue I had was every time I ended a flight or training mission or anything I would hit Esc like it instructed and all I would get is a black screen and that wouldn't take the program back to the menu board like I expected but just stay black until I hit the widows key and completely close it out at which time I would have to go back to the steam menu and hit play and start over again. This I believe to be more of a compatibility issue with Windows 10 and not one of the FSX program and look forward to getting it resolved very soon, even with all that said I'd say it was still worth the $13 I paid for it and am not worried this issue can't be resolved because the enjoyment I get out of running this program still out weighs any problem I have encountered thus far.  Personally I have to say that I can't fly or even drive to far anymore as a back injury put an abrupt end to all that a long time ago, and maybe that's why I am so grateful to have this program because even though it's called a "Simulation Game" it's a good way for me to get out and explore the world and see all the places I use to see and a few thousand more I haven't  all from the confines of my little apartment. I really have to hand it to the young people at Microsoft that put this together and continue to work hard everyday to make it even better and I have no doubt they will.
     If your the type of gamer that loves the feel of open world games and more realistic adventure then check this out, It's not perfect, then what is these days? I believe FSX has enough to do and see to keep anybody from getting board for as long,long time. The reviews and comments I have read that say the add-ons suck and some of the other aspects of this  or that aren't good enough, well all I can say to those people is just wait. It wasn't that long ago we were trying to hit a square ball with a short flat line to another short flat line on the other side of a dark green or black TV screen, Now one can fly one of many types of aircraft to thousands of destinations all over the world and talk with other people from around the world while you do it. Maybe FSX might have a few bugs but I think it's a really cool way to bring a world of people together instead of looking for a way to rip it apart. 
  Just one last thought,  the next time you go to see an air show and see a really cool plane parked in the hot sun but can't climb up inside to take a look because of the line of people with screaming kids got there way ahead of you, maybe you'll wish you spent the money on the simulated experience of flying it instead as long as you want without the long lines or the terrible parking or the cost of admission or gas to be there.
   Y'all take care and Maybe will CU one FSX, as usual, I'll be the one with my head in the clouds, bye-bye :)

I have too say, its great to play FSX again. I used to play the disk version (Dulux Edition) on desk top. Then I got an HP lap top Windows 8 with an Intel Core i7 and a Nvidia Geforce GT 635m. I thought that that would be good enough for FSX and it will run smoother but as soon as I installed it, I ran into many bugs and crashes. I stopped playing it all together. Then a year later FSX Steam Version comes out. At first I was skeptical and once it went on sale 80% off. I took a chance. I have too say so far I have had no problems what so ever! The Steam version runs a heck of a lot better and I was able to get all of my payware planes back. (PMDG MD-11, Cpt. Sim 757) and they both work just fine with the steam edition. I highly recommend this to any avid pc pilots that want a better experience with FSX. Happy flying!

Best Fllight Simulator hands down. This is the most realistic, most extensive, and (in my opinion) most fun flight simulator you can use. Tons of training content [b] THAT YOU CAN USE IN REAL LIFE [/b]. If you're going to be a pilot someday MFSX is the simulator for you!!

I want to use the excuse that this game is nearly ten years old, but there are so many flaws that plague it. From an inside the plane standpoint, it's absolutely gorgeous. The cockpits are nicely detailed and the controls are rather responsive. However, the game itself is barren. The terrain is much of the same, the cities are no different one from another. Alaska, for example is covered in cities that probably don't have the population the city sprites in-game would make you think they did. The worst part is actually wrecking. Don't worry about failing... Or actually damaging the plane. If you hit the ground your plane immediately flattens out and the game tells you to pull up, but other than that you go through buildings and scenery as if it is just there to look at. I wish there could be more responsiveness than this, especially from a plane sim. That makes it hard for me to recommend, simply because once you fail it no longer seems realistic.
Got the game cheaper than the DLC's. 10/10 would try to recreate 9/11 again.
Nice sim!

Great game/simulator. Being a pilot myself, I find this simulator has helped me a hell of a lot with my flight training in the real world. its as real on the computer or at home as it gets in the real world. Having known airline pilots and talking about FSX and having them even recommend FSX to supplement my training has been a huge benefit. If your going for your PPL or CPL or even RPL, this is totally worth getting. Also, if you get it, worth looking at add ons too on sites such as flight sim . com and fsdownload. Or just google up fsx addons free.

DEFINITELY GET THIS!!!

Microsoft Flight Simulator has been great software for litarally decades now.  So - You can't go wrong! If you never owned FSX you can not go wrong! And there is a utility out that allows you to connect one of those Oculus Rift DK2 devices FSX-SE (Flight Simulator Steam Edition shorthand name..important as FSX and FSX-SE are not always equal!)

Now for folks who have the BOXED version already: I feel your pain, your indecision....

Frustrated as I am that I own the box set and some new software requiring a latest version from Microsoft for the first time became a PAY ITEM! NOT A Service PAck! What the HECK! Had to buy it again here... if I wanted the new software to work (which I'm not happy about). Microsoft has bitten me a few times here and there over the years professionally, as programmers and Microsoft have a relationship of a different sort - often involving lots of money); this however is only a woe for folks who already had this software; and it is not a dig at Steam or the folks who seem to be maintaining FSX-SE now! Kinda nice to have some new blood in there that actually pops into the forums now and again - beats press releases only! lol 

No regrets - These folks optimized a lot of the stuff so out of the box you really can tweak the performance pretty sweetly after tinkering with the sliders and making tradeoffs speed/smooth versus sys candy - it's tough - deciding what to pick when you system can't do it all - almost seems to be part of the game is getting the thing tuned premo for your machine!

I have been mostly playing x-plane - love the physics - but the Virtual Reality brought me back; so I'm not a FSX-SE expert, however, after some fighting with things - cuz I break them making changes, add-on software etc... I am going run my FSX-SE once after this clean install finishes downloading... then I'm going to back up the entire FSX folder in steam.... THEN I'm going to tweak it so I can get things back without a full download again if things go wrong.

Don't get impression things go wrong all the time - instead - look at it this way - there are so many neat things you can add and enhance flight sim - well - sometimes these things don't play nice with each other - this is highly experimental - and usually not a problem - but every so often it's just easier to start fresh. (nice way of saying - i messed it up myself - its broke - it wont run - I killed - it but - .... never mind - its my fault) LOL

SO - Thinking about getting this? I recommend it.

On fence X-Plane or FSX-SE ? GET BOTH! Each have TONS to offer - different flight models, add-ons, aircraft.... GET 
THEM BOTH!

Oculus Rift Suppport? - There is a utility from FlyInsideX - I know it works with Direct-To-Rift or Shared Desk-Top modes, Direct-To-Rift is recommended. I have DK2 - So this I can say works and made me not give two cents about GPS, navigation, anything.... YUP.... Got me just flying... just flying for the sake of flying. 

I mean..  for me - this ... I mean I'm sitting at my desk one day hotdog'n a Mosquito One Man Sport Heli Ultra Light thingy - and I flew past something really fast and I looked back and then I stood up partially for some unknown reason while I whipped my attention foward - then , as if from another dimension, an disembodied entity punched me hard in the head - after my brain had a few seconds to realize that flight simulator isn;t haunted - I took the mask off, rubbed my head and saw how I slammed my head into My book shelf - some might think this is bad.. some might think nausea from a sim is bad.... ITS NOT  ....THESE ARE SELLING POINTS DARN IT!

Granted my rift locks up - why - dunno - fsx - dunno - the flybysim thing? Dunno - seriously but this is my recovery, rebooting being the last resort. 

Oculus Rift Frozen? 
- Turn Oculus RIFT Off - Keep PC ON! 
- LOG OUT (Don't shut down)
- Log back in
- Turn Rift On

Still Being Stubborn?
- Fire Up Rift Mode Utility
 + Switch it to SHARED DESKTOP MODE (wait for the flicker) 
 + Switch it back to Direct To Rift Mode

Still? Reboot! UGH! :-)

When you get some VR time in - you will forget all about the headaches... until it freezes up on ya the next time lol! So worth it!



Back to the rest of you with/without VR: Flight sim has all the radios, gps, navigation beacons, vor, airports from all over, and lots of eye-candy. Many hardcore simmers say get X-Plane for physics and FSX-SE for Eye candy.... Well - truth is you can manage both with both - but there is some truth in there - but there are really accurate flight models for some aircraft in FSX-SE while there are some real lame flight models for stuff in x-plane - but there is an important, undisputed fact in here....

FSX-SX Can look so freaking awesome! And you might have to look a little harder for those super advanced realistic physics models in FSX - but they are out there. There is even a tool to aument the handling of the FSX-SX helicopters to make them behave closer to life... HTR I think its called.

Anyway - this is a program you might find you use for years..take breaks perhaps but come back to. 

These flight simulators have been open sandbox games for over 20 years...  now go fly over some sand!

This is a great sim, and a great game. Keep in mind that you have to be connected to the internet for the game to boot successfully. The number of airstrips/ports, and variety and detail of the maps and biomes is pretty impressive. Plus the aircraft simulation is very scalable from super realistic to arcade. My only complaint is there really aren't that many aircraft and the DLC aircraft are very expensive. But it does take a while to master flight in each craft across different environments and conditions, so you will get your money's worth out of the base game. This is definitely the most comprehensive flight sim on the market. Pick it up whenever it's on sale.

I find myself using this over x-plane more and more lately. The bad: it is still a bit dated and dovetail keeps pushing dlc and removed multiplayer capability with stock fsx and lacks the comprehensive data and realism you can get with x-plane.

HOWEVER.

With the upgrades dovetail made to the game, it is much better optimized than x-plane. On my laptop, x-plane stutters even when run on some pretty low graphics settings (to be fair it offers more, but it isn't as scalable as its advertising would seem to suggest and it looks fugly when you reduce rendering range). With FSX:SE I can run the game at some pretty high settings, and it looks much prettier than X-plane given the same frame-rate, plus FSX:SE doesn't stutter. I think FSX:SE has new scenery textures that make it look much better than the old FSX.

For most entertainment purposes, FSX:SE is a much better experience than X-plane. It is a much better game. The traffic and ATC is much more bearable. The default scenery is good, if a bit outdated, but it comes at a much lower disk space cost which I'm finding to be a great advantage on my laptop's tiny SSD.

For professional purposes and if you have a high-end rig that can stomach it, X-plane is still an excellent training tool. But for recreation and if you don't need the most up-to-date scenery or a crazy amount of detail, then FSX:SE is worth the $5 discount purchase price (seriously don't buy it at full price, dlctail games will be making plenty off selling addon content)

developer_response:
With Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition you can simulate flight lessons with professional flight instructor Rod Machado. Interactive instruction makes the experience as real as it gets.

1. On the Main menu, click Learning Centre.
2. Click the Lessons tab.

If you are a beginner who just wants to fly now, click Missions on the Main menu, and then select a tutorial mission.

We hope that helps, happy flying 

The Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games
