There are some real ups and downs about this game tho, 
The grafics are terrible :
      - Most of the planes are undetailed
      - The cocpit views is not handy and not realistic
      - Almost no landscape details

After all i do enjoy playing it.

The good : brings FSX a little more up to date, and FSX remains a fabulous sim.  Multiplayer is also significantl modernised (and it works..)

The bad : Doesn't really do anything for DX10 mode, which is a missed opportunity.  Also the DLC.  DLC support is terrible - don't buy any.  If you have issues with the DLC, Dovetail will tell you it's an issue with the DLC vendor/developer (even though Dovetail are the ones selling it) and the vendor will tell you it's something specific to the Steam/Dovetail version of their DLC and to contact Dovetail.  Save your money, get and planes, scenery, missions directly from the vendors and not through Steam would be my advice.  At the end of the day, Prepar3d feels much better if you want to learn about flying; you can tell that FSX has gone for (too many?) years without any significant development.

review: cool

From my experience MFS-Steam it's self is no different than my boxed version with one exeception... there are many attractive add-ons that could add enjoyment to flight simulation.  The problem is some of them do not work and there is virtually no support or interest in any problems incurred with these products and in my case when payment for non-working download is withdrawn your account is frozen so that no more purchases can be made.  At that point you have wasted your money on the initial purchase of the right to play MFS steam.  You might as well have stayed with your box version.  There are way to many companies doing business in this manner where they insulate themselves from any direct customer contact and have no intention of standing behind there product.  "consumer beware" and purchase at your own risk.

FSX is a game I have played for 6 months and still struggle with. The game provides a very realistic look into the large capacity of solutions Pilots must conjure on a day to day basis with difficult challenges such as different weather conditions and the size of airport you choose to find yourself in. I would highly recommend buying a controller to use while playing the game at the least as I soon found the difficulties of flying with just a keyboard which increases the difficulty rating by about 10. Dont expect a GTA style flying conditions as members of the online community take the game very seriously in their approach which is in its own respect is a good thing for learners and experts of the game alike. 

This game will take a while to master but is well worth the purchase for a long gaming experience.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie 

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

I'm a private pilot & Ive been playing this game since before it was Microsoft flight sim (it used to be subLogic)... And it is hands down the best flight simulator available. While it does have its weaknesses from a simulation point of view, no other flight sim has ever come as close to simulating all the aircraft systems like MSFS does.

Every switch in the cockpit works. For example, you can reach down & yank the mixture knob all the way out & lean the engine out... tune (or turn off) the radios with the panel switches... flip the master switch & the panel goes dark... all just like in a real plane.

MS abandoned MSFS some time ago though & we thought the franchise was dead. Heres to hoping dovetail will bring something new to the game and not just charge us for airplane/scenery downloads.

EDIT: Changed from recommmended to not recommended because dovetail is doing exactly what i hoped they wouldn't

Hey dovetail... i can download literally thousands of free planes the same quality (or better)... what makes you think i'm going to pay $20 a piece for them.

what a shame.

EDIT: Tried the game again after dovetail attempted to fix MSFS broken multiplayer. They somehow managed to make it even worse. On the ground, other players planes will often be seen sliding around as if on ice, of even bouncing 20 feet up in the air and sometimes disappearing below ground.  In the traffic pattern you can often see players aircraft flying through buildings, mountains and other secenery. This wont be a problem for long though, because you will lose connection before you get very involved with anything. MSFS's hit-and-miss voice com has been replaced with a new mis-and-miss system that never seems to work at all.

Dovetail.. you suck! Would you please stop ruining these old games & just leave them alone?

Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is an excellent "revival" of an already good game. Many more features are available, and everything works smoothly.

+Excellent graphics - for 2006.
      While I will say that the graphics look outdated, they have a certain charm to them that adds a realm of nostolgia for older games.

+More planes/airports/scenery than the boxes edition.
      F-18 Fighter Jets, Grumman Goose, more updated locations calls for a great flying experience.

+Configurible settings.
      If you're like me, you won't exactly have the highest-end PCs. But in FSX: SE, it doesn't matter. With a few clicks, FSX: SE will be fully optomized for your computer, no matter the configuration.



-Poor DLC packs
      If you've ever seen DoveTailGame's Train Simulator 2015, you'll most certainly know their cash-grabbing techniques. That resulted in literally $3000+ worth of DLC on that game. Here you have a few poorly executed expansion packs. 

-Multiplayer Mode [READ THE WHOLE THING]
     Little squeakers. It's inevitable that you'll find one on any game, no matter the type. One word. PewDiePie. He plays all these games (I am not sure if he ever played FSX, I didn't stay on his channel for more than 10 minutes.) and they attract little kids. That ruins the fun experience of a GOOD GAME. One time I had this little kid screaming at me due to me landing (WITH CLEARENCE) because he claimed to be the U.S. President, Obama. 

Overall Rating: 8
The good aspects of this game outweigh the bad, although some things must be improved.

[h1]Good[/h1]
I previously play FS2004 on my laptop, with many add-ons installed (REX, AI Traffic, etc) and it runs at 50-60 fps, Later when I tried to switch to FSX it lags really bad, without any add-ons I was running at around 15-20 fps. I tried many optimization guide on the web and none works for me. My laptop isn't very powerful as it only got a AMD A10-5750m CPU, and Radeon 8670m GPU. At the time, I gave up on FSX, and sticks to FS 2004, as I thought my system isn't powerful enough for FSX. Couple of months later, FSX:SE was launched and I read many reviews on the web stating that it really improved stabilty and FPS (not by a very large margin, the reviewers said). At first i'm not really interested in acquiring the Steam Edition, since I thought my laptop isn't powerful enough for FSX, but then FSX:SE goes on sale for around $2-$3, and I decided to give it a shot. I launched the game for the first time, and surprisingly, none of the lag issue I encountered before was gone. I got a good 50 fps, without any add-ons, and even after installing many add-ons such as ORBX, REX, and AI Traffics I still get around 40 fps, with occasional drop to 20 fps, when i'm flying near third party airport, with many AI Traffics. The only optimization I did was changing the Affinity Mask on fsx.cfg. I'm really happy that FSX Steam Edition works well for me.

I bought this on sale and it has turned out to be a huge value and in a very short time has become my fifth most played game out of over 200 on Steam. The intuitive ability to go from full blown long hauls to extremely brief landing scenarios by saving flights as they progress (as completely separate vignettes) has given this game an additional depth far beyond the multitude of planes, skins, and locations.

So far I have had no issue installing and using third party freeware such as texture enhancements and liveries, and the game has proven quite stable in Windows 7. The current asking price is a good value for your hard earned dollars, but if you can grab this during a sale it is an insane steal.

I grew up with MSFS in DOS, so when I saw it return to Steam, it was a no brainer. Having spent more time in small aircraft in the past few years has made me interested in the actual dynamics and activities behind flying. Luckily, FSX provides an ample playground to try it out. Add to this a huge number of free internet resources about instrument navigation and it becomes all the more interesting. This is one of the few Steam purchases I'm looking forward to logging many more hours in.

Steam Edition is a dissapointing repackage filled to the brim with bugs and compatibility problems.

I'm running Windows 8.1 and had little to no problems with the original boxed version. 

With that said I STRONGLY suggest FSX be purchased boxed from Microsoft and dodge the inconceivable amounts of frustration awaiting the use of FSX:SE. 

It does offer one noticable benefit for me at least, the enviroment regardless of graphics settings will render quite pixelated giving a smoother framerate for the number of objects generated. Essentialy it's Flight Simulator: 2004 terrain level graphics with FSX framework running the show.
developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to write us a review of FSX: Steam Edition -=CyberNightmare=-

As you point out FSX: SE is a re-release of Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Gold Edition on the Steam digital platform. It includes all of the content from Flight Simulator X Deluxe, the Acceleration pack and both official Service Packs. We have made some functional changes to FSX in the development of FSX: Steam Edition most notably replacing the now-defunct Gamespy multiplayer systems and enabling multiplayer to work seamlessly once again over Steam.  However, in terms of content nothing new has been added at this time.

If you would like to find out exactly what has changed you can read the full details here: 

http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/discussions/7/530645961936099124/

Since the release of FSX: SE we have also been working closely with players to further update the sim. The details for all the updates we have released can be found on the Steam announcement page here:

http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/announcements

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is compatible with all versions of Windows from Windows® XP Service Pack 2 onwards. We have tested Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition on Windows XP, Windows Vista, Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 - both 32 bit and 64 bit (please note that FSX is only a 32 bit app) and can confirm running the software under all of these operating systems without need for workarounds. There are currently many players running FSX: SE with Windows 8.1 and if you would like some help setting up your PC to do this please get in touch with us via our dedicated support website here:

https://steamcommunity.com/linkfilter/?url=http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/

You will also find a detailed knowledgebase on the website with answers to most frequent question questions we get asked about FSX. 

There are so many add-ons currently available for FSX that we cannot promise that all of them will work with no issues. Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition is installed in a different way to the boxed version and occupies a different location so it is possible that some add-ons may not work, but rest assured that we have made every effort to ensure that as many of them as possible work. Where add-ons do not immediately function with Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition we will try to work with the community, developer or publisher of the add-on to find the solutions as needed. Again, we cannot promise that 100% of all add-ons released over the history of FSX will work with FSX: Steam, but we are committed to trying.

We understand that this can be frustrating for players who are keen to fly their favourite add-on, however many developers have already updated their add-ons to run with FSX: SE and many more are currently updating them. If you have a question relating to non-steam add-on we would advise contacting the developer who made it. These developers know their add-ons better than anyone else and are best placed to advise you on matters such as compatibility.

The graphics in FSX: SE have not been changed from the original release of the boxed game. If you would you like some help optimising your graphics settings for your PC, again, please don’t hesitate to get in touch with us via our support website above. 

Finally you might like to check out the FSX: SE Steam forum where you can chat to your fellow players and find out how they have set up their games. You will also find lots of useful information in the forums regarding installing add-ons which might be of interest to you. 

Thanks again for the review and giving FSX: Steam Edition a try, 

The Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

developer_response:
Hello steelguy25, thank you for giving FSX: SE a go and letting us know how you got on. 

That is some strange behaviour you are describing there and certainly not what your average FSX player experiences with the game. Sounds like either the game has not installed correctly on your PC or something else running on your computer is causing a conflict. We are sorry for any inconvenience this may of caused you. 

If you are having problems running Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition on your PC please try the following steps:

[b]Verifying your game files on Steam[/b]
This causes Steam to compare all the Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition files installed on your computer against the ones it believes you should have. If any are missing Steam will update and download them. In order to complete this procedure you will need to be connected to the Internet. 

To verify you game files please do the following:

1.	Load the Steam platform and log into your account
2.	Click the Library tab in the menu at the top of the screen
3.	Click the List View from the view options on the top right of the screen
4.	Right click on Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to bring up a popup menu
5.	Click on Properties from the popup menu to bring up another popup box
6.	Click on Local files from the popup box menu
7.	Click on Verify integrity of game cache from the Local file options
8.	Wait for the progress bar to finish verifying your files. Additional files may download
9.	Restart Steam
10.	Restart Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition 

[b]Free up your computer’s memory[/b]
Running lots of different programs in Windows at the same time may mean that Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition does not have enough memory available to run correctly. Your computer might be displaying an Out of memory error as a result. 

Please try the following steps:

1.	Check that your PC meets the minimum memory requirements to run Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition. The game requires 2 GB RAM to run. If you have less than the require 2 GB RAM then you will be unable to run the game. 
2.	Press Ctrl+Alt+Delete on your keyboard and select Task manager from the list options. Click on the Applications tab in the task manager to see all of the programs currently running in Windows. Shut down any additional programs you have running. Even if you have not started any programs running Widows may launch certain ones upon start up. Please refer to the Windows help files for more information about enabling and disabling programs when Windows starts. The less programs you have running the more memory will be available for Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to use. 

[b]Reinstall Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition[/b] 
Steam provides the ability to reinstall the game to the default system. To perform this reinstallation, you should perform the following steps:

1.	Sign out off Steam
2.	Backup the disk containing your FSX installation
3.	Delete the contents of "<drive:>\Program files (x86)\ Steam\SteamApps\Common\FSX\" and all subdirectories
4.	Log on to Steam
5.	Select "View Games Library" from the "Games" menu
6.	Right-click the Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition icon and select "Properties"
7.	Select the "Local Files" tab and click on "Verify Integrity of Games Cache"

If you are still experiencing issues you can reach us via our dedicated support website: 

http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/

If you drop us a message a member of our team will get back to you as soon as possible with some advice. 

Thank you for your review, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

developer_response:
Hi jwallin61 and thank you for your review of FSX: SE. 

FSX: Steam Edition is compatible with Windows 8.1. You will need to run the game as a Windows Admin however. If you use the User Access Control ("UAC") features of Windows, unless you are logged on as an administrator, you may be prompted to permit multiple program changes during installation. This is normal and can be avoided by temporarily disabling UAC via the Control Panel.

Further information about Windows UAC can be found here:

http://www.sevenforums.com/tutorials/11841-run-administrator.html

FSX: SE requires you to run it as an Admin in order to access addition folders on your hard drive where add-ons not available on Steam may have been installed.

If you are still experiencing issues you can reach us via our dedicated support website: 

http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/

If you drop us a message a member of our team will get back to you as soon as possible with some advice. 

Thanks again for your review, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

developer_response:
Hello Harbsco, 

It is great to hear that you have given FSX another go. It sounds like you are having some unexpected issues getting it up and running however. We are sorry for any inconvenience this may of caused you and would advise trying the following steps below. 

[b]Verifying your game files on Steam[/b]
This causes Steam to compare all the Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition files installed on your computer against the ones it believes you should have. If any are missing Steam will update and download them. In order to complete this procedure you will need to be connected to the Internet. 

To verify you game files please do the following:

1.	Load the Steam platform and log into your account
2.	Click the Library tab in the menu at the top of the screen
3.	Click the List View from the view options on the top right of the screen
4.	Right click on Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to bring up a popup menu
5.	Click on Properties from the popup menu to bring up another popup box
6.	Click on Local files from the popup box menu
7.	Click on Verify integrity of game cache from the Local file options
8.	Wait for the progress bar to finish verifying your files. Additional files may download
9.	Restart Steam
10.	Restart Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition 

[b]Free up your computer’s memory[/b]
Running lots of different programs in Windows at the same time may mean that Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition does not have enough memory available to run correctly. Your computer might be displaying an Out of memory error as a result. 

Please try the following steps:

1.	Check that your PC meets the minimum memory requirements to run Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition. The game requires 2 GB RAM to run. If you have less than the require 2 GB RAM then you will be unable to run the game. 
2.	Press Ctrl+Alt+Delete on your keyboard and select Task manager from the list options. Click on the Applications tab in the task manager to see all of the programs currently running in Windows. Shut down any additional programs you have running. Even if you have not started any programs running Widows may launch certain ones upon start up. Please refer to the Windows help files for more information about enabling and disabling programs when Windows starts. The less programs you have running the more memory will be available for Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition to use. 

[b]Reinstall Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition[/b] 
Steam provides the ability to reinstall the game to the default system. To perform this reinstallation, you should perform the following steps:

1.	Sign out off Steam
2.	Backup the disk containing your FSX installation
3.	Delete the contents of "<drive:>\Program files (x86)\ Steam\SteamApps\Common\FSX\" and all subdirectories
4.	Log on to Steam
5.	Select "View Games Library" from the "Games" menu
6.	Right-click the Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition icon and select "Properties"
7.	Select the "Local Files" tab and click on "Verify Integrity of Games Cache"

If you are still experiencing issues you can reach us via our dedicated support website: 

http://dovetailgames.kayako.com/

If you drop us a message a member of our team will get back to you as soon as possible with some advice. 

Thank you for your review, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

What can I say, been playing FSX ever since it came out. Awesome for anyone with an interest in flying.

Now, since coming to Steam, there have been a few, but not many updates from the original game. Main features are Steamworks integration, which brings online flying to anyone who wants it. In the old days you would have to play around with VATSIM and specific modules to get an online connection, which if you want to fly as accurate as possible is still available, but for the more casual gamer/pilot is a doddle. Works perfectly!

Also, there has been a DirectX 11 test system introduced into the graphics options, which not only improved framerates on my GTX660Ti, but also made the scenery look better. Only issue I had here was with the CamSIm aircraft, whos landing gear doesnt appear in DX11 mode, but that isnt a problem with the game, just older addon freeware aircraft, although out of the many I've tested this one is the only issue.

Also, from what I've tested, 99.9% of previous addons still work brilliantly. I use many of the UK2000 airports from my old FSX copy and they work fine in DX11 mode, along with the POSKY 73s, 74s,, 75s, 76s A330s and A340s, alongside the old iFDG A320 series for FS2004. Alongside these are many other various aircraft which I have loved to fly again.

Only issue I've seen is with some of the new DLC loaded alongside on Steam. As some of these are just a single aircraft with a saved set of flight plans for a ridiculous amount. Many packages like these can be found on sites like FlightSim.com and AVSim.com which will still be compatible from the original FSX and work fine in FSX Steam Edition.

All is all, still highly recommend this game for anyone with a passing interest in flying or higher.

Also, get a decent joystick or flight yoke if you can. I use a Saitek X45. If you do invest, ensure you have both a Rudder and Throttle controls.

I have this on my laptop and PC. on my PC I use all Saitk gear (yoke, pedals, radio, autopilot, TPM...), Track IR, and a Thrustmaster warthog stick if I'm going to fly a diamond, airbus, or some warbird. This is all good, and the game feels great (although my CFI irl still says I use too much left rudder, and I think it's FSX's fault). On my laptop I fly with just a 360 controller, and it also works fine.
So you can really have the best of both worlds with FSX. A complete sim pit, or just an xbox controller. It's really up to your preference. If you want to hang out on the back porch and drink a few road soda's while you fly from NH to NY in a Cessna on the laptop, that'll be a good time. If you want to rip a leerjet from coast to coast with a yoke and pedals, you can do that too. It can be as high or low fidelity as you want it to be. I prefer my simpit, but on a nice afternoon I don't want to be cooped up inside, and the laptop w/ xbox controller is enough to get you into the air and back down (although the TPM control would be nice, the B and Y buttons for throttle can be tough if you don't keep an eye on the RPM's).
There are plenty of addons for the game, most of the good ones are payware. I like some Carenado products, but A2A's Cessna is right on... You can burn out the starter, foul your sparkplugs, kill the battery, flood the engine, cylinders can loose compression... quite a bit can go wrong, making it more fun.
I play this usually once a week for a few hours, especially after a day of manuevers in a real c172s! Also call your local flight school and take a real plane up for an hour. You will come home and play FSX all week long.

Scans every disk drive in my system before it will start. I blocked it's access to the internet and now it won't run. All I wanted was a flight simulator.
Play it for fun. And stay away from real-life buildings.

When you first start the game figuring out the controls can be a hassle and although flying without a joystick is possible, you are going to need one if you want to be able to fly properly. However after that is all figured out, it is an amazing game to play for professionals and people who just feel like goofing around. There are fun missions for times when you dont know what to do and tutorials for newcomers You are going to eventually have to buy some payware addons to really make the game shine, but there is plenty of freeware like project opensky aircraft if you dont have the money. The game does not appear to be hard on your computer and has a really good community. The graphics are ok considering when it was made, but they could be better especially the water and there is no wingflex for the default 737 and the gear doesn't tilt in the 747 which is a realism killer. The clouds also magically fade away when you get near them and there is no volumetric effect. I would definitely recommend this. After making the move from x plane to fsx i feel that the colours look my vibrant and less gloomy, better freeware, more payware, and the wingtip vortices add a nice feel. In terms of physics, i have never flown a plane myself but the physics in airplanes feel not completely realistic but pretty good in my opinion. The touchdowns feel a bit stiff but the overall flight doesn't feel "on rails" as others say. Helicopter physics do not feel very realistic. They are too stable and easy to control. For how i like to fly though the physics suit me perfectly and i personally dont want that realism but i know others will. The atc is easy to use and great for beginners aswell. No need to go all professional and download flight plans, all you need to know is where you are leaving from and where your destination is. All in all i give this game a 7/10 by itself but if you include the vast amount of addons i give this a 9/10 Even if you think a 7/10 is a bit low my opinion is to watch and read some reviews, look at some pictures, if youve already done that then my opinion is buy the game. For total honesty, there is an 88.5 percent chance you wont regret it

performance 9/10

default aircraft quality 7/10

default scenery quality 5/10

Its as good as FSX ever was. The main improvement is that the multiplayer is now based on Steam rather than the defunct Gamespy (nice work). Also, if you're so inclined, the Xbox 360 controller is perfectly mapped out of the box, which I'm sure must be a new addition. Dovetail have made a really good job of this.

However, off the shelf, big 'survey simulators' like this represent the core of a simulator eco system. When FSX (and versions before it) was developed, Microsoft included a world that was passable, and in places quite detailed, but not detailed enough for VFR flight, and included a collection of aircraft, no single one of which was all that realistic, but was intended to be accessible to most people with an interest in aviation.

So what you're buying here is a product that is really just the tip of the iceberg. That's confirmed by the number of other companies that spend 100% of their time making, for example JUST scenery for FSX, or JUST as perfect a representation of a 747 as you can possibly get. Microsoft or Dovetail aren't going to spend their time creating ultra-realistic content because they don't need to, they can sell FSX as a platform to other developers that do that.

That said, you get a more 'complete' product designed for the home with FSX than you do with for example X-Plane 10 (X-Plane 10 is a very different beast and again, the core of a giant industrial sized simulator). Also I believe Microsoft worked with Cessna on this one, so the Skylake can't be all that bad.

If you're into flight simulators but don't own this, there is something missing in your life.

review:
This is a fun game, but do note that this is a legacy abandoned game as well. There are still DLC coming out for it, but the code-base is unsupported and the whole FSX franchise will die off eventually. Some zealots will try to convince you that it will continue for ever but as a deveper I would not buy any DLC that isn't ultra cheap.

This is also a [b]32-bit[/b] game so you will not be able to use more than 3.2 gig of ram.

It has good things going for it though, there are tutorials and achievments which can help you grow as a virtual pilot.
But eventually you should buy X-plane 10 which is the real deal. I recommend both, this game as a tutor to all things flight, and X-plane to try them out for real as it is a proper and very competent flight simulator.

This game is very fun and rewarding, given that the player takes the time to understand how aircrafts work, the controls, and how to navigate. This game has been around for a very long time, so I'm not going to try and reinvent the wheel by posting a full review. I just want to say that this game is at the top of my list of greatest games of all time, despite all the annoying bugs that somehow haven't been fixed yet. I hope that Dovetail offers more updates to fix these issues and continued customer support.

10/10

They however left 450+ MB of files, folders and other items from that SDK in the install, yet, left out the compilers.  They claim they can't give users the SDK, yet, give the users most of it.  Given this, plus a bad track record from Train sim,  I would strongly recommend against any DTG product.  Though its FS, its still nice, This version, isn't worth it, Go find FSX gold elsewhere if you are even remotely interested in developing for FS.

review: Best game great fun!!

With the last release being years ago and nothing new in sight, I was curious when I heard about the steam version and decided to give it a try. Though I love the game, I have been dissapointed in the "same old same old" in the steam version with no significant upgrades or improvements being offered which I don't understand given there are a plethera of freeware addons that make the game so much more enjoyable and realistic which most true simulator enthusiasts long for. I understand profit, but some upgrades to the existing scenery quality, flight dynamics and even some free addons would probably go far in maintaining a fan base and would definately encourage people to buy some addons (I have several) because they would see the company as being invested in the simmer which at this point I simply don't see. 

However, I have been a loyal follower and will continue to be regardless and simply will wait in the hope that we see some progress, improvements and forward movement in this game.

I've had both FS9 and FSX since 2003 and 2010 and enjoyed both until all the good FS Host servers died and the MP feature of FSX was turned off. Just having MP back is good enough to buy the Steam edition, but there are other reasons also.  The game is more stable than the older box version, I've yet to have it crash because any one of the many dll's stopped working. The frame rates are better, not only faster but smoother too. In general to me everything about it seems new again. 

You only need to buy 3 things for FSX and the last one is optional

A good stick and throttle controller

Paid license for FSUIP to unlock your controllers full potential. You can use it for free but you only get just the barest of functions

A 3rd party weather program, this is optional as the live weather in the sim seems to be improved.

Things I like about this

More stable than the original release

Faster frames and smoother graphics

MP is back (YAY!!!!!!!!!)

Plays nice with your existing install if you have one.

Things that I don't like ( most are not the fault of MS or DTG )

We had to wait years for the sim to be improved with out buying PrePared

Some 3rd party installers don't recognize the Steam install, and some 3rd party companies want you to pay again for a Steam compatible installer

A few companies selling old products with a Steam installer with one texture and then selling the remaining textures as Steam DLC. Note, buy the regular installer if you can and point it to your Steam install, it will work and you save some money.

Some MP servers are overrun with kids that think it's fun to override/monopolize comms, try to dog fight guys flying airliners and last but not least crashing into others for fun.

As I said my dislikes are targeted at things outside of DTG and Steam, the game in itself is a revitalized gem and still has life like it's older FS2004 sibling despite it's old age at 9+years. The FS community is still strong with active forums, flight clubs and virtual airlines. There are thousands of addon aircraft, scenery repaints, sounds and more for FSX and it's all for free. Don't like the sound that the default DC-3 makes? change it, theres a freeware sound package that 4 times as large as the original. Want a VFA-31 texture for the default F/A-18 ? theres one out there along with many other Navy and Marine squadrons. Want the one airplane that you've loved for ever? chances are that it's out there to be downloaded. And best of all the things I mentioned are free to use, for everyone. Okay, you might have to buy a membership for faster download speeds but 90% of those sites still provide free access.

   Buy it, fly it, you'll love it

I love this game. I have owned multiple Microsoft developed flight sims over the years as a recreational player here and there. It's a solid game that will give you hours of fun and teach you real things about aviation. I am also an air traffic controller in the Army and have used this game to gain more knowledge about flying to better understand my job and air traffic control as a whole. It is really cool to see things from the pilot's point of view in a traffic pattern and flying through center and approach control airspace. I know they made this game so cheap to buy because they planned on banking on the DLC, which is fine. I just wish they made some free add-ons as well. But that's not really much of a complaint. Great game, worth the money. If you are on the fence about it, wait until it goes on sale, which it does pretty often, and go for it. Buy a cheap joystick and you will be hooked once you figure it all out.

Here's the headline: BUY THIS! Especially if you're an aviation enthusiast and/or have a disc copy of FSX and are running Windows 7 or newer.

FSX has been my favorite flight sim for some time. I purchased the Gold Edition a few years ago and I enjoyed it. Unfortunately, FSX is nearly a decade old at this point and it hasn't been supported for years. Naturally, this meant than when I loaded it on my nice, shiny new Windows 8.1 machine with a powerful CPU and graphics chip, it ran poorly and in worse cases, caused it to bluescreen.

I was initially skeptical of purchasing another copy of a game I already own but since it was on sale for $5, I figured "Why not" and bought it. Did not regret it simply because of how much the game is an improvement over the retail version performance-wise. This game takes much, MUCH better advantage of the power of a modern midrange-high-end graphics card from a GTX 960/R9 270X to a GTX Titan X/R9 295X2. Furthermore, it natively supports Windows 7 and above, meaning that there will be no unpleasant effects playing the game on a machine running that or Windows 8.1.

Of course, FSX is not FSX without its planes. The default plane list is pretty okay-ish. Some airliners, fighters and whatnot. But where FSX truly shines is its unparalleled support for third-party content, both free and paid. The FSX modding community is one of the largest and most active ones out there and you can easily find your favorite plane and either get it or buy it. Free planes are decent and some are actually pretty good but if you want the true experience, payware planes are the way to go, offering outstanding realism both in terms of visuals and physics. Oh, and did I mention that FSX has graphics mods that turn it from a 2006 game to one released in 2012? 

Another important thing that has been added is online support. This is a HUGE plus, since my retail version did not have online after GameSpy shut down. Simply put, it's fun as heck to mess around with other pilots or impress them with landing skills and aerobatic moves.

All-in-all, I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves planes in general and/or is a seasoned veteran pilot, either in real-life or in FSX. Online support is a big plus and it's still compatible with the hundreds of thousands of planes made by talented people. For the best possible experience , invest in a joystick and some payware planes of your choice. Or if you really wanna go nuts, build an actual cockpit. :P

Planes that I usually fly in FSX are the Boeing 747-8i in Boeing Sunrise Livery, Boeing 777-300ER in Japan Airlines/Cathay Pacific livery, Boeing 777-9X in Boeing livery, Boeing 757-200 in AA livery, and a McDonnell Douglas/Boeing MD-11F in FedEx livery. Yes, I'm a huge Boeing fan, but I love each and every plane out there.
I liked the online part, but if you already own the MS version of this, and you like to fly alone, i'll say you should keep your money.

Just as good as it ever was!  Just waiting for the ACCELERATION EXPANSION PACK. I have the boxed version, but it doesn't recognize the STEAM EDITION and won't load.  All of my planes have been able to be added, so far.  Most of my scenery as well, with the exception of GSX (Ground Service) & FS DREAM TEAM'S JFK AIRPORT which is asking for the expansion pack.  Otherwise, I'm still loving it!

I have purchased Microsoft Flight Simulator to many times to remember now starting with a primitive version that ran on my TRS-80 Model One. That computer had a screen that boasted 96x32 monochrome pixels that looked more like tall boxes than dots, yet I learn to fly a virtual Sopwith Camel on that computer. FSX-SE is the best version that I have bought so far, far surpassing the original FSX. It runs more much more smoothly and produces a more realistic experience than any other version of Flight Simulator than I have seen before.

The changes that have been added to FSX to create this version make it more enjoyable to use, and make me want to return day after day to see some new part of the world. I'm sure I will enjoy this version for a long time.

Finally an updated and stable version of an amazing Flight Sim. I have to make you aware though, I have modified my Flight Sim with aftermarket Pay Mods. I use FSPassanger, I use TaxitotheGate Airports for Orlando KROD, and I use GEX and UTX, with Clouds and Weather Mods. It makes the realistic nature of flying so much more fun and real.

Can you fly for fun and do what ever? Sure
Can you study mechanics in a simulation where one mistake wont kill you and others? Yes
Can you practice landings, stalls, and get very close to realistic simulation of aircraft? Yes

I have used Flight Sim to scratch my itch of learning to fly. I also use XPlane as well for the ultra realistic aircraft aerodynamics, and trust me, learning to fly in XPlane over Flight Sim is rough, but a good natural progression.

Dovetail did a great job making this older flight sim much more stable, and much more enjoyable. It wont crash as it runs out of memory anymore unless you heavily modify it like I do and try to run insanely high auto gen than expect things to get interesting, but in reality, it is a solid update to a beloved flight sim and one everyone can enjoy.

If you are an enthusiast of MFSX this is your game. Updates, outstanding frame rate, compatibility with the most famous addons like UTX, A2A, REX, etc.
Now my Gold Edition is in the shelf... ;)
Steam version of FSX is the same game as the original FSX, the only difference is that it becomes better if you purchase DLC's

I do recommend getting the game if you like the old FSX and it is on sale for a couple of bucks, but otherwise I recommend buying the original deluxe version if you really need a copy. Seriously taxi lights and landing lights are two different things!
developer_response:
Tank you for taking the time to write us a review of FSX: Steam Edition. 

FSX: Steam Edition is a re-release of FSX Gold Edition so you should not expect dramatic differences.  However, we have updated it to include all standard Steam functionality, we’ve removed CD checking and combined the components of Gold Edition into a single installation.  The major change we've made is in replacing the now-defunct Gamespy multiplayer systems with Steam features, enabling multiplayer to work seamlessly once again.  Additionally, some outstanding bugs have been resolved, as detailed [url= http://steamcommunity.com/app/314160/discussions/0/622954747293264584/]here[/url]. Our aim in this first instance has been to ensure that the software will run for as many people as possible rather than radically improving or updating it.

Since this time we have released two further updates for FSX: SE to address outstanding bugs and issues reported to us by FSX: SE players. Please see [url=http://steamcommunity.com/gid/103582791436916733/announcements/detail/243535262349401340]here[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/gid/103582791436916733/announcements/detail/231141125830072041]here[/url] for further details. 

Thanks again for the review, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

review:
Started out great! Graphics couldn't be beat, still can't! But as all things go I bought some add on aircraft found they fly only from the virtual flight deck. This isn't good for weather or heavy ATC-environments, but not Steams fault. The Beta version that was released wreaked havoc with my system. Several third party aircraft lost textures and paints, the mouse went transparent and became useless.
Update: After a continuous battle of about a week, I have reached the conclusion that without the ability to nullify the beta release my system will be forever in ruins. I have recently discovered I can get my mouse back if I do an ALT + ENT and use a reduced screen. Again if I opt for the full screen no mouse with which to set courses, frequencies, altitudes or anything else you need a mouse for. My surrender doesn’t come lightly, I have headed the word of those much smarter than I and tried their fixes, work a rounds to no a vail. I have had the keepers of the program tell me that the fix I seek has already been discovered! All I need to do is go to this forum, search, read a couple hundred lines of data from others that are having similar problems and the answer will magically appear! After a Thirty-six hour delete and reload of Flight Simulator X Steam, (the initial only took twenty-three but was worth it) with me pushing the download instead of letting the system wait for the scheduled time, I’m no further than I was two days ago. So if you’re looking for the best graphics this is it. If you’re looking for the best support,,,,,,,,,, well let’s just say I have an email address. If they only answer. The route for requesting support in the Steam network left me a bit mystified. One place I would be logged in, the next place I wouldn’t be. I would put in ID and password and have to retrieving my password every-time I did this. I would get logged in go to support and the blocks of hell the first was pretty simple what was the problem, next block what system/game/something, and the last was just as informative. Anyway after getting this far nothing happens! 
So if you decide to try this simulator, good luck! I hope they have the bugs worked out because as it is I can’t fly and I so much want to!

WOW! I was honestly expecting alot of OOM'S (Out Of Memory Errors) with the steam version as in the same as the old box version, NOT THE CASE! There really is a difference in performance here in the steam version. With just a few tweaks i was able to fly into and out Flytampa Toronto for the first time, in the old version, i would get OOMS and crash to desktop before even landing. There is really a big difference in the steam version no matter what anybody says, I am very pleased with my purchase and strongly look forward to doing long hauls. Excellent Job Dovtail!
Great game well worth it :) I recommend using a joystick

An updated review for an updated game...

Since their last patch, the simulator platform has become quite stable and changes the experience quite a bit.  I actually have some flight experience and while certainly this is not a true measure of flight, it is a very good introduction to it as well as a means to maintain your skills.

PRO'S:
There's a robust support group out there, seasoned and developed and happy to help.

The missions supplied are very well arranged and developed, the presentation is enjoyable as opposed to a bitching betty.

The radio traffic is excellent, allows newer pilots a chance to get in some communication practice out of the real world.

This game still has collisions, which is great for those wishing to ensure they are "not hitting" obstacles.  The new simulators require that collisions are turned off, so if you're testing your skills to make sure you're clearing that 50ft tree at the end of that short runway, this simulator will definately let you know if you cleared or not.

CON'S:
Very few with this latest patch.  The graphics are getting a bit dated, but they're not bad.

Some of the missions do have dead spots or don't really give good instructions on what to do next to advance in the mission.  Most do very well.


Overall, I've enjoyed this Steam Edition very much and am regularly using it to keep up and develop my pilot skills.

The game offers an accurate representation of how an aeroplane works, people have been using this software for years to train pilots. A must buy for any PC gamer.  The DLC is not really worth it unless you have some extra money left over or if you're rich...
Love it !!  Much better than boxed !

another minus is all the addons - the addons are currently as much as the game itself.. seems a bit odd to me..
good to see the small fixes and changes definitely recommend it

I don't really know what I can tell you about FSX, mostly because I know quite a bit about it. Although my current in game hours may seem a bit low to give the game the raving review that I'm giving it,I assure you there is a reason.

I have owned a copy of FSX since it was realeased all the way back on Windows XP, and as it was my favorite game, and I was in gradeschool, I played the game. A lot. How much a lot? Total flight time was over 5,000 hours flying alone. My total landings were over 10k, and my total distance was enough to circle the globe 120 times.

I was very proud of my logbook (all printed about 25 pages), so when I went with my dad to work one day (he's the supervisor of ground operations at Cleveland Hopkins, he basically says if the airport is open or not **not if flights are cancelled or not**) and 12 year old me showed my printed log book to my dad's former boss.

He looked at my dad and asked "Did he really do this?" My dad, although enamored with the game himself, responded "Sadly, yes." (I would rather fly than play baseball or whatever) My dad's boss then took me to a 737 which was about an hour from departure. My dad's boss, my dad, and myself all walked into the cockpit, where the boss said to the pilot "Show me your logbook." (Every pilot has their own, and if they get filled up, they carry over like a checkbook) After looking at the logbook for a considerable amount of time, he said to the pilot "Impressive stuff captain, how long have you been flying?" He responded "Since I was 17 sir, and I'm 27 now, so 10 years."

"Good for you captain, however would you like to see something impressive? Check this out." He handed the pilot my logbook. After the pilot was done leafing through it, he looked in disbelief and said "Hell, you're more qualified to fly this plane than I am." I then looked at his logbook, which had totaled just under 4k hours, and less than a quarter of my landings.

Later that day, we went to the disastrous landings simulator, which tested pilot's abilities to land in the weird extremes of Cleveland weather, and the boss had the people running the simulator set it up for a 5min takeoff session, 5min  at cruise, and landing from 20k ft. I flew the simulator, and when I got out, the boss said to me "If you were 16, I'd hand you your license right now, and take you down to the Continental offices downstairs."

So yeah, thats the reason why I love this game, and it has been such a big part of both me and my childhood.

**My dad's boss is the SuperIntendant of the airport, basically he rules all
**What did 5000 hours do to me? Make me good at flying in simulators
**Yes, I have flown a plane in real life. Cessna 172 and Piper Cherokee
**No, I do not have my pilot's license
**I broke 4 different joysticks out of wear and tear during that time

TLDR: On the original version of this game, I put more than 5k hours into flight time, decide for yourself if I think its good or not.

developer_response:
Hello davonn832 and thank you for taking the time to write us a review of FSX: Steam Edition. 

Unless you are running in Steam offline mode you will need to log into Steam in order play Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition. Steam displays the error message you have described when you try to play a game in online mode without first logging into Steam. FSX: Steam Edition needs you to log into Steam when playing online because it uses the Steam multiplayer system. 

To resolve this please start Steam and log into your account. Then head to your Steam library and launch FSX: Steam Edition.

If you do not want to play online you can always launched the game in offline mode from the Steam menu. 

If you require any further help you can always reach us here in the studio by emailing our team at dtgflightsupport@dovetailgames.com. We will always get right back to you with some advice as soon as possible

Thanks again for the review, 

Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition Team
Dovetail Games

Considering this Sim came out in 2006, it is still one of the best Flight Sims to date. 

The downside is that the dated landscapes look more like the Sim was greated over a mapping of Google Earth from 2006.

The upside is that with all the mods available, the ground can be improved on a basic level across the entire globe or in higher detail in certain regions. With payware mods like REX or Soft Clouds, you can dramatically improve the skys, water and some airport ground textures.

Since you can load real weather into this Sim with no mods added, I too must agree with many, this is the best Flight Sim (for real Aircraft flying).  Thr learning curve may be steep but the rewards are many.

Soooooooo realistic.

Here's my take on the civilian flightsim hobby as it currently stands: More than ever, it is a period of transition and I believe the future looks good. I have and use both FSX and X-Plane and therefore have a foot in both camps. It's a case of fully realized capabilities versus future potential. From another perspective I see one nearing the end of its 32-bit lifecycle and the other very much in its 64-bit adolescence.

Background: I've been flight simming since SubLogic's C64 release, and have been firmly entrenched in the Microsoft FS camp on PC since FS5.1, although like everyone else in the day I had and used Flight Unlimited, FLY! and ProPilot. We loved the variety and happily used them all for what they had to offer. For me FS2004/FS9 was the watershed, and I was entrenched for a decade in the sim using all the familiar add-ons and a full suite of GoFlight hardware. Unfortunately my computer was firmly stuck in 2004 as well, so I avoided migrating to FSX. I was aware of and had messed around with XP during my biannual pilgrimage to Oshkosh, even chatting at length with Austin Meyer, but I was already too deeply invested in the MSFS camp. I'm certain that many can relate.

I've been a licensed private pilot since 1991, with a multi-engine endorsement and lucky enough to have had exposure and stick time on some pretty cool equipment. Now as most real world guys will tell you, flying a computer is NOT the same - I don't care if the flight models are based on lookup tables or basic real-time elemental calculations, it's just not worth arguing over. Get over it.  Where there is tremendous value in simming however, is the 'process' of flight - planning, procedures, checklist habits, instrument scans, IFR approaches. For true immersion in the system look up PilotEdge and add that to your mix no matter what platform you fly.

I was fortunate enough to finally build a cutting edge computer recently. As a treat, I picked up FSX-SE to see how she'd run on a modern box. Looked good and I was enthused enough to purchase Aerosoft's A320/321 (an absolutely excellent add-on BTW). Then the dreaded terrain.dll crashes started on flights lasting longer than about 60 minutes. While I understand these errors may have been largely addressed in the new FSX-SE beta patch, I am very grateful for them. They gave me pause and saved me the hundreds of $$ I was prepared to pour into the scenery and add-ons in order to bring it up to the available standards: Orbx, UTX, ASN, PMDG, et al. It's a slippery slope most know only too well, and when you finally stop and look back at all the resources you have dedicated, the thought of migrating to something totally new seems not only daunting, but is likely financially unwarranted as well.

While waiting for a decade old piece of software to get patched by a third party so that I could run it on modern equipment and proceed to spend a great deal of money and tweaking time to get it to run correctly, the light bulb went on for me. Here I was at a crossroad and I was prepared to reinvest in the same old song and dance. Yes, it's the one tune everybody knows, but there was an opportunity to learn a new one. Even though I tried and failed to get the X-Plane demo working, I purchased the full version (10.35 currently) in order to give it an honest shakedown, flying it exclusively for a week. What that week gave me was an appreciation for just how immersive, smooth and realistic XP can be.

I spent a good deal of time reading the related forums, familiarizing myself with the tips, tricks and FAQs. I found the stock 172 and Baron okay (certainly the equal of their stock FSX equivalents), but added the beautiful Carenado C340 for some GA flying. (Aside - the C340 is a nice looking package and I'm glad I have it but there are some unforgivable faults that required modifications to actually work - in particular the CDI when tuned to an ILS. Basic stuff. For shame.) Then the FlyJsim 737-200 for some good old fashioned radio navigation at jet speeds. Wonderful aircraft, beautifully modelled cockpit and convincingly realistic performance numbers. Definitely a pilot's plane. The coming IXEG 737-300 looks incredible. And I needn't mention that PMDG is developing for XP with a DC6 to be followed by one or more of their 7xx series...

Sparse scenery? To me it looks far and away better than stock FSX. It's nicely scalable to the hardware you're running, and XP definitely makes proper use of modern hardware. The stock mesh is great, autogen works well, the road traffic is cool, and the night lighting is the stuff of pilot training heaven. But here's the kicker - there's so much freely available from the community. I've managed to populate my XP world with all the airport scenery I will be reasonably using with a few visits to the XP ORG. And if you have a look at what's possible using world2xplane... the future looks not only bright, but incredible. Need I mention no terrain.dll CTDs or OOM errors?

Stock XP weather is in my opinion better than stock FSX. Dressed up with ASN and REX however, and FSX has a strong lead. But based on how close XP is getting with aircraft and scenery, the weather engine won't be far behind.

Stock ATC is crap. But so is FSX's. Sorry, it's just not real. I alluded to it above, but try PilotEdge to see what real ATC is. Full stop.

This has become a rather long piece, sorry about that. I suppose I felt I had a lot to say about where we've been, where we are, and where we're going. MSFS has been how it was, and largely how it is now (I include P3D here). Is it time for change? One platform is nearing a developmental dead end, albeit with some wonderful add-ons, and one is just beginning to realize its potential with continuous and meaningful support.

I'll continue to use both platforms for now, I mean why not, I own both and enjoy each for what they offer. Let me be clear though - I will not be adding anything further to my FSX ecosystem, but will simply enjoy what I already have. FSX will be limited to getting my bus fix with that awesome Aerosoft A320, at least until the sim crashes with the latest .dll or OOM error. For the price of a decent FSX add-on, I would urge you to give XP a fair evaluation.

In the end I see FSX as an old woman all gussied up in makeup and a new designer dress. She looks great and is pleasant to spend quality time with, but be careful if you go out dancing - she may fall and break a hip. Now have you seen the new girl in town? Dances funny, but she's smart, modern, and has some really cool moves. You may want to meet her.

My future in the hobby is with XP. I know I am not alone. Developers take note.

This sim comes with a unique history - it should have been dead years ago but a stubborn community kept it alive, more specifically they kept developers alive who pushed the engine harder and farther than it was intended to be pushed, with some stunningly complex and complete simulations of the flying experience being released as addons.  This new release has met with some criticism, such as dovetail didn't listen to the community and releases addons that are weak, old and overpriced.  There might be some merit in that, but in some ways the complaints are inevitable.  On the good side, the sim is 64 bit, more stable and, like it or not, the future of the software.  The actual flight mechanics are "solid", I would say(X Plane has more sophistication there), but the addons are phenomonal and more and more are becoming compatible with the Steam version as devs see which way the wind blows. 
You'll definitely want to get some addons at some point.  I'd go for orbx scenery over the ones being sold here(expensive but just pick the areas you want to fly), ezdok camera(there's a beta for the steam edition that works fine), Accufeel, DX10 fixer, FSFlyingSchool and some of the higher rated planes that interest you(again, the ones on steam are 'meh' at best).  You'll probably want to make a decision on what sort of experience you want - some are really into all the navigation and procedures(real world pilots use them as a decent alternative to a real flight sim), some just want to fly around and look at scenery.  They are two very different worlds.

The age of this game shows in its user interface (settings / controls etc) but the gameplay itself is superb. Setting up controls can be fiddly, as there are a huge number of them, but not all need to be mapped to achieve a successful flight. The in-game graphics are fabulous and especially so in some cases, and the flight characteristics of the included aircraft seem very accurate and well-modelled (to me anyway, with only 1 hours' worth of real-world flight experience!). And it's a huge amount of fun, with hundreds of different locations around the world in which to fly. At the price I paid for the game (9.99GBP) I would say that it's a complete steal. So if you like flight sims, what's stopping you?

Planning to be a pilot?This game has been used as a flight simulator for In-Training pilots and can help you practice with your flying. Anyone who is planning to get a pilot license should check this game out!

Pluses: (1) Fantastic array of freeware and payware addons; (2) Very capable ATC and if wanted payware ATC; Great Traffic AI programs such as Ultimate Traffic; MyTraffic; Traffic 360; (3) numerous ground texture substitutions; (4)  very good flight planning tools;  (5) great weather overhaul programs (I have REX Essential plus overdrive).

Minuses: (1) stuck at 32 bit. Can bring big time systems to their knees when you crank up the visuals; (2)  dated look graphics wise.

Overall, FSX is a proven commodity but  could seriously do with a 64 bit  visual overall.

Other issues with a dated program such as this: Limited memory that it can access. I believe it is 4 gbs. So you will be looking at Out of memory errors as you add on the addons as it were. You will try to compensate by making room on your hard drive for virtual memory. But this will be an ever present issue with this 32 bit program.

The addons are multitudes.  Many will work and many won't or will need significant modification. These are the lifeblood of FSX and DT should do their level best to accelerate the transition.

I wish the DX10 issue was sorted out as it remains a problem on the Steam version.UPDATE: DX10 FIXER payware now available and compatible with FSX steam! Huge PLUS.

I just installed all the Orbx scenery texture/landclass  addons (3 main ones) and all work flawlessly including the great nightlighting.

So ultimately the success going forward for this franchise is DLCs . In that respect, I see some reviews crying about payware. Well yes, while freeware was the lifeblood of the entire franchise of MS flightsimming for years, when the 2000 editions overhauled the looks and graphics, etc. payware vendors started to create important content. You work, you get paid. Cry a river of tears otherwise or check out AVSIM as there is still plenty of freeware stuff out there. The reality is that it takes time and energy to create content such as a voice ATC communication program like MCE Ultimate Edition, beautiful airports, etc. It's in fact what has driven this franchise despite the fact MS dumped it but still retain the SDK like the family jewels (and on that issue MS - you're morons - like you dumped the other franchise which was getting a fantastic makeover MS train sim).

The only thing that will perenially afflict FSX is its 32 bit ceiling which severally limits memory access and is heavily dependent on the main processor. That's why you can come back to FSX after being away for several years, crank up the textures, etc. and your powerful 17-4790 and GTX 9800 graphics card  will be brought to their knees when you have weather implemented, textures maxed out,  AI going, etc.

Final point about this Steam version. Disappointed that though it appears more stable than the dvd version  it plays absolute second fiddle to Prepar3D v2.5. This latter FSX incarnation got a graphics overhaul and it is now DX11 compatible!! And it looks gorgeous and runs way better than any previous incarnations. What that means to me is that the Steam version will now be displaced. I've migrated all my stuff over.

At the end of the day this is the MOTHER franchise of all franchise games - the Bruce Artwick child of the Sub Logic days to it's sale to Microsoft and MFS 1.01. By the time of 2000 Microsoft Flight Simulator the franchise was  in the Guinness Book of Records with 21 million copies sold per June 1999. So why not dump such a successful franchise right? Tells you a lot about Microsoft and where it presently stands as a company.

OVERVIEW:
This game, for being made in 2006 is amazing, and with the Steam Edition revamp it's 400% better. It has an entire Learning Center for learning just about anything you could think of. FSX still rules as the best Flight Sim for someone to pick up and to play professionally, or casually. It has Free Flight where you can do whatever you want, and make your own trips, it also has Missions, where you can do stuff from flying around taking a guy who yells at you for turning to hard, to intercepting a suspected plane of illegal goods! The graphics are yes, a bit dated.
   Also the game plays alot like FS2004 and  shares alot of the same charactoristics.
   BE WARNED: I advise you not to buy the DLC because it doesn't have a rating of over 35% recommendation. ONLY AND ONLY IF it is 80% you should buy the DLC. Dovetail makes good games, but milks em' of money from DLC.
   This is also not really a game itself rather a learning tool, but there is alot of missions you can do.
   While this game works well with a keyboard, I like my XBox 360 controller a whole lot more.
   The Steam Edition is FSX Gold with acceleration.
PROS:
Great Sim for Pros and Novice flyers
Highly customizable flight conditions
Lots of missions to do
Many, many buttons to push
30+ Planes
Fly absolutely anywhere in the world
50+(ish) Missions
CONS:
Rather dated graphics (they get the job done)
A rather large learning curve if you never played a flight sim before (nothing that Learning Center can't fix tho)
DLC is worthless if not 80% off (but thats not the game itself)

It's not crashed for no reason during regular gameplay but try to do anything like alt-tab to check something else and you'll likely crash the game. 

However the time I have spent with it is fun and I'm loving the learning centre features. 

Unless they fix the many bugs I can recommend you pick this up only at a discount. I'd be upset if I paid more than US$15 for it but fortunately got it while on a steep discount.

*addendum* After tinkering with some settings the game has massively improved in stability. In particular it can save without crashing to desktop. FYI changed settings to allow Dirext X 10 (confused why that wasn't set as default) seems to have fixed it.

Plug in your Pilot Joystick or XBox Controller, and take to the skies in a virtual reality-like cockpit, while Microsoft handles the technical quirks.

First and foremost, I would like to recommend this game to my fellow Steam players and aviation enthusiests. It is awesome that there was a deal struck across Microsoft, Steam, and Dovetail, to create this offering to keep this great simulation product alive and kicking. 

To those of you looking to buy, this product has 20 years of experience and refinement behind it, while it is not still officially supported except by the Lockheed Prepare3d franchise (hopefully gainfully employing the awesome talent behind FSX). I am an instrument rated pilot in small planes, and it is every bit realistic as the real thing. Yes, you can use it to practice, yes you can use it to shoot instrument approaches and get better IMHO, but NO, the time/experience does not count with the FAA. 

There is a great group of hobbiests that continue to build/ship awesome programs to augment this franchise as well as cockpits and planes, both paid and free, that are available.

Good luck flying.

--g

This is more like comparison for new Flight Sim enthusiasts

FSX:SE
Pros:
- Cheapest Flight Sim with flexible payment methods on steam.
- Steam multiplayer and also some other steam features (like download, easy community access, home streaming...)
- Increased performance and better VAS usage over FSX:MS (boxed)
- Many add-ons already working, others also getting update for being compitable.
- Limited Support
Cons:
- Its not 64bit so still OOMs
- Not %100 FSX:MS add-ons compitable
- Limited Support
- SDK is not included

FSX:MS (Boxed)
Pros:
- Main game for Add-ons
- DVD installation (no download required)
- SDK included (Gold and Deluxe edition)
Cons:
- No support
- Unused copies can be expensive, hard to find in retail stores
- Only on DVD no download option or official online store
- Performance issues
- No official multiplayer servers. (Other multiplayer options still available)

Prepar3d
Pros:
- Most advanced FSX engine
- DX11 support
- Better system resources usage
- Updated landclass for some regions
- Many FSX add-ons already updated for it
Cons:
- Its not for "ENTERTAINMENT"
- Still not looks like new Flight Sim more like FSX with DX11
- Not developing by game studio
- After almost 10 years still no big changes on FSX engine
- Price is high, only sale on their own website (60$ is high for DX11 update, you should also re-buy some FSX add-ons)
- Some add-ons are expensive then FSX, 
- Bad UI
- FSX add-ons not %100 compitable (FSX:SE more compitable)
- EULA restrictions (also for add-ons)

X-plane 10:
Pros:
- Only 64 bit and OpenGL flight sim on market (so its supports Mac PC)
- Steam support, flexible payment methods.
- Its actually very different Flight Sim then FSX engine based games so you should read its own reviews. Because there are too many new features
Cons:
- Limited 3rd party support, limited add-ons
- Huge Download Size
- Worst UI

Let me get straight to the point. 

I use Windows 8.1 so when I bought the boxed version of FSX it didn't turn out so well. It crashed all the time, low frame rates and lets just say it didn't suit my computer as its a very old game. After a while it went completely corrupt on my computer and I gave up all together. Then I bought X-plane 10 when it went on sale. It was alright. Then one day I saw FSX on sale for only £3.99 and thought to myself, hell I enjoyed FSX so much before so why not buy this and if it goes corrupt on me then its only just £3.99. Let me tell you one thing. It was the best decision I had made in a while. It took me about 35mins to download (its a big game around 10gb) and as soon as I put it on I could tell this was made for my computer. I have around 24 hours on it and never has it once crashed on me. The boxed version felt like it was made for a 10 year old computer but Dovetail have done a great job on this and now it works great on Windows 8.1. I even use the PMDG 737ngx on it and no crashes whatsoever. Downloadable content is bs but I don't really care about that not when there's so much 3rd party content out there. 

If you are hesitant to buy this after having a bad experience on the boxed version, especially if your on Windows 8/8.1, well be hesitant no more. Hopefully Dovetail will continue to work on this game and make it even better then it is now.

I used to have this game some years ago for PC and it's better than I remember!! Even for an older product, "Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition" remains a truly immersive game, for experienced flyers and newbies alike. Before you get the game though, you should know that you need a joystick w/ a throttle for the "full experience."

I hate to refer to this as a game because most of the time I sit here staring intently trying to remember the most basic flight rules.  I have completed ground school years ago and have started getting back into learning the basics before getting into an actual plane, and although I loved FS9 and FSX, they never really worked well on Win7.  This works perfectly, no issues with graphics, updates, service packs, or even issues dealing with multiplayer.

The realism is done very well in smaller planes, I can't comment on larger planes because I've never flown anything bigger than a Cessna 172, however it's a great sim to sit and brush up on skills and review procedures.  It is a simulator though.  If you want fun crashing planes and shooting down  other people in an arcade fashion, you probably won't enjoy this.  If you enjoy learning to fly, the lessons by Rob Machado offered in-game are very realistic and would cost thousands in real life.  If you want to brush up on flight, procedures, or just learn more about how planes work and mechanics of flight, this is a great game.

I think this is a great game and all, but when I am taxing to my gate I don't want to have to use progressive taxi. If Dovetail could put numbers on the gates I would give this a ten out of ten, but for now I have to give it a nine out of ten.

Also  there hasn't been one update posted on here since I purchase it, not a bug-fix or note about what they are working on... just DLC $$$... Not what I want to see.
