I will tell you one thing about FSX Steam Edition: It runs much much better than the original FSX. I played and compared both editions on my old laptop (Core 2 Duo T9300 2.5 GHz , NVidia GeForce 8700M) and was delightedly surprised to find out that I was able to max more sliders and get higher frame rates than what I was able to achieve with the original FSX. The functioning multiplayer alone is worth purchasing this game. I am definitely enjoying the steam edition far more than I enjoyed the original FSX, and I will soon order my Saitek yoke and pedals to go along with it.

A much cleaner install and experience versus the boxed version. I am pretty sure the framerate is higher and smoother. Furthermore it works with Windows 8.1 whereas the boxed version was getting quite glitchy, having been released around the time of Windows XP/Vista. At the discount price this is worth getting.

Where it falls down is in compatibility with add-ons, which is patchy. I know ORBX are working on sorting this out for their products. Dovetail will apparently release official add-ons themselves, which should be interesting.

This is not a bad stop-gap pending the release of something all-new (FS 11) which is well overdue now. Dovetail may be working on this as I write.

Addon aircraft works! Here is how to make it work:

1. Make a folder:

32-bit Windows:  C:/Program Files/Microsoft Games/Microsoft Flight Simulator X
64-bit Windows:  C:/Program Files (x86)/Microsoft Games/Microsoft Flight Simulator X

2. Go to your directory that FSX Steam Edition is installed at: 

Steam/SteamApps/common/FSX

3. Copy fsx.exe to step 1

4. Install Aircraft then move all folders under step 1 to step 2.

Complete and enjoy! - FSXVM_BLAZE

I'm a private pilot and I've owned the boxed version of Flight Simulator X for years.

When I upgraded my system to Windows 8.1 I was saddened to see that my old Flight Simulator X started to develop glitches.  So when Steam released a new version I was excited.  I bought it on day one of it's release.
 
However, free flight mode wouldn't work.  But after emailing DoveTail Games tech support they deteremined that I had a corrupt download.  I did a re-download and install and it worked perfectly.  The problems were not with the game.
 
I'm very pleased that the graphics are better than ever.  There is over 24,000 airports around the world all with exact runway layouts, taxiways, buildings and scenery around the airports.  Plus every major city, tourist attraction, landmark, river, lake, stream around the world has been simulated. Navigation aides operate just like in real life.  Flight Simulator was a huge undertaking and it's all at your fingers for just a few bucks.  Amazing.

If you plan to get your pilot's license or need a tool to stay sharp (without spending $100+ per hour to rent a plane), then Flight Simulator X is a must have.  It's just a no-brainer.  Even if you own other flight simulators, you won't find any with all these features.
 
Microsoft along with other companies spent many years and millions and millions of dollars developing this product.  When it was developed it was actually built to take advantage of faster computers that would be available in the future.  That's why as time goes by, the game actually gets better.  
 
While I use it as a flight instruction tool, my son uses it like a game.  He enjoys the missions and together we go on sight-seeing tours.  We've  Flown over the pyramids and over the Nile river.  We've tooled over Washing DC and viewed the Lincoln Memorial, The Washington Monument and the Whitehouse.  You name it we've been there, Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, Space Needle, etc.
 
Your kids will learn more about world gerography from this game than from any book.  Because it's not just pictures, it's real life simulation.  They have to take off froma local airport and actually find landmarks.  
 
After I bought my Steam version of Flight Simulator, I was going to install my boxed "Accelleration Expansion Pack".  But to my surprise, I found that it already came pre-installed with this Steam set.
 
AND THE BEST PART... I once paid over $600.00 for a packaged video course on getting a private pilot's license.  But FSX comes with built in flying lessons by legendary Certified Flight Instructor Rod Machado.  He will teach you how to get not only your private pilot's license, then your instrument rating, then your commercial license, and then how to become an Airline Transport Pilot.  That much real life training in a real life flight school would be at least $25,000.  But you get it for free with FSX.  

Obviously nothing beats learning in a real plane, but this is a close second.  And it's all for the price of a pizza.
 
Since my first purchase I have purchased several copies as gifts for friends and family and would recommend it as either a game or a learning tool for any future private pilots.

One word: wonderful. 

To start with; the game itself didn't change that much compared to the boxed version. One of the best things of this version is the framerate. Dovetail did some engine tweaks which causes the game to run very smoothly now. Before this wasn't.

Multiplayer is a sort of back, although there are (yet) a few servers and that's it. At least game-spy is done.

Now, very important to remember: [b]this is [u]not[/u] a game[/b]. It's a simulator and basically it's kinda hardcore. Don't expect easy handling which makes you just fly. If you are thinking of buying this game, I recommend to buy a joystick as well. It gives you a better experience and makes it just easier.

Addons on fsxinsider.com are payware (which means you have to pay for those addons) ones, yet there are [b]a lot[/b] of freeware addons. Just google it.

Now, the game doesn't really have downsides other than the few multiplayer server which people have to host themselves. And there is yet no working multiplayer with the boxed version. It seems they will possibly do some updates... I hope at least.

In a nutshell:

Buy this game if you are a aviation freak, and buy a joystick or a home cockpit if you want to play seriously. Don't expect this to be a game where you just fly, and I'd love to have people who want to play multiplayer seriously.

After dabbling around with early versions of MS Flight Simulators and after Microsoft FLIGHT I was finally able to break my fears and frustrations when landing a plane.   I was just awful at it and it kept me from being serious at all or wanting to learn any more for many years.
     After the challenges in MS FLIGHT I wanted to commit to learning all the rest and sought out the MS FSX Demo and learned on that. 

     Earlier this year. After trying to find out if Microsoft would release a FSXI I,  learned Dovetail would be bringing it to STEAM and just waited... ...and am so happy I did.

     You can understand as a noob and with no investment in FSX beyond the demo and with no mods or add-ons to worry about how that would be a good thing.  Just to get the box, the patches, etc. etc. and hope it all works with Win7, etc. was a big worry for me. Typically I am not good with that kind of thing and get very frustrated when things aren't just, "Install and go!"   Dovetail was going to take care of all that and I was elated to wait.

     When September and October passed I was a little dis-heartened and wrote Dovetail a "Dear Santa" letter. To tell them FSX was still #1 on my list and it would be great to get it for Christmas.  My reply was short: "Stay tuned"

    Every few days I would check and was gobsmacked when it quietly released with no fanfare. Finding out it was available for only $5.00 after the wait and the work they put into it made my Christmas and this whole year! To me...they are the GREATEST!

     "Install and go!" And. I have. A no hastle install. It runs beautifully. There have been some random crashes now and then but to me...that is expected for awhile as they fully work it all out.   It's been wonderful to finally go through the tutorials and start making my way through the missions. I'm up to the, 'Rome-Naples Airline Run'

     The mods and add-ons are amazing and blow my mind how far people have taken it.  The Google and BING map/scnery integration and newer GPS systems are at the top of my list and getting them free or in a DLC would be nice.  

    My hopes are there will be a happy medium with regards to the folks who already have content. I see it both ways and can understand and feel the frustration.

   Anyway I have gone on long enough. I am a very happy individual and am very happy to finally join the ranks of the FSX community thanks to Dovetail!

     THANK YOU
     HAPPY HOLIDAYS

BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK.

I've been flight simming since the FS98 days and FSX is still the unoptomized pig that it was on initial release. Not to say that this isn't a good sim, but the hassle and frustration of going through individual files, tweaking values, and finding the one set of settings that works for your PC isn't worth the effort. And to give you an idea, I'm running an i7 3770k at 4.5ghz paird with a brand new GTX 970 and still get sub 30s with the graphics set to medium high. Get airbourn its not so bad, but the engine still chugs when you're close to the ground (usually on final appraoch, THE MOST IMPORTANT PHASE OF FLIGHT when you need smoothness the most).

The FSX community is fantastic, and there are those who are more than willing to help you find those desired settings to get the game running as smoothly as possible. However, if you just want a sim that is easy to pick up and use, go back to FS9 or go to X-Plane 10. There's a reason why the Microsoft team fired everyone that made this game.

This review is based on my personal experiences.

For the simulator fan:
I will start off by saying that I have both FSX and X-Plane 10, and that I am also a pilot in training in real life. I am relitively new to flight simulators but I would reccomend FSX over X-Plane 10 because it is very intuitive, easy to get flying, has great mechanics and loads of fun. X-Plane 10 also has realistic mechanics as well as great weather and detail in the cockpit, but is very hard to actually get started. I found it quite difficult to use, the contol menu baffled me with all the buttons and was just a pain to get running (I was completely new to that sort of thing). Then I got FSX on steam and it was extremely easy to get going. The graphics (especially in the cockpit) may not be as good as in X-Plane 10 though the scenery is still fantastic and I have had some very enjoyable 737 flights so far. The flight planner is also very simple and you can create a route which you can use in game in no time at all. When you launch the program, everything you need to set up is in the 'launcher' and when you click the 'fly' button, you're left free in the cockpit. FSX also has the addition of missions from an airline pilot role to rescue and military, which are fun and a nice touch. They are rated to a skill level so you know what sort of missions you will be able to do.

For a casual gamer:
If you are looking for some fun or you just want to try out flying aircraft, this game is great. However, it does require some understanding of aircraft(which you can learn as you play if you put the time into it) in order to get the most out of FSX. You can use the 'learning centre' in the launcher to get to know your way round the simulator and learn how to fly anything from a small single engine Cessna to a huge Boeing 747 airliner, and it is most enjoyable with a joystick. Mine just worked as soon as I started the game without me even having to change the settings. Compared to other simulators FSX makes it easy to get flying, just select 'free flight', pick an aircraft, practically any airport in the world, time of day, and weather and hit 'fly now'. I would not suggest getting this game if you just want a laugh, because it does require some time to fully get to grips with it and doesn't really offer any fun from messing about with a plane (crashing isn't any fun - I've tried). You may find it hard to understand all the features in the game (as I did), such as communicating with ATC or performing a landing with full ILS, but through time you get used to it.

Verdict:
This game is great for simulator fans and casual gamers alike. The graphics are not bad even by today's standards and it does not have many bugs, though the ones it does have are noticeable, but not game-breaking. You can get a lot of fun out of it if you stick with it and try to understand everything, and in my opinion is the best low-cost flight simulator on the market - perhaps even competes with higher-budget options. I would definately reccomend this game.

Concept is good, but execution is very poor. Wish I had never bought this.

Flight Simulator X is not a new game. However, this is an upgraded and improved version of the original game you could only get on a disk. It's an older game, so your pc can probably handle it. The original boxed version had some annoyances, including huge patches you needed to download, an annoying activation limit (don't expect to install the disk version on your new pc..) -- these problems have been resolved.

If you have a joystick, flying around is pretty fun. Recommended for anyone who wants to be a pilot (even if only virtually). Just don't expect dogfighting, this is a simulation game after all. You'll learn how to fly simple planes... and eventually a Boeing. Or you can just go ahead an immediately fly in a jet. There's missions and free flight, and even Steam multiplayer. Oldie but goodie with solid (stability) improvements.

It's great to see this franchise resurrected! I have been playing Flight Simulator since the days of FS98. FSX was a true masterpiece as others have commented and I was very sad to see the franchise get axed by Microsoft. Thankfully, Dovetail has released the classic game on Steam. Through some under-the-hood tweaks, it plays better than the boxed version of FSX that Microsoft released!

The performance increase alone makes this a worthwhile purchase. It is also worth the money to not have to safeguard your old FSX discs and serial since you can always re-download on Steam.

I would highly recommend and encourage people to support this effort and game. We need some life breathed back into the flight simming world!

Eight years later and there's still tons to do do and see in FSX! Dovetail Games (of Train Simulator fame) has done an amazing job on the re-release, boosting performance significantly and restoring the multiplayer feature that sadly died with GameSpy earlier this year. People of all ages and experience should be able to enjoy this title. Best of all, the flight simulation marketplace is full of addons that add everything from high-res graphics to scenery to new models. The sky really is the limit!

Flew Cessna... yuck! Awful flight model. Try X-Plane, it has a much more immersive behaviour (granted the terrain graphics/models are a far more generic... but then the graphics in this FSX are hardly like being there either, and have a very gamey feel.)

In the past 24 hours, I've learned a lot about flying. This simulator, while elderly by computer standards, is an absolute dream. It runs perfectly on my laptop. It also comes with a TON of literature about flying, so you can really get into the whys and wherefors of the simulation (hint: learn to trim so you don't have to keep a deathgrip on your stick). The playthrough tutorials are good but the flight lessons have long, entertaining essays that will really hone your skills. Sadly, the in-game scripts for the flight lessons are not included as of this writing. Still, for someone on a budget with an older machine, this is about as good as it gets.

It's just the boxed FSX with a new logo and splashscreen.

But it's on steam, which means it's even better. You get the acceleration pack, updated multiplayer and better performance than the boxed version.

As a boxed version owner, which the key only had a limited amount of usage, the steam version is way better, as you can have FSX on more computers (I believe).

Overall, a big thumbs up from me!

How to play olympic flight simulator:

I have owned FS9 and FSX:Gold and have flown hundreds of hours with my dad, and I have to say... They really fixed it! This simulator used to run terrible even on my current i5-3570k OC + GTX 970 build, even on Medium-High settings with no anti-aliasing. They really have fixed it as now I can get a solid 60+ FPS (on a 144hz monitor >.>) on Ultra with Dense Autogen scenery and Anti-aliasing.

Looking forward to future updates!

I've held on to Flight Simulator X. I love this simulator to death. Of course, the simulator itself has been showing it's cracks and it's not as shiny as X-Plane or DCS, but make no mistake. There is a reason why a majority of the people play FSX over other Flight Simulator platforms. That said, I was quite surprised to see FSX live its legacy with a Steam Edition.

To be honest, I'm quite mixed about seeing the game on Steam. FSX is my little niche thing and it would be quite annoying (or amusing) to see some nine-year old flying like... a nine-year old, but with this release, the simulator receives a new lease of life as support is finally restored to a game that has long been thought abandoned by the publishers (We all know MS Flight sucked).

That said, I've tried and tested the simulator. For starters, the simulator runs quite well 'out of the box'. I then tested the simulator with add-ons as well. I had too. I've heard that this game has 'improvements'. So I've installed and tested ORBX YBBN Airport scenery with FTX Australia SP4. When I test for performance, I always test this particular airport. FTX is an amazing developer of add-on sceneries, but the Brisbane Airport (IATA:YBBN) is poorly optimized. No matter what setting I do, it just falls flat of expectation (Some settings are smooth, but it's below their recommended graphics settings). And I'm running an i7 3770k clocked at 4.2 GHz. I'm also using a GTX 660Ti. Just a note, the GPU is not necessarily the depending factor here. Usually, a better CPU leads to significant performance gains. CPUs needs to be overclocked (usually above 4.0 GHz) for optimum performance.

Unfortunately, it was no surprise that FSX:SE performed poorly in this scenery. Who was I to expect something short of a miracle? Unfortunately, this confirms what I've feared. The Steam Edition provides improvements (I will explain later), but you still need to tweak the fsx.cfg file located at the AppData\Microsoft\FSX folder. Some tweaks that I had to adjust were the Texture Bandwith Multiplier = 40 (It was set to 160), Set Affinity Mask = 15, Fiberframetimefraction=0.50 (default is 0.33), WideViewAspect = True, Regardless, it still performed like pizza in this scenery (I actually regret having this scenery), Just a note, while I've actually copypasta the entire fsx.cfg installed in my other hard drive, take caution in doing so. I noticed that the cfg file of the standalone and the steam edition are arranged differently. The [MULTIPLAYER] section of the cfg file is most definitely different.

Now I've noticed that some people in youtube have uploaded themselves playing the Steam Edition. I noticed one video where the person was using DX10. It's quite easy to spot when one is using DX10 even if they don't mention it. I found it quite odd. Everyone in to flightsim should know, unless you have Steve's DX10 scenery fixer, It is usually common knowledge to always use DX9. The reason for this is because while performance gains are realized in DX10, DX10 mode is inherently broken. That's why the ticker box is 'DX10 Preview'. Development was never finished. That said, I gave it a shot.

Here is where I was impressed.

Steam Edition performed phenomenally well in DX10. It's still not the homerun, but I was pleased with the performance. By this time, I had installed the ORBX Cairns Airport Scenery and compared it with DX9 and DX10. Brisbane performance was still kinda bad, but better. In both the Brisbane and Cairns scenery, I flew in the 3D cockpit of the default F/A-18 aircraft.

But you said DX10 performs well in FSX in the first place?

I did, but I was quite shocked with what I saw while running the simulator in DX10. Some of the broken things about DX10 have been fixed. One of the most annoying DX10 blunders is the opaque gray texture replacing the livery texture of commercial AI aircraft. That's been fixed. You could fly in the day with no problem. Flying at Dawn/Dusk, or night time can still be a problem though. The runway/taxiway still becomes opaque at dawn/dusk and the lights still disappear at these times. Cockpit shadows are still blunt. So while some DX10 blunders have been fixed, you may still require Steve's DX10 Scenery Fixer.

So do I recommend this game?
Considering that multiplayer is restored in the Steam Edition and DX10 performance is quite well, I'd definitely recommend this game, especially for the price. However, unless you're not into playing with add-ons free or paid, be prepared to modify the fsx.cfg, which I can say from experience, is a frustrating activity. Also, if you're in to add-ons, make sure you do have a Core-i7 desktop and a GTX 660Ti  equivalent or higher. Always overclock your CPU above 4.0 GHz. Memory with low timings also helps (although some will dispute that this is not necessary). It also helps to have an SSD if you plan to install FSX on a separate drive (FSX can take a long time time to load).

That pretty much wraps up my review, so Good luck and Happy flying to you all!

EDIT: So apparently, I had forgotten that my CPU is 4 cores, 8 threads. I was using the wrong value for the affinity mask. I changed the value from 15 to 85. Both DX9 and DX10 run better now. Brisbane is much better, but still gets some hiccups.

Having owned the boxed copy of FSX: Deluxe as well as the Acceleration addon, I was originally on the fence when I first noticed FSX:SE on Steam. When it went on sale, I jumped on it simply thinking I'll have the convenience of a digital copy (installing from multiple DVDs + manually entering two serial numbers plus hunting down the latest patches and tweaks to get it to run on Win7 x64 is tiresome).

Little did I realize that FSX:SE isn't just the same binary distribution from the boxed DVD set, but has been updated. The source was modified to support Steam multiplayer and chat, rebuilt with VS2013*, tweaked to ensure Win7/8/10 64-bit compatibility**.

I haven't benchmarked the sim compared to its boxed counterpart on the same system, but it certainly feels smoother. I've cranked the custom details completely to their highest (texture size, terrain visibility, cloud detail, autogen, scenery density, traffic, etc) and haven't noticed any studdering or low frame rates. It might be placebo, but nonetheless it's nice to finally be able to run a 2006 sim flawlessly and smoothly, albeit on a 2014 PC (i7-4770K, 16GB RAM, Geforce 770).

Unfortunately, I don't own any additional payware test out with FSX:SE, but the free aircraft I've tried out thus far appear to work with no issue. I'm hoping to see Steam Workshop support in the future. However, I'm only concerned about the possibility that DTG might start reselling previously-advertised features as DLC (like they did with TS).

*I'll vouch for the advances in optimizations that MS's C++ compiler has undergone since VS2005. I've seen some cases increase ~10% in performance between VS2008 and VS2010 alone.

**Contrary to some info on the forums, the binaries are still 32-bit. While it no longer crashes or runs abnormally on Win7/8/10 64-bit platforms, there's still a 4GB limitation that might be problematic if one loads too many resource-intensive addons. I'm hoping DTG addresses this in a future update.

I have been a real world aviator for the past 18 years. Back when I was training for my Instrument Rating, MS Flight Sim became more than just a game. It was an essential tool in the flight bag that helped solidify essential skills needed to fly in the IFR world. The end result of which saved me time and money obtaining my rating. I basically taught myself IFR flying. It was essential to understanding VOR radials and ADF tracking and intercepts.

After flying for a career for the past 8 years I'd never thought I'd have use for MS Flight Sim ever again. However, recently I dusted off my old copy of MS Flight Sim to help prepare for my Boeing 737 type rating. A company designed a fairly accurate version of the 737 with the correct system logic. It even included a fairly accurate FMC. Once again MS Flight Sim proved useful and was essential to understanding the systems of the 737 and cockpit flows. Hopefully the Steam version will allow for these add-ons. 

My advice to anyone using MS Flight Sim as a training tool would be to treat it as just a game until you start instrument training and be prepared for many misunderstandings. My previous four year’s experience as flight instructor and chief flight instructor has taught me that those used Flight Simulators during their Ab Intio training developed bad habits that needed to be trained out of them. Once you have completed your Ab Intio training, it can be an excellent training tool.

I can fly anywhere in the world. This game is truly amazing. There are over 20,000 airports in this game. Even in a small island country there are airports.

If you're flying a jet, you're more than likely going to be using autopilot most of the time, so it won't really matter anyways.

At the time of posting this (22/12/14)  a lot of addons for the DVD game isn't working. The devs may fix that, they may not.  However, the amount of content in this game is still outstanding. You have over 20 planes that you can play and mess around with it. If you really like flight games, then this is the game for you.

If you are buying this steam version because some people said it’s smoother and gives more FPS, you’ll be disappointed because there is no enhancement whatsoever apart from the return of multiplayer. 

I own a boxed version and have acceleration with service parks including lots of add-ons. I get a reasonable FPS in my windows 7-64bits but just like every fsx simmer you never get enough. So when I read the feedbacks here about how it was improved, I decided to give this steam version a go. I bought it yesterday, download took like an hour or so and installation was smooth. I have made few flights now, the truth is that the only difference is that it is a combination of Gold Edition, Acceleration and Service park, and that Multiplayer is back, also uiautomationcore.dll was added to the main directory for windows 8. Performance is exactly the same as FSX Deluxe Edition with Acceleration and service park without any add-on or tweak.

I have to admit that I am not very sad that I bought this steam version, but this is because my boxed version is almost cracked and I think it’s a good idea to have a digitally signed one saved at Steam library. Another thing I’m hoping for is that since this simulation is very old and therefore do not take advantages of new and better graphic cards and systems and Microsoft no longer provide updates, hopefully with steam re-releasing it now future updates will be a possibility, if not it is going to be a waste for those who have boxed version already. 

As for those wondering if existing addons will work. Almost all addons that you can normally copy and paste into FSX will work in Steam version, Mine worked, I have never installed any which needs installation yet. Also I installed this version in the same PC I already have FSX, both are working fine.


If you want to read the reviews, from the beginning there is a separate tab for positive and negative feedbacks, which I didn’t notice. The default is positive so make sure to check the negatives also.
Dated in many ways, FSX still manages to entertain as a good civvie sim. For the price and the sheer amount of content involved, this is a great sim to start on

I have been playing FSX for 5 years now. I am not a pilot, I just always enjoyed games that aloowed you to fly. 

That said, FSX is an awesome experience for players looking for a good flying experience, all the way to real life pilots looking to practice their skills without paying for it in fuel. This game actually has the largest map ever, it's Planet Earth. The shear number of places to go and things to see is insane. Even for a game that is 8 years old, it still has scenes of absolute beauty.

This isn't an easy game. You throw on full realism, a crosswind, and a major thunderstorm... good luck making it off the ground. The physics of this game are beyond good. The controls leave you options as well. You can use keyboard and mouse, or a gamepad, or a joytick, or a full blown yoke, rudder pedals, and throttles. Whilst the full setup is a little spendy, I myself am saving up for one to experience flying in a more realistic manner, the Attack 3 doesn't cut it.

When gamespy went down, FSX multiplayer went with it. I suck at piloting, my joystick doesn't cut it for me. So in multiplayer I tried out being an air traffic controller. Let me tell you, I found my niche. I got hours upon hours of enjoyment guiding players to their runway, destination, or gate. Ground, Tower, Approach, Departure, Center, you name it, I loved it. Then gamespy happened. I was said. Now with Dovetail getting rights, I am happy to be able to try out my ATC again.

Speaking of Dovetail, cudos to them for wanting to continue one of the world's most storied game series. Hopefully they don't use the same sales model as Train Simulator, because that would suck. But alas, the series is being developed again. I for one cannot wait to see a new version with even more up to date graphics and physics that take full advantage of today's powerful computers.

Just a rock solid good experience. 10/10

The most classic Flight Simulator is a "new polished gem" by Dovetail Games and finally on Steam. 
No more hassle with no working keycodes anymore and a more pleasant multiplayer experience.

I strongly recommend Flight Simulator Steam Edition.

Classic Microsoft Flight Simulator X, what more can you say? Great realism and complexity, some new aircraft thrown in the mix, with the promise of add-on packs and the possibility of Steam Workshop content. This is the best flight simulation game on the market, and Steam is brilliant for acquiring and releasing this well-loved classic. I'm an M-Soft F-Sim vet, I fell in love with the series with Flight Sim 2000, then 2002, I've owned the tin box edition of 2004: A Century of Flight for years. Never got to play X until now; the mechanics are vastly improved, as are the graphics and the quality of the missions.  

In the first mission I played, I took mid-air control of a Cessna flying towards a small airstrip set on a peninsula in Alaska. I followed a Cessna Grand Caravan to the runway, and slowed my approach to give the Grand Caravan time to clear the runway. When air traffic control declared the runway clear, I aligned my approach and set the flaps to full. However, as I approached the runway I saw that my path would be blocked by a large cruise liner entering port. His path intersected with mine, bringing him between my plane and the runway just as I was slowing for the final stages of my approach. I increased throttle and pulled up, passing dangerously close to the gigantic liner; but having cleared the ship, I slammed my throttle closed and pulled the air brake in an attempt to land at a safe speed. I hit the runway and bounced once, twice, and on the third dip made contact with the runway and slowed to under forty knots. I then gently taxied to the airport terminal and parked next to the Grand Caravan that I had followed to the runway.

In my second mission, I took mid-air control of a Learjet over the mountains of Colorado, near Telluride. This is familiar territory for me, so I took time to appreciate the rendering of the scenery: deep valleys with low-lying fog at their centers, rivers carving their ancient paths through the Rocky Mountains. Then I was politely warned that I was flying too low and too fast, and needed to maintain an altitude of 12,000 feet to approach the airport, at a speed of 140 knots. I obliged the polite air traffic controller, and spotted the runway nestled at the top of a mesa ahead of me. I was told to increase flaps to full and extend my landing gear, but a problem with the landing gear triggered a buzzing alarm which would become the soundtrack for my panicked descent. I attempted several more times to extend the gear, but to no avail; the doors were apparently stuck. On my last attempt, with the runway in sight only a few hundred yards ahead of me, the doors opened and the landing gear deployed. I engaged the airbrake and pulled the nose back as I gently made contact with the runway. Following the ATCs intructions, I taxied to the left of the runway and parked next to two limosines. The celebrity cargo was safely delivered, and I was rewarded with a autograph that read, "Greetings from Telluride!"

The missions in this game are incredible and engaging, leaps and bounds ahead of the boring missions of the previous games. The heart of the game, however, is in simulating flights in real-time, and if you have never played a Microsoft Flight Sim before, you are in for a treat. You are given full control of the simulation, you can plan flights to anywhere in the world. Locations are rendered beautifully, and the graphics settings are flexible enough to run smoothly on most any gaming rig. The game automatically logs all of your free and mission flights.  You can communicate and plan with ATCs at any airport in your vicinity, even requesting an emergency landing if you need to do so. Using the flight planner, you can set starting points and destination points, and the game includes almost every airstrip in the world (even private strips). The game can be set to include in-flight emergencies, can require you to stop and refuel when you get low. Nearly every aspect of this game can be customized to suit your playing style.

In short, this is the king of flight simulation games, and Flight Simulator X was the final and greatest installment in this series. Do yourself a favor and learn to fly like a pro, Steam did the gaming community a service by reviving this amazing classic.

For those who don;t know what FSX is, it's a kind of gateway drug to the life consuming hobby of Flight Simulation. It's a proper sandbox, in the sense that you can set your own goals and make it pretty realistic and learn about flight procedures, flight planning, ATC jargon etc etc or you can just try and fly a jumbo under bridges on the Thames upside down. Whatever.

There is a huge communtity of hobbyists producing freeware as well as some incredible commercial products, and things like IVAO and VATSIM who provide a networked environment with live Air Traffic Control. 

It's the one area of gaming which I return to again and again, as I get bored of the GTA's and Skyrims etc etc limited gameplay and repetition. 

Anyway, get this! Just get it.

Cons: 
-Poorly detailed terrain (but you do get the entire planet).
-Low speeds, even for commercial airliners.
-No crash effects, kind of boring this way.
-No co-pilot AI.
-VERY steep learning curve, but it is a flight simulator.
-No real air transit companies, but you do get real aircraft manufacturers.
-Cities are lifeless.
-No aircraft paint customization.

Pros:
-As mentioned, YOU GET THE ENTIRE PLANET!!!
-Several planes and helicopters to start with, each with a few paint variants.
-Every airport, big and small, seems to be included.
-Confusing controls, but you can easily simplify them.
-Real-time weather based on your location in-game and what it is really like there in real life.
-Static weather choices as well.
-Most major landmarks can be seen.
-Controller support (I haven't used a joystick yet, but you can).
-Air traffic controller and pilot voices, adding realism.
-Can listen in on radios to hear talking between AI aircrafts and AI traffic controllers.
-Great tutorials.
-Multiplayer.
-Sandbox mode, as well as missions
-Custom difficulty (unlimited fuel, or not, etc).
-Weather does affect the aircraft.
-Aircrafts look good.
-Well organized menus.
-Able to customize your voice and callsign.
-Able to customize your jets flight number.
-It feels like a real airplane/helicopter.
-Other aircrafts in the sky, landing or taking off.
-A million ways to customize the gameplay.
-Pretty good sounds, but I do recommend playing your music in the background.

Verdict:
-I have never actually flown a plane or helicopter before, nor will I. However, this game/simulator allows people, like me, to fly the aircrafts of their dreams! I wish that the cities were better, and the terrain looked like real terrain, but this is about the flying, and the flying is great! From fighter jets, which control like the ones in the ARMA series, to the commercial airliners, Microsoft Flight Simulator X provides a fun and exciting experience for anyone who wants it. 

-Minor flaws like the lifeless cities and the lack of damage/explosions does hold the game back a bit, but the flying more than makes up for it! 

-As I said before, the game has a huge learning curve and only real pilots will feel right at home. However, the game does provide several helpful tutorial missions that will get the rest of us in the cockpit in no time!

-Overall, I think that Microsoft Flight Simulator X is a very good game. Now that it is on Steam, I recommend that anyone who likes airplanes, helicopters or simulators should give this a shot.

-Balancing out the poor graphics with the amazing flying, I would give MSFSX an 8/10.

Microsoft Flight Simulator 10 (FSX) In the steam sale at $4.99 (80 percent off) was absolutely worth it not to have to worry about buying discs again. 
Masses of free addons and content available on the flightsim sites, so you never need to buy the planned DLC unless you really want it but these simulators with this quantity of existing free content on flightsim sites all over the web are under-selling that aspect of the game and community by not including steam workshop as an easy way to import content, instead of trawling the internet for it.

If you are only ever going to buy one flight simulator, and even you are new to flight simulation and want something that you can add to and get a lot of time out of, you really should consider this one, specially in the next steam sale.  In the meantime there are plenty of other really outstanding free open source simulators if you just want to try the genre.

TL/DR: 9/10 worth it just to have the last in the historically important Microsoft Flight Simulator series in your collection.  Demo/Trial version here  http://www.microsoft.com/Products/Games/FSInsider/downloads/Pages/FlightSimulatorXTrialVersion.aspx

The game I have logged countless hours, is finally on Steam! 
With many improvements. But please note that some of the both freeware and payware addons(for example ORBX) will struggle to locate your FSX directory and the cfg directory.

This version is just like the Boxed Version of FSX when it first came out in it's Gamespy days.

The Steam version is not compatible (Multiplayerwise) with the FSX Boxed version which has been around for years which is a shame, as this would take flightsim Multiplayer back to the glory days.
Because of this you will find lots of Noob players and may find it hard to find the simmers that take it a little more serious, but not too serious it is a game after all. ;)

FSX in general is perfect for both the Professional Pilot and Air Traffic Controller if used correctly, whilst also being a game for those just starting out with an aviation interest.

Aircraft can be setup to be easy to fly or configured to fly realisticly including startup procedures.
Don't flick the switches in order and your plane won't start or Overspeed and you will stress your aircraft.

There are lots of FSX groups about.
Some can be very strict sticking to real life rules, Some groups can be a lot of fun with little to no rules and there are groups that combine the two providing a fun session whilst trying to stick the the real world rules.

FSX is a must if your interested in aviation in anyway.

Over all FSX Steam Edition on its own is a great deal at its current price, espcially considering it includes the Acceleration addon with the latest updates for newer computers. It runs like a dream and for those just starting flight sims this is a steal of a deal.   Easy to play and lots of fun!

A word of cultion however, with regards to addons.  Right now from my use most Freeware addons (Aircraft repaints, etc) do work fine.  

But if you're a hard core FSX Player or Sim gamers or are thinking of buying PAYWARE Addons from 3rd parties at the moment many of these appear to not be compatiable with this current version.

Some options you have are currently for these payware items are

1. Most payware addons for weather, and ai traffic generators have demos,  I would reccomend trying the demo first before buying it. Odds are if the demo doesn't work the real thing won't work in game. Most demos are basicly just restricted acesses versions of the real DLC so be sure to TRY IT before you Buy it

2. Wait for payware 3rd party addons or steam to solve exisiting problems (though some issues may never be resolved so keep that in mind)

3. Simply avoid payware 3rd party addons and stick to the basic "vanaliia" version: or stick with free ware.

4. For the Hard core gamer it who already has FSX, unless you're intrested in the mutiplayer I would reccomend not getting it until such issues are resolved with payware.   But that's up to you

Over all the steam addition is great and works really well and if the minnor issues of compatitbility/game version recognition errors this will likely become a MUST BUY game for any aviation enthusiasts or starting sim players.

So take to the skies but don't thorw calution  to the wind!

I'm a lover of simulators, and a long time customer of Microsoft's Flight Simulator series, all the way back from 98 to FSX. FSX was a great game back in 2006, but this new release makes a great oldie even better. 

Yes, they couldn't really update the graphics engine, and yes the framework is still 8 years old, but it works and works well. Steam integration makes it seamless to launch. Bugs have been fixed and the game is a MUCH better experience. 

And biggest of all, ALL MY FAVORITE FREEWARE MODS STILL WORK. Yes, the file structure is EXACTLY the same as FSX used to be. Everything still works. Mods from 2007 dropped in seamlessly. 

So don't be worried. If you loved this game before, you'll still love it here. I HIGHLY recommend this game.

Wow! I wasn't expecting this to be released any time soon on steam. I was aware that earlier in the year Dovetail was going to publish this as a Steam edition version, but I definitley didn't expect it to come out day 1 of the Winter sale and for 5 dollars on sale (25 USD regular). There was a time I felt like a few months ago that it would be great to finally actually own a legit copy of the sim I spent so much time on - but boxed versions on Amazon were becoming increasingly rare and expensive. Now, I'm happy I can have this forever through a decent game client. Yes!!

Just to set some things clear, I've spent tons of hours in the non steam version of FSX: Acceleration. I switched to, and now own Prepar3d V2 Academic a few months ago (basically FSX but optimized as much as possible for DX11 features and some other tweaks to that effect) and a variety of addons. I still think P3D is probably the best you can get for a modern 2014 PC if you want the FSX experience, being as it gets frequent performance updates and has DX11 lighting, etc - but it isn't on Steam, and is 50 dollars for an academic license. There is also the somewhat large issue that most of the FSX addons either don't work in P3D, have some kind of yakety way of overcoming that, or are just flat out not compatible with P3D. So what do you do if you want modern performance enhancements, but want to use your addons?

Enter the Steam Edition. Reading the changelog of the SE version, you can see that Dovetail has taken the best fixes and tweaks that flight simmers have analyzed and tinkered with tooth and nail since 2006 to get the sim working well and incorporated it into FSX. If you enjoy doing .cfg tweaks; you still can, but the workload is much less to worry about if you're just wanting to hop in and fly in regards to performance. the HIGHMEMFIX entry, the uiautomationcore.dll, all of that stuff is a part of this package. Anyone who frequently installed or messed with FSX Accel would know all too well about these "annoyances" (in my opinion) and would be happy that they're finally here by default. 

I cannot speak high enough of the sim. The only thing that I never really liked was the infinite tweaking I had to do to get blurry textures to load faster, frame rate to become stable, and the dozens of frame limiting programs and graphic card tweaking I had to do to get an extra frame or so - all recommended by people who were in no way involved in the actual development process. For the longest time, this sim has had to stand on the legs of the community propping it up - which in itself isn't a bad thing at all - just a very slow and tedious way of improving the sim as much as possible, which in my opinion could have happened a lot faster if the original dev team supporting it were still around. Is this sim now so well optimized that you no longer need to tweak? Probably not, but this edition is about half the battle already.

To wrap this recommendation up, the things I'm most happy/sad about in this edition are:

The long known optimization tweaks being implemented as standard, the newer splash screen, the multiplayer coming back (it was so sad when the boxed version's multiplayer died :'[ ) The real world Jeppensen weather feature now back and able to download for real weather anywhere in the world, and the Steam integration. I can also use REX Natural ENB with this without errors. The negative? Some of my FSX addons as of SE release still do not work with this edition. It is unknown to me why. Texture replacers like REX seem to work fine, but weather engines like my copy of ASN do not. It tells me SimConnect isn't installed when you do in fact install it as a first step of the installation of the sim. Uninstalling and re-installing seem to do nothing. ASN is a weather injector that is highly dynamic, similar to OPUS and the REX weather engine. I use it for P3D, but my purchase also has an FSX version as well - which as stated has these problems. It would be an issue if they had not revived the Jeppensen weather downloader in the sim, which is fine for now, but I'd rather like to use my own weather engine!


All in all, P3Dv2 will still be my main simulator, without a doubt. My Orbx addons are there, my aircraft addons are there, ASN works there, and my REX4 HD textures are compatible there. The lighting is better optimized in DX11, and the scenery, performance and frame rate are consistent. The FSX SE brings back multiplayer, FSX only addons, and some under the hood tweaks that have made it function at an acceptable level again - and that, I think is worth sticking around for.

It's still FSX, it's just on Steam. 

Still only uses one processor core, still doesn't properly use the graphics card.

I'd still recommend as it's the Gold Edition (with all the DLC) and everything is handled by Steam, no faffing with service packs or trying to get it to run on later versions of Windows, it's much more stable and that's really nice, but expect little to no performance gains as other reviews claiming optimisations are vastly exaggerated. 

I've got an AMD FX-8120
A GTX 760
16BG RAM

Full settings (all sliders up) 1080p runs at 10fps in cities, minimum settings (all sliders down) 720p can still drop below 40fps, maxing at about 80fps,

Both min and max setting have core 1 at 99% with no other cores active.

It works, but not well.

My personal opinion about this game or simulation software (whatever you prefer). I'm using FSX since 2006, and honestly, it was a nightmare back than since there simply was no hardware you could buy for money which was able to run it in a way that it was playable. This lasted for approximately 3 years. During that time Microsoft released 2 service packs and Intel released the first generation  of i7 processors which finally allowed the game/software to become really playable. 

I'm always juggling between the terms game and simulation software. This is because to some users FSX is a game and to other users it is a flight simulation platform. What is the difference? Well, if you see it like a game, then FSX does offer you great missions which will provide you a great deal of fun during a few weeks. If you see it as a flight simulation software, then it will become more complicated. The reason is because you can start training for a real pilot licence with this software. But this will only be interesting if you try to do it right as closely as possible as real pilots do. The problem with this is that then it is no more about flying around, which by the way will become boring very fast. But then, you will have to learn the real rules of the sky and the aviators. The learning curve will be much steeper but so much more rewarding. There are some really good books on the market which are based on Microsoft flight simulator training which will guide you through the process. I am myself a real world private pilot and I started with Microsoft Flight Simulator back in 2006 and then started working on my real pilot licence in 2009. It did help me a lot, but I also caught some flaws by simming. The problem is that in the sim you mostly have only one screen and thus you tend to focus more on your instrument panel. In real world VFR flying you have to focus more on the outside of the plane in order to navigate. I was so proficient when I started flight training that my instructor asked me if I already had some flight lessons in the past. But he also caught me too often staring at my instruments, because I got used to it while doing flight simulation. You will for sure not be able to fly a real plane only with flightsim training, but it will help you a great deal to get proficient in procedures and radio navigation and lots of other things.

But Flight Simulator X really starts to shine when you start to add quality add-ons. They bring FSX to a whole new level. You can add new weather engines, highly detailed aircrafts which do cost more than FSX itself but which allow you to operate them by the real airplane books. This is the case for general aviation airplanes as for airliners. But there is also a bunch of software add-ons which enhance the whole world of FSX. More detailed elevation meshes which cover countries, continents of even the whole world! The same is true for airports, roads, amd rivers which are much more detailed. You can buy add-on airports which look exactly like the real thing. Actually most of the large airports have been recreated in detail by add-on companies.

Now you could ask yourself, but what do I get then in the Steam Edition, which is in my opinion nothing else than a MS FSX Gold Edition with a few optimizations and bug fixes. You do get a game/simulation software which tries to approximately simulate the whole planet earth, get a nice fleet of airplanes to start with. Yes, you will be able to fly in every country on earth. But only something like 40 or 50 cities and large airports have been recreated in more detail, which is already very pleasant. The other cities and airports in the world do also exist (well, most of them) but they are recreated in a more schematic way with landclasses and autogen, but lets don't get too technical.

Today's hardware enables you to run FSX in a pleasant way. Since the two service packs which Microsoft did release plus the few optimizations Dovetail did, it should normally run in a stable way. I like Microsoft Flight Simulator X very much and this is why I have already plunged thousands of dollars (yes, you do read correctly) in add-ons and hardware in order to be able to fly as real as it can get in order to stay sharp for my real world flights. I have also bought some great hardware from Saitek and VRinsight which enable me to fly with a yoke, pedals and throttle levers, radio navigation stack. We nearly as I do in the real plane. So beware, if you become addicted, then it can become an expensive hobby :-)

I like the fact that Dovetail now ported FSX on the Steam platform because the flight simulation community is lacking new adopters for years now, thus eroding the user base. The average age of a simmer tends to be in the mid forties and we could really use youngsters which come along to enhance the base of users. So if you dream of becoming a real world pilot or only want to have some fun, try it, I did at least never regret it.

Ok at the time of this review I have only played about 10 minutes, just some quick flying to check it out and I have to say this version is much more stable than the original version. I have the dvd version of FSX gold edition and even on my mid-highend system it lagged. However, the steam edition of FSX is stable with full graphics, full AI traffic.

10/10

A must have for a flying sim fan, and a must for MS: Flight Sim fans.

Fantastic to have this show up here!  Runs great and so much simpler to install than the disc version.  Impressed with the tweaks, game still looks really nice, I forgot how "alive" the world feels.  By comparison, X-Plane 10 (which I also love) simply feels "sterile".  Highly recommend and look forward to what else they have to offer.

This is one of the first flight sims I bough over a decade ago and when i rebought it today i was suprised to find its be IMPROVED 10 fold. It's still the great old sim it was but it has better graphics, not a ram whore, and brings back a refreshing blast from the past. It comes with a couple dozen aircraft all with 3D cockpit view and chase view. you can fly from any where to any where using real weather and time with generally accurate generic modles of where towns cities and land masses should be. All in all a good flight sim plus it comes with multi player!
at this price there is no reason not to buy this
Good old reliable FSX!

If this game gets workshop support....oh mannnnnnnn...

Anyways, this game is great.  Multiplayer works well (although voice chat is a bit choppy) and the game comes with FSX:Acceleration.  Also, it's a lot more optimized than it used to be (though even now, I still can't turn all the settings all the way up and get a good frame rate, but I disgress.)  If you have 5 bucks and a flight stick, you'll have fun.
Doesn't work. Very dissapointed even though I only paid £4 for this. Not worth it. Crashes all the time I try and fly or play on a map. Great game. Doesn't work!!
Great old FSX, slightly updated awith working MP and a few other bits to run on modern machines. All  now in the one stop STEAM eco system, whats not to like?

The multiplayer works, and it's oh-so much better than what it was back in the day! This version also runs much more smoothly on my PC than my old version, and seems to be a lot more stable as well. Would highly reccommend it to anyone with an interest in aviation, especially while it's on sale for $5!

When this game came out, I spent countless hours. When the online was shut down, it was the worst. The game was very buggy and even powerful systems use to only run it on low or medium. But steam does what they did best, and Fixed the game completely, remaking the online, and I couldnt be happier. If you ever have thought about getting this game, Do it! It is definately worth the $25 because of Free Roam ALL OVER THE WORLD and even missions, then the online free roam. Definately Do it!!!!!!

FSUIPC or PMDG products won't work. The game it self is protected by the steam.api and won't allow to add stuff with dll files and will make an instant fatal error, fun that the multiplayer is back on it but I advice you for online flying either IVAO or VATSIM for the real deal, I talk about more than over 1000 people online almost every day! If you have Windows 8 and want to fly FSX? Bad news you can't you need to roll back to Windows 7 or using X-Plane or either Prepar3D for Windows 8. Sorry but this is not for me as hardcore simming with all addon's, and I saw they added uiautomationcore.dll and that is likely what they called Windows 8.1 fix which is not true it fixed some freezing problems on Windows 7 and it have no effect on Windows 8 whatsoever.

 For to the devs you did what you can do for the basic flyers and I do recommand this for them and I surely need to guys give you respect for picking up such a classic game back up applause!
So glad its out on steam

Currently running FSX on Windows 10 Technical Preview without a hitch!  It's actually running much smoother on my medium class laptop than the disc version.  I don't know why, and quite frankly, am not going to complain! Well done!

i dont play flight sims but after 30 mins i do think this one is cool easy to set up fun to play now i have had a few beers and was able to get the air bus to fly uesing an xbox controller O.K. maybe more than a few beers. dcs world even sober i could not get the dam game to work so if you are a bit of a noob at this like me and got stung by other flight sims like me do try this one its great even drunk you can fly planes. landing may be a problem but i will try that when i sober up 8/10 as i got this in day one sale but it is almost idiot proof and p#ss head proof
Fianlly optimized and doesnt crash. Great and fun game! 10/10
Loads of fun to fly with a friend. Performs better than the original FSX. 12/10 would fly again.

Vote 9/11

I couldn't fly my planned cross-country solo flight from Phoenix to Yuma this morning due to weather.

Came home, bought this, streamed my flight on Twitch, and had just as much fun.

This is almost exactly FSX: Gold, with working multiplayer, more stability, no crashes, low ram requirements, and has pretty much the same file structure as the original (albeit in the SteamApps folder) so all of your addons should work. 

If you don't have FSX, buy it. It's worth the normal price. This is the simulator all other simulators look up to.

Finally stable on Windows 8.1!
It's just perfect now!

It's finally here! I first heard from PCgamesN website that there were plans to bring FSX to steam with stability and performance improvements and have been anxiously checking since. This was about half a year ago and finally the wait is over and with such a great intro price! This is basically FSX Gold with said improvements. Although it's early days, steam workshop/store addons/DLC WILL be added down the line. I've not tried any of my existing addons with this installation yet but I'll update the review once I have to let you know of compatibility and if there are any issues or things to know. All I can say is I'm so glad this iconic, timeless masterpiece is finally here and for them to have worked on the performance issues? Just an absolute pleasure! (Although by now, most of our rigs can run it perfectly anyway however start throwing addons into the mix such as REX, Weather systems, OrbX environments, highly detailed custom aircraft etc... well, we'll see!) Stay tuned guys!

Update: I can confirm my addons are so far working perfectly! Christmas has surely come early guys and girls!

Let me just start off by saying that I've owned about 4 copies of FSX:deluxe edition. No, I don't have 4 computers to play on, I just kept loosing all my copies. I even bought them for $10 at the MS store a couple years ago on sale. Those are gone, too. 

So, now this comes along at $5 (currently on sale). This is great. Just purchased and I won't have to worry aobut loosing this one.
